src_text.2622: Nec levi cura sollicitus sed oppido suspensus animi mecum   ipse cogitationes exercitius agitabam, quorsus nova haec et inaudita se caelestium porrigeret intentio, quid subsecivum quamvis iteratae iam traditioni remansisset:
src_text.2623: nimirum perperam vel minus plene consuluerunt in me sacerdos uterque 1:
src_text.2624: et Hercule iam de fide quoque eorum opinari coeptabam sequius.
src_text.2625: Quo me cogitationis aestu fluctuantem ad instar insaniae percitum sic instruxit nocturna divinatione demens imago:
src_text.2626: Nihil est inquit Quod numerosa serie religionis, quasi quicquam sit prius omissum, terreare.
src_text.2627: Quin assidua ista numinum dignatione laetum capesse gaudium, et potius exulta ter futurus quod alii vel semel vix conceditur, teque de isto numero merito praesume semper beatum.
src_text.2628: Ceterum futura tibi sacrorum traditio pernecessaria est, si tecum nunc saltem reputaveris exuvias deae, quas in provincia sumpsisti, in eodem fano depositas perseverat, nec te Romae diebus sollemnibus vel supplicare iis vel, cum praeceptum fuerit, felici illo amictu illustrari posse.
src_text.2629: Quod felix itaque ac faustum salutareque tibi sit, animo gaudiali rursum sacris initiare diis magnis auctoribus.
src_text.2630: Hactenus divini somnii suada maiestas, quod usus foret, pronuntiavit.
src_text.2631: Nec deinceps postposito vel in supinam procrastinationem reiecto negotio, statim sacerdoti meo relatis quae videram, inanimae     protinus castimoniae iugum subeo et lege perpetua praescripta illis decem diebus spontali sobrietate multiplicatis, instructum teletae comparo largitus, ex studio pietatis magis quam mensura rerum collatis.
src_text.2632: Nec Hercule laborum me sumptuumque quicquam tamen paenituit;
src_text.2634: Liberali deum providentia iam stipendiis forensibus bellule fotum.
src_text.2635: Denique post dies admodum pauculos deus deum magnorum potior, et maiorum summus, et summorum maximus, et maximorum regnator Osiris, non alienam quampiam personam reformatus, sed coram suo illo venerando me dignatus affamine per quietem praecipere visus est, quam nunc incunctanter gloriosa in foro redderem patrocinia, nec extimescerem malevolorum disseminationes, quas studiorum meorum laboriosa doctrina ibi differebat.
src_text.2636: Ac ne sacris suis gregi cetero permixtus deservirem, in collegium me pastophorum suorum, immo inter ipsos decurionum quinquennalem allegit:
src_text.2637: rursus denique quam raso capillo collegii vetustissimi et sub illis Syllae temporibus conditi munia, non obumbrato vel obtecto calvitio sed quoquoversus obvio, gaudens obibam.

tgt_text.0: THE author of the celebrated romance of " THE GOLDEN Ass" lived in the early part of the second century, under the Antonines.
tgt_text.1: By most modern biographers he is called Lucius Apuleius, or Appuleius, but the authority on which they assign him that præ­ nomen is very questionable.
tgt_text.2: He was a native of Madaura, an inland African town, and he styles himself, in allusion to its po­ sition on the borders of two kingdoms, " a half-and-half Numi- than and Getulian;
tgt_text.3: " adding that, in that respect, he resembled the elder Cyrus, who was " a Semi-Median and Semi.Persian."
tgt_text.4: Madaura, after having formed part of the kingdom of Syphax.
tgt_text.5: was bestowed by the Romans on their ally Masinissa, and being eventually resumed and peopled by veterans, it obtained the rank and immunities of a " colony," and rose to considerable splendour.
tgt_text.6: The father of Apuleius filled the office of duumvir, the highest magisterial dignity in his native place, and bequeathed at his death the sum of nearly two millions of sesterces to his two sons, one of whom, the subject of our present inquiries, succeeded to his office.
tgt_text.7: These facts we learn from the direct testimony of the son in his Apologia or Defence ;
tgt_text.8: but most of the biographers of Apuleius add other particulars, drawn from the assumption that, under the character of Lucius, the imagi­ nary hero of the story of "the Golden Ass," the author has related sundry details of his own personal history.
tgt_text.9: Upon this supposition, we are told that our author's prænomen was Lucius, that his father's name was Theseus, his mother's Salvia, and that she was of a Thessalian family, and descended from the illustrious Plutarch;
tgt_text.10: furthermore, that Apuleius was ignorant of the Latin language until he visited Rome.
tgt_text.11: where he acquired it without the aid of a master;
tgt_text.12: and that by the time he arrived at the capital of the empire, he had so completely dissipated his patrimony, as to be under the necessity of selling his clothes, in order to defray the cost of his initiation into the mysteries of Osiris.
tgt_text.13: This latter statement is at variance with the account which he gives of his fortune in the Apologia, where he says, merely, that it had been, " modice imminutum," somewhat im.
tgt_text.15: the other particulars may or may not be true.
tgt_text.16: There is, no doubt, such a 'resemblance between Apuleius and Lucius, both as regards mental characteristics and outward incidents, that we can hardly suppose it to be fortuitous.
tgt_text.17: It is highly probable that the author drew his hero from his own likeness;
tgt_text.18: but on the other hand, it is absurd to look for literal fidelity in such a por­ trait.
tgt_text.19: It is not likely, for instance, that Apuleius would have deemed it consistent with decorum to speak of himself, his father and his mother, by their real names, in so frolicsome a work of fiction as " The Golden Ass," since we find, that when addressing the sons of a friend in some complimentary verses of a peculiar character, such as the habits of his day allowed, he thought it his duty to invent pseudonymes for the objects of his flattery.
tgt_text.20: *Apuleius received the first rudiments of education at Carthage, renowned at that time as a school of literature, and there he adopted the Platonic system of philosophy, in which he perfected himself by his subsequent studies at Athens.
tgt_text.21: There, too, he laid the foundations of that copious stock of various and profound learning, through which he became the most distinguished lite­ rary character of his age.
tgt_text.22: Still thirsting for knowledge, and impelled, like his own Lucius, by an insatiable curiosity to ex­ plore all that was hidden from the vulgar gaze, he travelled through Greece, Asia, and Italy, and became a member of many religious fraternities, and a proficient in their mys­ teries.
tgt_text.23: After his return to Africa, he was about to renew his travels, and on his way to Alexandria was taken ill at Oëa, a maritime town, which some geographers have identified with the modern Tripoli.
tgt_text.24: A young man, named Pontianus, whom he had known as a fellow-student at Athens, invited the invalid to become the guest of his mother, a wealthy widow, named Pudentilla.
tgt_text.25: In making this hospitable proposal, Pontianus had more in view than the comfort of his friend, and the restoration of his health.
tgt_text.26: Pudentilla was herself also an invalid, being affected with a chronic complaint, which had lasted thir­ teen years-the duration of her widowhood-and for which her medical advisers all agreed in prescribing marriage as a remedy.
tgt_text.27: The son, seeing his mother prepared to try the effect of that nostrum, was desirous that her new husband should be one of his own choosing.
tgt_text.28: Accordingly, he begged Apuleius would do him the favour to become his stepfather, putting the affair to him, says the latter, in the light of an onerous service, such as one might ask a friend and a philosopher to undertake.
tgt_text.29: The widow was neither young nor handsome, but she was virtuous, fond, and very rich.
tgt_text.30: Apuleius, if not poor, was, at least, reduced in circumstances, in consequence of his long-continued course of study, his protracted residence in foreign countries, and various acts of generosity towards his friends and instructors ;
tgt_text.32: so in fine he married the widow.
tgt_text.33: But this act involved some unpleasant consequences.
tgt_text.34: Before it was accomplished, Pontianus had married the daughter of one Rufinus, who, long eager to secure to his son-in-law as large a share as possible in the fortune of Pudentilla, did all he could to prevent her marriage with Apuleius;
tgt_text.35: and in this he was seconded by Pontianus, over whom he had acquired such an influence, as to make him look with aversion on the suc­ cess of his own project.
tgt_text.36: But not with standing all opposition, Pudentilla persisted in her resolution ;
tgt_text.37: and soon after her mar­ riage, Pontianus died.
tgt_text.38: His uncle, AEmilianus, then united with Rufinus in endeavours to ruin Apuleius.
tgt_text.39: They gave out that he had poisoned Pontianus, that he was a magician, and had gained the affections of Pudentilla by witcheraft.
tgt_text.40: They even prosecuted him upon the latter charge, and the cause was tried at Sabrata, before Claudius Maximus, the proconsul of Africa.
tgt_text.41: It was on that occasion he delivered the Defence, a translation of which will be found in this volume.
tgt_text.42: It is a clever and amusing per formance, having nothing of the tragic earnestness of a man who is pleading for his life;
tgt_text.43: on the-contrary, Apuleius appears, from first to last, to have felt quite secure as to the issue, and to have flung himself with great glee into a contest which afforded him such capital opportunities for displaying his wit, his learning, and his powers of rhetoric.
tgt_text.44: His adversaries had a bad game to play;
tgt_text.45: they played it into his hands, and he made good use of their blun­ ders.
tgt_text.46: The main charge was ridiculous enough, and Apuleius had for it a ready and sufficient answer :
tgt_text.48: You are surprised," he said, " that a woman should have married again after thirteen years of widowhood;
tgt_text.49: but the real wonder is, that she should have remained unmarried so long.
tgt_text.50: You pretend that magic alone could have forced a widow of her years to marry a young man ;
tgt_text.51: but that is just the sort of case in which magic would be quite superfluous."
tgt_text.52: As if to give the more force to this argument, the prosecutors were indiscreet enough to lay great stress on the graces and ac­ complishments of the accused, and to press upon the notice of the court that Apuleius was altogether such a man as was most likely, in the natural course of things, to find favour in a woman's eyes;
tgt_text.53: for he was handsome, and not negligent of his person ;
tgt_text.57: and this handsome man, who cultivated cleanliness as well as phi­ losophy, had a ready wit and a fluent tongue!
tgt_text.58: After the discomfiture of his wife's relations, it seems probable that nothing very remarkable occurred to disturb the even tenour of a life of literary labour to which Apuleius devoted himself.
tgt_text.59: All that is known of this latter part of his career, is, that he was a most voluminous writer;
tgt_text.60: that he frequently declaimed in public with great applause;
tgt_text.61: he was a priest of Æsculapius, the pa­ tron god of Carthage;
tgt_text.62: he had the charge of exhibiting gladi­ atorial shows and wild beast hunts in the province, and statues were erected in his honour by the senate of Carthage and of other states.
tgt_text.63: It was probably in his latter days that he composed his most celebrated work, " The Metamorphoses, or the Golden Ass for neither does he allude to it in those passages in which he boasts of the extent and variety of his literary productions ;
tgt_text.64: nor was any mention made of it upon the occasion of his trial for magic, as would certainly have been done had his prosecutors been aware of the existence of such a book.
tgt_text.65: This celebrated romance pur­ ports to be the autobiography of a certain Lucius of Madaura, whose curiosity with respect to magic.
tgt_text.66: has been rewarded by his tranformation into the form of a jackass, in which he undergoes many curious and ludicrous adventures, until he is at last restored to human shape by the interposition of the goddess Isis, to whose service he devotes himself.
tgt_text.67: Had this amusing story appeared before the trial at Sabrata, it might have been used with formid­ able effect against its author, whose contemporaries, anticipat­ ing the opinions of a subsequent age, might have identified Lucius with Apuleius, and believed the latter to be a great magician.
tgt_text.68: Lactantius informs us that the early pagan controversialists used to rank Apuleius with Apollonius of Tyana, as a thauma- turgus, and to cite various miracles performed by him as equal, or superior to those of Christ.
tgt_text.69: A generation later, St. Augustine permitted himself to doubt whether the account given by Lucius, or Apuleius, of his change into an ass was not a true relation "
tgt_text.70: Aut indicavit," says he, " aut finxit.
tgt_text.71: "The Golden Ass, in which many writers, especially Bishop War­ burton, have been at pains to discover a profound theological purpose, appears to have been written with a view to little else than the amusement of a profane public.
tgt_text.72: It is enriched with numerous episodes, of which the best known, and by far the most beautiful, is the story of Cupid and Psyche.
tgt_text.73: Another forms the second story of the seventh day of the Decameron.
tgt_text.74: An adventure which befel Lucius, probably suggested to Cervantes the dreadful combat which took place at an inn between Don Quixote and the Wine-skins;
tgt_text.75: and there is a striking resemblance between the occur- fences seen by Lucius at the habitation of robbers, and some of the early incidents in Gil Bias.
tgt_text.76: Apuleius, who is now comparatively neglected, was familiarly known to all readers of the classics during the three centuries preceding our own;
tgt_text.77: but it is only through the medium of a translation that Englishmen, at least, are likely to make much acquaintance with him for the future.
tgt_text.78: His Latin is very troublesome to read, and it is not worth reading for its own sake.
tgt_text.79: He is a most amusing writer, with an execrable style, and therefore he is one of the few who ought to gain rather than lose by translation.
tgt_text.80: "No one," says Professor Ramsay, " can peruse a few pages of Apuleius without being at once im­ pressed with his conspicuous excellencies and his glaring defects.
tgt_text.81: We find everywhere an exuberant pl ay of fancy, liveliness, humour, wit, learning, acuteness, and not unfrequently real eloquence.
tgt_text.82: On the other hand, no style can be more vicious.
tgt_text.83: It is in the high­ est degree unnatural, both in its general tone and in the phrase­ ology employed.
tgt_text.84: The former is disfigured by the constant recur­ rence of ingenious but forced and learned conceits and studied prettinesses, while the latter is remarkable for the multitude of obsolete words ostentatiously paraded in almost every sentence.
tgt_text.85: The greater number of these are to be found in the extant com­ positions of the oldest dramatic writers, and in quotations pre­ served by the grammarians ;
tgt_text.86: and those for which no authority can be produced, were, in all probability, drawn from the same source, and not arbitrarily coined to answer the purpose of the moment, as some critics have imagined.
tgt_text.87: The least faulty perhaps, of all, is the Apologia.
tgt_text.88: Here he spoke from deep feeling;
tgt_text.89: and although we may in many places detect the inveterate affectation of the rhe­ torician, yet there is often a bold, manly, straightforward hearti­ ness and truth, which we seek in vain in those compositions where his feelings were less couched.
tgt_text.90: "Of all the voluminous writings of Apuleius there are only six extant of unquestioned authenticity.

tgt_text.119: While I listened to hear what was the subject of their conversation, one of them, bursting .into a loud laugh, said to the other, Do leave off tell­ ing such absurd, such monstrous ‡ lies.
tgt_text.120: "Hearing this, I, who am generally athirst after novelty, struck in, and said, " May I beg you will make me acquainted with your story;
tgt_text.121: not, indeed, that I would be impertinently inqui­ sitive, but I long to know everything, or at least as much as I can;
tgt_text.122: besides, some pleasant amusing tales will smooth the ruggedness of this hill we are just ascending.""
tgt_text.123: Decidedly," said the first speaker, " this lying story is about as true as if a person should think fit to assert, that by magical mutterings rapid rivers can be made to run back­ wards, the ocean be congealed, the winds robbed of breath, the sun stopped in his course, the moon made to drop her foam,* the stars plucked from their spheres, the day annihilated, and the night-indefinitely prolonged.
tgt_text.124: "On this, assuming a somewhat confident air, " Do not you," said I, " who began the story, repent of having so done, nor think it a trouble to tell the remainder."

tgt_text.126: " But as for you," said I, " you reject with dull ears and stubborn disposition, a statement of things which, perhaps, are true.

tgt_text.129: whereas, if you examine them a little more attentively, you will find them not only manifest to the senses, but even easy of accom­ plishment.

tgt_text.143: Having understood that at Hypata,* which is the principal city of all Thessaly, new cheese of exqui­ site flavour was to be sold -at a very reasonable price, I made the best of my way to that place, with the intention of buy­ ing up the whole of it.

tgt_text.147: Weary with my rapid journey, undertaken to so little pur­ pose, I proceeded, early in the evening, to the public baths, when, to my surprise, I espied an old companion of mine, named Socrates.
tgt_text.148: He was sitting on the ground, half covered with a sorry, tattered cloak, and looked almost another person, he was so miserably wan and thin;
tgt_text.149: just like those outcasts of Fortune, who be- alms in the streets.
tgt_text.150: Consequently, although he had been my friend and particular acquaintance, I yet accosted him with feelings of hesitation."
tgt_text.151: 'How now, friend Socrates,' said I, 'what is the meaning of this ?
tgt_text.153: What crime have you been guilty of?
tgt_text.154: Why, you have been lamented at home, and for some time given up for dead.
tgt_text.156: Guardians have been as­ signed to your children, by decree of the provincial magistrate.
tgt_text.157: Your wife, having fulfilled what was due to the dead, all dis­ figured by grief and long-continued sorrow, and having almost cried herself blind with excessive weeping, is being worried by her parents to repair the misfortune of the family by the joys of a new marriage.
tgt_text.158: But here you come before our eyes like some spectral apparition, to our extreme confusion.'"
tgt_text.159: ' 0 Aristomenes !' said he, ' it is clear that you are igno­ rant of the slippery turns, the unstable freaks, and the ever- changing vicissitudes of Fortune.''"

tgt_text.161: At last, unable to endure the sight of such a miserable spectacle of woe, I took hold of him, and endeavoured to raise him from the ground.

tgt_text.167: Having paid every attention to him, though tired myself, I supported his enfeebled steps, and with great difficulty brought him to my inn;
tgt_text.168: where I made him rest on a couch, gave him plenty of food, cheered him with wine, and entertained him with the news of the day.
tgt_text.169: And now our conversation took quite a merry turn, we cracked jokes, and grew noisy in our prattle;
tgt_text.170: when, heaving a bitter sigh from the bottom of his -breast, and violently striking his forehead with his right hand:
tgt_text.171: " 'Miserable man that I am!' said he;
tgt_text.172: 'to have fallen into these misfortunes while intent on gratifying myself with a famous gladiatorial spectacle.
tgt_text.173: For, as you are very well aware, I went to Macedonia on an affair of business;
tgt_text.174: and after being detained there for the space of ten months, I was on my return homewards, having gained a very pretty sum of money.
tgt_text.175: I had nearly reached Larissa, * which I had included in my route for the purpose of seeing the spectacle I mentioned, when I was attacked by some desperate robbers, in a lonely and rugged valley, and only effected my escape, after being plunderer!
tgt_text.176: by them of all I possessed.
tgt_text.177: Being thus reduced to extreme dis­ tress, I betook myself to a certain woman named Meroe, who kept a tavern, and who, though old, was remarkably engaging;
tgt_text.178: and to her I related the circumstances of my lengthened ab­ sence, of my earnest desire to reach home, and of my being plundered of my property on that day.
tgt_text.179: After I, unfortunate wretch, had related such particulars as I remembered, she treated me with the greatest kindness, supplied me with a good supper, all for nothing, and afterwards, instigated by lust, admitted me to her bed.
tgt_text.180: But from the very moment that I, unhappy man, first lay with her, my mind contracted a last­ ing malady;
tgt_text.181: and I even made her a present of those garments which the robbers, in their humanity, had left me to cover my nakedness.
tgt_text.182: I likewise presented her with the little earnings I made by working as a cloakmaker while I was yet in good con­ dition of body;
tgt_text.183: until at length this worthy partner, and ill fortune together, reduced me to that state in which you just now saw me.'"
tgt_text.184: 'By Pollux, then,' said I, ' you deserve to suffer extreme misfortunes, if there is anything still more extreme than that which is most extreme, for having preferred the pleasures of dalliance and a wrinkled harlot, to your home and children.'"

tgt_text.192: She is a sorceress,' he replied, ' and endowed with powers divine;
tgt_text.193: she is able to draw down the heavens, to uplift the earth, to harden the running water, to dissolve mountains, to raise the shades of the dead, to dethrone the Gods, to extin­ guish the stars, and to illumine the depths of Tartarus itself.'"

tgt_text.196: Why, as for making not only her fellow-countrymen love her to distraction, but the Indians even, or the inhabitants of both the Æthiopias, * and even the Antichthones t themselves;

tgt_text.198: Listen, then, and hear what she has performed in the presence of many witnesses.
tgt_text.199: By a single word only, she changed a lover of hers into a beaver, because he had by force debauched another woman;
tgt_text.200: since that beast, when in fear of being taken, escapes from its pursuers by the abscission of its genitals;
tgt_text.201: and she de­ sired that the same might likewise befall him, as a punishment for having been connected with another woman.
tgt_text.202: She likewise changed an innkeeper, who was her neighbour, and of whom she was envious on that account, into a frog;
tgt_text.203: and now the old fellow, swimming about in a cask of his own wine, or buried in the dregs, croaks hoarsely to his old customers, quite in the way of business.
tgt_text.204: She likewise transformed another person, an advocate of the Forum, into a ram, because he had conducted a cause against her ;
tgt_text.205: and to this very day that ram is always at loggerheads..+
tgt_text.206: Then there was the wife of a lover of hers, ,whom she condemned to perpetual pregnancy, when on the point of increasing her family, by closing her womb against the egress of the infant, because she had chattered scandal against the witch;
tgt_text.207: and, for these eight years, according to the general computation, this poor creature has been swelling with her burden, as if she were about to be brought to bed of an elephant.
tgt_text.209: After this woman, however, and many other persons, had been injured by her arts, the public indignation became aroused against her;

tgt_text.212: and as Medea, having obtained by entreaty from Creon the truce of a single day, prior to her departure, burned his whole palace, his daughter, together with the old man himself, with flames issuing from a garland, so, likewise, did this sorceress, having performed certain deadly incantations in a ditch,* (as she herself lately told me in a fit of drunkenness), confine all the inhabitants of the town, each in his own house, through a secret spell of the daemons;
tgt_text.213: so that, for two whole days together, neither could the bars be wrenched off, nor the doors be taken off the hinges, nor, in fine, could a breach be made in the walls;

tgt_text.291: So I took my bundle, and, having paid the innkeeper for our night's lodging, we started on our road.

tgt_text.293: 'Foolish man,' said I to myself, ' buried in your cups, you certainly have had a most absurd dream.

tgt_text.298: Addressing myself to him, ' Decidedly,' said I, ' skilful doctors have good reason to be of opinion that it is those who are stuffed out with food and fermented liquors who are trou­ bled with portentous and horrible dreams.
tgt_text.299: My own case is an instance of this:
tgt_text.300: for having in my evening cups exceeded the bounds of temperance, a wretched night has been presenting to me shocking and dreadful visions, so that I still fancy my­ self besprinkled and defiled with human gore.'"
tgt_text.301: ' 'Tis not gore,' he replied with a smile, ' you are sprinkled with, but chamber-lye;
tgt_text.302: and yet I too, thought, in my sleep, that my throat was cut:
tgt_text.303: some pain, too, I felt in my neck, and I fancied that my very heart was being plucked out:
tgt_text.304: and even now I am quite faint, my knees tremble, I stagger as I go, and feel in want of some food to refresh my spirits.'"
tgt_text.305: ' Look,' cried I, 1 here's breakfast all ready for you;
tgt_text.306: ' and so saying, I lifted my wallet from off my shoulders, and at once handed him some cheese and bread, saying, ' Let us sit down near that plane-tree.'"
tgt_text.307: We did so, and I also helped myself to some refresh­ ment.
tgt_text.308: While looking at him somewhat more intently, as he was eating with a voracious appetite, I saw that he was faint, and of a hue like box-wood;
tgt_text.309: his natural colour in fact had so forsaken him, that as I recalled those nocturnal furies to my frightened imagination, the very first piece of bread I put into my mouth, though a very tiny bit, stuck in the middle of my throat, so that it could neither pass downward, nor yet return upward.
tgt_text.310: And then besides, the number of people passing along increased my apprehensions;
tgt_text.311: for who would be­ lieve that one of two companions could meet with his death without any harm done by the other ?
tgt_text.312: "Meanwhile, after having devoured a sufficient quantity of food, he began to be impatient for some drink;
tgt_text.313: for he bad voraciously eaten a good part of a most excellent cheese;
tgt_text.314: and not very far from the roots of the plane tree, a gentle stream flowed slowly along, just like a placid lake, rivalling silver or glass in its lustre.
tgt_text.315: ' Look,' said I, 1 drink your fill of the water of this stream, bright as the Milky Way.'"
tgt_text.316: He arose, and, wrapping himself in his cloak, * with his knees doubled under him, knelt down upon the shelving bank, and bent greedily towards the water.
tgt_text.317: Scarcely had he touched the dewy surface of the water with the edge of his lips, when the wound in his throat burst wide open, the sponge suddenly rolled out, a few drops of blood accom­ panying it;
tgt_text.318: and then, his body, bereft of life, would have fallen into the river, had I not laid hold of one of his feet, and dragged it with the utmost difficulty and labour to the top of the bank;
tgt_text.319: where, having, as well as the time permitted, lamented my unfortunate companion, I buried him in the sandy soil that eternally begirt the stream.
tgt_text.320: For my own part, trem­ bling and terror-stricken, I fled through various and unfre­ quented places ;
tgt_text.321: and, as though conscious of the guilt of homi­ cide, abandoning my country and my home, and embracing a voluntary exile, I now dwell in Ætolia, where I have married another wife.
tgt_text.324: Here Aristomenes ended his story, but his companion, who from the very first had rejected it with obstinate incredulity, at once exclaimed, " Nothing is there in fable more fabulous than this story, nothing more absurd than these lies."
tgt_text.326: " And you," said he, " who are a person of liberal education, as your dress and appearance bespeak, do you give credit to this story ?
tgt_text.327: "I replied, "1 consider nothing impossible, but hold that just as the Fates have preordained, so all things happen to mortals.'
tgt_text.328: For both to me and to you, and to all men, many things do happen of so wonderful a nature, that they are nigh to not happening at all;
tgt_text.329: which, nevertheless, if narrated to an ignorant person, would fail to obtain belief.
tgt_text.330: But this story, by Hercules, I do believe, and I return right hearty thanks to the narrator, for having so well entertained us by his pleasant recital, that I have got over a rough and tedious por­ tion of my journey without labour or weariness.
tgt_text.331: With this good service, I fancy that this nag of mine is also much grati­ fied, inasmuch as I have been carried, without fatigue to him, up to the very gate of this city, not on his back, but by my ears.
tgt_text.332: "This was the termination of our conversation and of our journey together;
tgt_text.333: for both my fellow-travellers turned away to some neighbouring villages on the left;
tgt_text.334: while I approached the first inn I cast eyes upon, and at once accosted the old woman who kept it:
tgt_text.335: "Is this the city of Hypata?" said I;
tgt_text.336: she gave me to understand, by a nod, that it was. " Do you know," said I, " a certain person of the name of Milo, who is one of the first men of the city ?"
tgt_text.337: She smiled, and replied, " With good reason is this Milo considered one of the first* men, inasmuch as he dwells beyond the whole city, and in the Pomœrium."
tgt_text.338: † "Joking apart," said I, " tell me, I beg of you, good mother, what kind of man he is, and in what house he lives.""
tgt_text.339: Do you see," said she, " those last windows which look on this side towards the city, and that gate on the other side, looking upon the blind alley in front ?
tgt_text.340: There it is that Milo dwells, a man abounding in money, and extremely opulent;
tgt_text.341: but disgraced by inordinate avarice and shameful sordidness.
tgt_text.342: In short, he entirely devotes himself to usury, taking, pledges of gold and silver.
tgt_text.343: Shut up in a scanty house, and always bending over his pelf, there he dwells with a wife, the partner of his misery.
tgt_text.344: And no one besides does he keep in his house, except one servant girl;
tgt_text.345: and when he goes abroad, he is al­ ways dressed like a common beggar.""
tgt_text.346: Well," said I to myself, with a smile, " my friend De­ meas has taken excellent care of me, in giving me a letter of introduction to such a man;
tgt_text.347: while I stay with him I need not be afraid of smoke, or the smell of the kitchen.
tgt_text.348: "Thus saying, and proceeding to a little distance, I came to the gate, which was strongly bolted, and began to hallo and knock.

tgt_text.350: you who have been knocking at our door so violently, what is the pledge on which you want to borrow money ?
tgt_text.351: Are you the only person that doesn't know that we take in no pledge except it is gold or silver ?""
tgt_text.352: Meet me with words of better omen," said I, " and rather inform me, whether I have found your master at home ?

tgt_text.355: ""I have brought a letter," said I, "written to him by Demeas, the duumvir of Corinth." *"

tgt_text.357: And so saying, she fastened the door again, and re­ turned into the house.
tgt_text.358: She came back in a few minutes, and, opening the door, said, "My master requests you to come in."
tgt_text.359: I accordingly entered, and found him reclining on a very small couch, and just beginning his dinner.
tgt_text.360: His wife was sitting at his feet,t and a scantily furnished table was before them;
tgt_text.361: pointing at which, he said, " Behold your entertainment."
tgt_text.362: " 'Tis well," said I, and immediately delivered him the letter from Demeas.
tgt_text.363: Having hastily read it, he said, " I thank my friend Demeas for having introduced to me such a worthy guest:
tgt_text.364: " and then he ordered his wife to leave the room,j and invited me to sit in her place;
tgt_text.365: at the same time taking hold of my garment, and drawing me towards him, as I still hesitated through bashfulness. "
tgt_text.366: Sit down there," said he, " for through fear of robbers, we cannot provide ourselves with seats, nor even as much other furniture as we have need of."
tgt_text.368: "From the genteel appearance of your person," he conti­ nued, ' and from this maiden bashfulness of yours, I might reasonably conjecture that you are sprung from a good family.
tgt_text.369: Besides, my friend Demeas also asserts the same thing in his letter.
tgt_text.370: I beg, therefore, you -will not despise the poverty of our little cottage;
tgt_text.371: and, look you, you will have the little bed- chamber adjoining to this room, where you will be very com­ fortable.
tgt_text.372: Do not, therefore, hesitate to take up your abode with us.
tgt_text.373: For you will magnify our poor house through your condescension, and will, besides, procure for yourself no small renown, if, content with a humble dwelling, you emulate the virtues of Theseus, your father's namesake,*who did not dis­ dain the slender hospitality of the aged woman Hecale."
tgt_text.374: tThen, calling to the maid-servant, "Fotis," said he, "take the baggage of our guest, and put it with care in that bed- chamber, and at the same time, bring quickly from the store- room some oil for anointing, towels for drying, and other needful things useful, and then conduct my guest to the nearest baths;
tgt_text.375: for he must be weary after his very long and toilsome journey.
tgt_text.376: "On hearing these directions, I reflected upon the mode of liv­ ing, and the parsimonious habits of Milo, and wishing to in­ gratiate myself with him in a still greater degree-,, I do not stand in need of any of these things," said I, " as I generally carry them with me on a journey.
tgt_text.377: And as to the baths, I can easily find my way thither by enquiring where they are.
tgt_text.378: My principal concern is for my horse, who has so stoutly carried me hither ;
tgt_text.379: do you, therefore, Fotis, take this money, and buy me some hay and barley.
tgt_text.380: "When matters were arranged, and my things had been put into the bedchamber, I went into the provision market on my road towards the baths, that I might first provide us with something in the way of eating.
tgt_text.381: There I saw a splendid sup­ ply of fish on sale, and after asking the price of some, and declining it, because the dealer asked a hundred pieces ‡ of money, I finally bought it for twenty denars.
tgt_text.382: Just as I was going away from there, I was followed out by one Pytheas, who had been a fellow-student of mine at Athens;
tgt_text.383: who, after having recognised me at last, embraced me in a friendly manner, and exclaimed, "By Gemini, friend Lucius, what a time it is since I last saw you!
tgt_text.385: not since we left our mas­ ter and quitted the city.§
tgt_text.386: But what is the cause of this journey of yours?""

tgt_text.391: "He replied, " I have the inspection of the markets* and hold the office of ædile, and if it is your wish to buy any provisions, I will take care and accommodate you."
tgt_text.392: I declined his offer, as I had already provided myself with a sufficient quantity of fish for my dinner.
tgt_text.393: Pytheas, however, having caught sight of my basket, and shaking up the fishes, that he might inspect them the better-
tgt_text.394: "And pray," said he, what sum may you have given for this rubbish?
tgt_text.396: "It was with considerable trouble," said I, " that I could get the fishmonger to take twenty denars for them."
tgt_text.397: On hearing this, he immediately seized me by the right hand, and bringing me back again into the market:
tgt_text.398: "From which of these men did you buy this worthless stuff?" said he.
tgt_text.399: I pointed out to him a little old man, who was sitting in one corner;
tgt_text.400: upon which, immediately rebuking him in a most se­ vere tone of voice, in virtue of his authority as sedile, , How now!" said he, "have you no consideration for our friends, not to say for strangers, . to sell your pitiful fish at such an exorbitant price, and thus bring this city, the flower of the province of Thessaly, to be as bad as a desert and a rock, through the dearness of provisions ?
tgt_text.401: But you shall not escape with impunity.
tgt_text.402: For I will soon make you know how rogues are to be kept in order, as long as I am magistrate.

tgt_text.404: whole of them to pieces under his feet.

tgt_text.406: "for," said he, "my dear Lucius, I have sufficiently disgraced this little old fellow.
tgt_text.407: "Astonished and dumb-foundered, at finding myself deprived of both money and supper, through the clever device of my knowing fellow-student, I betook myself to the baths.
tgt_text.408: After bathing, I returned to the house of Milo, and was going to my bedchamber, when the maid-servant, Fotis, said, " Your host invites you to supper.
tgt_text.410: I, however, who was already aware of the parsimony of Milo, courteously endeavoured to excuse myself by saying, that I thought the fatigue of the journey would be repaired not so much by food, as by sleep.
tgt_text.411: Milo, however, on receiving this message, came himself, and taking me by the right hand, politely tried to lead me in to supper;

tgt_text.413: At the same time, enforcing his words with an oath, he led me, thus obliged reluctantly to give way to his perseverance, to that same couch of his.
tgt_text.415: And how is our friend Demeas?" said he. " Are things going on prosperously with him ?
tgt_text.419: I answered every one of his enquiries.
tgt_text.420: He then minutely questioned me as to the object of my journey;
tgt_text.421: after I had fully informed him, he next asked me, with the most scrupulous inquisitiveness, concerning my country, and the principal people there ;
tgt_text.422: and, lastly, he was enquiring about our prefect, when, on perceiving that, weary from my long jour- ney, as veil as'from the length of my narration, I nodded, and stopped short in the middle of my sentences, and that, quite knocked up, I was stammering away at different words, so as to render them unintelligible, he at ength permitted me to go to rest.
tgt_text.423: Glad to escape from the prosy and famishing entertainment of the shabby old fellow, overpowered with sleep, and not with good cheer, having made my meal on talk alone:
tgt_text.424: * I re­ turned to my chamber, and surrendered myself to the repose I so much longed for.
tgt_text.425: So soon as a new sun had dispersed the night, and ushered in­ the day, I awoke and jumped out of bed;
tgt_text.426: being by nature anxious and, indeed, over-desirous of becoming acquainted with whatever is rare and admirable, I called to mind that I was in the very heart of Thessaly,* celebrated, by the unanimous consent of the whole world, as the land where the incantations of the magic art are indigenous., and in that very city which was the scene of the story of my worthy fellow-traveller Aris­ tomenes.
tgt_text.427: Excited in the highest degree by my longing de­ sire and my ardent temperament, I examined everything with eager curiosity.
tgt_text.428: Indeed, there was nothing in that city, which on beholding, I could believe to be what it really was;
tgt_text.429: but I fancied that everything was utterly transformed into another shape by means of some deadly spell, that the stones I kicked against were petrified men, that the birds I heard singing, were men transformed and feathered, that the trees which surrounded the pomoerium, were people in like manner, covered with leaves, and that the fountains of water flowed forth from the liquefied human bodies.
tgt_text.430: I was every instant expecting that the statues and pictures would take to walking, that the walls would speak, that oxen and cattle of all kinds would utter prophecies,* and that an oracle would issue on a sudden from the rays of the sun in heaven.
tgt_text.431: Thus bewildered, indeed I may say stupefied with torment­ ing anxiety, perceiving no likelihood or even trace of the ob­ jects of my wishes, I perambulated the whole city.
tgt_text.432: Wandering in this way just like one intoxicated, from door to door, I suddenly, without knowing where I was, found myself in the provision market.
tgt_text.433: Here, as it happened, quickening my pace, I overtook a lady, who was walking along, attended by a great retinue of domestics.
tgt_text.434: The gold that hung on her cheeks and her embroidered garments, bespoke her to be, beyond a doubt, a woman of the highest rank.
tgt_text.435: Close by her side walked a man considerably advanced in years, who, the moment he saw me, exclaimed, " By Hercules !
tgt_text.436: here is Lucius," and at the same moment embraced me, after which he whispered in the lady's ear something I could not hear."
tgt_text.437: And will you not, then," said he, " approach and salute your parent ? "t" I dare not," I replied, " salute a lady whom I do not know;
tgt_text.438: " and immediately the colour rising to my cheeks, I turned away my head and stood stock still;
tgt_text.439: while the lady looked at me with a steady gaze."
tgt_text.440: Behold," said she, " the high-born breeding of his most virtuous mother Salvia;
tgt_text.441: ‡ and then, his person bears an inex­ pressible resemblance to hers in every particular;
tgt_text.443: a slender but well-rounded figure, clear rosy complexion, hair yellow, and arranged without foppery, § eyes grey but keen, and glancing in all directions as brightly as an eagle's;
tgt_text.444: in short, he is comely in every point, and his carriage is graceful and unaffected.
tgt_text.445: "Then addressing herself to me, she added, " In these very arms of mine, Lucius, have I nursed you, and, indeed, how could it be otherwise?
tgt_text.446: seeing that I not only participated with your mother in blood, but was brought up along with her.
tgt_text.447: For we are both descended from the family of Plutarch, both of us sucked the breast of the same nurse, and grew up to­ gether in the ties of sisterhood;
tgt_text.448: nor is there any other differ­ ence between us, except that of rank;
tgt_text.449: for while she contracted a splendid alliance, I married a person in a private station.
tgt_text.450: I am that Byrrhæna, whose name, probably, you may recollect, as having been frequently mentioned among those who brought you up.
tgt_text.451: Come, therefore, with all confidence to our house, or rather, I would say, to your own home.
tgt_text.452: "Having had time to digest my bashfulness while the lady was speaking, I replied, " Far be it from me, my parent, that I should leave my entertainer, Milo, without any just cause of complaint.

tgt_text.454: And as often as I shall have occasion hereafter to come this way, I will be sure to call upon you.
tgt_text.455: "Conversing in this way, we had proceeded but a few paces, ere we arrived at Byrrhæna's house.
tgt_text.456: The hall* was most beautiful, and had statues of the goddess of Victory, † raised on pillars which stood at the four corners.
tgt_text.457: The wings of the figures were expanded;
tgt_text.458: their dewy feet seemed to brush the surface of a rolling sphere, although it moved not;
tgt_text.459: and they looked, not as if they were attached to it, but hovered in the air.
tgt_text.460: A statue of Diana, in Parian marble, occupied a level space in the middle of the enclosure.
tgt_text.461: The figure was singularly beau- tiful;
tgt_text.462: the garments of the goddess were blown back by the wind;
tgt_text.463: she seemed in the act of running directly towards you as you entered, and awed you by the majesty of her godlike form.
tgt_text.464: Dogs supported the goddess on either side, and these, too, were of marble.
tgt_text.465: Their eyes were fierce and threatening, their ears erect, their nostrils open, their jaws agape to devour ;
tgt_text.466: and had any barking been heard in the neighbourhood, you would have thought it proceeded from those marble throats.
tgt_text.467: A thing, also, in which the excellent sculptor had given proof of the most consummate art, was this, that the fore feet of the dogs, up­ lifted to their chests, were in the act of running, while the hind feet pressed the ground.
tgt_text.468: At the back of the goddess stood a rock, wrought to resemble a grotto, overgrown with moss, grass, leaves, and brushwood;
tgt_text.469: with vines and shrubs here and there;
tgt_text.470: and the reflection of the statue gleamed from the polished marble within the grotto.
tgt_text.471: Over the extreme edge of the rock hung apples and grapes, most exquisitely wrought, and in which art, rivalling nature, had so counterfeited their originals, that you would have thought they might be gathered for eating, when fragrant autumn had breathed upon them the tints of maturity.
tgt_text.472: And if, leaning forward, you had beheld the streamlets, which gently rippled as they ran beneath the feet of the goddess, you would have thought that, like clusters of grapes which hang from the vine, they too resembled real life in the faculty of motion.
tgt_text.473: In the midst of the foliage was Action, carved in marble, peering over his shoulders, and at the very instant changed into the wild form of a stag;
tgt_text.474: and both in the marble and in the reflection of the stream he was seen lying in ambush, await­ ing the coming of Diana to bathe.

tgt_text.477: After they were gone, " I take this goddess* to witness," said she, "my dearest Lucius, how great are the anxious apprehensions I entertain for you, and how earnestly I desire that you, who are as it were my son, should be put upon your guard.

tgt_text.483: Moreover, the instant she has beheld-any youth of handsome appearance, she is capti­ vated by his good looks, and immediately rivets her eyes and her affections upon him.

tgt_text.485: but as for those who are not suffi­ ciently compliant, she loathes and scorns them, and either changes them in a moment into stones, cattle, and animals of every kind,* or utterly annihilates them.

tgt_text.503: She was neatly dressed in a linen garment, gathered in by a bright red sash, just below her breasts, and as she stirred the saucepan round and round by a circular movement of her rosy hand, her supple form partook in the motion, her loins vi­ brated, and her flexible spine was thrown into charming un­ dulations.
tgt_text.504: Entranced by the sight, I stood gazing in admiration;
tgt_text.505: all my passions, which before lay dormant, were aroused.
tgt_text.506: At last I said to her, " With what a graceful, what a delightful twist of your hips, you stir that saucepan, my Fotis !

tgt_text.510: for if but a spark of it touch you, you will be burnt to the vitals ;

tgt_text.515: since it has ever been my sole care, in the first place, to scrutinize the head and the hair in public, and after­ wards to enjoy their loveliness in private :
tgt_text.516: and in this I pro­ ceed upon sure and fixed principles, first, because these are the most important features of the person, and from their conspi­ cuous position, they are the first to present themselves to our sight;
tgt_text.517: and, secondly, because the natural brilliancy of the hair effects for the head what the cheerful colour of a showy garment effects for the other members of the body..
tgt_text.518: Besides, most women, in order to display their native charms and loveliness, divest themselves of all neck mufflings, throw open their outer garments, and delight to show their naked beauty;
tgt_text.519: being conscious that they shall please more by the roseate hue of their skin, than by the golden tints of their robes.
tgt_text.520: But, on the other hand, (I shudder to speak of such a thing, and may there never be an instance of a catastrophe so dreadful,) if you deprive the most surpassingly beautiful woman of her hair, and thus strip her face of its native orna.
tgt_text.522: though she were begotten by heaven, conceived by the sea, and nurtured amid the waves;
tgt_text.523: though, I say, she were Venus herself, surrounded by all the choir of the Graces, at­ tended by a whole multitude of Cupids, girt with her cestus redolent of cinnamon, and bedewed with balsams-still, if she were bald, she would not find favour even in the eyes of her own Vulcan.
tgt_text.524: How exquisitely charming is hair of a beautiful hue and rich lustre, when it flashes back the rays of the sun, or shines with milder radiance, and varies its lovely aspect with every change of light!
tgt_text.525: now emitting a brightness like that of gold, now shaded off into the softer hue of honey;
tgt_text.526: raven-black at one moment, at the next reflecting the myriad blossom tints of the pigeon's neck;
tgt_text.527: or, when anointed with Arabian drops,* parted by the slender tooth of the comb, and gathered up be­ hind the head, it presents itself to the eyes of the lover, and like a mirror reflects his overjoyed features.
tgt_text.528: How beautiful, when its luxuriant mass is accumulated on the crown of the head, or suffered.
tgt_text.529: to flow down the back in profuse curls.
tgt_text.530: Such, in short, is the dignity of the hair, that though a woman should go adorned with jewels of gold, rich garments, precious stones, and every other kind of ornament, still she could not possibly seem well dressed, unless she had duly arranged her hair.
tgt_text.532: my Fotis, not studied artifice, but the neglect of orna­ ment, added graces to her person.
tgt_text.533: For her copious hair, thrown loosely back and falling adown her neck, rested lightly on the flexuous fringe of her garment;
tgt_text.534: then, after being gradually drawn together, the ends were looped up, and fastened by a knot to the crown of her head.

tgt_text.536: She looked at me over her shoulder, and her eyes lit into my heart with their sidelong glances:
tgt_text.537: " So then, you school-boy," said she, " you have taken a sweet, and at the same time, a bitter draught.

tgt_text.560: At this speech, Milo, bursting into a laugh, exclaimed, " In this lamp, we feed a mighty Sibyl, who looks down from the socket, § as from a watch-tower, upon all that is going on in the heavens, and even the sun himself.
tgt_text.561: "Mingling in the conversation, I said, " This is only a simple instance of this kind of divination, and, indeed, it ought not to seem wonderful, that this flame, small though it is, and ignited by human hands, should still have a consciousness of the greater and celestial fire, as of its parent, and should thus, by divine presage, know and announce to us what the source of its existence is about to effect in the summit of the firmament.
tgt_text.562: For with us, at Corinth, a certain Chaldean stranger is just now disturbing the whole city with his wonderful replies to questions asked him, and is disclosing the secrets of the Fates to the public for payment.
tgt_text.563: Thus, for instance, he would tell the day on which a marriage should be contracted that was destined to last long, or when the foundations of walls should be laid so as to re­ main for ever;
tgt_text.564: what day would be advantageous to the mer­ chant ;
tgt_text.565: or which one would be suited to the traveller, or adapted for setting sail.
tgt_text.566: In fine, when I consulted him as to what would be the result of this journey of mine, he told me many things of a very wonderful and an extremely varied nature.
tgt_text.567: He said, for instance, that I should shortly obtain a very considerable renown, and that I should be the writer of an incredible story, and of sundry books.""
tgt_text.568: What was the appearance of this Chaldean?" said Milo, with a smile, " and what was his name r""
tgt_text.569: He was a tall man," replied I, " of a dark complexion, and his name was Diophanes.""
tgt_text.570: It is the very same person," said Milo, " and no other, and here also, among us, he made many similar predictions to vari­ ous persons, and realized thereby no little wealth, indeed, I may say, a considerable sum of money;

tgt_text.572: *ONe day, when, encircled by a great crowd of people, he was dealing out the fates to the bystanders, a certain merchant, Cerdo by name, came to him, desirous to know what day would be suitable for a journey.
tgt_text.573: After Diophanes had named one, Cerdo took out his purse, poured out the money, and counted a hundred denars, which Diophanes was to receive as the price of his predictions, when a young man of a noble family, com­ ing softly behind him, pulled him by the garment, and on his turning round, embraced and kissed him in the most affectionate manner.
tgt_text.574: Diophanes having returned the embrace, desired the young man to take a seat beside him, and, under the surprise of his unexpected appearance, quite forgot the business with which he was just then engaged."
tgt_text.575: How long is it," said he, "since you, whom I have so much wished for, arrived in this neighbourhood ?
tgt_text.576: ""I arrived early last evening," replied the other.

tgt_text.581: Whatever we could scrape together, either from the pity of strangers, or the benevolence of our friends, a band of robbers laid hands on the whole of it;
tgt_text.582: and my only brother, Arisuatus, resisting their violence, was murdered, poor fellow!
tgt_text.584: "While Diophanes was dolefully relating these particulars, the merchant Cerdo, snatching up the money he had paid as the price of the prediction, instantly took to his heels.
tgt_text.585: Then, in­ deed, Diophanes at length aroused from his fit of abstraction, perceived the blunder he had made, especially when he saw all of us who stood around him burst into loud fits of laughter.
tgt_text.587: Nevertheless, master Lucius, I sincerely wish that the Chaldean may have predicted the truth to you if to no one else, and that you may be fortunate, and make a prosperous journey.
tgt_text.589: While Milo was thus prosing on at interminable length, I groaned inwardly, and was not a little vexed with myself for having voluntarily introduced a series of wearisome stories, and thus losing a good part of the evening, and its delightful enjoyments.
tgt_text.590: At length, therefore, gulping down all my bash­ fulness, I said to Milo, "Let Diophanes carry his destiny with him, and again expose the plunder of the public to land and sea.
tgt_text.591: But permit me, who am still sore from the fatigues of yesterday, to retire early to rest.
tgt_text.592: "So saying, I rose up and betook myself to my bedchamber;
tgt_text.593: and there I found a very nice assortment of good cheer.
tgt_text.594: The bed of the servant boys was laid on the floor, at a con­ siderable distance outside the door;
tgt_text.595: in order, I suppose, that they might not be within hearing of our chatter in the night.
tgt_text.596: Close by my bed stood a small table, laden with the choice remains of the whole supper, and some fair cups already half filled with- wine, only waiting for the admixture of water.
tgt_text.597: Near these, also, was a flagon, with a gradually dilated orifice, for the more convenient pouring forth of the wine;
tgt_text.598: the whole being a whet, as it were, for what was to follow.
tgt_text.599: I had scarcely laid me down, when, behold!
tgt_text.600: my Fotis (her mistress having now retired to rest) came in throwing a gar­ land of roses upon the bed, and wearing a single rose in full bloom in her bosom.

tgt_text.602: Before I had drunk the whole, she gently took it from me, and gradually di­ minishing with her lips what was left, sipped it sweetly, with her eyes fixed on me all the while.

tgt_text.611: "Fight," she said, "and fight bravely, for I will not give way an inch, nor turn my back.

tgt_text.624: But, look you," said she, " take care that you return early from this supper, for a frantic faction of the young nobles has been disturbing the public tranquillity, and you will see mur­ dered men lying here and there in the streets;

tgt_text.635: the couches, framed with polished ivory, were covered with cloth of gold;
tgt_text.636: the cups were ca­ pacious, of various graceful designs, and all unique in value.
tgt_text.637: Some were of glass, with figures exquisitely embossed:
tgt_text.639: others, again, of burnished silver, or of glittering gold, or of amber, admirably wrought and hollowed out into beakers.
tgt_text.640: In short, whatever one thought impossible to be made by man, was there.
tgt_text.641: The carvers* were numerous, and their dresses splendid;
tgt_text.642: the dishes were abundant, damsels waited gracefully at table, while youths with curled locks, and beautifully attired, ever and anon handed to the guests old wine in cups of precious stone.
tgt_text.643: And now, lights being brought in, the conversation gradually became more convivial;
tgt_text.644: there was abundance of laughter, and good-humoured quips and jokes flew about in every direction, when Byrrhæna thus addressed me :
tgt_text.646: How do you enjoy your­ self in this country of ours ?
tgt_text.647: If I am not mistaken, we greatly excel all other cities in temples, baths, and other public works.
tgt_text.648: And then we have an extraordinary abundance of all the commo­ dities of life.
tgt_text.649: Beyond a doubt here one enjoys full liberty, and may live at his ease ;
tgt_text.650: for the stranger who is a man of busi­ ness, there is all the bustle of Rome, while for the new-comer who is of retiring habits, the quiet of a country-house is here to be found.
tgt_text.651: In fine, our city is a place of resort for all the plea­ sure-seekers of this province.""
tgt_text.652: What you say is quite true," I replied, " and no where have I felt myself more perfectly at liberty than I am here.
tgt_text.653: But I am sadly frightened at the dark mysteries and irresis­ tible spells of the magic art.
tgt_text.654: For it is said, that here not even the sepulchres of the dead are unmolested, but that certain remnants and cuttings from the dead bodies are sought from the tombs and funeral-piles, to ensure deadly misfortune to the living.
tgt_text.655: I am told also that when foreigners are buried, old hags of sorceresses are in the habit of outstripping the funeral procession, in their speed to ravage the corpse.

tgt_text.723: ' Out with you, nasty little beast!

tgt_text.739: and, as often as you stand in need of my services, you may confidently command me.'"
tgt_text.740: Hardly had I thus spoken, when all the servants, heaping curses upon the dreadful ominousnesst of my words, snatched up whatever came to hand, and fell upon me.
tgt_text.741: One began to strike me in the face with his fist, another to dig me in the back and ribs with his elbows, a third to kick me with his feet, a fourth to pull out my hair, a fifth to tear my clothes.
tgt_text.742: Thus, mauled and mangled almost as badly as was Adonis or Orpheus, J I was thrust out of doors."
tgt_text.743: I stopped to recover myself in the next street, and reflect­ ing too late on my inauspicious and imprudent remark, I could not but acknowledge that I had fully deserved to suffer even still more blows than I had received.
tgt_text.744: By and by the dead person was carried out, accompanied, for the last time, by lamentations and outcries;
tgt_text.745: and, according to the custom of the country, was borne with all the pomp of a public funeral, as being one of the principal men, through the forum.
tgt_text.746: To the side of the corpse there runs up an old man, bathed with tears, and tearing his venerable white hair;
tgt_text.747: and then, seizing the bier with both his hands, and with a voice raised to the highest pitch, though interrupted with frequent sobs, 1 0 Romans,' exclaimed he, ' by your faith, and by the public morality, espcase the cause of your murdered fellow-citizen, and wreak your severe vengeance on this abominable and wicked woman, for her most atrocious crime;
tgt_text.748: for she, and no one else, has cut off by poison this unfortunate young man, my sister's son, for the sake of her paramour, and made a prey of the inheritance.'"
tgt_text.749: After this manner, the old man loudly uttered complaints and lamentations, broken by his sobs.
tgt_text.750: In the meantime, the people began to express their indignation, being impelled to a belief in the charge, on the grounds of its probability alone.
tgt_text.753: they incited the boys to the destruction of the woman;
tgt_text.754: but she, pretending to shed tears, and adjuring all the Divinities, denied most solemnly that she had perpetrated a crime of such great enormity." , Well then,' said the old man, ' let us refer the decision of the truth to divine providence.
tgt_text.755: Here is Zachlas, the Egyptian, a first-rate prophet, it who has already agreed with me, for a considerable sum, to recall the soul for a few moments from the realms beneath, to reanimate this body.'
tgt_text.756: Thus saying, he brought forward into the midst of the people a young man, clothed in linen garments,† with his head close shaven, and having on his feet sandals made of palm leaves.
tgt_text.758: After having for some time kissed his hands and embraced his very knees, 1 0 priest,' said he, ' take pity on me, by the stars of the heavens, by the Gods of the infernal regions, by the elements of nature, by the silence of night, by the Coptic en- closures,* by the overflowing of the Nile, by the mysteries of the Memphis, and by the sistrum of Pharos, I implore you.
tgt_text.759: Give to this dead body a short enjoyment of the sun, and infuse a portion of light into eyes that have been buried in eternal night.
tgt_text.760: We are not offering resistance to fate, nor do we deny to the earth what is her property;
tgt_text.761: but we only request a short space of life, that we may have the consolation of avenging her death!"
tgt_text.762: The prophet being thus propitiated, laid a certain herb three times on the mouth of the corpse, and placed another on its breast.
tgt_text.763: He then turned towards the east, and silently prayed to the rising disk of the glorious Sun, whilst an intense interest was excited among the byestanders, by the sight of such awful preparations, and the prospect of a miracle.
tgt_text.764: I mingled with the crowd, and standing on an elevated stone, close behind the bier, observed every thing with inquisitive eyes."
tgt_text.765: Presently the breast of the corpse began to be inflated, the artery to throb with pulsation, the body to be filled with breath;
tgt_text.766: at last the corpse arose, and thus addressed the young man:
tgt_text.767: t Why, I beseech thee, dost thou bring me back to the duties of a momentary existence, after having drunk of the Lethæan cup, and floated upon the Stygian lake ?
tgt_text.768: Cease, I beseech thee, cease and leave me to my repose.'
tgt_text.769: These were the words heard to proceed from the body."
tgt_text.770: On this, the prophet, becoming still more excited, exclaimed, ' Why dost thou not relate to this crowd each particular, and disclose the mysteries of thy death ?
tgt_text.771: Knowest thou not that the Furies can be summoned by my imprecations to rack thy wearied limbs ?'"
tgt_text.772: The body looked up from the bier, and with a deep groan thus addressed the people:
tgt_text.773: ' Cut off through the nefarious arts of my newly-married wife, and by a poisonous draught, I have yielded my yet warm bed to her paramour.'"
tgt_text.774: Then that choice specimen of a wife, arming herself with audacity, began to contradict the accusation of her husband in a wrangling and sacrilegious manner.
tgt_text.775: The excited mob took different sides;
tgt_text.776: one party contended that this most iniquitous woman should be immediately buried alive, with the corpse of her husband ;
tgt_text.777: the other declared that credit ought not to be given to the lying testimony of the dead body.
tgt_text.778: The subsequent disclosures, however, of the young man put an end to this dis­ pute ;
tgt_text.779: for, again heaving a deep groan, ' I will give you,' he said, ' I will give you incontrovertible evidence of the truth of my statements, and will disclose to you what is known to no other person whatever.'"
tgt_text.780: Then, pointing to me with his finger :
tgt_text.782: When that most sagacious guardian of my body,' said he, ' was diligently keep­ ing watch over me, the hags of sorceresses who eagerly hovered over my mortal spoils, and who, to gain possession thereof, had often changed themselves in vain into other forms, on finding that they could not deceive his unwearied vigilance, at length threw over him a cloud of drowsiness, and buried him in a profound sleep;
tgt_text.783: after which, they did not cease to call upon me by my name, till my weakened joints and chilled limbs strug­ gled, with convulsive efforts, to obey the mandates of the magic art.
tgt_text.784: Then this person, who though alive was still.
tgt_text.785: dead, so far as sleep goes, happening to be of the same name as myself, unconsciously arose on hearing his name called, and spontane­ ously walking just like an inanimate shadow, suffered the in­ tended mutilation instead of myself;
tgt_text.786: for although the doors of the bedchamber were carefully bolted, the witches entered through a chink, and cut off his nose first, and then his ears.
tgt_text.787: And, that the rest of the transaction might correspond with their artful doings, they with the greatest exactness fitted on to him wax, fashioned in imitation of his ears that had been cut off, and provided him with a nose of the same substance, just like his own.
tgt_text.788: And here now stands the unfortunate wretch who has obtained the reward dearly earned, not by his vigilance, but by his sore mutilation.'"
tgt_text.789: Exceedingly terrified on hearing this, I began to test my fortune.
tgt_text.790: Clapping my hand to my nose, I took hold of it, and off it came:
tgt_text.791: I touched my ears, and they fell to the ground.
tgt_text.792: Meanwhile the spectators pointed their fingers at me, nodded their heads, and greeted me with loud roars of laughter, until streaming with cold perspiration I dashed through the surrounding crowd, and effected my escape.
tgt_text.793: Nor, thus mutilated and an object of ridicule, could I return to my native place;
tgt_text.794: * but, with my hair falling on each side of my lace, I concealed the wounds of my ears, and decently covered the disgrace of my nose with this linen cloth, closely applied to it by means of glue."
tgt_text.796: As soon as Telephron had ended this story, the guests, elated with wine, again renewed their bursts of laughter.
tgt_text.797: While they were proposing his health, t Byrrhaena thus addressed me :
tgt_text.799: To-morrow is a day which it has been usual to cele­ brate from the earliest infancy and very foundation of this city, a day on which we exclusively, among mankind, propitiate the most sacred God of Laughter,J with ceremonies of joviality and mirth.
tgt_text.800: Your presence will render the festival still more pleasing to us;
tgt_text.801: and I wish that with your native wit, you would devise something of a right joyous nature in honour of the God, in order that we may the more becomingly and abundantly shew our veneration for so great a Divinity.""
tgt_text.803: " what you request shall be done.
tgt_text.805: I wish I may invent some piece of merriment with which a god so mighty may be becomingly graced.
tgt_text.806: "By this time, having had my fill of wine, and being warned by my servant it was now night, I immediately arose, and having hastily bid farewell to Byrrhæna, took my way home­ ward, with unsteady steps.
tgt_text.807: But while we were going through the first street, the light upon which we relied was extin- guished by a sudden gust of wind;
tgt_text.808: so that, with difficulty groping our way through the darkness of the night against which we were so badly provided, and continually knocking our toes against the stones, we were quite wearied before we arrived at home.
tgt_text.809: When we had now entered our own street, lo and behold, three men, of lusty and stout appearance, were pushing with all their might against our door, and were not in the smallest degree alarmed at our coming up;
tgt_text.810: on the contrary, they kicked at it more and more repeatedly with all their might, so that to us, and to myself especially, they appeared unquestionably to be robbers, and of the most desperate character.
tgt_text.811: Accord­ ingly, I instantly drew forth my sword, which I carried with me concealed under my cloak against such an emergency.
tgt_text.812: Without delay I rushed into the midst of the robbers., and plunged my sword to the hilt into the body of each, as I en­ gaged with him in combat, till at length, pierced with many and deadly wounds, they breathed their last before my very feet.
tgt_text.813: Awakened by the tumult of this combat, Fotis came and opened the door.
tgt_text.814: I crawled into the house, panting for breath and bathed in perspiration, and immediately threw myself on my bed and fell asleep, as much fatigued with the slaughter of these sturdy robbers, as if I had killed Geryon.
tgt_text.815: *AURORA, with her rosy arm uplifted, had just begun to drive her purple-caparisoned steeds through the heavens;
tgt_text.816: and de­ parting night surrendering me up to day, roused me from placid slumbers.
tgt_text.817: Compunction then seized my mind at the recollec­ tion of the deed I had perpetrated on the previous evening.
tgt_text.818: Gathering my feet beneath me, locking my fingers upon my knees, and so sitting up in bed on my haunches, I wept abundantly;
tgt_text.819: picturing to myself, in imagination, now the Forum and the trial, now the condemnation, and lastly, the executioner himself."
tgt_text.820: Shall I," said I to myself, " shall I meet with any judge so mild and so considerate as to be able to pronounce me inno­ cent,, when here I am, imbrued with the blood of a threefold homicide, and reeking with the gore of so many citizens ?
tgt_text.821: Is this the journey so glorious in its results which Diophanes, the Chaldaean, so confidently predicted for me ?"
tgt_text.822: While with such reflections ever and anon crossing my mind, I deplored my evil fortune, a violent knocking at the door, and shouting was heard at the gate:
tgt_text.823: without more ado, it was thrown open, and a great multitude rushing into the house, every part of it was filled with the magistrates and their officers, and a miscel­ laneous gathering of people.
tgt_text.824: Instantly two of the lictors, laying hands upon me, by order of the magistrates, began to drag me along, whilst I offered no resistance.
tgt_text.825: When we had got to the end of the lane,* we were immediately met by such an astonishing multitude, that it seemed as if the whole city was pouring forth.
tgt_text.826: And though I walked sorrowfully along, with my head bowed down towards the ground, or rather, I may say, to the shades below, yet, on casting a glance aside, I saw a thing which caused me the greatest surprise.
tgt_text.827: For among the many thousands of people that surrounded me, there was not a single one who was not ready to split his sides with laughter.
tgt_text.828: At length, having passed through all the principal streets, and turning corner after corner, like the victim of a lustral sa­ crifice, led all round the city before it is slain, to expiate the anger of the Gods, I was marched into the Forum, and placed before the judgment seat.
tgt_text.829: And now, the magistrates being seated on an elevated platform, the public crier proclaimed silence, when suddenly the people, with one unanimous voice, requested that, in consequence of the multitude of spectators, whose lives were in peril from the enormous pressure, this im­ portant trial might take place in the theatre.
tgt_text.830: Forthwith the Forum was evacuated in every direction, the people filled every seat in the body of the theatre* with extraordinary celerity;
tgt_text.831: and in the very entrances also, and over the whole of the roof, they crowded as thick as they could stand.
tgt_text.832: Great numbers clung to the columns;
tgt_text.833: some hung on to the statues;
tgt_text.834: others were only half visible through windows and between the beams of the ceiling;
tgt_text.835: and all, in their ardent desire to witness the sight, paid no attention whatever to their own safety.
tgt_text.836: The public officers now led me through the proscenium, t just like some victim, and placed me in the midst of the orchestra.
tgt_text.837: The accuser being again summoned by the loud bellowing of the crier, arose, and after water had been poured into a certain vessel, ‡ which was finely perforated like a cullen­ der, and through which it flowed drop by drop, for the purpose of regulating the time for speaking, he thus addressed the people:
tgt_text.839: A case is now brought before you, most worthy fellow- citizens, which is of no trifling magnitude, but one which es­ pecially regards the peace of the whole city, and is likely to prove a momentous example, profitable to future ages.
tgt_text.840: Where­ fore, it is the more requisite that each and all of you should have due regard for the public dignity, that so this nefarious homicide, who has murdered so many citizens, may not go un­ punished, for having thus cruelly butchered them.
tgt_text.841: And do not suppose that I am actuated by any private grudge, or moved by personal animosity, in making this charge against him.
tgt_text.842: For I am the prefect of the night-watch :
tgt_text.843: and I fully believe there is not one person who can impeach my vigil­ ance and attention.
tgt_text.844: Accordingly, I will faithfully relate the exact circumstances, and the transactions that took place last night."
tgt_text.845: When about the third watch, * I had nearly gone my rounds of the whole city, and had examined every corner from door to door with scrupulous attention, I perceived this most blood- thirsty young man laying about him on every side, and slaugh­ tering with his drawn sword ;
tgt_text.846: and I saw that three persons, who had just fallen victims to his rage, were laid at his feet, still breathing, and their bodies palpitating amid streams of gore.
tgt_text.847: Then, conscience-stricken, and with good reason, at the commission of such a heinous deed, he immediately took to flight, and having, through the protection of the darkness, es­ caped into a certain house, he there lay concealed the whole night.
tgt_text.848: By the providence of the gods, however, which allows no crime to pass unpunished, I took care to arrest him in the morning, and bring him hither for the most august judgment of your venerable tribunal, before he could make his escape clandestinely.
tgt_text.849: You have, therefore, before you a cul­ prit defiled with so many murders, a culprit taken in the very fact, a culprit who is a foreigner.
tgt_text.850: Unhesitatingly, then, pass sentence on this stranger, for a crime, for the commission of which you would severely punish one of your own citizens.
tgt_text.851: "My most unsparing accuser having thus spoken, closed his tremendous harangue.
tgt_text.852: The moment he ceased, the crier ordered me to begin, if I wished to make any reply to what had been said.
tgt_text.853: But as for me, at that moment I could do nothing but weep ;
tgt_text.855: so much on account of the dreadful accusation, as of my own wretched conscience.
tgt_text.856: At last, however, inspired by the gods with some degree of boldness, I thus answered the charge:
tgt_text.857: "I am far from ignorant how difficult it is for any one, when three corpses of citizens are lying exposed, and he is accused of the murder, to persuade so vast a multitude that he is really innocent, while he speaks the truth, and readily con­ fesses that he committed the deed.
tgt_text.858: But if your humanity will allow me a public hearing for a short time, I shall have no difficulty in showing you that I now stand in peril of my life, not through any ill-deserts of my own, but that it is through a fortuitous result of justifiable indignation, that I am innocently subjected to the reproach of so great a crime."
tgt_text.859: For, as I was returning from an entertainment, somewhat later than usual, and besides, being in a state bordering on intoxication, which indeed I will not deny was really my crime, I beheld before the door of the place where I reside (for I am staying with your worthy fellow-citizen Milo), I be­ held, I say, some most desperate robbers trying to force an entrance, and to wrench the door off its hinges.
tgt_text.860: Already they had with great violence torn away all the bars which had been put up with the greatest care, and at that very moment they were meditating the murder of the inhabitants within.
tgt_text.861: One of them, in fact, who was the most active with his hands, and the largest in bulk, was encouraging the others with these words, ' Come on, my lads, let us fall upon those within while they are asleep, with manly spirits and vigorous hands.
tgt_text.862: Be all hesitation, all sluggishness, banished from your breasts.
tgt_text.863: Let slaughter stalk, sword in hand, from one end of the house to the other.
tgt_text.864: Let him who lies sound asleep be put to death ;
tgt_text.865: let him who endeavours to resist be knocked down.
tgt_text.866: Thus shall we get off in safety, if we don't leave a single person in safety in the house.
tgt_text.868: seeing that I entertained extreme fears both on account of my entertainers and myself, and that I was armed with a sword which I carried with me as a pro­ vision against dangers of this kind, I thought it was the duty of a good member of the community, to endeavour to alarm and put to flight these most desperate robbers.
tgt_text.869: But the barbarous and bloodthirsty villains were far from taking to flight;
tgt_text.870: and though they raw that I was armed, they still offered a bold resistance, and stood their ground in battle array.
tgt_text.871: In fact, the leader and standard-bearer, as it were, of the rest, attacking me at once with great impetuosity, seizing me by the hair with both his hands, and bend­ ing me backward, tried to smash me with a stone.
tgt_text.872: But while he was crying out for one to be handed to him, making a sure thrust at him, I fortunately laid him prostrate.
