tgt_text.1366: or at least, that once again, impregnated by a new emanation' from the starry heavens, not the sea, but the earth, had brought forth another Venus, gifted with the flower of virginity.
tgt_text.1367: Thus did her fame travel rapidly every day;
tgt_text.1368: thus did the news soon traverse the neighbouring islands, a great part of the con- tinent, and multitudes of provinces.
tgt_text.1369: Many were the mortals who, by long journeys over land, and over the deep sea, flocked from all quarters to behold this glorious specimen of the age.
tgt_text.1370: No one set sail for Paphos,* no one for Cnidus, nor even for Cythera, to have sight of the goddess Venus.
tgt_text.1371: Her sacred rites were abandoned, her temples suffered to decay, her cushions † trampled under foot, her ceremonies neglected, her statues left without chaplets, and her desolate altars defiled with cold ashes.
tgt_text.1372: A young girl was supplicated in her stead, and the divinity of the mighty goddess was worshipped under human features;
tgt_text.1373: and the maiden was propitiated in herjnorn- ing walks with victims and banquets offered her in the name of the absent Venus.
tgt_text.1374: And ever, as she passed along the streets, the people crowded round, and adoringly presented her with garlands, and scattered flowers on her (path."
tgt_text.1375: This extraordinary transfer of celestial honors to a mortal maiden, greatly incensed the real Venus;
tgt_text.1376: and, unable to sup­ press her indignation, and shaking her head, in towering wrath, she thus soliloquized:
tgt_text.1377: ‘ Behold how the primal parent of all things, behold how the first source of the elements,‡ behold how I, the genial Venus of the whole world, am- treated!
tgt_text.1378: The honor belonging to my majesty shared 'by a mortal girl!
tgt_text.1379: My name, that isregistered in heaven, profaned by the dross of earth!
tgt_text.1380: I must be content, forsooth, with the un­ certain homage of a vicarious worship, and with my share in expiations offered to me in common with another!
tgt_text.1381: And a mortal girl shall go about in my likeness !
tgt_text.1382: It is all for nought that the shepherd Paris, whose justice and good faith the mighty Jupiter approved, preferred me to such mighty God­ desses, § on account of my unparalleled beauty.
tgt_text.1383: But this crea- ture, whosoever she be, shall not so joyously usurp my honors ;
tgt_text.1384: for I will soon cause her to repent of her contraband good looks.
tgt_text.1385: '"Thus saying, the goddess forthwith summons her son ;
tgt_text.1386: that winged and very malapert boy, who, with his evil manners, sets at nought all ordinary institutions, and, armed with flames and with arrows, runs by night from one man's house to another, and blighting matrimonial happiness on all sides, com­ mits such mighty mischiefs with impunity, and does nothing whatever that is good."
tgt_text.1387: Mischievous as he was by inborn licentiousness, she in­ cites him to still more evil, by her words:
tgt_text.1388: she brings him to that city I mentioned, and points out Psyche to him* (for that was the name of the maiden), and after telling him the whole story about that mortal's rivalry of her own beauty, groaning with rage and indignation, she said," ' I conjure you by the ties of maternal love, by the sweet wounds inflicted by your arrow, by the warmth, de­ lightful as honey, of that torch, to afford your parent her revenge, ay, and a full one too, and as you respect myself, severely punish this rebellious beauty:
tgt_text.1389: and this one thing, above all, use all your endeavours to effect;
tgt_text.1390: let this maiden be seized with the most burning love for the lowest of mankind, one whom fortune has stripped of rank, patrimony, and even of personal safety;
tgt_text.1391: one so degraded, that he cannot find his equal in wretchedness throughout the whole world.'“
tgt_text.1392: Having thus said, and long and tenderly kissed her son, she sought the neighbouring margin of the shore on which the waves ebb and flow, and, with rosy feet, brushing along the topmost spray of the dancing waters, behold!
tgt_text.1393: she took her seat on the watery surface of the main;
tgt_text.1394: where the powers of the deep, the instant that she conceived the wish, appeared at once, as though she had previously com­ manded their attendance.
tgt_text.1395: The daughters of Nereus were present, singing in tuneful harmony;
tgt_text.1396: Portunus,* too, rough with his azure-coloured beard, and Salacia,† weighed down with her lapful of fish, with little Palæmon, their charioteer, upon a dolphin, and then troops of Tritons, furrowing the main in all directions.
tgt_text.1397: One softly sounded his melodious shell, another, with a silken canopy J protected her from the un­ pleasant heat of the, sun, a third held a mirror before the eyes of his mistress, while others, again, swam.
tgt_text.1399: Such was the train that attended Venus, as she proceeded to the palace of Oceanus."
tgt_text.1400: In the meantime, Psyche, with all her exquisite beauty, derived no advantage whatever from her good looks;
tgt_text.1401: she was gazed on by all, praised by all, and yet no one, king, noble, or plebeian even, came to woo her for his bride.
tgt_text.1402: They admired, no doubt, her divine beauty, but then they all ad.
tgt_text.1403: mired it as they would a statue exquisitely wrought.
tgt_text.1404: Long before this, her two elder sisters, whose more moderate charms had not been bruited abroad among the nations, had been wooed by kings, and happily wedded to them;
tgt_text.1405: but Psyche, forlorn virgin, sat at home,'bewailing her lonely condi­ tion, faint in body and sick at heart;
tgt_text.1406: and hated her own beauty, though it delighted all the rest of the world.
tgt_text.1407: "The wretched father of this most unfortunate daughter, sus­ pecting the enmity of the gods, and dreading their wrath, con­ sulted the very ancient oracle of the Milesian God, and sought of that mighty divinity, with prayers and victims, a husband for the maiden whom no one cared to have.
tgt_text.1408: But Apollo, though a Grecian and an Ionian, by right of the founder of Miletus, delivered an oracle in Latin verse to the following effect:
tgt_text.1410: scopulo desiste puellam Ornatam mundo funerei thalami:
tgt_text.1413: Sed sævum atque ferum, vipereumque malum ;
tgt_text.1414: Qui, pinnis volitans super æthera, cuncta fatigat, Flammaque et ferro singula debilitat;
tgt_text.1417: Flumina quern horrescunt, et Stygiæ tenebræ.’*“
tgt_text.1418: The king, who had led a happy life till then, on hearing the announcement of the sacred oracle, returned home sad and slow, and disclosed to his wife the behests of inauspicious fate.
tgt_text.1419: Many-days together were passed in grief and tears, and lamentation.
tgt_text.1420: But time pressed, and the dire oracle had now to be fulfilled.
tgt_text.1421: The procession was formed for the deadly nuptials of the ill-fated maiden;
tgt_text.1422: the lighted torch burns ashy, black, and sooty;
tgt_text.1423: the strains of Conjugal Juno's pipes are changed for the plaintive Lydian melody;
tgt_text.1424: the joyful hyme­ neal song sinks into a dismal wailing, and the bride wipes away her tears with the nuptial veil † itself.
tgt_text.1425: The whole city groaned in sympathy with the sad destiny of the afflicted family, and a public mourning was immediately proclaimed.“
tgt_text.1426: The necessity, however, of complying with the celestial mandates, importunately called the wretched Psyche to her doom.
tgt_text.1427: The solemn preliminaries, therefore, of this direful marriage being completed in extreme sorrow, the funeral pro­ cession of the living dead moves on, accompanied by all the people;
tgt_text.1428: and the weeping Psyche walks not to her nuptials, but to her obsequies.
tgt_text.1429: And while her woe-begone parents, over­ whelmed with horror, strove to delay the execution of the abominable deed, the daughter herself thus exhorted them to compliance:
tgt_text.1430: " 1 Why torment your unfortunate old age with continual weeping ?
tgt_text.1431: Why waste your breath, which is more dear to me than to you, with repeated lamentations ?
tgt_text.1432: Why deform your features, to me so venerable, with unavailing tears ?
tgt_text.1433: Why lacerate my eyes in afflicting your own?
tgt_text.1435: Why beat your bosoms and those hallowed breasts ?
tgt_text.1436: Are these to be the glorious results to you of my surpassing beauty ?
tgt_text.1437: Too late do you perceive that you have been smitten by the deadly shaft of envy.
tgt_text.1439: then should you have wept and lamented, then bewailed me as lost, when tribes and nations celebrated me with divine honors, and when, with one consent, they styled me a new-born Venus.
tgt_text.1440: Now do I feel and see that through that name of Venus alone I perish.
tgt_text.1441: Lead me away, then, and expose me on the rock to which the 'oracle has devoted me;
tgt_text.1442: I am in haste to encounter these auspicious nuptials;
tgt_text.1443: I am in haste to see this noble bridegroom of mine.-
tgt_text.1445: Why avoid his approach, who has been born for the destruction of the whole world ?'"
tgt_text.1446: The maiden, after these words, said no more, but with un­ faltering steps, took her place in the multitudinous procession.
tgt_text.1447: They advanced to the destined rock on a lofty mountain, and left the maiden alone on the summit;
tgt_text.1448: the nuptial torches, with which they had lighted their way, were now extinguished in their tears, and thrown aside, the ceremony was at an end, and with drooping heads they took their homeward way.
tgt_text.1449: "As for her wretched parents, sinking under the weight of a calamity so great, they shut themselves up in their darkened palace, and abandoned themselves to perpetual night.
tgt_text.1450: Meanwhile, as Psyche lay trembling and weeping in dismay on the summit of the rock, the mild breeze of the gently-blowing.
tgt_text.1451: Zephyr played round her garments, fluttering and gradually expanding- them till they lifted her up, and the god, wafting her with his tranquil breath adown the lofty mountain side, laid her softly on the flowery turf in the lap of the valley." *“
tgt_text.1452: PSYCHE, therefore, delightfully reclining in this pleasant and grassy spot, upon a bed of dewy herbage, felt her extreme agitation of mind allayed, and sank into a sweet sleep, from which she awoke refreshed in body, and with a mind more composed.
tgt_text.1453: She then espied a grove, thick planted with vast and lofty trees ;
tgt_text.1454: she likewise saw a fountain in the middle of the grove, with water limpid as crystal.
tgt_text.1455: Near the fall of the fountain there was a kingly palace, not raised by human hands, but by divine skill.
tgt_text.1456: You might know, from the very entrance of the palace, that you were looking upon the splendid and delightful abode of some God.
tgt_text.1457: For the lofty ceilings, curiously arched with cedar and ivory, were sup­ ported by golden columns.
tgt_text.1458: The walls were encrusted all over with silver carving, with wild beasts and domestic ani­ mals of all kinds, presenting themselves to the view of those who entered the palace.
tgt_text.1459: A wonderful man was he, a demigod, nay, surely, a god, who with such exquisite subtlety of art, moulded such vast quantities of silver into various ferine forms."
tgt_text.1460: The very pavement itself consisted of precious stones cut out and arranged so as to form pictures of divers kinds.'
tgt_text.1461: Blessed, thrice blessed, those who can tread gems and bracelets under foot!
tgt_text.1462: The other parts, as well, of this palace of vast extent, were precious beyond all computation;
tgt_text.1463: and the walls being everywhere strengthened with bars of gold, shone with their own lustre, so that even were the sun to withhold his light, the palace could make for itself a day of its own;
tgt_text.1464: so effulgent were the chambers, the porticos, and the doors.
tgt_text.1465: The furni­ ture, too, was on a scale commensurate with the majesty of this abode ;
tgt_text.1466: so that it might well be looked upon as a palace built by mighty Jove, where he might dwell among mankind."
tgt_text.1467: Invited by the delightful appearance of the place, Pysche approached it, and, gradually taking courage, stepped over the threshold.
tgt_text.1468: The beauty of what she beheld lured her on, and everything filled her with admiration.
tgt_text.1469: In another part of the palace, she beheld magnificent repositories, stored with im­ mense riches;
tgt_text.1470: nothing, in fact, is there which was not there to be found.
tgt_text.1471: But besides the admiration which such enormous wealth excited, this was particularly surprising, that this treasury of the universal world was protected by no chain, no bar, no guard."
tgt_text.1472: Here, while Psyche's gaze was ravished with delight, a bodiless voice thus addressed her;
tgt_text.1473: ' Why, lady,' it said, ‘ are you astonished at such vast riches ?
tgt_text.1475: Betake yourself, therefore, to your chamber, and refresh your wearied limbs on your couch, and, when you think proper, repair to the bath;
tgt_text.1476: for we, whose voices you now hear, are your hand­ maidens, and will carefully attend to all your commands, and, when we have dressed you, a royal banquet will be placed be­ fore you without delay.
tgt_text.1478: Psyche was sensible of the goodness of divine providence, and, obedient to the admonitions of the unembodied voices, relieved her fatigue, first with sleep, and afterwards with the bath.
tgt_text.1479: After this, perceiving, close at hand, a semicircular dais with a raised seat, and what seemed to be the apparatus for a banquet, intended for her refreshment, she readily took her place;
tgt_text.1480: whereupon nectareous wines, and numerous dishes containing various kinds of dainties, were immediately served up, impelled, as it seemed, by some spiritual impulse, for there were no visible attendants.
tgt_text.1481: Not one human being could she see, she only heard words that were uttered, and had voices alone for her servants.
tgt_text.1482: After an exquisite banquet was served up, some one entered, and sang unseen, while another struck the lyre, which was no more visible than himself.
tgt_text.1483: Then, a swell of voices, as of a multitude singing in full chorus, was wafted to her ears, though not one of the vocalists could she descry."
tgt_text.1484: After these delights had ceased, the evening now persuading to repose, Psyche retired to bed:
tgt_text.1485: and when the night was far advanced, a certain gentle, murmuring sound fell upon her ears.
tgt_text.1486: Then alarmed for her honor, in consequence of the profound solitude of the place, she trembled and was filled with terror, and dreaded that of which she was ignorant more than any misfortune.
tgt_text.1487: And now her unknown bridegroom ascended the couch, made Psyche his wife, and hastily left her before break of day.
tgt_text.1488: Immediately the attendant voices of the bedchamber came to aid the wounded modesty of the new-made bride.
tgt_text.1489: This course was continued for a length of time ;
tgt_text.1490: and, as by nature it has been so ordained, the novelty, by its constant repetition, afforded her delight, and the sound of the voices was the solace of her solitude.“
tgt_text.1491: In the meantime, her parents were wasting their old age in sorrow and lamentation;
tgt_text.1492: and the report of her fate, be­ coming more widely extended, her elder sisters had learnt all the particulars;
tgt_text.1493: whereupon leaving their homes in deep grief, they hastened to visit and comfort their parents.
tgt_text.1494: On that night, did Psyche's husband thus address her-for she could discern his presence with her ears and hands, though not with her eyes:
tgt_text.1495: " ' Most charming Psyche, dear wife, cruel fortune now threatens you with a deadly peril, which needs, I think, to be guarded against with the most vigilant attention.
tgt_text.1496: For ere long, your sisters, who are alarmed at the report of your death, in their endeavours to discover traces of you, will arrive at yonder rock.
tgt_text.1497: If, then, you should chance to hear their lamentations, make them no reply, no, nor even so much as turn your eyes towards them.
tgt_text.1498: By doing otherwise, you will cause most grievous sorrow to me, and utter destruction to yourself.'"
tgt_text.1499: Psyche assented, and promised that she would act agreeably to her husband's desire.
tgt_text.1500: But when he and the night had de­ parted together, the poor thing consumed the whole day in tears and lamentations, exclaiming over and over again, that she was now utterly lost, since, besides being thus confined in a splen­ did prison, deprived of human conversation, she was not even allowed to relieve the minds of her sisters, who were sorrowing for her, nor, indeed, so much as to see them.
tgt_text.1501: Without having refreshed herself, therefore, with the bath or with food, or, in fact, with any solace whatever, but weeping plenteously, sha retired to rest.
tgt_text.1502: Shortly afterwards, her husband, coming to her bed earlier than usual, embraced her as she wept, and thus expostulated with her:
tgt_text.1503: " 'Is this, my Psyche, what you promised me ?
tgt_text.1504: What am I, your husband, henceforth to expect of you ?
tgt_text.1505: What can I now hope for, when neither by day nor by night, not even in the midst of our conjugal endearments, you cease to be dis­ tracted with grief?
tgt_text.1506: Very well, then, act now just as you please, and comply with the baneful dictates of your inclina­ tion.
tgt_text.1507: However, when you begin too late to repent, you will recall to mind my serious admonitions.'"
tgt_text.1508: Upon this, she had recourse to prayers;
tgt_text.1509: and threatening that she would put an end to herself if her request were de­ nied, she extorted from her husband a consent that she might see her sisters, to soothe their grief, and enjoy their con­ versation.
tgt_text.1510: This he yielded to the entreaties of his new-made wife, and he gave her permission, besides, to present her sis­ ters with as much gold and as many jewels as she pleased;
tgt_text.1511: but he warned her repeatedly and so often as to terrify her, never, on any occasion, to be persuaded by the pernicious advice of her sisters, to make any enquiries concerning the form of her husband;
tgt_text.1512: lest by a sacrilegious curiosity, she might cast her­ self down from such an exalted position of good fortune, and never again feel his embraces.“
tgt_text.1513: She thanked her husband for his indulgence;
tgt_text.1514: and now, having quite recovered her spirits, 'Nay,' said she, ‘ I would suffer death a hundred times rather than be deprived of your most delightful company, for I love you, yes, I do at upon you to desperation, whoever you are, ay, even as I love my own soul, nor would I give you in exchange for Cupid him­ self.
tgt_text.1515: But this also I beseech you to grant to my prayers;
tgt_text.1516: bid Zephyr, this servant of yours, convey my sisters to me, in the same manner in which he brought me hither.'
tgt_text.1517: Then, pressing his lips with persuasive kisses, murmuring endearing words, and enfolding him with her clinging limbs, she called him coaxingly, 'My sweet, my husband, dear soul of thy Psyche.'
tgt_text.1518: Her husband, overcome by the power of love, yielded reluc­ tantly, and promised all she desired.
tgt_text.1519: After this, upon the approach of morning, he again vanished from the arms of his wife."
tgt_text.1520: Meanwhile, the sisters, having inquired the way to the rock on which Psyche was abandoned, hastened thither;
tgt_text.1521: and there they wept and beat their breasts till the rocks and crags re­ sounded with their lamentations.
tgt_text.1522: They called to their unfor­ tunate sister, by her own name, until the shrill sound of their shrieks descending the declivities of the mountain, reached the ears of Psyche, who ran out of her palace in delirious trepi­ dation, and exclaimed:
tgt_text.1523: " 1 Why do you needlessly afflict yourselves with doleful lamentations ?
tgt_text.1524: Here am I, whom you mourn;
tgt_text.1525: cease those dismal accents, and now at last dry up those tears that have so long bedewed your cheeks, since you may now embrace her whom you have been lamenting.'"
tgt_text.1526: Then, summoning Zephyr, she acquaints him with her hus­ band's commands, in obedience to which, instantly wafting them on his gentlest breeze, he safely conveyed them to Psyche.
tgt_text.1527: Now do they enjoy mutual embraces, and hurried kisses ;
tgt_text.1528: and their tears, that had ceased to flow, return, after a time, sum­ moned forth by joy.
tgt_text.1529: 'Now come,' said Psyche, ‘enter my dwelling in gladness, and cheer up your afflicted spirits with your Psyche.'
tgt_text.1530: Having thug said, she showed them the vast treasures of her golden palace, made their ears acquainted with the numerous retinue of voices that were obedient to her commands, and sumptuously refreshed them in a most beauti­ ful bath, and with the delicacies of a divine banquet;
tgt_text.1531: until, satiated with this copious abundance of celestial riches, they began to nourish envy in the lowest depths of their breasts.
tgt_text.1532: One of them, especially, very minute and curious, persisted in making enquiries about the master of this celestial wealth, what kind of person, and what sort of husband he made."
tgt_text.1533: Psyche, however, would by no means violate her husband's injunctions, or disclose the secrets of her breast;
tgt_text.1534: but, de­ vising a tale for the occasion, told them that he was a young man, and very good looking, with cheeks as yet only shaded with soft down, and that he was, for the most part, engaged in rural occupations, and hunting on the mountains.
tgt_text.1535: And lest, by any slip in the course of the protracted conversation, her secret counsels might be betrayed, having loaded them with ornaments of gold and jewelled necklaces, she called Zephyr, and ordered him at once to convey them- back again."
tgt_text.1536: This being immediately executed, these excellent sisters, as they were returning home, now burning more and more with the rancour of envy, conversed much with each other;
tgt_text.1537: at last one of them thus began:
tgt_text.1538: “Do but see how blind, cruel, and unjust, Fortune has proved!
tgt_text.1539: Were you, my sister, de­ lighted to find that we, born of the same parents, had met with such a different lot ?
tgt_text.1540: We, indeed, who are the elder, are delivered over as bondmaids* to foreign husbands, and live in banishment from our home, our native land, and our parents;
tgt_text.1541: and this, the youngest of us all, the last production of our mother's exhausted powers of parturition, is raised to the en­ joyment of such boundless wealth, and has a god for her hus­ band, she who does not even know how to enjoy, in a proper manner, such an abundance of blessings ?
tgt_text.1542: You saw, sister, what a vast number of necklaces there were in the house, and of what enormous value, what splendid dresses, what brilliant gems, and what heaps of gold she treads upon in every direc­ tion.
tgt_text.1543: If, besides all this, she possesses a husband so handsome as she asserts him to be, there lives not in the whole world a happier woman than she.
tgt_text.1544: Perhaps, however, upon continued acquaintance, and when his affection is strengthened, her hus­ band, who is a god, will make her a goddess as well.
tgt_text.1547: she comported and demeaned herself just like one:
tgt_text.1548: the woman must needs assume a lofty bearing, and give herself the airs of a goddess, who has voices for her attendants, and commands the very winds themselves.
tgt_text.1549: But I, wretched creature, am tied to a husband who, in the first place, is older than my father;
tgt_text.1550: and who, in the next place, is balder than a pumpkin, and more dwarfish than any boy, and who fastens up every part of his house with bolts and chains.'"
tgt_text.1551: ' But I,' replied the other sister, 'have got to put up with a husband who is tormented and crippled with gout;
tgt_text.1552: and who, on this account, seldom honours me with his embraces, while I have to be everlastingly rubbing his distorted and chalky fingers with filthy fomentations, nasty rags, and stinking poul­ tices ;
tgt_text.1553: scalding these delicate hands, and acting the part not of ft wife, but of a female doctor.
tgt_text.1554: You, sister, seem to bear all this with a patient, or rather a servile spirit, for I shall speak out fully what I think;
tgt_text.1555: but, for my part, I can no longer en. dure that such a fortunate destiny should have so undeservedly fallen to her lot.
tgt_text.1556: And then, recollect in what a haughty and arrogant manner she behaved towards us, and how, by her boast­ ing and immoderate ostentation, she betrayed a heart swelling with pride, and how reluctantly she threw us a trifling portion of her immense riches;
tgt_text.1557: and immediately after, being weary of our company, ordered us to be turned out, and to be puffed and whisked away.
tgt_text.1558: But may I be no woman, nor indeed may I breathe, if I do not hurl her down headlong from such mighty wealth.
tgt_text.1559: And if this contumely offered to us stings you, too, as it ought, let us both join in forming some effective plan.
tgt_text.1560: In the first place, then, let us not show these things that we have got, either to our parents or to any one else ;
tgt_text.1561: in fact, we are to know nothing at all about her safety.
tgt_text.1562: It is quite enough that we ourselves have seen what it vexes us to have seen, without having to spread the report of her good fortune among our parents and all the people;
tgt_text.1563: for, in fact, those persons are not wealthy whose riches no one is acquainted with.
tgt_text.1564: She shall know that in us she has got no handmaids, but elder sis­ ters.
tgt_text.1565: For the present, then, let-us away to our husbands, and revisit our poor and plain dwellings, that after long and earnest consideration, we may return the better prepared to humble her pride.'“
tgt_text.1566: This wicked project was voted good by the two wicked sisters.
tgt_text.1567: Concealing those choice and sumptuous presents which they had received from Psyche, tearing their hair, and beating their faces, which well deserved such treatment, they redoubled their pretended grief.
tgt_text.1568: In this manner, too, hastily leaving their parents, after having set their sorrows bleeding afresh, they returned to their homes, swelling with malicious rage, and plotting wicked schemes, nay, actual parricide against their innocent sister."
tgt_text.1569: In the mean time, Psyche's unknown husband once more admonished her thus in their nocturnal conversation:
tgt_text.1570: ' Are you aware what a mighty peril Fortune is preparing to launch against you from a distance, one too, which, unless you take strenuous precautions against it, will ere long confront you,* hand to hand ?
tgt_text.1571: Those perfidious she-wolves are planning base stratagems against you with all their might, to the end that they may prevail upon you to view my features, which, as I have often told you, if you once see, you will see no more.
tgt_text.1572: If, then, these most abominable vampires* come again, armed with their baneful intentions, and that they will come I know full well, do not hold any converse whatever with them;
tgt_text.1573: but if, through your natural frankness and tenderness of disposition, you are not able to do this, at all events, be careful not to listen to or answer any inquiries about your husband.
tgt_text.1574: For before long we shall have an increase to our family, and infantine as you are, you are pregnant with another infant, which, if you preserve my secret in silence, will be born divine, but if you profane it, will be mortal!
tgt_text.1575: "Radiant with joy at this news, Psyche exulted in the glory of this future pledge of love, and in the dignity of a mother's name.
tgt_text.1576: Anxiously did she reckon the increasing tale of the days and the elapsing months, and wondered in simple ignorance at the structure of this unknown burden, and how her wealthy womb could have gathered such an increase from a tiny point."
tgt_text.1577: But now those pests and most dire Furies, breathing viperous virulence, were hastening towards her with the speed of ruthless hate.
tgt_text.1578: Then again her husband warned his Psyche to this effect during his brief visit:
tgt_text.1579: -, The day of trial, and this most utter calamity, are now at hand.
tgt_text.1580: Your own mali­ cious sex, and your own blood, in arms against you, have struck their camp, drawn up their forces in battle array, and sounded the charge.
tgt_text.1581: Now are your wicked sisters aiming with the drawn sword at your throat.
tgt_text.1583: darling Psyche, by what mighty dangers are we now surrounded!
tgt_text.1584: Take pity on yourself and on me;
tgt_text.1585: and by an inviolable silence, rescue your home, your husband, yourself, and that little one of ours, from this impending destruction.
tgt_text.1586: Shun those wicked women, whom, after the deadly hatred which they have con­ ceived against you, and having trampled under foot the ties of blood, it were not right to call sisters;
tgt_text.1587: neither see, nor listen to them, when, like Sirens, hanging over the crag, they shall make the rocks resound with their ill-omened voices.'"
tgt_text.1588: Psyche, in accents interrupted by sobs and tears, thus re­ plied :
tgt_text.1589: ‘Already, methinks, you have experienced convincing proofs of my fidelity and power of keeping a secret;
tgt_text.1590: and the constancy of my mind shall be no less approved of by you in the present instance.
tgt_text.1591: Only order Zephyr once again to discharge his duties, and at least grant me a sight of my sisters, by way of compensation, for your own hallowed form.
tgt_text.1592: By those aro­ matic locks, curling on every side!
tgt_text.1593: by those cheeks, tender, smooth, and so like my own!
tgt_text.1594: by your breast that- glows with I know not what a warmth!
tgt_text.1595: and by my hopes that in this babe at least I may- recognise your features, I beseech you to comply with the affectionate prayers of your anxious sup­ pliant;
tgt_text.1596: indulge me with the gratification of embracing my sisters, and refresh with joyousness the soul of Psyche, who is so devoted and so dear to you.
tgt_text.1597: Then no longer I shall be anxious to view your features.
tgt_text.1598: Henceforth, not even the shades of night will have any effect on me.
tgt_text.1599: I clasp you in my arms, and you are my light.'“
tgt_text.1600: Enchanted by these words, and by her honeyed embraces, her husband brushed away her tears with his locks, and as­ suring her that he would do as she wished, instantly anti­ cipated the light of the dawning day by flight.
tgt_text.1601: But the pair of sisters who had engaged in this conspiracy, not having so much as visited their parents, direct their course with precipi­ tate haste straight from the ships towards the rock, and not waiting for the presence of the buoyant breeze, leap into the abyss with ungovernable rashness.
tgt_text.1602: Zephyr, however, not for­ getful of the royal commands, received them, though reluc­ tantly, in the bosom of the breathing breeze, and laid them on the ground."
tgt_text.1603: With rapid steps and without a moment's delay, they entered the palace, and deceitfully screening themselves under the name of sister, embraced their prey;
tgt_text.1604: then, covering a whole store-house of deeply hidden treachery beneath a joyous countenance, they thus addressed her in flattering terms:
tgt_text.1605: 'Psyche, you are not quite so slender as you used to be.
tgt_text.1606: Why, you will be a mother before long.
tgt_text.1607: Can you fancy what delight you have in store for us in that reticule* of yours ?
tgt_text.1608: With what exceeding joy you will gladden our whole house!
tgt_text.1609: 0 how delighted we shall be to nurse this golden baby, for if it only equals the beauty of its parents, it will be born a per­ fect Cupid.'"
tgt_text.1610: Thus, by a false appearance of affection, they gradually stole upon the heart of their sister, while she, after making them sit awhile to recover from the fatigue of their journey and re­ fresh themselves with warm baths, regaled them in a marvel­ lously splendid manner with innumerable exquisite dainties.
tgt_text.1611: She bade the harp discourse, and its chords were struck;
tgt_text.1612: flutes to play, and they were heard;
tgt_text.1613: vocalists to sing in concert, and they sang;
tgt_text.1614: and though invisible, they ravished the souls of the hearers with the most delicious music."
tgt_text.1615: But the malice of those wicked women was not softened or lulled to rest even by the dulcet sweetness of the music;
tgt_text.1616: but, shaping their conversation so as to lead Psyche into the in­ tended snare, they began insidiously to inquire what sort of a person her husband was, and from what family he was descended.
tgt_text.1617: She, in her extreme simplicity, having forgotten her former account, invented a new story about her husband, and said he was a native of the adjoining province;
tgt_text.1618: that he was a merchant, with abundance of money, a man of middle age, with a few grey hairs sprinkled here and there on his head.
tgt_text.1619: Then, abruptly terminating the conversation, she again committed them to their windy vehicle, after having loaded them with costly presents.
tgt_text.1620: “While they were returning home wards, soaring aloft on the tranquil breath of Zephyrus, they thus interchanged their thoughts with each other:
tgt_text.1621: ‘ What are we to say, sister, of the monstrous lies of that silly creature ?
tgt_text.1622: At one time her hus­ band is a young man, with the down just beginning to show itself on his chin;
tgt_text.1623: at another he is of middle age, and his hair begins to be silvered with grey.
tgt_text.1625: this be, whom a short space of time thus suddenly changes into an old man ?
tgt_text.1626: You may depend upon it, sister, that this most abominable woman has either invented this lie to deceive us, or else that she does not herself know what is the appearance of her hus­ band.
tgt_text.1627: But whichever of these is the case, she must as soon as possible be deprived of these riches.
tgt_text.1628: And yet, if she really is ignorant of the appearance of her husband, she must no doubt have married a god, and then through this pregnancy of hers.

tgt_text.1633: The sisters, thus inflamed with passion, called on their parents in a careless and disdainful manner, and after being kept awake all night by the turbulence of their spirits, made all haste at morning to the rock, whence, by the usual assist­ ance of the breeze, they descended swiftly to Psyche, and with tears squeezed out, by rubbing their eyelids, thus craftily ad­ dressed her:
tgt_text.1634: ‘ Happy indeed are you, and fortunate in your very ignorance of a misfortune of such magnitude.
tgt_text.1635: There you sit, without a thought upon your danger;
tgt_text.1636: while we, who watch over your interests with the most vigilant care, are in anguish at your lost condition.
tgt_text.1637: For we have learned for a truth, nor can we, as being sharers in your sorrows and misfortunes, conceal it from you, that it is an enormous serpent, gliding along in many folds and coils, with a neck swollen with deadly venom, and prodigious gaping jaws, that secretly sleeps with you by night.
tgt_text.1638: Do for a moment recall to mind the Pythian oracle, which declared that you were destined to be­ come the wife of a fierce and truculent animal.
tgt_text.1639: Besides, many of the husbandmen, who are in the habit of hunting all round the country, and ever so many of the neighbours, have observed him returning home from his feeding-place in the evening, and swimming across the shoals of the neighbouring stream.
tgt_text.1640: All declare, too, that he will not long continue to pamper you with delicacies, but that as soon as ever your pregnancy shall have arrived at maturity, he will devour you, as being in that state a most exquisite morsel.
tgt_text.1641: Wherefore, it is now for you to consider whether you shall think fit to listen to us, who are so anxious for your precious safety, and avoiding death, live with us secure from danger, or be buried in the entrails of a most savage monster.
tgt_text.1642: But if you are fascinated by the vocal solitude of this country retreat, or the charms of clandestine embraces so filthy and perilous, and the endearments of a poisonous ser­ pent, we have, at all events, done our duty towards you like affectionate sisters.'"
tgt_text.1643: Poor simple, tender-hearted Psyche, was aghast with norror at this dreadful story;
tgt_text.1644: and, quite bereft of her senses, lost all remembrance of her husband's admonitions and of her own promises, and hurled herself headlong into the very abyss of calamity.
tgt_text.1645: Trembling, therefore, with pale and livid cheeks, and with an almost lifeless voice, she faltered out these broken words:
tgt_text.1646: " ' Dearest sisters, you have acted towards me as you ought, and with your usual affectionate care;
tgt_text.1647: and indeed it appears to me that those who gave you this information, have not in­ vented a falsehood.
tgt_text.1648: For, in fact, I have never yet beheld my husband's face, nor do I know at all whence he comes.
tgt_text.1649: I only hear him speak in an undertone by night, and have to bear with a husband of an unknown appearance, and one that has an utter aversion to the light of day:
tgt_text.1650: I consequently have full reason to be of your opinion, that he may be some monster or other.
tgt_text.1651: Besides, he is always terrifying me from attempting to behold him, and threatens some shocking misfortune as the consequence of indulging any curiosity to view his features.
tgt_text.1652: Now, therefore, if you are able to give any saving aid to your sister in this perilous emergency, defer it not for a moment:
tgt_text.1654: Finding the approaches thus laid open, and their sister's heart exposed all naked to their attacks, these wicked women thought the time was come to sally out from their covered ap­ proach, and attack the timorous thoughts of the simple girl with the drawn sword of deceit.
tgt_text.1655: Accordingly, one of them thus be­ gan :
tgt_text.1657: Since the ties of blood oblige us to have no fear of peril before our eyes when your safety is to be ensured, we will dis­ cover to you the only method which will lead to your preserva­ tion, and one which has been considered by us over and over again.
tgt_text.1658: On that side of the bed where you are accustomed to lie, secretly conceal a very sharp razor, one that you have whetted to a keen edge by passing it over the palm of your hand;
tgt_text.1659: and hide likewise under some covering of the surrounding tapestry* a lamp, well trimmed and full of oil, and shining with a bright light.
tgt_text.1660: Make these preparations with the utmost secrecy, and after the monster has glided into the bed as usual, when he is now stretched out at length, fast asleep, and breathing heavily, then slide out of bed, go softly along with bare feet and on tiptoe, free the lamp from its place of concealment in the dark, and borrow the aid of its light to execute your noble purpose;
tgt_text.1661: then at once, boldly raising your right hand, bring down the keen weapon with all your might, and cut off the head of the noxious serpent at the nape of the neck.
tgt_text.1662: Nor shall our assist­ ance be wanting to you;
tgt_text.1663: for we will keep anxious watch, and be with you the very instant you shall have effected your own safety by his death;
tgt_text.1664: and then, immediately bringing you away with all these things, we will wed you, to your wish, with a human creature like yourself."
tgt_text.1665: Having with such pernicious language inflamed the mind of their sister, and wrought her to a perfect pitch of determi­ nation, they deserted her, fearing exceedingly even to be in the neighbourhood of such a catastrophe;
tgt_text.1666: and, being laid upon the rock by the wonted impulse of their winged bearer, they im­ mediately hurried thence witli impetuous haste, at once got on board their ships, and sailed away.

tgt_text.1699: Her divine lover, however, not deserting her as she lay on the ground, alighted upon a neighbouring cypress tree, and thus angrily addressed her from its lofty top:
tgt_text.1700: —‘ 0 simple, simple Psyche, for you I have been unmindful of the commands of my mother Venus;
tgt_text.1701: for when she bade me cause you to be infatuated with passion for some base and abject man, I chose rather to fly to you myself as a lover.
tgt_text.1702: That in this I acted inconsiderately, I know but too well.
tgt_text.1703: I, that redoubtable archer, have wounded myself with my own arrow, and have made you my wife, that I, forsooth, might be thought by you to be a serpent, and that you might cut off my head, which bears those very eyes which have so doated upon you.
tgt_text.1704: This was the danger that I told you again and again to be on your guard against, this was what I so benevolently forewarned you of.

tgt_text.1709: Meanwhile Psyche lay prostrate on the ground, gazing on the flight of her husband as long as ever he remained in sight, and afflicting her mind with the most bitter lamentations.
tgt_text.1710: But when the reiterated movement* of his wings had borne her husband through the immensity of space till she saw him no more, she threw herself headlong from the bank of the adjacent river into its stream.
tgt_text.1711: But the gentle river, honouring the God, who is in the habit of imparting his warmth to the waters t themselves, and fearing his power, bore her on the surface of a harmless wave to the bank, and laid her safe on its flowery turf."
tgt_text.1712: It chanced that just then the rural god Pan was seated on the margin of the river, embracing the goddess Canna,J and teaching her to sing all kinds of pleasant ditties.
tgt_text.1713: Close by, some she-goats gambolled as they browsed along the grassy bank.
tgt_text.1714: The goat-legged god, aware of Pysche's misfortune, kindly called the fainting, heart-stricken girl to him, and thus comforted her in soothing language:
tgt_text.1715: —‘ Pretty damsel, though I am a countryman and a shepherd, still, through the benefit of a prolonged old age, I have acquired considerable experience;

tgt_text.1939: 'You appear to me to be a pro­ found and malevolent sorceress, or you never could with so much dexterity have performed my commands :

tgt_text.1943: for she has consumed all the beauty she possessed, through the attention which she pays to her sick son.
tgt_text.1944: But return with the utmost expedition ;
tgt_text.1945: for I must adorn myself with this beauty of Proserpine, before I go . to the theatre of the gods.'"
tgt_text.1946: Psyche was now truly sensible that she was arrived at the extremity of her evil fortune;
tgt_text.1947: and clearly perceived that she was openly and undisguisedly impelled to immediate destruc­ tion, since she was forced to direct her steps to Tartarus and the shades below.
tgt_text.1948: Without any further delay, therefore, she proceeded towards a lofty tower, that she might thence hurl herself headlong;
tgt_text.1949: for she considered that she should thus descend by a straight and easy road to the infernal regions.
tgt_text.1950: But she was no sooner arrived there, than the tower suddenly addressed her in the following words:
tgt_text.1952: Why, 0 miserable creature, dost thou seek to destroy thy­ self by falling headlong hence ?
tgt_text.1953: And why dost thou" rashly sink under this thy last danger and endurance ?
tgt_text.1954: For as soon as thy breath shall thus be separated from thy body, thou wilt indeed descend to profound Tartarus, but canst not by any means return thence.
tgt_text.1956: Lacedæmon, a noble city of Achaia, is not far from hence.
tgt_text.1957: Near this city, concealed in devious places, is Tenarus, which you must seek;
tgt_text.1958: for there you will find a cavity, which is Pluto's breathing hole, and an untraversed road presents itself to the view through the yawning gap.
tgt_text.1959: As soon as you have passed the threshold of this cavity, you will proceed in a direct path to the palace of Pluto.
tgt_text.1960: You ought not, however, to pass through those shades with empty hands, but should take a sop of barley bread, soaked in hydromel, in each hand, and in your mouth two pieces of money.
tgt_text.1961: And when you have accomplished a good part of your deadly journey, you will meet a lame ass laden with wood, with a driver as lame as himself, who will ask you to reach him certain cords to fasten the bur­ den which has fallen from the ass:
tgt_text.1962: but be careful that you pass by him in silence.
tgt_text.1963: Then, without any delay, proceed till you arrive at the dead river, where Charon, immediately de­ manding his fee, ferries the passengers over in his patched boat to the farthest shore." , Avarice, it appears, lives among the dead ;

tgt_text.2040: And now the robbers returned laden with booty, having apparently fought a severe battle.
tgt_text.2041: Nevertheless, some of the more active spirits among them leaving the wounded at home to be cured, proposed to go and bring away the other bundles of plunder, which, as they said, they had concealed in a certain cave.
tgt_text.2042: So having hastily devoured their dinner, they turned me and my horse into the road, intending to load us with those bundles;
tgt_text.2043: and striking us with staves, they marched us over many ups and downs, and through many windings, until we arrived, towards evening, very weary, at a certain cavern, from whence they quickly brought us back, heavily loaded, without having allowed us a moment's rest.
tgt_text.2044: Such was their haste and trepidation, that they drove me by their blows against a stone which lay in the road, and caused me to fall down;
tgt_text.2045: and then the blows fell thicker and faster to compel me to rise, which I could hardly do being severely hurt in my off leg and near hoof.

tgt_text.2048: "Decidedly," said a third, " as soon as he has brought home this burden, which he carries so unwillingly, I will immediately hurl him down a precipice as dainty food for vultures.
tgt_text.2049: "While those mildest of men were debating with each other about the death I was to die, we had now reached our home ;

tgt_text.2052: Meanwhile, I was made not a little uneasy by thoughts of the death with which I was threatened;
tgt_text.2054: " Why do you stand still, Lucius ?
tgt_text.2055: Why do you tamely await the last calamity that can befall you ?
tgt_text.2056: Death, and that of the most cruel kind, is decreed for you by the robbers, nor is the execution of the sentence a thing to cause them any great diffi­ culty.
tgt_text.2057: You see those neighbouring precipices, and those sharp rocks projecting from their sides, which, fall wherever you may, will penetrate your body and tear you limb from limb.
tgt_text.2058: For that illustrious magic you were so fond of has given you only the form and the labours of an ass, but has invested you not with the thick hide of that animal, but with the deli­ cate skin of a horse-leech.
tgt_text.2059: Why do you not, therefore, assume a masculine spirit, and consult your safety while yet you may ?
tgt_text.2060: You have an excellent opportunity for flight while the robbers are away.

tgt_text.2065: And with that I made a strong effort, broke the thong by which I was tied, and was off as fast as my four legs could carry me.

tgt_text.2067: for, as soon as she saw me free, she laid hold of the thong, with a boldness above her sex and age, and strove to lead me back again.
tgt_text.2068: I, however, bearing in mind the deadly purpose of the robbers, was moved by no pity, but immedi­ ately knocked her down with a stroke of my hind feet.

tgt_text.2071: but all the noise she made was of no use ;
tgt_text.2072: for there was no one but the captive virgin that could afford her aid;
tgt_text.2073: and she, startled by the uproar, ran out of the cave, and saw, by Hercules, a most remarkable scene, the old woman, like another Dirce, only hanging not to a bull, but to an ass.*
tgt_text.2074: Then did the virgin, with virile daring, perform an admirable exploit.
tgt_text.2075: For, wrest­ ing the thong from the hands of the old woman, she checked my speed with bland words, mounted cleverly on my back, and again incited me to hasten away.
tgt_text.2076: Besides my own spon­ taneous desire to escape, I was now impelled by a wish to liberate the virgin, and further urged by the blows with which she frequently admonished me;
tgt_text.2077: so that my four feet beat the ground at the rate of a courser's gallop;
tgt_text.2078: and all the while I endeavoured to reply by my braying to the sweet words of the virgin.
tgt_text.2079: Sometimes, also, turning my neck, and pretending to scratch my back, I kissed her beautiful feet.
tgt_text.2080: At last, sighing deeply, and looking anxiously to heaven, "0 ye Gods," she said, " give me your aid, now or never, in my extreme danger;

tgt_text.2084: In the first place, I will comb that mane of yours nicely, and adorn it with my virgin hands;

tgt_text.2124: And now, while they were devouring everything with greedy voracity, they began to discuss the question of our punishment, and their own revenge, and the opinions expressed on the subject were various, as is usually the case in a turbulent crowd.
tgt_text.2125: One proposed that the virgin should be burnt alive;
tgt_text.2126: a second was for exposing her to wild beasts;

tgt_text.2149: On hearing their decision with my long cars, what could I do but bewail my poor body that was to be a dead carcase next morning ?
tgt_text.2150: As soon as darkness gave place to the fair light of day, and all things were illuminated by the splendid chariot of the sun, a certain person, one of the robbers' comrades, arrived;
tgt_text.2151: for so he appeared to be, by their mutual salutations.
tgt_text.2152: This man sat down at the entrance of the cavern, and after he had reco­ vered his breath, and was able to speak, he made the following narration to his companions :
tgt_text.2154: With respect to the house of Milo, of Hypata, which we lately plundered, we may now be quite at our ease, and fear nothing.
tgt_text.2155: For after you, brave men, had returned to our cave, carrying off with you all Milo's property, I mingled with the crowd of the citizens, and assuming the appearance of one who was grieved and indignant at what had happened, observed what course was taken for an investigation of the affair, and whether, and to what extent, they would inquire after the robbers;
tgt_text.2156: in order that I might relate to you every particular, conformably to your injunctions.
tgt_text.2157: Now one Lucius, whoever he may be, was accused, by the unanimous voice of all the mul­ titude, as the manifest author of the robbery, and this not upon dubious surmises, but upon convincing evidence.
tgt_text.2158: This Lucius, not long before, by false commendatory letters, passing himself off for a respectable man, strongly ingratiated himself with Milo, so that he was hospitably received by him, and ranked among his intimate friends.
tgt_text.2159: And when he had remained there not a few days, having ensnared the mind of a maid servant of Milo with false love, he diligently explored the bolts and bars of the house, and curiously surveyed those parts of it in which all the property was usually deposited.
tgt_text.2160: This, also, was con­ sidered as no small indication of his guilt, that he fled on the very same night, and at the very moment the robbery was committed, and has not been heard of since.
tgt_text.2161: He had ready means of flight too, whereby he could rapidly elude his pur­ suers, and get farther and farther away from their search;
tgt_text.2162: for he rode away on his own white horse.
tgt_text.2163: Moreover, his servant was found in the same house, and, being accused as accessary to the felony and escape of his master, was, by order of the magis­ trates, committed to the common gaol, and subjected on the fol­ lowing day to many torments.
tgt_text.2164: But though tortured till he was almost dead, he confessed, after all, nothing of the kind.
tgt_text.2165: Nevertheless, many persons were sent to the country of tha' Lucius in search of him, in order that he might undergo the punishment of his crime.
tgt_text.2166: "While he was narrating these things, my vitals were wrung with grief at the comparison they suggested between my an­ cient fortune and my present calamity, between that once happy Lucius and a miserable jackass.
tgt_text.2167: It also occurred to me, that not without reason had ancient sages pronounced Fortune to be blind, and entirely deprived of eyes;
tgt_text.2168: since she always bestows her riches on the unworthy and the wicked, and never judiciously makes any mortal the object of her regard;
tgt_text.2169: but indeed attaches herself for the most part to men from whom, if she could see, she ought to By far away.
tgt_text.2170: And what is worst of all, she causes opinions to be entertained of us that are at variance with our real character, or even contrary to it;
tgt_text.2171: so as to enable the bad man to exult in the renown of the good man, and, on the other hand, to cause the most innocent to suffer such punishment as befits the most guilty.
tgt_text.2172: Here, methought, am I, to whom she has done her worst in changing me into a beast, and a quadruped of the vilest condition, I, whose mis­ fortune would strike the most hardened reprobate as worthy to be lamented and commiserated, I am here accused of the crime of burglary, committed upon my most dear host;
tgt_text.2173: a crime for which burglary is too mild a name, and which one may more rightly denominate parricide.
tgt_text.2174: Yet I was not permitted to defend myself, or to utter so much as one word in denial of the charge.
tgt_text.2175: Now, however, when it was made in my presence, lest my silence should be mistaken for the acquiescence of a guilty conscience, I was racked with impatience to speak, were it only to say, Non feci, I did not do that deed.
tgt_text.2176: The former word, indeed, [non] I roared out again and again, but the other [feci]
tgt_text.2177: I could by no means pronounce, but I continued to vociferate non non ;
tgt_text.2178: and no more could I get out, though I made my pendulous lips vibrate with excessive rotundity.
tgt_text.2179: Why, however, do I prolixly complain of the spitefulness of Fortune, since she was not ashamed to make me a fellow- servant and yoke-mate with my own horse.
tgt_text.2180: While these thoughts were floating through my mind, a concern of a more important nature engaged my attention, viz., the recollection that I was destined by the decree of the robbers to be a victim to the manes of the virgin;
tgt_text.2181: and frequently casting a look at my belly, I seemed to myself to have the unhappy damsel enclosed within it.
tgt_text.2182: The robber who had just brought t he news of that false accusation against me, having drawn out a thousand pieces of gold coin, which he had sewn up and concealed in his garment, and which he had taken, as he said, from different travellers, and had conscientiously brought to the common treasury, began to inquire anxiously concerning the welfare of his comrades.
tgt_text.2183: Finding that some of them, and indeed all the bravest, had perished by various deaths, but all with great gallantry, he advised them to leave the highways at peace for some time, and rather apply themselves to searching after other associates, and to supplying the deficiency of their warlike band by the election of new hands from among the youths of the country.
tgt_text.2184: For, he observed, those that were unwilling might be com­ pelled by fear, and the willing be incited by reward;
tgt_text.2185: and not a few would gladly abandon an abject and servile life, and unite themselves to an association which possessed a power like that of royalty.
tgt_text.2186: For his own part, he had some time since met with a certain man of a lofty stature, young, of vast bodily dimensions, and of great strength;
tgt_text.2187: and after much ar­ gument had at length persuaded him to make better use of his hands, which had become torpid through long idleness;
tgt_text.2188: to enjoy while he might the advantages of a prosperous condition of body;
tgt_text.2189: and instead of holding out his powerful hand for alms, to exert it rather in helping himself to gold.
tgt_text.2190: All present assented to what he said, and decreed to receive the man he had spoken of, as he Appeared to be a tried man, and also to search after others who might supply the places of those they had lost.
tgt_text.2191: He went out, and returning shortly after, brought with him, as he had promised, a certain tall young man, with whom I do not think any one present could have stood a comparison;
tgt_text.2192: for, besides the great bulk of his body, he surpassed all the rest in height by a whole head, and yet the down had but just begun to overspread'his cheeks.
tgt_text.2193: He was only half clothed, with odds and ends of cloth, cobbled together, through the joinings of which his brawny breast and belly seemed ready to burst forth.
tgt_text.2194: Thus entering, " All hail," said he, " ye, who are under the protection of the most powerful God Mars, and who are now become my trusty comrades;
tgt_text.2195: receive willingly a willing recruit, a man of magnanimous spirit, who more cheerfully receives wounds in his body than gold in his hand, and who despises death, which others dread.
tgt_text.2196: And think not that I am a needy or abject man, nor judge of my merits from these rags;
tgt_text.2197: for I have been the leader of a most powerful band, and have, in fact, plundered all Macedonia.
tgt_text.2198: I am that famous robber Hæmus the Thracian, whose name whole provinces dread;
tgt_text.2199: and am the offspring of There, who was an equally illustrious robber;
tgt_text.2201: educated among bands of men of this description, and the heir and imitator of my father's valour.
tgt_text.2202: But I lost in a short space of time all my old band, all my brave comrades, and, all the great wealth we had amassed.
tgt_text.2203: For passing by Oratum,* I attacked one of Caesar's commissaries, who had been high in office, but was afterwards deprived of his employment through the malignity of fortune.
tgt_text.2204: I will, however, relate the whole affair in order that you may understand it the better."
tgt_text.2205: There was a certain person honourably distinguished by the many offices he held in the palace of Caesar, and who was also well esteemed by Cæsar himself.
tgt_text.2206: Malignant envy, and the crafty accusations of certain persons, hurled him into exile.
tgt_text.2207: But his wife, Plotina, a woman of rare fidelity and singular chastity, who had given stability to the family of her husband by the birth of ten children, spurned and despised the plea­ sures of city luxury, and became the companion of her husband's flight, and a partaker of his misfortune.
tgt_text.2208: For this purpose she cut off her hair, changed her dress, so that she might appear like a man;
tgt_text.2209: and begirt with necklaces of the greatest value and with zones of gold coin, she moved intre­ pidly amidst the drawn swords of the soldiers that guarded her husband, a partaker of all his dangers, maintaining an ever- wakeful care for his safety, and enduring continual labours with the fortitude of a man.
tgt_text.2210: And now having vanquished the greater part of the difficulties of the journey, and the dangers of the sea, she went with her husband to Zacynthus, † which their fatal destiny had decreed to be their temporary habita­ tion.
tgt_text.2211: As soon, however, as they had arrived on the shores of Actium, where we were then roving about on our return from Macedonia, they went late at night to a certain cottage which was near the shore and their ship, and there they slept in order to avoid the tossing of the sea.
tgt_text.2212: In this cottage we attacked and plundered them of every thing.
tgt_text.2213: Yet we did not depart without great danger.
tgt_text.2214: For as soon as the mistress of the house heard the first noise of the gate, she ran into the bedchamber, and disturbed all that were in the house by her tumultuous clamours.
tgt_text.2215: She likewise called on her servants by name, and on all her neighbours;
tgt_text.2216: but it so happened that we escaped with impunity through the general fear, each conceal­ ing himself out of regard to his own safety."
tgt_text.2217: This excellent woman, however, (for the truth must be spoken), who was a pattern of fidelity and was beloved for her virtues, immediately pouring forth her prayers to the majesty of Cæsar, obtained both a speedy return for her husband, and a complete revenge of the assault.
tgt_text.2218: In short, Cæsar was un­ willing that the band of the robber Hæmus should any longer exist, and it was forthwith immediately destroyed.
tgt_text.2219: So much can the mere wish of a great prince effect.
tgt_text.2220: At length, when, by the pertinacious pursuit of the emperor's army, all our band was destroyed, I scarcely saved myself, and escaped from the midst of the jaws of hell, after the following manner.
tgt_text.2221: I clothed myself in the florid vestment of a woman, with nume­ rous flowing folds, covered my head with a small woven mitre, and put on my feet those white and thin shoes which are worn by women;
tgt_text.2222: and thus, as it were, implanted and concealed in the other sex, I passed through the midst of the troops of hostile soldiers, riding on an ass laden with sheaves of barley.
tgt_text.2223: For, believing me to be a female ass-driver, they let me pass free;
tgt_text.2224: because at that time my beardless cheeks were still soft and smooth as a boy's.
tgt_text.2225: Yet I have not degenerated from my paternal glory, or forgotten my fortitude, though somewhat fearful in consequence of being placed in the midst of martial blades ;
tgt_text.2226: but protected by the disguise of a dress foreign to my sex, and attacking villas or towns, single handed, I have pro- sured for myself this small viaticum by plunder."
tgt_text.2228: Ripping open his rags as he spoke, he poured forth into the midst of them two thousand pieces of gold coin.
tgt_text.2229: "There," said he, "I willingly offer to your band this contribution, and myself also (if you do not reject my offer), as a most faithful leader, who, in a short space of time, will make this your habitation to be no longer rocky, but golden."
tgt_text.2230: The rob­ bers, without hesitation, unanimously elected him their leader.
tgt_text.2231: They also brought forth a tolerably fair garment, which he put on, throwing away his rich rags.
tgt_text.2232: And having thus changed his attire, and embraced each of them, he was placed on the couch at the head of the table, and his leadership was inaugu­ rated by a supper, and copious bowls.
tgt_text.2233: In the conversation that ensued, the robber was made aware of the flight of the damsel, of my carrying her, and of the monstrous death to which each of us was destined.
tgt_text.2234: He asked where the virgin was, and being taken to her, and seeing her laden with chains, he turned away from her, with a contemp­ tuous curl of his nose, and said :
tgt_text.2235: "I am not indeed so stupid, or at least so rash, as to oppose your decree;
tgt_text.2236: but I should have to endure the reproaches of my own conscience, if I dissembled what appears to me to be for your benefit.
tgt_text.2237: But, in the first place, suffer me, who am solicitous for your sake, to speak boldly, especially since, if my views are not acceptable to you, you may fall back on what you have decreed concerning the virgin and the ass.
tgt_text.2238: Now, I think that those robbers who are truly wise ought to prefer nothing to their own gain, not even vengeance itself, which is often detrimental to those who inflict it as well as to others.
tgt_text.2239: If, then, you destroy the virgin in the body of the ass, you will gratify nothing but your indig­ nation, without any profit to yourselves.
tgt_text.2240: It is my opinion that she should rather be taken to some city, and there sold;
tgt_text.2241: for a virgin of her age may be sold for no small price.
tgt_text.2242: I myself, some time ago, knew certain bawds, one of whom might, as I think, give a great sum of money for this virgin, and place her in a brothel, suitable to her birth, and from which she will not be likely to run away again.
tgt_text.2243: She will also have afforded you some revenge, when she has passed into bondage at a brothel.
tgt_text.2244: I have sincerely offered this counsel to you, as conducive to your advantage ;
tgt_text.2245: but you are the masters of your own judg­ ments and acts."
tgt_text.2246: Thus it was that this advocate of the rob­ bers' exchequer, and no less excellent saviour of the virgin and ass, pleaded our cause.
tgt_text.2247: The rest of the robbers, after tormenting my entrails and my miserable spirit by their tedious deliberations, at length cor­ dially acceded to the opinion of the new robber, and immedi­ ately freed the virgin from her bonds.
tgt_text.2248: But as for her, from the moment she beheld that young man, and heard him men­ tion a brothel and a bawd, she began to be elated, and to smile most joyfully, so that I felt inclined, with good reason, to vitu­ perate the whole sex, when I saw a virgin, who pretended that she was enamoured of a young lover, and was desirous of a chaste marriage, now suddenly delighted with the name of a vile and filthy brothel.
tgt_text.2249: It was a case in which the character of the whole female sex was in question, and the verdict de­ pended on the judgment of an ass.
tgt_text.2250: The young man, how­ ever, resuming his discourse, said :
tgt_text.2252: Why do we not proceed to supplicate Mars to be propitious to us in selling the virgin, and searching for other associates ?
tgt_text.2253: But, as far as I see, we have not any beast for sacrifice, nor sufficient wine for drink­ ing largely.
tgt_text.2254: Send with me, therefore, ten of our comrades, with whom I may go to the next town, and bring you thence meat and drink fit for priests."
tgt_text.2255: Accordingly, he departed, attended by ten of the robbers, and the rest prepared a great fire, and raised an altar of green turf to the god Mars.
tgt_text.2256: The foragers soon returned, bringing with them skins full of wine, and driving before them a great number of cattle;
tgt_text.2257: from among which they selected a large he-goat, old and shaggy, and sacrificed it to Mars the Secutor* and Associate.
tgt_text.2258: A sumptuous supper was immediately prepared.
tgt_text.2260: "You must consider me as a strenuous leader not only of your plundering expeditions, but also of your pleasures."
tgt_text.2261: And with that he went cleverly to work, and performed every thing that was requisite with admirable dexterity.
tgt_text.2262: He swept the floor, made the couches smooth, cooked the meat, seasoned the dishes, and served them up handsomely;
tgt_text.2263: but especially he plied each of them, and that frequently, with large bowls of wine.
tgt_text.2264: Nevertheless, under pretence of fetching what he wanted from time to time, he often went to the virgin, and gaily presented her with fragments which he had se­ cretly taken away, and cups of wine, of which he had pre­ viously tasted.
tgt_text.2265: And she most willingly received what he brought her, and sometimes, when he wished to kiss her, she readily responded to his wish, and kissed him.
tgt_text.2269: Shame upon you, girl, do you forget your faithful lover and your nuptials ?
tgt_text.2270: Do you prefer this foreign and cruel homicide to that young man, whoever he be, to whom your parents have betrothed you ?
tgt_text.2271: Does not your conscience prick you, that you thus trample on affection, and are pleased to act libidinously among gleaming spears and swords ?
tgt_text.2272: What if the other rob­ bers, likewise, should, by some means or other, perceive what you are doing, would you not again return to the ass, and again procure my destruction?
tgt_text.2273: Really you are playing your game at the risk of another's skin.
tgt_text.2274: Whilst I was thus cogitating in great indignation, and falsely accusing the virgin in my own mind, I gathered from certain words of theirs, which though dubious, were not obscure to an intelligent ass, that the young man was not the famous robber Hsemus, but Tlepolemus, the bridegroom of the virgin.
tgt_text.2275: For, in the course of their conference, caring nothing for my pre­ sence, he said somewhat more distinctly:
tgt_text.2276: " Be of good cheer, dearost Charite;
tgt_text.2277: for you shall presently have all these your enemies in captivity."
tgt_text.2278: And I observed that while he himself refrained from drinking immoderately, he never ceased to ply the robbers more and more with wine, now unmingled with water, and moderately heated, so that they began to be over­ come with intoxication.
tgt_text.2279: And, by Hercules, I suspect that he had mingled in their cups a certain soporiferous drug.
tgt_text.2280: At last, when they all, without a single exception, lay dead drunk on the floor, then Tlepolemus, having without any difficulty bound them strongly with ropes, and tied them together as he thought proper, placed the damsel on my back, and directed his steps to his own home.
tgt_text.2281: As soon as we arrived there, the whole city turned out at the wished-for sight.
tgt_text.2282: Parents, kindred, retainers, bondmen, and servants, joyfully ran out to meet us.
tgt_text.2283: You might see a procession of every age and sex, and, by Hercules, a new and memorable spectacle, a virgin riding in triumph on an ass.*
tgt_text.2284: As for myself, rejoicing with all my might, and not choosing to be at variance with the present display, as if I had no concern in it, I brayed strenuously, with erect ears and expanded nos­ trils, or rather, I trumpeted with a noise like thunder.
tgt_text.2285: The damsel having now retired to her chamber, where her parents cherished and caressed her, Tlepolemus immediately took me back to the cave, accompanied by a great number of beasts of burden, and a multitude of his fellow-citizens.
tgt_text.2287: for, curious at all times, I was then particularly desirous to be a spectator of the captivity of the robbers, whom we found still fast bound, with wine even more than with ropes.
tgt_text.2288: Having, therefore, ransacked the cave, and brought out every thing that was in it, and we, and all the rest being loaded with gold and silver, Tlepolemus and his at­ tendants rolled some of the robbers, bound as they were, over the neighbouring cliffs, and others they beheaded with their own swords.
tgt_text.2289: Then we returned to the city, exulting and re­ joicing in so complete a revenge.
tgt_text.2290: The robbers' wealth was deposited in the public treasury;
tgt_text.2291: but the damsel, who had been recovered by Tlepolemus, was given to him according to law.
tgt_text.2292: Then that noble woman paid the greatest attention to me, whom she called her saviour;
tgt_text.2293: and, on the very day of her nuptials, ordered my manger to be completely filled with bar­ ley, and as much hay to be given me as would be enough for a Bactrian eamel.
tgt_text.2294: But what sufficiently dire execrations could I imprecate on Fotis, who had transformed me not into a dog, but an ass, when I saw all the dogs stuffed and crammed with the relics of the most abundant supper, and with the food they had pillaged ?
tgt_text.2295: After the first night, the bride did not cease to tell her parents and her husband how greatly she was in­ debted to me, till they promised that they would confer on me the- highest honours.
tgt_text.2296: Convoking, therefore, their most inti­ mate friends, they held a consultation as to how I might most worthily be rewarded.
tgt_text.2297: One was of opinion that I should be shut up in the house, and there, leading an idle life, be fattened with choice barley, beans, and vetches.
tgt_text.2298: But the opinion of another prevailed, who regarded my liberty, and persuaded them rather to give me the run of the plains and meadows, where I might take ray pleasure among the herds of horses, and procreate many mules, for the masters of the mares.
tgt_text.2299: The keeper of the horses was accordingly summoned, and I was delivered over to him, with many injunctions that he should take care of me.
tgt_text.2300: And right gaily did I trot along by his side, rejoicing at the thought that I was now to have nothing more to do with packs and bags, and so forth, and that having obtained my liberty, I should doubtless find some roses in the meadows, when they began to blossom in spring.
tgt_text.2301: Frequently, too, it occurred to me, that since such great marks of gratitude and so many honours were conferred on me when but an ass, so much the greater would be the re­ spect and favour shown me when I had recovered the human form.
tgt_text.2302: But when the keeper of the horses had taken me to the country, I found there none of the pleasure or the liberty I ex­ pected.
tgt_text.2303: For his wife, an avaricious, bad woman, immediately yoked me to the mill, and frequently striking me with a green stick, prepared bread for herself and her family at the expense of my hide.
tgt_text.2304: And not content to make me drudge for her own food only, she also ground corn for her neighbours, and so made money by my toil.
tgt_text.2305: Nor, after all my weary labours, did she even afford me the food which had been ordered for me;
tgt_text.2306: for she sold my barley to the neighouring husbandmen, after it had been bruised and ground in that very mill, by ray own round­ about drudgery;
tgt_text.2307: but to me, who had worked during the whole of the day at that laborious machine, she only gave, towards evening, some dirty, unsifted, and very gritty bran.
tgt_text.2308: I was brought low enough by these miseries ;
tgt_text.2309: but cruel Fortune ex­ posed me to fresh torments, in order, I suppose, that I might boast of my brave deeds, both in peace and war, as the saying is.
tgt_text.2310: For that excellent equerry, complying, rather late, indeed, with his master's orders, for a short time permitted me to as­ sociate with the herds of horses.
tgt_text.2311: At length a free ass, I capered for joy, and softly ambling up to the mares, chose out such as I thought would be the fittest for my concubines.
tgt_text.2312: But here my joyful hopes gave place to extreme danger.
tgt_text.2313: For the stallions, who had been fed high for the sake of copulating with the mares, and who, independently of this, were terribly strong creatures, more than a match for any ass, regarding me with suspicion, and anxious to preserve the purity of their race, furiously pursued me as their rival, without respect for the laws of hospitable Jupiter.
tgt_text.2314: One of them, with his head and neck and ample chest aloft, struck at me like a pugilist with his forefeet;
tgt_text.2315: another, turning his brawny back, let fly at me with his hind feet;
tgt_text.2316: and another, with a vicious neigh, his ears thrown back, and showing his white teeth, sharp as spears, bit me all over.
tgt_text.2317: It was like what I have read in history of the King of Thrace,* who exposed his unhappy guests to be lacerated and devoured by wild horses.
tgt_text.2318: For so sparing was that power­ ful tyrant of his barley, that he appeased the hunger of his voracious horses by casting human bodies to them for food.
tgt_text.2319: In fact, I was so worried and distracted by the continual attacks of the horses, that I wished myself bark again at the mill round.
tgt_text.2320: Fortune, however, who could not be satiated with my tor­ ments, 'soon after visited me with another calamity.
tgt_text.2321: For I was employed to bring home wood from a mountain, and a boy, the most villanous of all boys, was appointed to drive me.
tgt_text.2322: It was not only that I was wearied by toiling up and down the steep and lofty mountain, nor that I wore away my hoofs by running on sharp stones, but I was cudgelled without end, so that all my bones ached to the very marrow.
tgt_text.2323: More­ over, by continually striking me on the off-haunch, and always in the same place, till the skin was broken, he occa­ sioned a great ulcerous cavity, gaping like a trench or a window;
tgt_text.2324: yet he never ceased to hit me on the raw.
tgt_text.2325: He likewise laid such a load of wood on my back, that you might have thought it was a burden prepared for an elephant, and not for a jackass.
tgt_text.2326: And whenever the ill-balanced load inclined to one side, instead of taking away some of the faggots from the heavier side, and thus easing me by somewhat lightening, or at least equalizing the pressure, he always remedied the inequality of the weight by the addition of stones.
tgt_text.2327: Nor yet, after so many miseries which I had endured, was he content with the immoderate weight of my burden;
tgt_text.2328: but when it happened that we had to pass over a river, he would leap on my back in order to keep his feet dry, as if his weight was but a trifling addition to the heavy mass.
tgt_text.2329: And if by any acci­ dent I happened to fall, through the weight of my burden, and the slipperiness of the muddy bank, instead of giving me a helping hand as he ought to have done, and pulling me up by the headstall, or by my tail, or removing a part of my load, till at least I had got up again;
tgt_text.2330: this paragon of ass-drivers gave me no help at all, however weary I might be, but begin­ ning from my head, or rather from my ears, he thrashed all the hair off my hide with a huge stick, till the blows stirred me up and served me instead of a stimulating medicament.
tgt_text.2331: Another piece of cruelty he practised on me, was this.
tgt_text.2332: He twisted together a bundle of the sharpest and most venomous thorns, and tied them to my tail as a pendulous torment;
tgt_text.2333: so that, jerking against me when I walked, they pricked and stabbed me intolerably.
tgt_text.2334: Hence, I was in a sore dilemma.
tgt_text.2335: For when I ran away from him, to escape his unmerciful drubbings, I was hurt by the more vehement pricking of the thorns;
tgt_text.2336: and if I stood still for a short time, in order to avoid that pain, I was compelled by blows to go on.
tgt_text.2337: In fact, the rascally boy seemed to think of nothing else than how he might be the death of me by some means or other;
tgt_text.2338: and that he sometimes threatened with oaths to accomplish.
