tgt_text.2339: And, indeed, there happened a thing by which his detestable malice was stimulated to more baneful efforts ;
tgt_text.2340: for on a certain day, when his excessive insolence had overcome my patience, I lifted up my powerful heels against him ;
tgt_text.2341: and for this he retaliated by the following atrocity.
tgt_text.2342: He brought me into the road heavily laden with a bundle of coarse flax, securely bound together with cords, and placed in the middle of the burden a burning coal, which he had stolen from the neighbouring village.
tgt_text.2343: Presently the fire spread through the slender fibres, flames burst forth, and I was all over in a blaze.
tgt_text.2344: There appeared no refuge from immediate destruction, no hope of safety, and such a conflagration did not admit of delay, or afford time for deliberation.
tgt_text.2345: Fortune, however, shone upon me in these cruel circumstances ;
tgt_text.2346: perhaps for the purpose of reserving me for future dangers, but, at all events, liberating me from present and decreed death.
tgt_text.2347: For by chance perceiving a neighbouring pool muddy with the rain of the preceding day, I threw myself headlong into it;
tgt_text.2348: and the flame being immediately extinguished, I came out, lightened of my burden, and liberated from destruction.
tgt_text.2349: But that audacious young rascal threw the blame of this most wicked deed of his on me, and affirmed to all the shepherds, that as I was passing near the neighbours' fires, I stumbled on purpose, and set my load in a blaze ;
tgt_text.2350: and he added, laughing at me, "How long shall we waste food on this fiery monster?
tgt_text.2351: "A few days after this, he had recourse to still worse artifices against me.
tgt_text.2352: After having sold my load of wood at the nearest cabin, he led me home unladen, declaring that he could not mar age so vicious a brute, and that he renounced the miserable office of being my driver.
tgt_text.2354: Look at that lazy, crawling, out-and-out jackass," said he. "
tgt_text.2355: Besides all his other miss- deeds, he is now worrying me with new ones that put me in mortal fear.
tgt_text.2356: For whenever he sees a traveller, be it a comely woman, or a marriageable girl, or a tender youth, he imme­ diately makes at them as if he was mad, upsetting his burden, and sometimes pitching off his very pack-saddle, and throws them down with abominable intentions, makes up his great ugly mouth as if to kiss them, and bites and tramples them most indecently.
tgt_text.2357: All this occasions us no small strife and quarrels, and will perhaps bring us into trouble with the ma­ gistrates.
tgt_text.2358: Just now, espying a decent young woman, this frolicksome gallant ran at her, scattering all his wood, threw her down in the mud, and wanted to have his wicked will of her there and then.
tgt_text.2359: Had not her shrieks brought some people to her help, who were passing that way, and who snatched her half dead from under his hoofs, she must have died a horrible death, and left us to suffer the last penalty of the law.
tgt_text.2360: "With these and other such lies, which hurt my modesty the more because I could not reply to them, he desperately incensed the herdsmen against me.
tgt_text.2361: At last said one of them, " Why do we not immolate as he deserves this public paramour, this universal adulterer ?
tgt_text.2363: cut off his head, throw his entrails to the dogs, and keep his flesh to feed the work­ people ;
tgt_text.2364: then we will carry his skin, well rubbed with ashes and dried, to our master, and easily make up a story of his having been killed by a wolf.
tgt_text.2365: Without delay my villanous accuser prepared joyfully to execute the herdsman's sentence with his own hand, and began to sharpen his knife on a whetstone, mocking, my woe, and maliciously calling to mind the kick I had given him, and which, by Hercules !
tgt_text.2367: But one of the rustics exclaimed that it was a shame to slaughter so fine an ass. "
tgt_text.2368: Why lose the services of so useful a beast," he said, " merely because he is too lustful ?
tgt_text.2369: Only geld him, and he can no how play his pranks any more ;
tgt_text.2370: we shall be safe from danger on his account, and besides, he will grow stouter and fatter than ever.
tgt_text.2371: I have known many an animal, not asses merely, but even high-spirited horses, that were so hot after mares, as to be quite furious and unmanageable, and which, after being cut, became quiet and fit to carry loads or do any- thing else that was required of them.
tgt_text.2372: So if you have no ob­ jection to what I say, after I have been to the market, which will not detain me long, I will fetch the implements from home, and immediately come back and geld this terrible rude gallant, and make him gentler than any wether.
tgt_text.2373: "Snatched by this proposal from the very clutches of death, but reserved for a most cruel punishment, I grieved as though I were about to perish wholly in losing an appendage to my body, and thought of destroying myself by continual fasting, or by leaping down a precipice:
tgt_text.2374: in that way I should die none the less, but I should die entire.
tgt_text.2375: Whilst I was pondering my choice of deaths, morning came again, and that boy, who was my tormentor, led me as usual up the mountain, where fastening me to a branch of great oak, he went a little way off, and began to cut down a load of wood with his axe.
tgt_text.2376: Just then, I saw a horrid bear lift up its great head, and creep out of a cave close by.
tgt_text.2377: Appalled at the sudden sight, I started back, sinking down with all my might upon my haunches, while my head and neck were held up by the thong, until it broke ;
tgt_text.2378: whereupon I dashed down the mountains, not on my feet only, but projecting myself bodily, reached the plains beneath, and scoured across them, running with all my might from the dreadful bear, and the boy that was worse than the bear.
tgt_text.2379: A man who was passing that way, seeing me roam at large, caught me, got on my back, and thumping me with a stick, turned me into a side road unknown to me.
tgt_text.2380: I carried him along with good will, thinking I was running away from that cruel operation, and caring little about the blows I received, for I was used to that sort of thing.
tgt_text.2381: But Fortune, with her inveterate malice, anticipated so opportune a chance of escape, and gave me over to fresh sufferings.
tgt_text.2382: For my master's herds­ men having gone out in all directions to look for a stray heifer, Happened to fall in with us, and seizing me by the head stall, which they readily identified, they began to lead me away.
tgt_text.2383: My rider, however, making a bold resistance, called gods and men to witness against them. "
tgt_text.2384: Why do you pull me about in this violent way ?" he said, "
tgt_text.2385: Why do you lay hands on me ?
tgt_text.2387: "Do we behave unjustly to you," said- the herdsmen, " when we find you making off with our ass ?
tgt_text.2388: Tell us where you have hid the body of his driver, whom you have killed, no doubt."
tgt_text.2389: So saying, they knocked him to the ground, and kicked and pummelled him with their fists, he swearing all the while that he had seen no one with the ass, but had found it running away, alone, and had caught it, that he might restore it to its owner, and be rewarded for his trouble."
tgt_text.2390: Would to heaven!" he cried, " that I had never seen this ass, or that he could speak with a human voice, and bear testi­ mony to my innocence.
tgt_text.2391: You would surely be ashamed of the way in which you treat me.
tgt_text.2392: "But all his protestations were of no avail, for the angry herdsmen marched him along, with a rope round his neck, to the forest on the mountain, where the boy used to fetch wood.
tgt_text.2393: He was no where to be found;
tgt_text.2394: but at last they discovered what were plainly the remains of his body, torn to pieces and strewed here and there.
tgt_text.2395: I knew well it was the bear's teeth had done this, and I would certainly have said so, had I possessed the fa­ culty of speech.
tgt_text.2396: All I could do was to rejoice silently at seeing myself revenged at last.
tgt_text.2397: After they had with much pains collected the scattered frag­ ments of the body, they buried them on the spot, and marched my Belerophon* to their cottages, there to remain tied fast, as a thief taken in the fact, and a bloody assassin, until they de­ livered him up next morning, for condign punishment, into the hands of the magistrates.
tgt_text.2398: Meanwhile, in the midst of the lamentations raised by the parents of the dead boy, up came that rustic who had promised to perform the operation upon me, and who now proposed to keep his word. "
tgt_text.2399: Our present loss is not of his causing," said one of the byestanders;
tgt_text.2400: " nevertheless you may cut what you please to-morrow from this villanous jackass—his head if you have a mind, and you shall not want for help.
tgt_text.2401: "Thus it came to pass that my calamity was postponed for another day, and I gave thanks to that kind boy, whose death, at all events, procured me one little day's respite from the knife.
tgt_text.2402: But I was not allowed even that short space of time to be grateful to him or to enjoy repose ;
tgt_text.2403: for his mother rushed into my stable, weeping and bewailing her son's premature death, dressed in a black robe, tearing out her white hair, bestrewed with ashes, and vehemently beating her breasts."
tgt_text.2404: Look at him," she screamed, " how easily he takes it, that cursed ass, with his head stuck in the manger, indulging his gluttony, and for ever stuffing his insatiable belly.
tgt_text.2405: He has no pity for my affliction, nor does he bestow a thought upon the horrible fate of his deceased driver;
tgt_text.2406: no, he despises my age and weakness, and thinks that he shall get off with impunity after his enormous crime;
tgt_text.2407: perhaps he has the audacity to suppose he shall be thought innocent;
tgt_text.2408: for it is the nature of the worst criminals to expect impunity, even in spite of the reproaches of their own guilty conscience.
tgt_text.2409: Now, in the name of all the Gods, most infamous of quadrupeds, though you could borrow the use of speech for a while, do you think you could persuade any one, aye the veriest fool, that you were without fault in that horrid disaster, when you could have fought for my poor boy, and defended him with heels and teeth ?
tgt_text.2410: You could often lift your heels against himself;
tgt_text.2411: why could you not use them with the same alacrity in his defence ?
tgt_text.2412: You should have galloped off with him on your back, and saved him from the bloody hands of the robber;
tgt_text.2413: above all, you should not have fled alone, after throwing and deserting your fellow-servant, your conductor, your comrade, the friend who fed you.
tgt_text.2414: Do you not know that those who refuse help to persons in mortal peril are punished, . because therein they offend against all good principles ?
tgt_text.2415: But you shall no longer rejoice over my calamities, murderer that you are;
tgt_text.2416: I will let you know what strength there is in violent grief.
tgt_text.2417: "So saying, she took off her girdle, and tied my feet separately, and as tightly as she could, so as to deprive me of the means of revenging myself.
tgt_text.2418: Then snatching up a great stake, which was used to bar the stable door, she never ceased whacking me with it until her strength was quite spent, and it fell from her wearied hands.
tgt_text.2419: Then complaining of the too speedy ex­ haustion of her arms, she ran back into the house, fetched a live coal from the hearth, and thrust it between my thighs;
tgt_text.2420: until, employing the only means of defence left me, I squirted a volley of liquid ordure into her face and eyes, and thus put­ ting her to the rout, blinded and stinking, I saved myself from destruction;
tgt_text.2421: otherwise the ass would have perished like another Meleager by the brand of this raving Althea.
tgt_text.2422: *AT that time of the night when the cocks crow, a young man came from the next city, who, as I perceived, was one of the servants of that virgin Charite, who had endured equal sorrows with myself among the robbers.
tgt_text.2423: Sitting near the fire, in the company of his fellow-servants, he related, as follows, the wonderful and execrable particulars of her death, and the de­ struction of her whole house.
tgt_text.2424: "Grooms, shepherds, and cow-herds, we have lost our unfortunate mistress, Charite, and by a most grievous catastrophe.
tgt_text.2425: Yet she did not depart to the shades alone.
tgt_text.2426: But, that all of you may know the particulars, I will narrate to you from the beginning what happened, and which deserves to be committed to writing, in the form of a history, by more learned men, on whom Fortune has conferred the ability of writing with facility and elegance."
tgt_text.2427: There was a young man in the next city, whose name was Thrasyllus, of noble birth, of knightly rank, and very rich ;
tgt_text.2428: but he was a man addicted to the luxury of taverns, and to harlots, and potations by day.
tgt_text.2429: On this account he iniquitously associated with a factious band of robbers, and his hands were dyed with human blood.
tgt_text.2430: Such was the man, and such was the report concerning him.
tgt_text.2431: Now, as soon as Charite was mar­ riageable, he was among her principal suitors, and most ar­ dently endeavoured to obtain her in wedlock.
tgt_text.2432: And, though he surpassed in nobility all the rest of her lovers, and solicited her parents with splendid gifts, yet he was rejected by them, on account of his morals, and suffered the disgrace of a repulse.
tgt_text.2433: When, therefore, Charite, my master's daughter, came into the hands of the worthy Tlepolemus, Thrasyllus, though disap­ pointed in his hopes, yet firmly cherishing his love, and adding to his passion the rage he felt on account of his rejected suit, sought for an opportunity of perpetrating a bloody deed.
tgt_text.2434: At length, a seasonable occasion presenting itself, he prepared to execute the wickedness which had for a long time been the subjects of his thoughts.
tgt_text.2435: On the day on which the virgin had been liberated, by the cunning and fortitude of her spouse, from the deadly swords of the robbers, he mingled with the crowd of those that congratulated her, and made himself re­ markable by the exulting joy he professed in the present safety of the new married pair, and in the hopes of their future off­ spring.
tgt_text.2436: Hence, being received into our house, among the principal guests, as the nobility of his race demanded, and con­ cealing his wicked designs, he falsely personated the character of a most faithful friend."
tgt_text.2437: And now, gradually ingratiating himself more and more by his assiduity, by frequent conversation, and sometimes also by sitting as a guest at the young couple's table, he fell, by imperceptible degrees, into deeper love than ever.
tgt_text.2438: Nor is this wonderful, since the flame of love, small at first, delights with a gentle glow ;
tgt_text.2439: but, when fanned by continued familiar inter­ course, it waxes fierce, and burns a man up wholly.
tgt_text.2440: Thra­ syllus for a long time pondered how he might find an oppor­ tune place for clandestine conference.
tgt_text.2441: He perceived that he was more and more excluded from the avenues to an adulterous intercourse by the multitude of observers, and that the strong bonds of a new and increasing affection could not be severed;
tgt_text.2442: and, further, that even if Charite were willing to comply with his desires, which she never would be, her ignorance of the art of deceiving a husband would hinder such a purpose.
tgt_text.2443: Yet, in spite of all these obstacles, ho was bent with desperate ob- stinacy on the accomplishment of what was impossible, as though it had not been so.
tgt_text.2444: Things which seem difficult in the beginning of love, appear easy when it has been strengthened by time.
tgt_text.2445: Hear now, and carefully note, I pray you, to what deed he was driven by the violence of his furious lust."
tgt_text.2446: One day Tlepolemus, accompanied by Thrasyllus, went to hunt wild beasts, if, indeed, the roe comes under that denomi­ nation ;
tgt_text.2447: for Charite would not allow her husband to pursue beasts armed with tusk or horn.
tgt_text.2448: The toils were spread round a hill thickly covered with trees, and the high-bred hounds were turned in to rouse the beasts from their lairs.
tgt_text.2449: Their good training was immediately seen, for they spread abroad so as to enclose every avenue.
tgt_text.2450: For a while they followed the scent in silence, till at last one gave tongue, and then they all burst out with impetuous, dissonant yells, that made everything ring again.
tgt_text.2451: But it was not a roebuck, nor a timid doe, nor a hind, the gentlest of all wild creatures, that was started, but an enor­ mous boar, the like of which was never seen-a brawny, thick- hided, filthy brute, with bristles standing upright on his back, foaming and gnashing his teeth, with eyes that darted fire, and rushing along like a thunderbolt.
tgt_text.2452: The keenest of the hounds that pressed upon his flanks were ripped up by his tusks, and flung here and there;
tgt_text.2453: then he broke through the toils at the first charge, and got clear off.
tgt_text.2454: We, meanwhile, were terror- stricken, having been used only to such hunting as was without danger, and being, besides, without weapons or means of de­ fence ;
tgt_text.2455: so we hid ourselves the best way we could under thick foliage and behind trees."
tgt_text.2456: Thrasyllus now seeing a favourable opportunity for accom­ plishing his intended treachery, said insidiously to Tlepolemus:
tgt_text.2458: Why do we remain stupified with surprise, or even dismayed, like these low-souled slaves, and trembling like women, whilst we suffer such a fine prey to escape us ?
tgt_text.2460: You take a javelin, and I will take a lance.'"
tgt_text.2461: Without more said, they jumped at once on their horses, and made after the brute with all speed.
tgt_text.2462: But the boar, conn- dent in its strength, wheeled round, and looking horribly fero­ cious as it gnashed its teeth, stood glaring at them uncertain which to attack first.
tgt_text.2463: Tlepolemus hurled his javelin, and lodged it in the animal's back;
tgt_text.2464: but Thrasyllus, leaving the boar alone, charged the horse Tlepolemus rode with his lance, and cut its hamstrings.
tgt_text.2465: The quadruped, sinking down in a poo* of its own blood, rolled over on its back, and involuntarily threw its master, whom the boar immediately rushed at in fury, and after tearing his clothes, rent his body in many places as he was endeavouring to rise.
tgt_text.2466: Meanwhile, his good friend felt no remorse for the infamous deed he had begun, nor was his cruelty yet satisfied;
tgt_text.2467: for whilst Tlepolemus was striv­ ing to defend his gored legs, and was piteously calling to him for help, he pierced him through the middle of the right thigh with his lance;
tgt_text.2468: which he did the more boldly, because he judged that the wound would resemble those made by the brute's tusks.
tgt_text.2469: Afterwards he ran the boar through and through with­ out difficulty."
tgt_text.2470: After the young man was thus slain, we were all called out from our hiding-places, and ran to him in great grief.
tgt_text.2471: But Thrasyllus, though he had accomplished his purpose, and re­ joiced in having slain him whom he looked on as his enemy, yet concealed his joy under a countenance that simulated sorrow;
tgt_text.2472: and ardently embracing the corpse that he himself had made, he cleverly counterfeited all the signs of mourning, only his tears refused to flow.
tgt_text.2473: Thus imitating us who lamented truly, he falsely cast upon the boar the odium of the deed his own hand had done.
tgt_text.2474: "The news of this crime spread quickly, and first of all reached the family of Tlepolemus, and smote the ears of his unhappy wife.
tgt_text.2475: The moment she heard it—she will never hear news more-she lost her senses, and ran like a frantic bacchanal through the crowded streets, and away over the fields, scream­ ing out her husband's name, and bewailing his fate.
tgt_text.2476: The com­ passionate citizens flocked after her;
tgt_text.2477: all who met her followed Jier, sympathizing in her grief;
tgt_text.2478: and the whole city was emptied to see the sad spectacle.
tgt_text.2479: At last, she reached the spot where lay the body of her husband;
tgt_text.2480: there, swooning away, she fell prostrate on his corpse, and all but yielded up on the spot the soul that was devoted to him;
tgt_text.2481: but her friends with difficulty forced her away, and she remained unwillingly alive.
tgt_text.2482: "At last, the body was carried to the tomb, the whole city joining in the funeral procession.
tgt_text.2483: Then did Thrasyllus cry, and roar, and beat his breast, and even weep, for the tears which lie had been unable to shed in his first feigned sorrow, were now supplied him by his augmented joy.
tgt_text.2484: He concealed his real feelings with all sorts of affectionate words, calling piteously to the deceased by name, as his friend, his playmate in boyhood, his comrade, his brother.
tgt_text.2485: And every now and then he would take hold of Charite's hands to hinder her from beating her bosom;
tgt_text.2486: would try to mitigate her grief and wail­ ing with words expressive of the liveliest sympathy, and with various examples of the uncertainty of life.
tgt_text.2487: And amidst all these false shows of humanity and friendship, he took every opportunity of touching the person of the bereaved woman, and nourishing his own odious passion by that stolen pleasure."
tgt_text.2488: The funeral being ended, the widow was now impatient to join her husband, and thought over all means to that end.
tgt_text.2489: At last, she chose one that was gentle, cost no effort, needed no weapon, and was like quietly falling asleep.
tgt_text.2490: She abstained from food, neglected her person, and would have passed away from daylight to the darkness of the grave, but for the urgent pertinacity of Thrasyllus, who, partly by his own efforts, partly through those of her friends and her parents, prevailed on her to refresh her disfigured and almost perishing body with the bath and with food."
tgt_text.2491: Charite, who revered her parents, yielded against her will to a religious sense of duty, and with a somewhat more serene countenance did what was necessary for the preservation of her life;
tgt_text.2492: but still her inmost soul was consumed with grief.
tgt_text.2493: She spent all her days and nights in pining remembrance, and in paying divine honours to an image of the deceased, which she had caused to be made in the costume of the god Bacchus, so that she tortured herself, even by that kind of consolation.
tgt_text.2494: Meanwhile, the reckless, headlong Thrasyllus, without waiting until the tears she shed had satisfied her grief, nor till the commotion of her spirits had partly subsided, and time had gradually blunted the keenness of her sorrow, did not forbear to speak to her of marriage while she was still weeping for her husband, rending her garments, and tearing her hair, and to reveal to her by his indecent importunity the secret of his breast and his ineffable treachery."
tgt_text.2495: Charite was seized with horror and loathing at the abo­ minable proposal, which came upon her like a clap of thunder, or a blast from some malignant star, and she fell senseless as if smitten by lightning.
tgt_text.2496: Recovering after a while, with wild shrieks, she called to mind what had passed between her and the villain Thrasyllus, and postponed her reply to his suit until she should have maturely considered it.
tgt_text.2497: "During that delay, the shade of the cruelly-slam Tlepo­ lemus, lifting up its ghastly, gory face, thus addressed her as she slept:
tgt_text.2498: ' My own wife, a name which none else shall call you, if my memory dwells in your heart-if my cruel death has broken the bonds of affection that united us, contract a happier marriage with whom you will, only give yourself not into the sacrilegious hands of Thrasyllus:
tgt_text.2499: neither talk with him, nor sit at the same board, nor share the same bed with him.
tgt_text.2500: Shun the blood-stained hand of my murderer;
tgt_text.2501: begin not your marriage with parricide.*
tgt_text.2502: Those gory wounds which you have washed with your tears were not all inflicted by the tusks of the boar;
tgt_text.2503: but the lance of the wicked Thrasyllus has parted me from you.'
tgt_text.2504: And then he told her all the circum­ stances, and set before her the whole scene of the crime."
tgt_text.2505: When Charite had first laid her head upon her pillow, her tears flowed over her beautiful cheeks even while she slept;
tgt_text.2506: but roused by the vision of her restless sleep as by the wrench of the rack, she broke out again into loud and long wailing, tore her night-dress, and beat her lovely arms with merciless hands.
tgt_text.2507: Yet she imparted to no one the story of the appari­ tion she had seen;
tgt_text.2508: but concealing altogether the knowledge she had obtained of the crime, she secretly resolved to punish the nefarious murderer, and to deliver herself from the intoler­ able burthen of life.
tgt_text.2509: "Again the odious and importunate suitor assailed her obdu­ rate ears with proposals of marriage;
tgt_text.2510: but she gently declined them, and dissembling her purpose with admirable artifice, she thus replied to his urgent supplications :
tgt_text.2512: The sweet face of your brother, my beloved husband, is still before my eyes;
tgt_text.2513: the cinnamon odour of his ambrosial body is still in my nostrils;
tgt_text.2514: the beautiful Tlepolemus still lives in my bosom.
tgt_text.2515: You will do best then if you allow a most wretched woman the necessary time for mourning, and let the remaining months of the year be spent in that legitimate duty.
tgt_text.2516: What I ask concerns not only my own reputation, but your safety also, lest by a prema­ ture marriage we provoke the just indignation of my husband's ghost to your destruction '"Unchecked in his importunity by these arguments, and even by the promise that accompanied them, Thrasyllus persisted in molesting her ears with his vile addresses, until, apparently overcome, Charite said to him:
tgt_text.2517: ' One thing at least, Thra­ syllus, you must grant to my earnest entreaties, and that is that our cohabitation be quite secret and unknown to any of my family until the year is out.'
tgt_text.2518: Thrasyllus was completely duped by her feigned compliance with his suit;
tgt_text.2519: he consented with 'alacrity to the clandestine intercourse, and passionately longed for the return of night and darkness, caring for nothing in comparison with the possession of Charite.
tgt_text.2520: ' But mind,' said Charite, ' come well muffled up, without any attendant,- and approach my door in silence at the first watch.
tgt_text.2521: Only whistle once, and wait for my nurse, who will be on the watch behind the door, and will instantly open it for you, and conduct you in the dark to my chamber.'"
tgt_text.2522: Thrasyllus, suspecting nothing, was delighted with the scheme of those funereal nuptials, and was only troubled with impatience at the length of the day and the slow approach of evening.
tgt_text.2523: At last, when daylight had disappeared, dressed as Charite had directed, he was admitted by the watchful nurse, and stole full of hope to the nuptial chamber.
tgt_text.2524: There the old woman, treating him with obsequious attention by her mis­ tress's orders, noiselessly produced cups and a flagon con­ taining wine mixed with a soporiferous drug.
tgt_text.2525: Then excusing her mistress's delay on the pretext that she was with her father, who was ill, she plied him with the beverage, which he drank freely, and without suspicion, until he fell fast asleep."
tgt_text.2526: As soon as he lay stretched on his back in that helpless state, Charite was summoned, and rushing in with dire deter­ mination, stood quivering with rage over the murderer, ' Be­ hold,' she cried, ' this faithful companion of my husband!
tgt_text.2529: This is the hand that shed my blood;
tgt_text.2530: this is the breast that conceived treacherous plots for my undoing :
tgt_text.2531: those are the eyes that to my sorrow I delighted, but that now anticipate their coming punishment, wrapped in the darkness that will cover them perpetually.
tgt_text.2534: I will not smite you with sword or spear.
tgt_text.2535: Far be it from me to put you on an equality with my husband in the manner of your death.
tgt_text.2536: Your eyes shall die in your living head, and you shall never see more but in dreams.
tgt_text.2537: I will make you think your enemy's death happier than your own life.
tgt_text.2538: Never shall you see the light;
tgt_text.2539: you shall need to be led by the hand;
tgt_text.2541: you shall not enjoy your pro­ mised nuptials;
tgt_text.2542: you shall know neither the repose of death nor the pleasure of life ;
tgt_text.2543: but you shall wander like an erring phantom between the infernal regions and the sun;
tgt_text.2544: and you shall long seek the hand that has blinded you, and, what is the most miserable thing in calamity, you shall not know whom to complain of.
tgt_text.2545: I will make a libation of the blood of your eyes at the tomb of my Tlepolemus, and sacrifice those eyes to his sacred shade.
tgt_text.2546: But why do I suffer you to have a respite from your deserved torture, while you are dreaming perhaps of embracing me, who am your bane ?
tgt_text.2547: Wake from the darkness of sleep to a worse darkness;
tgt_text.2551: compute the sum of your miseries.
tgt_text.2552: Thus have your eyes charmed your modest bride;
tgt_text.2553: thus have the nuptial torches lighted your chamber;
tgt_text.2554: you shall have the Furies for brides­ maids, and blindness and the perpetual stings of conscience for companions.'"
tgt_text.2555: Having poured out these words like one inspired, Charite drew out the pin from her hair, and plunged it over and ovei again into the eyes of Thrasyllus;
tgt_text.2556: then leaving him to awake in pain and blindness from his lethargic sleep, she caught up the naked sword which Tlepolemus used to wear, and rushed frantically through the city towards her husband's tomb, mani­ festly bent on some desperate deed.
tgt_text.2557: All of us, servants, and the whole population, anxiously pursued her, crying out to each other to wrest the weapon from her insane hands.
tgt_text.2558: But Charite standing by the coffin of Tlepolemus, kept everybody off with the glittering blade ;
tgt_text.2559: and when all around her were weeping and lamenting, she cried:
tgt_text.2560: ' Away with these impor­ tunate tears!
tgt_text.2561: Away with this wailing, which ill accords with my fortitude.
tgt_text.2562: I have taken vengeance upon the bloody murderer of my husband.
tgt_text.2563: I have punished the accursed de.
tgt_text.2565: it is now time that with this sword l make my way straight to my Tlepolemus.'"
tgt_text.2566: Then having related all that her husband had told her in the dream, and the artifice by which she had inveigled Thra­ syllus, she plunged the sword beneath her right breast, fell bathed in blood, murmured a few broken' words, and breathed out her magnanimous spirit.
tgt_text.2567: The friends of the unfortunate Charite immediately washed her body with care, and depositing it by the side of Tlepolemus, re-united her for ever to the husband she loved."
tgt_text.2568: When Thrasyllus was aware of all this, he thought he could not inflict on himself a death commensurate with the cala­ mities he had caused, and that the sword could not suffice to expiate his guilt;
tgt_text.2569: therefore he had himself carried to the tomb of Tlepolemus and Charite, where, crying out repeatedly, ' Be­ hold, 0 ye injured manes, here is your voluntary victim,' he caused the doors to be firmly closed upon him;
tgt_text.2570: and there he suffered the doom pronounced by himself, and perished by starvation."
tgt_text.2572: Such was the story, interrupted with many sighs and tears, which the servant told to the sorrowing rustics, who fearing a change of master, and deeply commiserating the misfortune of the house to which they had belonged, determined to run away.
tgt_text.2573: The master of the stud, the same to whom I had been given in charge with such impressive orders to be kind to me, plun­ dered the cottage of everything valuable in it, and loading me and other beasts of burden with the spoil, deserted his old abode.
tgt_text.2574: We carried women and children, cocks and hens, geese, kids, whelps ;
tgt_text.2575: in short, whatever was unable to keep up with our pace, was made to walk with our feet.
tgt_text.2576: But enormous as my load was, I did not care for it, so glad was I of the flight that saved me from the knife of that abominable -elder.
tgt_text.2577: Having crossed a steep mountain covered with a forest, and descended to the plain on the other side, we arrived, just as evening was throwing its shadows on our road, at a certain populous and thriving town, whence the inhabitants would not allow us to proceed by night, nor even in the morning.
tgt_text.2578: The reason of this was, that the whole district was infested by mul­ titudes of fierce wolves of enormous bulk and strength, that even beset the roads and fell like highway robbers on those who travelled by them.
tgt_text.2579: Nay, sometimes impelled by the rage of hunger, they stormed the neighbouring farms, and the men were no more safe from their fury than their defenceless flocks.
tgt_text.2580: They told us too, that the road we should have to travel was strewn with half-eaten human bodies, and whitened with flesh­ less bones;
tgt_text.2581: and therefore, that we ought to proceed with ex­ treme caution, and be especially careful to travel only in broad day-light, while the sun was high in the heavens, since its light checks the fury of those dreadful creatures;
tgt_text.2582: 'and that we should move, not stragglingly, but in close compact order, through those dangerous places.
tgt_text.2583: But our rascally fugitive conductors, in blind haste to escape the risk of pursuit, despised these salutary warnings, and with­ out waiting for day-light, loaded and drove us forward.
tgt_text.2584: Then I, aware of the danger, took all possible care to keep between the other beasts in the very middle of the throng, so as to save my buttocks from the fangs of the wolves;
tgt_text.2585: and all our con­ ductors were much surprised to see me beat the horses in speed.
tgt_text.2586: But this was not the result of my natural quickness of limb, but of my fear;
tgt_text.2587: and I thought within myself that it was nothing else than fright which had given such agility to the renowned Pegasus, and that the reason why he had been styled winged, was, doubtless, because he had skipped and bounded up to the very sky, in his dread of being bitten by the fire-breath­ ing Chimæra.
tgt_text.2588: Meanwhile the herdsmen who drove us had armed themselves as if for battle.
tgt_text.2589: This one carried a lance, that one a hunting spear, another a bundle of javelins, another a club ;
tgt_text.2590: and some had provided themselves with stones, which the rough road supplied in abundance.
tgt_text.2591: A few carried sharpened stakes, and a great number waved blazing torches to frighten the beasts;
tgt_text.2592: and nothing but the trumpet was wanting to give our troop the appearance of an army in battle array.
tgt_text.2593: But after having terribly frightened ourselves, we escaped the threatened danger only to fall into a worse one.
tgt_text.2594: For, whether scared by the shouting of solargeabody of men, and by the glare of the torches, or being engaged elsewhere, the wolves never approached us, nor did one of them come in sight even at a distance.
tgt_text.2595: But the labourers on the farm which we were then passing, taking us for a gang of robbers, and letting slip enormous dogs, which had been carefully trained for their masters' defence, and were fiercer than any wolves or bears, urged them against us with all sorts of shouts and cries.
tgt_text.2596: With their natural ferocity thus encouraged and exasperated, the dogs rushed at us, at­ tacked ns on all sides, men and cattle w ithout distinction, and after mauling them a long time, laid many of them low.
tgt_text.2597: It was certainly a remarkable, and still more a pitiable spectacle, to see all those dogs seizing those that.
tgt_text.2598: fled, ravening at those who stood their ground, mounting upon the bodies of those who were down, and overrunning our whole troop, biting all that came before them.
tgt_text.2599: This was terrible indeed, but worse was added to it;
tgt_text.2600: for the peasants poured down showers of stones upon us from the roofs of their cottages and from an adjacent hill, so that we were quite at a loss to know which we should most avoid, the dogs that attacked us at close quarters, or the stones that were launched at us from a distance.
tgt_text.2601: One of the latter fell upon the head of a woman who was seated on my back, and who, smarting from the blow, immediately began to scream and roar for her husband to come to her aid.
tgt_text.2602: Wiping the blood from her wound, the herdsman cried out, " In the name of all the gods, why do you so cruelly assault and maltreat poor hard­ working travellers ?
tgt_text.2603: Have we offered to rob you ?
tgt_text.2604: What harm have we ever done you ?
tgt_text.2605: You do not live in dens like wild beasts, or in caves like savages, that you should take delight in shedding human blood.
tgt_text.2606: "As soon as he had said this, the shower of stones ceased, the ferocious dogs were called off, and one of the peasants cried out from the top of a cypress tree- on which he was perched:
tgt_text.2607: "And we too, are no robbers, and do not want to plunder you;
tgt_text.2608: we only fight to protect ourselves from suffering the like at your hands, so now you may go your ways in peace and safety."
tgt_text.2609: Therefore we continued our journey, but wounded in all manner of ways, some with stones, others by the teeth of the dogs, but all more or less hurt.
tgt_text.2610: Having gone a little way further, we reached a grove of tall trees, with pleasant green glades, where our leaders thought good to rest and take some refreshment, and dress the wounds of their bruised and mangled bodies.
tgt_text.2611: So they threw them­ selves on the ground in all directions, and after lying awhile to recover from their fatigue, they began to apply various re­ medies to their wounds, washing the blood from them in the running stream ;
tgt_text.2612: applying wet sponges to their contusions, and tying up their gaping wounds with bandages.
tgt_text.2613: In this way each did the best he could for himself.
tgt_text.2614: Meanwhile, an old man was descried on the top of a hill, with goats feeding round him, and plainly showing that he was a goat-herd.
tgt_text.2615: One of our people called out, and asked him had he any milk or new cheese to sell.
tgt_text.2616: But he, shaking his head a long while, replied :
tgt_text.2617: "And are you thinking of food or drink, or of any refreshment at all ?
tgt_text.2618: Do you not know what sort of a place you are in ?"
tgt_text.2619: So saying, he turned his back upon us, and went off with his flock.
tgt_text.2620: His words, and the manner of his departure, struck our people with no small fear;
tgt_text.2621: and while they were all anxious to ascertain the nature of the spot where they lay, but could find no one to tell them, another old man made his appearance.
tgt_text.2622: He was a tall man, bent with age, and dragged his feet slowly and wearily along, leaning heavily on his staff, and weeping profusely.
tgt_text.2623: When he came up with our men, he threw himself on his knees before them, and embracing them one after the other, thus besought in most piteous accents:
tgt_text.2624: " By your for­ tunes, by your genii,* and as you hope to live strong and hearty till you reach my age, help an unfortunate old man, who has lost his only hope, and save my little boy from the jaws of death.
tgt_text.2625: My grandson, the sweet companion of my journey, tried to catch a sparrow chirping on a hedge, and he fell into a ditch close by here, that was hidden with low shrubs, and there he lies in extreme peril of his life.
tgt_text.2626: I know indeed, by his cries to me for help, that he is still alive.
tgt_text.2627: But being so weak in body, as you see, I cannot succour him.
tgt_text.2628: But you, who enjoy youth and strength, can easily aid an unhappy old man, and save for him this'child, the last and only scion of my stock.
tgt_text.2629: "As the old man made these entreaties and tore his white hair, we were all moved with pity;
tgt_text.2630: and one of the party, the youngest, boldest and strongest of them all, who besides, was the only one that had come off unwounded from the late con­ flict, sprang to his feet, and enquiring where it was the boy had fallen, went with the old man towards some rough bushes which the latter pointed out a little way off.
tgt_text.2631: Meanwhile, after the cattle had done feeding, and their drivers had finished their meal and the dressing of their wounds, each of them packed up his baggage again, and.
tgt_text.2633: They called loudly to the young man who had gone away with the old stranger, and afterwards, surprised by his long delay, they sent one of their number to look for him, and tell him it was time to be off.
tgt_text.2634: The messenger came back soon, trembling, and ghastly pale, and brought strange news of his fellow-ser­ vant.
tgt_text.2635: He had seen him, he said, lying on his back, half eaten, and a monstrous dragon squatting over him;
tgt_text.2636: whilst the un­ fortunate old man was not to be seen at all.
tgt_text.2637: Considering this matter, and comparing it with the words of the shepherd on the hill, which had doubtless been intended to warn them against that terrible inhabitant of the neighbour­ hood, our men hurried away as fast as they could from the deadly spot, drubbing us briskly with their sticks.
tgt_text.2638: After getting over a long stage at a very quick rate, we arrived at a village where we halted for the night, and there I learned a very extraordinary occurrence which I will relate.
tgt_text.2639: THERE was a servant to whom his master had committed the management of all his affairs, and who was bailiff of that large farm where we had taken up our quarters.
tgt_text.2640: He had married one of his fellow-servants, but fell in love with a free woman who was not of the household.
tgt_text.2641: Enraged by his adultery, his wife burned all his account books, and all the contents of his store-room.
tgt_text.2642: And not content with having thus avenged the wrongs of her bed, but turning her fury against her own flesh and blood, she put a rope round her neck, fastened to it also an infant she had borne to her husband, and threw herself into a deep well along with her little one.
tgt_text.2643: Her master was exceed­ ingly incensed at her loss, and seizing the servant who had pro­ voked his own wife to the commission of such a dreadful deed, had him stripped naked, smeared all over with honey, and bound fast to a fig-tree, the rotten trunk of which was filled with the nests of a prodigious multitude of ants, that were continually running to and from all directions.
tgt_text.2644: As soon as these ants smelt the honey with which the bailiffs body was smeared, they fastened upon him, and with minute, but innumerable and in­ cessant bites, gradually consumed his flesh and his entrails;
tgt_text.2645: and after the miserable man had been thus tortured a long while, his bones were at last picked clean;
tgt_text.2646: and so they were still to be seen, quite dry and white, attached to the fatal tree.-
tgt_text.2648: Quitting this detestable dwelling, and leaving the rustics in great sorrow, we proceeded on our journey.
tgt_text.2649: After travelling all day over a level country, we came much fatigued to a hand­ some populous town.
tgt_text.2650: There our men resolved to stop and take up their permanent abode, both because the place offered them every convenience for hiding from those who might come from a distance in pursuit of them, and because the town was abundantly blessed with provisions.
tgt_text.2651: Myself and the other beasts were allowed three days' rest to improve our condition, and then we were led out for sale.
tgt_text.2652: The crier proclaimed the price of each of us with a loud voice, and all were bought by wealthy persons, except myself, whom all the purchasers passed by with contempt.
tgt_text.2653: I lost patience at the manner in which I was handled, and my teeth examined to ascertain my age;
tgt_text.2654: there was one man especially, who was always poking his nasty dirty fingers against my gums;
tgt_text.2655: but at last, I caught his hand between my teeth, and nearly crushed it.
tgt_text.2656: That deterred every one from buying me, as a ferociously vicious brute.
tgt_text.2657: Then the crier, bawling till his throat was almost split, cracked all sorts of ridiculous jokes upon me.
tgt_text.2659: What is the use," said he, “of offering for sale this old screw of a jackass, with his foundered hoofs, his ugly colour, his sluggishness in everything but vice, and a hide that is nothing but a ready-made sieve ?
tgt_text.2660: Let us even make a present of him, if we can find any one who will not be loth to throw away hay upon the brute."
tgt_text.2661: In this way the crier kept the byestanders in roars of laughter.
tgt_text.2662: But my merciless fortune, which I had been unable to leave behind me, far as I had fled, or to appease by all my past suf­ ferings, again cast its evil eye upon me, and for a wonder, pro­ duced a purchaser, the fittest of all men to prolong my hard sufferings.
tgt_text.2663: He was an old eunuch, partly bald, with what grizzled hair he had left hanging in long curls, one of those lowest dregs of the rabble who compel the Syrian goddess to beg, hawking her about the highways and the towns, and playing on cymbals and castanets.
tgt_text.2664: This man having a great mind to buy me, asked the crier of what country I was.
tgt_text.2665: The latter replied that I was Cappadocian,* and a fine strong animal.
tgt_text.2666: Again, the other asked my age.
tgt_text.2667: “The mathema­ tician who cast his nativity," replied the joking crier, " cal­ culated that he was fire years old;
tgt_text.2668: but no doubt he is better informed on this point than any one else, from the register of his birth.
tgt_text.2669: Now though I make myself liable to the penalties of the Cornelian law if I knowingly sell you a Roman citizen for a slave, what should hinder you from buying a good and useful servant, who will do your pleasure at home and abroad?
tgt_text.2670: "The odious purchaser went on asking questions without end, and at last came to the important point, was I gentle ? "
tgt_text.2672: "it is not an ass, but a wether you see before you, such a quiet thing you may do what you will with himj none of your biters or kickers;
tgt_text.2673: but altogether such an animal that you might suppose there was a decent, honest man under his ass's hide.
tgt_text.2674: You may convince yourself of the fact without difficulty;
tgt_text.2675: only stick your face between his thighs, and you will see how patient he will be.
tgt_text.2676: "Thus did the crier make fun of the old vagabond;
tgt_text.2677: but the latter perceived that the other was mocking, and cried out in a passion:
tgt_text.2678: “What, you deaf and dumb carcase, you crazy crier, may the omnipotent and all-procreant Syrian goddess, and blessed Sabazius, and Bellona, and the Idœan mother, and our mistress Venus, with her Adonis, strike you blind, you that have been flinging your scurrilous jokes at me this evei so long.
tgt_text.2679: Do you think me such a fool as to put the goddesf on the back of a vicious brute, that he might pitch the divine image to the ground, and that I should have to run about with my hair streaming, to look for some one to lift my goddess from the ground, and repair her hurts ?
tgt_text.2680: "When I heard him talk in this strain, I thought of prancing suddenly, like mad, that seeing how very wild I was, he might give up the thought of buying me.
tgt_text.2681: But the anxious purchaser anticipated my intention by at once paying down the price, seventeen denars, which my master promptly took up, to his own satisfaction and my vexation, and immediately delivered me to my new owner, Philebus, with a rush halter round my neck.
tgt_text.2682: Philebus took me home with him, and cried out the moment he reached the door:
tgt_text.2684: here is a handsome servant I have bought for you."
tgt_text.2685: Now these girls were a set of eunuchs, who immediately broke out into screams of joy, with broken, hoarse, effeminate voices, thinking it was a slave fit to render them good service.
tgt_text.2686: But when they per­ ceived the substitution, not of a stag for a virgin,* but of a jackass for a man, they turned up their noses, and jeered at their leader, saying he had not brought a servant for them, but a husband for himself.
tgt_text.2687: " Mind," said they, " you don't keep this pretty dear all to yourself, but let us too, your doves, have the use of him sometimes."
tgt_text.2688: Thus babbling, they took and tied me to the manger.
tgt_text.2689: There was among them a strapping young fellow, who played extremely well on the horn, and whom they had bought at the slave mart, with the money they had collected here and there.
tgt_text.2690: Abroad he used to play before them when they led the goddess in procession, and at home they employed him in other ways.
tgt_text.2691: As soon as he witnessed my arrival, he was greatly delighted, and gave me plenty of fodder, joyfully exclaiming:
tgt_text.2692: " You are come at last to relieve me in my terrible labours ;
tgt_text.2693: long may you live, and be a pleasure to your masters, and give me a chance to recruit my exhausted strength.”
tgt_text.2694: Hearing him talk thus, I pondered on the new troubles that were before me.
tgt_text.2695: Next day they went out, all dressed in various colours, hideously bedizened, their faces and eyelids daubed with paint, with small mitres on their heads, and wearing saffron-coloured linen and silk vestments.
tgt_text.2696: Some of them had white tunics, covered with narrow purple stripes in all directions;
tgt_text.2697: and they all wore girdles and yellow shoes.
tgt_text.2698: They laid the goddess, covered with a silk mantle, on my back;
tgt_text.2699: and brandishing enormous swords and axes, with their arms bared to the shoul­ der, they danced and bounded like maniacs to the sound of the flute.
tgt_text.2700: After going about a good many cottages, they came to a rich man's villa, and setting up their yells at the very gate, they rushed frantically in.
tgt_text.2701: Bending down their heads, they rolled their necks about, making their long hair stand out in a circle;
tgt_text.2702: from time to time they bit their flesh with their teeth, and lastly, they cut their arms with the sharp weapon which each of them carried.
tgt_text.2703: There was one of them who was trans­ ported with a more ecstatic fury than the rest, and heaving his breath rapidly from the bottom of his chest, as if filled with the divine spirit, he pretended to be stark mad;
tgt_text.2704: as if the pre­ sence of the gods did not do men good, but weakened or disor­ dered them.
tgt_text.2705: But you shall see how by divine providence tney received their due reward.
tgt_text.2706: The fellow began by delivering a trumped-up story of his own guilt, and crying out aloud, in the tone of a prophet, that he had committed some offence against the holy laws of religion;
tgt_text.2707: and then he called upon his hands to inflict on.
tgt_text.2708: him the chastisement due to his crime.
tgt_text.2709: At the same time he took up one of the whips usually carried by those half men, with several long lashes of twisted wool, strung with knuckle-bones of sheep, and gave himself a severe flog­ ging, the pain of which he endured with astonishing firmness.
tgt_text.2710: You might see the ground wet with the blood that flowed from the gashes of the sword and the strokes of the whip.
tgt_text.2711: Now the sight of all this blood and wounds caused me no slight uneasiness, lest perchance the stomach of the foreign goddess might crave for ass's blood, as some men's for ass's milk.
tgt_text.2712: When at last they were tired, or thought they had scarified themselves sufficiently, they left off their butchery.
tgt_text.2713: Then the byestanders vied with each other in dropping money, not only brass, but silver too, into the open bosom of their robes.
tgt_text.2714: They received, besides, a barrel of wine, milk, cheese, barley, and wheaten meal, besides barley for myself, the bearer of the god­ dess.
tgt_text.2715: All these things they stuffed into bags provided for the receipt of such doles, and laid them on my back;
tgt_text.2716: so that being doubly laden, I was at once a walking temple and a walking granary.
tgt_text.2717: Roaming about in that manner, they plundered the whole region.
tgt_text.2718: One day, being highly pleased with an unusually large col­ lection they made in a certain town, they resolved to regale themselves and be merry.
tgt_text.2719: They begged a very fat ram from a farmer, whom they cajoled with a lying prophecy, and told him they would sacrifice it to appease the hunger of the Syrian goddess.
tgt_text.2720: Having made all their preparations for the banquet, they went to the baths, and on their return they brought a remarkably vigorous peasant home with them to supper.
tgt_text.2721: They had only tasted a few morsels of the first course, when they started up from table, and gathering round the young man, began to assail him with execrable solicitations.
tgt_text.2722: Unable to endure the abominable spectacle, I tried to shout.
tgt_text.2724: but could not get beyond the 0, which I uttered in a fine sonorous tone, well becoming a jackass, but very un­ luckily timed.
tgt_text.2725: For several young men, who were looking for an ass that had been stolen the night before, and who were closely examining all the inns to see if the animal was not in one of them, happening to hear me bray, and thinking it might be their own ass that was hidden in the house, rushed in un­ expectedly, and caught these miscreants in the very midst of their detestable turpitudes.
tgt_text.2726: Instantly calling in the neigh­ bours from all quarters, they made them aware of the horrible discovery, bestowing at the same time sarcastic compliments on the sanctimonious purity of those priests.
tgt_text.2727: Struck with consternation at this disclosure of their infamy, which spread rapidly among the people, and made them objects of universal abhorrence, my masters packed up every thing, and secretly quitted the town about midnight.
tgt_text.2728: After getting over a good deal of ground before dawn, and arrived by daylight in an unfrequented spot, they held a long consultation, which ended in their proceeding to punish me unmercifully.
tgt_text.2729: They lifted the goddess off my back, and laid her on the ground, stripped off all my trappings, tied me to a tree, and flogged me with their whip strung with sheep's bones until I was all but dead.
tgt_text.2730: There was one who proposed to hamstring me with an axe, because I had so foully scan­ dalised his modesty;
tgt_text.2731: but the others voted for leaving me alone, not from any good will to me, but in consideration of the image that lay on the ground.
tgt_text.2732: They replaced my load therefore on my back, and drove me before them with blows of the flat of their swords, till we are rived at a great town.
tgt_text.2733: One of its principal inhabitants, a very religious man, who had a great reverence for the gods, hearing the tinkling of the cymbals, the beating of the timbrels, and the soft Phrygian music, came to meet us, and offer his devout hospitality to the goddess.
tgt_text.2734: He lodged us all within his fine spacious mansion, and sought to win the divine favour by the most profound veneration and the finest victimsHere it was that my life was exposed to the greatest danger I ever remember to have incurred.
tgt_text.2735: A certain person in the country had sent as a present to our host, who was his land­ lord, the haunch of a very large and fat stag he had killed in the chase.
tgt_text.2736: It had been carelessly hung rather low behind the kitchen door, where a hound seized it, and carried it off.
tgt_text.2737: When the cook discovered his loss, which he imputed to his own negligence, his lamentation was extreme, and for a long time he shed unavailing tears, thinking that his master would pre­ sently call for hIs supper.
tgt_text.2738: Terrified at last at the punishment that awaited him, he tenderly kissed his little son, snatched up a rope, and set about hanging himself.
tgt_text.2739: But his affectionate wife became opportunely aware of his desperate case, and seizing the fatal noose in both hands with all her might, “What,” she cried, "has this accident frightened you.
tgt_text.2741: Do you not see the remedy which the providence of the gods has offered to your hands ?
tgt_text.2742: If you have any sense left in this whirlwind of disaster, rouse it up and listen to me.
tgt_text.2743: Take that ass, that was brought here to-day, to some out-of-the-way place, and cut his throat;
tgt_text.2744: then take from the carcase a haunch just like that which is lost, cook it nicely, dress it with the most savoury sauce you can make, and serve it up before your mas­ ter, instead of the venison.
tgt_text.2745: "The rascally cook was delighted at the thought of saving his own life at the cost of mine ;
tgt_text.2746: and highly extolling his wife's sagacity, he set about sharpening his knives, to execute the butchery she had recommended.
tgt_text.2747: THUS did that cursed butcher arm his nefarious hands against me.
tgt_text.2748: There was no time to be lost;
tgt_text.2749: the danger was too urgent to allow of long cogitation;
tgt_text.2750: I resolved to escape by flight from the knife that was so near my throat, and instantly breaking the halter with which I was tied, I galloped away as fast as my legs could carry me, flinging out my heels as I ran for the greater safety.
tgt_text.2751: Having quickly shot across the first portico, I dashed without hesitation into the dining-room, where the master of the house was feasting with the priests of the god­ dess on the sacrificial meats ;
tgt_text.2752: and I upset and smashed great part of the supper things, and even the tables.
tgt_text.2753: The master of the house, greatly annoyed by such unseemly havoc, ordered one of his servants to take away “the troublesome, frisky brute," as he called me, and gave the man strict injunctions to shut me up in some safe place, that I might not again dis­ turb the quiet of his guests by such pranks.
tgt_text.2754: For my part, having saved myself from the knife by this clever feat, I was very glad to enjoy the security of my prison.
tgt_text.2755: But certainly it is not for mortal man to prosper against the will of fortune, nor can all the contrivances of human wisdom overthrow or alter the fatal disposition of divine providence.*
tgt_text.2756: That very device of mine, which seemed to have afforded me a momentary deliverance, brought upon me another peril, which went near to cause my instant destruction;
tgt_text.2757: for one of the servants, as I afterwards learned from what passed between his fellows, rushed in great agitation into the supper-room, and told his master that a mad dog had just before run into the house through a back door, opening on a lane;
tgt_text.2758: that he had fallen furiously on the hounds;
tgt_text.2759: then made for the stables, where he had wreaked his rage on the horses;
tgt_text.2760: and lastly, that he had not spared the men either, for he had bitten Myrtilus, the muleteer, Hephæstion, the cook, Hypatius, the chamber- lain, and Apollonius, the physician, besides a great many other servants who had endeavoured to drive him out;
tgt_text.2761: and some of the animals he had bitten, already showed undoubted symptoms of rabidness.
tgt_text.2762: The whole party was struck with dismay at this intelligence, and guessing from my wild behaviour, that I was infected with the same malady, they caught up such weapons as lay at hand, and exhorted each other to despatch me for their com­ mon safety, though, in fact, it was they themselves who were mad, and not I.
tgt_text.2763: They would doubtless have cut me to pieces with the lances, spears, and even axes, with which the servants readily supplied them, had I not run before the storm, and burst into the bed-chamber of the priests, my masters.
tgt_text.2764: My pursuers then fastened the door upon me, and kept me be­ sieged, that the deadly virus might do its work, and destroy me, without their running the risk of coming in contact with me.
tgt_text.2765: Finding, therefore, that I was left alone and free to do as I pleased, I profited by the opportunity which fortune offered me, lay down on a bed, and enjoyed what I had so long foregone, a good sleep in human fashion.
tgt_text.2766: Having slept off my fatigue on that good bed, I awoke when it was already broad daylight, and jumped up fresh and hearty.
tgt_text.2767: Then I heard the people who had kept watch all night outside the door, thus debating with one another about me.
tgt_text.2769: Is it likely that this unfortunate ass can go on raging everlastingly ?
tgt_text.2771: It is rather to be presumed that the virus has spent itself, and his fit is over."
tgt_text.2772: As their opi­ nions differed on this question, they agreed to have a look at me;
tgt_text.2773: and peeping through a chink in the door, they saw me standing at my ease, apparently as quiet and as well as ever.
tgt_text.2774: Thereupon, they ventured to open the door and examine my state more fully;
tgt_text.2775: and one of them, who was sent from heaven to be my saviour, proposed to the rest a means of knowing whether I was mad or not.
tgt_text.2776: This was to put a vessel full of fresh water before me;
tgt_text.2777: if I drank it without hesitation, in my usual way, this would be a sure proof that I was quite free from all distemper;
tgt_text.2778: on the contrary, if I shunned the water with manifest horror at the sight of it, it would be a clear case that the dreadful malady had still fast hold of me ;
tgt_text.2779: for so it was laid down in ancient books, and confirmed by frequent experience.
tgt_text.2780: This advice being voted good, they forthwith fetched a large vessel full of fine clear water from the nearest fountain, and placed it before me, still keeping on their guard.
tgt_text.2781: I went up to it at once, being very thirsty, and plunging my head into the vessel, drank up the water, which truly did me much good in every way.
tgt_text.2782: Then I quietly suffered them to pat me with their hands, rub my ears, lead me by the headstall, and do whatever else they pleased by way of trying me, until they were all convinced of my gentleness, and of their own mistake in supposing me to be mad.
tgt_text.2783: Having thus preserved myself from two great dangers, I was again loaded next day with the divine baggage, and marched away to the sound of cymbals and castanets, to con­ tinue our mendicant rounds.
tgt_text.2784: After visiting a great number of hamlets and towns, we arrived at a village built on the ruins of a town that had formerly been very opulent, as the inhab­ itants reported.
tgt_text.2785: We entered the first inn we came to, and there we heard a pleasant story of the way in which the wife of a poor man cuckolded her husband:
tgt_text.2786: and you shall hear it too.
tgt_text.2787: THERE was a poor man who had nothing to subsist on but his scanty earnings as a journeyman carpenter.
tgt_text.2788: He had a wife who was also very poor, but notorious for her lasciviousness.
tgt_text.2789: One day, when the man had gone out betimes to his work, an impudent gallant immediately stepped into his house.
tgt_text.2790: But whilst he and the wife were warmly engaged, and thinking themselves secure, the husband, who had no suspicion of such doings, returned quite unexpectedly.
tgt_text.2791: The door being locked and bolted, for which he mentally extolled his well-conducted wife, he knocked and whistled to announce his presence.
tgt_text.2792: Then his cunning wife, who was quite expert in such matters, released the man from her close embraces, and hid him quickly in an old empty butt, that was sunk half-way in the ground, in a corner of the room.
tgt_text.2793: Then she opened the door, and began to scold her husband the moment he entered.
tgt_text.2795: So you are come home empty-handed, are you?” said she, "to sit here with your arms folded, doing nothing, instead of going on with your regular work, to get us a living and buy us a bit of food;
tgt_text.2796: while I, poor soul, must work my fingers out of joint, spinning wool day and night, to have at least as much as will keep a lamp burning in our bit of a room.
tgt_text.2797: Ah, how much better off is my neighbour Daphne, that has her fill of meat and drink from daylight to dark, and enjoys herself with her lovers.""
tgt_text.2798: What need of all this fuss ?" replied the abused husband;
tgt_text.2799: for though our foreman has given us a holiday, having busi­ ness of his own in the forum, I have nevertheless provided for our supper to-night.
tgt_text.2800: You see that useless butt, that takes up so much room, and is only an incumbrance to our little place;
tgt_text.2801: I sold it for five denars to a man who will be here presently to pay for it and take it away.
tgt_text.2802: So lend me a hand for a mo­ ment, till I get it out to deliver it to the buyer.
tgt_text.2803: "Ready at once with a scheme to fit the occasion, the woman burst into an insolent laugh :
tgt_text.2805: Truly I have got a fine fel­ low for a husband;
tgt_text.2806: a capital hand at a bargain, surely, to go and sell at such a price a thing which I, who am but a woman, had already sold for seven denars, without even quitting the house.
tgt_text.2808: And who is he," said the husband, “who has bought it so dear ?
tgt_text.2810: “He has been down in the cask ever so long, you booby," she replied, " examining it all over to see if it is sound.
tgt_text.2811: "The gallant failed not to take his cue from the woman, and promptly rising up out of the butt, “ Shall I tell you the truth, good woman?" he said;
tgt_text.2812: " your tub is very old, and cracked in I don't know how many places."
tgt_text.2813: Then turning to the hus­ band, without appearing to know him:
tgt_text.2814: " Why don't you bring me a light, my tight little fellow, whoever you are, that I may scrape off the dirt from the inside, and see whether or not the tub is fit for use, unless you think I don't come honestly by my money ?
tgt_text.2815: "That pattern of all quick-witted husbands, suspecting no­ thing, immediately lighted a lamp, and said, " Come out, bro­ ther, and leave me to make it all right for you."
tgt_text.2816: So saying, he stripped, and taking the lamp with him into the tub, went to work to scrape off the old hardened dirt.
tgt_text.2817: And while he was polishing the inside, the charming gallant polished off the carpenter's wife, laying her on her belly on the outside, she meanwhile amusing herself, like a harlot as she was, with making fan of her husband, poking her head into the tub, and pointing out this place and that to be cleaned, and then another, and another;
tgt_text.2818: until both jobs being finished, the unfortunate carpenter received his seven denars, and had to carry the butt on Iris back to the adulterer's house.
tgt_text.2820: After staying a few days in this town, where they were pampered by the bounty of the public, and made a great deal by their soothsaying, these pious priests bethought them of a new device for getting money.
tgt_text.2821: They composed a single oracular response, which would fit a variety of cases, and thus they gulled a great number of persons who came to consult them upon all sorts of subjects.
tgt_text.2823: The steers are yoked, and till the ground, That crops may rise, and joys abound.
tgt_text.2824: *Suppose now that a person consulted the oracle with regard to his marrying:
tgt_text.2825: to him it said plainly that he should take upon him the yoke of matrimony, and raise a fine crop of chil­ dren.
tgt_text.2826: Suppose it was one who had a mind to buy land:
tgt_text.2827: the yoked oxen and the abundant harvests were quite to the point.
tgt_text.2828: If the applicant was anxious about a journey he had to take:
tgt_text.2829: the meekest of quadrupeds were ready yoked, and the produce of the soil signified a lucrative result.
tgt_text.2830: If he was one who had to go into battle, or to pursue a gang of robbers:
tgt_text.2831: the priests declared that the oracle promised him victory, and that he should bring the necks of his enemies under the yoke, and reap a rich harvest of bootyMy masters had gained no little money by this cheating method of divination;
tgt_text.2832: but exhausted at last by perpetual in­ terrogations for which they had but one answer, they again departed by a road much worse than that which we had tra- yelled the preceding night.
tgt_text.2833: The greater part of it was broken up into deep ruts and holes full of water, and the rest was co­ vered with thick mud and very slippery.
tgt_text.2834: At last, greatly fatigued, and with my legs bruised by continually slipping and falling, I had just reached a smooth bit of ground, when sud­ denly a body of armed men on horseback galloped down upon us, and after pulling up with difficulty, seized Philebus and his companions by the throat, and beat them with their fists, calling them sacrilegious, obscene villains.
tgt_text.2835: Then they hand­ cuffed them all, and bellowed to them to produce the golden bowl they had stolen.
tgt_text.2836: "Produce," they shouted, "that proof of your crime, which you filched from the very shrine of the Mother of the Gods, when you shut yourselves up in her tem­ ple, under pretence of solemnizing secret rites;
tgt_text.2837: and then you quitted the town before daylight without saying a word to any one, as if you thought you could escape punishment for such abominable guilt."
tgt_text.2838: Meanwhile, one of them searching the goddess I carried on my back, found the gold cup in her bosom, and drew it forth in the eight of all present.
tgt_text.2839: But even that palpable evidence could not abash or dismay those nefarious wretches, but affecting to laugh, and to turn the affair into a joke, they exclaimed:
tgt_text.2841: How often the innocent are put in jeopardy!
tgt_text.2842: Here are ministers of religion put in peril of their lives only for a cup which the Mother of the Gods made a present to her sister, the Syrian Goddess, as a pledge of hospitality."
tgt_text.2843: But in spite of all such frivolous excuses, the rustics marched them back, and lodged them in prison;
tgt_text.2844: and the cup and the image I had carried having been solemnly deposited in the temple, I was brought forth on the following day, and again offered for sale by the voice of the crier.
tgt_text.2845: A certain baker from the next town bought me for seven denars more than Philebus had given for me;
tgt_text.2846: and putting on my back a good load of corn he had just bought, he took me to his mill by a very rough road, full of stones and roots of trees.
tgt_text.2847: There were a good many beasts employed there, in turning several millstones, and that not only by day, but all night long too, for the mill was always kept going.
tgt_text.2848: Lest I should be disgusted with the beginning of my servitude, my new master treated me with all the honours due to a stranger of consider­ ation, and I had a holiday, and a manger abundantly supplied;
tgt_text.2849: but the beatitude of having nothing to do and plenty to eat did not last beyond the first day.
tgt_text.2850: On the following day, I was fastened up to turn what seemed to me the largest mill­ stone of all, and with my head covered I was put into a little hollow path in the form of a circle, in which I was to go round and round perpetually.
tgt_text.2851: But I had not so far forgotten my old cunning as to fall in easily with this new discipline;
tgt_text.2852: and though when I was a man I had often seen machines of that kind re­ volve, yet, as if I was quite a novice at the work, and did not know what to do, I stood stock still, pretending stupefaction.
tgt_text.2853: I imagined that when they saw I was not fit for the work, they would put me to something else that was less fatiguing, or that they would let me eat and do nothing.
tgt_text.2854: But my craft, instead of doing me good, only brought me into trouble.
tgt_text.2855: For several men armed with sticks came round me while I suspected no­ thing, for my head was covered and I could not see ;
tgt_text.2856: and at a given signal they all shouted out together, and let fall upon me a storm of blows.
tgt_text.2857: I was so terrified by the uproar, that, abandoning all thoughts of trickery, and pulling at the trace with all my might, I paced the ring nimbly, and excited a general burst of laughter by my.
tgt_text.2859: The day was near its end, I was very tired, when they loosed the rush ropes that fastened me to the mill, and let me go to the manger.
tgt_text.2860: Though exhausted with fatigue and hunger, and in great need of having my strength recruited, yet prompted by my natural curiosity, I neglected the food that was before me to observe with a sort of pleasure the economy of our detest­ able work-place.
tgt_text.2862: what a set of stunted men I saw there!
tgt_text.2863: Their skins were seamed all over with marks of the lash;
tgt_text.2864: their scarred backs were shaded rather than covered with tattered frocks;
tgt_text.2866: and all were so clothed, that their skin was visible through the rents in their rags.
tgt_text.2867: Their foreheads were branded with letters ;
tgt_text.2869: they had irons on their legs;
tgt_text.2871: their eyes were bleared, and sore and raw from the smoke of the ovens;
tgt_text.2872: * and they were covered with flour, as athletes are with dust when they contend in the arena.
tgt_text.2873: But how shall I describe my brute companions?
tgt_text.2874: What worn-out old mules and geldings !
tgt_text.2875: How they hung their heads at the manger as they chewed the heaps of straw!
tgt_text.2876: Their necks were covered with putrid sores;
tgt_text.2877: they coughed incessantly, and panted through their gaping nostrils;
tgt_text.2878: their chests were raw from the friction of the rush breast rope ;
tgt_text.2879: their flanks laid open to the bone with continual cudgelling;
tgt_text.2880: their hoofs lengthened to an extraordinary degree by dint of walking in the mill round;
tgt_text.2881: and their hides were rough all over with mange.
tgt_text.2882: Beholding the wretched plight of those animals, whom I myself might be brought to resemble, and recollecting my own happy fortune when I was Lucius, I hung my head and sorrowed over the deep degradation into which I had fallen.
tgt_text.2883: The only consolation I had was in the pleasure of indulging my inborn curiosity, by observing all that was said and done around me without reserve, for no one took any account of my presence.
tgt_text.2884: Truly, it was with good reason that the divine author of the ancient Greek epos, wishing to depict a man of consummate wisdom and prudence, sang of one who had visited many cities and become acquainted with many peoples.*
tgt_text.2885: I myself hold my asinine days in grateful remembrance, be­ cause, being hidden under that form, I went through a great number of adventures, which made me acquainted with many things, if they have not rendered me wiser.
tgt_text.2886: Thus I picked up an excellent story, which particularly interested me, and which you shall hear.
tgt_text.2887: The baker who had bought me was a worthy, well-conducted man, but suffered the most cruel domestic affliction in conse­ quence of having to wife the wickedest of all women;
tgt_text.2888: inso­ much, that even I often groaned in secret over his sad lot.
tgt_text.2889: There was not one vice from which that nefarious woman was free;
tgt_text.2890: but every kind of iniquity had flowed into her soul, as into a cesspool for the reception of all uncleanness.
tgt_text.2891: She was mischievous, malignant, addicted to men and to wine, froward and stubborn, vilely rapacious, unbounded in profusion, a foe to faith and chastity.
tgt_text.2892: Moreover, despising and trampling under foot the majesty of heaven, instead of the true religion, she affected to entertain some fantastic and sacrilegious notion of a God whom she declared to be the only one,† and under pretence of certain frivolous observances with which she im­ posed upon the public and beguiled her unfortunate husband, she got drunk in the morning, and prostituted her body at all hours.
tgt_text.2893: This woman persecuted me with amazing rancour.
tgt_text.2894: For before the dawn of morning, as she lay still in bed, she used to call out and bid them yoke the new ass to the mill;
tgt_text.2895: as soon as she was up she used to order me to be drubbed without stint in her presence ;
tgt_text.2896: and when the cattle were unyoked at breakfast-time, she would order me to be kept from the manger long after the rest.
tgt_text.2897: These cruelties greatly whetted my natu­ ral curiosity to scrutinize her behaviour.
tgt_text.2898: I perceived that a certain young fellow was continually going into her room, and I greatly longed to catch sight of his face, if the covering put on my head had only allowed me the use of my eyes;
tgt_text.2899: in that case I should not have wanted sagacity enough to discover in some way or other the criminal proceedings of the abandoned woman.
tgt_text.2900: A certain old woman, who was her confidante, and the go- between in her intrigues, was with her every day from morn- in- to night.
tgt_text.2901: After breakfasting together, they used to sit and drink neat wine as if for a wager, all the while devising schemes to cheat the unfortunate husband.
