tgt_text.2902: Now, though I was greatly vexed at the blunder committed by Fotis, who had made an ass of me when intending to change me into a bird, yet I had at least this comfort in my lamentable deformity, that being furnished with very long ears, I could hear what was said even at a great distance.
tgt_text.2903: One day, for example, I heard the squeaking old woman talk as follows :
tgt_text.2904: “Make up your mind, mistress, what you will do with that pluckless acquaintance you chose without consulting me, a coward that shudders at the grim frown of your sour and odious husband, and torments you by the laggard weakness of his love, that corresponds so ill with your own warmth.
tgt_text.2905: What a different man is Philesietæros!
tgt_text.2906: young, handsome, generous, met­ tlesome, and more than a match for all the useless vigilance of husbands.
tgt_text.2908: he is the only man that deserves to enjoy the embraces of all the ladies of quality, he alone de­ serves to be crowned with gold, if it was only for that capital trick he lately played on a jealous husband.
tgt_text.2909: Listen, now, and see the difference between such a man and your lover.
tgt_text.2910: You know one Barbarus, the decurion* of our town, whom the people nickname Scorpion, on account of his peevish, spiteful disposition.
tgt_text.2911: He has a wife of a good family, and surpassing beauty, whom he keeps shut up at home with all the caution imaginable.
tgt_text.2913: "To be sure," said the miller's wife, "I know her very well.
tgt_text.2915: ""Then you know the whole story about Philesietærus?” rejoined the old woman."
tgt_text.2916: Not at all," replied the other;
tgt_text.2917: but I long to hear it, so tell it all, mother, from beginning to end."
tgt_text.2918: Accordingly, the qld woman, who was an interminable chatterer, began as fol­ lows :
tgt_text.2920: THIS Barbarus, being obliged to go a journey which he could not avoid, and wishing to take all possible measures to keep his dear wife faithful to him, secretly communicated his inten­ tions to his slave Myrmex, the one in whom he had most con­ fidence, and ordered him to watch over the conduct of his mis­ tress, threatening him with chains, and prison, and starvation, and a torturing death to end all, if any man so much as touched her with the tip of his finger as he passed her in the street;
tgt_text.2921: and all these threats he confirmed with the most solemn oaths.
tgt_text.2922: Having thus left Myrmex terribly frightened and disposed to keep a most vigilant watch over his wife, Barbarus set out on his journey without fear of bad consequences."
tgt_text.2923: Intensely anxious about his charge, Myrmex would never let his mistress go out alone.
tgt_text.2924: He kept her shut up all day spinning wool, always under his own eye;
tgt_text.2925: and when it was necessary for her to go in the evening to the public baths, he went with her, sticking like glue to her side, and holding the skirt of her robe in his hand, so wonderfully awake was he to all the duties of his trust."
tgt_text.2926: But the beauty of the lady could not escape one who was so keen-sighted in matters of gallantry as was Philesietærus;
tgt_text.2927: but what piqued and incited him above all things, was the repute of her impregnable virtue, and the extraordinary care with which it was guarded.
tgt_text.2928: He resolved, then, to lay siege with all his might to the house in which she was immured, and to make his way in at all costs and hazards, in spite of its commander's vigorous discipline.
tgt_text.2929: And knowing well the frailty of human nature, and that gold can smooth down all difficul­ ties, and break open adamantine gates, he addressed himself to Myrmex, whom he fortunately met alone, told him of his love for his mistress, and conjured him to afford some remedy for his torments;
tgt_text.2930: assuring him that his speedy death was certain, if his desires were not quickly fulfilled.
tgt_text.2931: 'Besides,' said he, ' you have nothing to fear in so easy a matter as that which I ask of you;
tgt_text.2932: since no more is required than that I should steal into your house alone, under cover of darkness, and remain there only a moment.'
tgt_text.2933: These insinuating arguments he fol­ lowed by the application of a wedge that was well adapted to cleave asunder the stubborn toughness of the servant's resolu­ tion ;
tgt_text.2934: for holding out a handful of shining gold coin fresh from the mint, he told him that twenty of them were for the lady, and that ten of them should be freely at his own service."
tgt_text.2935: Terrified at the stupendous proposal, Myrmex took to his heels at once, without listening to another word.
tgt_text.2936: But he could not get the lustre of the yellow gold out of his sight;
tgt_text.2937: and though he had left it behind, and had never stopped running till he got home, he still seemed to behold the beautiful coin, and clutched it in imagination.
tgt_text.2938: Miserably was the poor fellow distracted between opposite feelings:
tgt_text.2939: he thought of the fidelity he owed his master, and then of his own gain;
tgt_text.2940: the fear of horrible punishment made him hang back;
tgt_text.2941: the bewitching thought of that money lured him on.
tgt_text.2942: At last the gold prevailed over the fear of death, and time by no means allayed his longing for that lovely coin;
tgt_text.2943: it clung to him like a pestilence even through the anxious night;
tgt_text.2944: so that while his master's threats would have detained him at home, yet the gold irresistibly summoned him abroad.
tgt_text.2945: Gulping down all shame, therefore, he went straightway to his mistress, and de­ livered his message from Philesietærus;
tgt_text.2946: and she, a wanton born, at once sold her virtue for cursed metal.
tgt_text.2947: So Myrmex, deluged with joy at the wreck of his fidelity, and eager to finger the gold which it was his ill fate to have seen, went in quest of Philesietærus, and told him that at last, with great difficulty, he had effected his wishes.
tgt_text.2948: Then he asked on the epot for the promised recompense, and suddenly found himself possessed of a handful of gold coin, he who had never in his life been master of a copper.
tgt_text.2949: “When night was come, he conducted the bold gallant, alone and with his face well muffled, to the house, and into his mistress's chamber.
tgt_text.2950: But just as the pair were paying their first adorations to Love, just as the naked recruits in the war­ fare of Venus were performing their first service, the husband, who had chosen that time of night on purpose, arrived sud­ denly at the moment when he was least expected.
tgt_text.2951: He knocked, he called, he pounded at the door with a stone, and growing more and more suspicious in consequence of the delay, he threat­ ened terrible vengeance against Myrmex, who was so bewildered by the sudden calamity that he knew not what to do, and could only excuse himself by saying that the darkness'of the night had hindered him from finding the key, which he had hidden with great care.
tgt_text.2952: Meanwhile, Philesietærus, alarmed, by the noise, hastily put on his clothes, and ran out of the bedroom, but forgot in his confusion to thrust his feet into his shoes.“
tgt_text.2953: Then Myrmex put the key in the lock and let in his mas­ ter, who was still bawling and swearing with all his might;
tgt_text.2954: and whilst the latter hurried to his chamber, Myrmex let Phi­ lesietærus slip out unperceived, shut the door behind him, and went back to his bed with his mind quite at ease.
tgt_text.2955: But when Barbarus got up in the morning, he saw a strange pair of shoes under the bed ;
tgt_text.2956: and instantly suspecting what had happened, but saying not a word to his wife or any of the servants, he took up the shoes unobserved and hid them in his bosom;
tgt_text.2957: then ordering Myrmex to be bound and marched off to the forum, he went thither himself, groaning inwardly, and assuring him­ self he should trace out the adulterer by means of the shoes."
tgt_text.2958: As Barbarus walked along the street with lowering brows and a face swollen with rage, Myrmex followed him in chains.
tgt_text.2959: He had not, indeed, been taken in the fact, but overwhelmed by a guilty conscience, he cried and lamented, so as to excite the useless compassion of the beholders.
tgt_text.2960: Philesietærus hap­ pened very opportunely to pass that way, and though he had business which called him elsewhere, yet being forcibly struck, but not dismayed, by the spectacle that suddenly came before him, he recollected the mistake he had made in his haste, and immediately inferring all the consequences, he acted on the spot with his usual cleverness and presence of mind.
tgt_text.2961: Pushing aside the other servants, he rushed upon Myrmex, bawling at him with all his might, and hitting him on the face with his fists, but so as not to hurt him much :
tgt_text.2962: ' Villain and liar !' he cried, 'may your master and all the gods, by whose names you forswear yourself, punish you as such a rascal deserves !
tgt_text.2963: You that stole my shoes yesterday from the bath.
tgt_text.2964: You de­ serve, by Hercules, to have those chains upon you until they are worn out, and to be shut up for ever in the darkness of a dungeon.'"
tgt_text.2965: Completely duped and befooled by the ready-witted strata­ gem of the bold youth, Barbarus went back to his house, called Myrmex before him, and putting the shoes into his hands, for­ gave him with all his heart, and advised him to return them to their owner from whom he had stolen them.
tgt_text.2968: No sooner had the old woman ended her story, than the baker's wife cried out:
tgt_text.2969: " Happy is the woman who has such a stout-hearted lover as that;
tgt_text.2970: while I, poor thing, have got one that trembles at the mere sound of the mill, and even at the hoodwinked face of that mangy ass.""
tgt_text.2971: Never mind," said the old woman. " I will engage to bring you this brisk lad presently, well inclined, and in good courage."
tgt_text.2972: Then, having arranged to return in the evening, she went away.
tgt_text.2973: The chaste wife forthwith set about preparing a banquet fit for priests.
tgt_text.2974: She filtered choice wine, made fresh savoury ra­ gouts, and furnished out an abundant table.
tgt_text.2975: In short, she made ready for her paramour's arrival as for that of some god;
tgt_text.2976: for it happened conveniently for her, that her husband supped abroad with his neighbour the fuller.
tgt_text.2977: The hour of noon hav­ ing arrived, I was released from the mill, and let go to feed;
tgt_text.2978: but what pleased me most was, not that I had a respite from drudgery, but that having my head uncovered and the free use of my eyes, I could watch all the doings of that wicked wo­ man.
tgt_text.2979: At last, when the sun had sunk beneath the ocean to illuminate the inferior zones of the earth, in came the bold gallant alongside of the wicked old hag.
tgt_text.2980: He was quite young, with smooth blooming cheeks, and very handsome.
tgt_text.2981: The miller's wife received him with all sorts of caresses, and the supper being ready, she made him take his place at the table.
tgt_text.2982: But scarcely had he put his lips to the preparatory potion, taken by way of a whet, when the husband was heard return­ ing much sooner than he had been expected.
tgt_text.2983: Thereupon, his exemplary wife, heaping all sorts of curses upon him, and wishing he had broken his legs, hid the pale and trembling youth under a bin for sifting corn which happened to be at hand;
tgt_text.2984: then, with a face of perfect composure, she asked her husband why he had so soon quitted the entertainment of his crony, and returned home.
tgt_text.2985: The miller, who seemed greatly distressed, replied, with a sigh:
tgt_text.2986: "I hurried away because I could not endure the abo­ minable guilt of his abandoned wife.
tgt_text.2988: what a faithful, well-conducted matron she seemed, and how infa­ mously she has disgraced herself!
tgt_text.2989: I swear by yonder sacred Ceres, that even yet I can hardly believe the evidence of my own eyes against such a woman.
tgt_text.2990: "The miller's impudent wife hearing her husband talk thus, and being curious to hear the whole story, pressed him to re­ late all that had happened;
tgt_text.2991: and never ceased importuning him until he yielded, and began to relate to her the disgrace of his neighbour's house, while he yet knew not of his own."
tgt_text.2992: THE wife of my old comrade, the fuller," said he, "who appeared a very honest woman, and bore the best character, and seemed to manage her husband's house with great propriety, fell in love with a certain man, and as they saw each other frequently in secret, it happened that when the fuller and I returned from the baths to supper, the pair were then in the very act."
tgt_text.2993: Startled and confused by our sudden arrival, the woman could do no better on the instant than hide her paramour under a very high wicker cage, hung round with cloths, which were exposed there to the bleaching fumes of sulphur burned be­ neath them.
tgt_text.2994: Having thus concealed him, quite safely as she thought, she came and sat down with us to supper.
tgt_text.2995: Mean­ while, the young man was obliged to breathe the suffocating vapour of the sulphur;
tgt_text.2996: and, according to the usual effect of that acrid and penetrating mineral, he was forced to sneeze re­ peatedly.
tgt_text.2997: The husband, who was opposite his wife at table, hearing the sound that came from behind her, thought it was herself that sneezed, and said, ' Jove save you !' as usual on such occasions.
tgt_text.2998: This happened a second, a third, and many more times in succession;
tgt_text.2999: till at last, surprised at these endless sneezings, he began to suspect the real state of the case, and pushing aside the table, he upset the cage, and discovered the man, who lay panting for breath, and almost suffocated.
tgt_text.3000: “Transported with rage at the outrage done him, he shouted for his sword, and would have cut the throat of the half-dead wretch, had I not, with great difficulty, restrained him from an act which would have been perilous to us all, by assuring him that his enemy would soon die from the effect of the sulphurous fumes, without our making ourselves guilty of his death.
tgt_text.3001: Yielding not so much to my persuasions as to the necessity of the case, he dragged the half-lifeless young man into the next lane ;
tgt_text.3002: and then I pressed his wife, and at last prevailed upon her, to quit the house and take refuge with some of her friends, until time should have somewhat cooled her husband's boiling rage;
tgt_text.3003: for I made no doubt but that, in the furious exaspera­ tion he then exhibited, he would proceed to some desperate extremity against her and himself too.
tgt_text.3004: I had now had more than enough of my friend's entertainment, and so I returned home.
tgt_text.3007: Whilst the miller was telling this story, his wife, with un­ paralleled effrontery, broke out from time to time with invec­ tives and curses upon the fuller's wife, calling her a perfidious.
tgt_text.3008: wretch, a shameless strumpet, an opprobrium to her whole sex, to fling aside all sense of honour and decency;
tgt_text.3009: to trample on the obligations of the marriage-bed;
tgt_text.3010: to turn her husband's house into an infamous brothel;
tgt_text.3011: to have abandoned the dignity cf a married woman, and earned for herself the name of a prostitute.
tgt_text.3012: Such women, she said, ought to be burnt alive.
tgt_text.3013: Conscious, however, of her own secret guilt, she pressed her husband to go to bed early, that she might the sooner relieve her gallant from the misery of his confinement;
tgt_text.3014: but the miller having been disappointed of his supper at the fuller's, and having returned home hungry, requested her to have the table laid.
tgt_text.3015: She quickly served him up, but with anything but good will, the:
tgt_text.3016: supper she had provided for another.
tgt_text.3017: Meanwhile, my very entrails were racked when I thought of the late do­ ings and present effrontery of that abominable woman;
tgt_text.3018: and I pondered anxiously in my mind whether I could not find some means of doing a service to my master by disclosing her treachery;
tgt_text.3019: and whether I could not expose the young fellow to the eyes of every body, by upsetting the bin under which he was squatting like a tortoise.
tgt_text.3020: Whilst I was thus distracted by the thought of the outrage done my master, the providence of the gods came to my aid.
tgt_text.3021: For a lame old man, who had charge of the horses and other beasts of burthen, seeing it was the time to give us water, came to drive us all to the next pond.
tgt_text.3022: This afforded me a most favourable opportunity for vengeance.
tgt_text.3023: I noticed, as I passed, that the young gallant's fingers projected beyond the edge of the bin, and pressing the point of my hoof on them I squeezed them flat, so that yelling with the intolerable pain, and throwing off his cover, he stood manifest to every eye, and unmasked the falsehood of that libidinous woman.
tgt_text.3024: The miller did not seem greatly shocked by the disclosure of his wife's debauchery, but began with a mild and quiet countenance to reassure the lad, who trembled all over, and was pale as death. "
tgt_text.3025: Don't be afraid, my boy," he said;
tgt_text.3026: " I am not a barbarian, or a man of rough and savage ways.
tgt_text.3027: I will not smoke you to death with sulphur;
tgt_text.3028: nor will I put such a pretty boy as you into the hands of justice, to suffer the se­ vere penalties of the law against adultery.
tgt_text.3029: But I will come to an arrangement with my wife, not, however, for a division of property;
tgt_text.3030: no, I will rather make a partnership affair of it, so that, without any dispute or disagreement, we three may make ourselves comfortable in one bed.
tgt_text.3031: I have always lived with my wife on such harmonious terms, that, as became discreet people, what the one liked the other liked also.
tgt_text.3032: But common justice demands that the wife should not have more authority than the husband.
tgt_text.3033: "After quietly joking in this way, he made the unwilling youth go with him to his chamber, and shutting out his modest wife, he exacted what he thought a pleasant sort of vengeance for the wrong done to his bed.
tgt_text.3034: But when the sun had risen next morning, he called for two of the strongest of his work­ people, who hoisted the lad, while the miller himself flogged his buttocks with a rod.
tgt_text.3035: “What!” said he, "you, who are so soft and tender, a mere boy, you hanker after women, do you ?
tgt_text.3036: And nothing will suit you but women of free condition, that have got husbands;
tgt_text.3037: you have such a precocious longing for the reputation of an adulterer."
tgt_text.3038: After reprimanding him in this sort of way, and giving him a right good flogging, he thrust him out of doors.
tgt_text.3039: And thus did that most enterprising of all gallants escape far better than he had hoped for, but in woful plight and with aching buttocks.
tgt_text.3040: The baker, moreover, divorced his wife, and made her quit his house forthwith.
tgt_text.3041: Thereupon the woman's natural mali-,- nity being exasperated by this affront, however well deserved, she had recourse to her familiar weapons, and to the customary devices of women.
tgt_text.3042: She sought out with diligence a certain nefarious woman, who was believed to be able to do whatever she pleased by means of her enchantments and drugs ;
tgt_text.3043: her she loaded with presents, and importunately besought her to do one of two things :
tgt_text.3044: either to soften the heart of her husband, that he might be reconciled to her;
tgt_text.3045: or if that could not be done, to send at least some ghost, or some dire demoniacal power, to take away his life by violent means.
tgt_text.3046: Upon this, the witch, who was capable of exercising an influence upon the gods, employed at first only the milder resources of her wicked art, and endeavoured to influence the feelings of the husband that had been so seriously offended, and lead them back to their former affection.
tgt_text.3047: When, however, the result turned out to be quite different from what she had anticipated, being incensed with the gods, for the contempt with which they had treated her, as well as by the loss of the gain which was to have been hers, if she succeeded, she now began to level her attacks against the life of the unfortunate husband, and to stimulate to his destruction the ghost of a certain woman, who had met with a violent death.
tgt_text.3048: Perhaps, however, 0 scrupulous reader, you will carp at my story, and will reason as follows:
tgt_text.3049: “How is it possible, you silly ass, that you could know, as you say you did, what was done by women in secret, when at the very moment you were pent up within a bakehouse ?"
tgt_text.3050: Hear, then, how I, an inquisi­ tive man, wearing the shape of a beast of burden, came to know all that was transacted with a view to the destruction of my master, the baker.
tgt_text.3051: About midday there suddenly appeared in the bakehouse a woman of a hideous aspect, marked by guilt and extreme sor­ row ;
tgt_text.3052: she was half clad in a patched mourning mantle, her feet were naked, and her haggard face was sallow as boxwood.
tgt_text.3053: Her grizzly, dishevelled hair, defiled with ashes, hung over her forehead, and concealed the greater part of her face.
tgt_text.3054: This strange-looking woman, taking the baker gently by the hand, led him aside into his chamber, as if she had something to say to him in secret, and having shut the door, remained there a very long time.
tgt_text.3055: However, when all the wheat was ground which had been delivered out to the workmen, and it became necessary to get more, the servants went to the door of the chamber, and calling to their master, asked for more wheat for the mill.
tgt_text.3056: But as no master answered them, though they shouted to him again and again, they began to knock more loudly at the door.
tgt_text.3057: Finding, too, that it had been carefully bolted, they suspected something tragical had occurred, and making a violent effort, they tore the door off the hinges, and rushed in.
tgt_text.3058: The woman, however, was no where to be found, but they saw their master hanging lifeless from a beam.
tgt_text.3059: Loosening the rope from his neck, they took him down, and with great lamentations and weeping, bestowed upon the corpse the last ablution.
tgt_text.3060: Finally, having performed the customary offices for the dead, they committed him to the tomb, a great crowd attending the funeral.
tgt_text.3061: On the following day, his daughter came running from the neighbouring village, where she had lately been married, full of sorrow, shaking her dishevelled hair, and ever and anon beating her breasts with her hands.
tgt_text.3062: For she had discovered all that happened, although no one living had related to her the misfortune that had befallen the family;
tgt_text.3063: but the piteous form of her father had presented itself to her in her sleep, his neck still bound with the halter, and disclosed to her all the wickedness of her stepmother, her infidelity, the en­ chantment, and how he had been strangled by a ghost, and had descended to the realms below.
tgt_text.3064: After she had given way to long-continued lamentations, at last, being prevailed upon by the united entreaties of her friends and acquaintances, she put an end to her wailings.
tgt_text.3065: And now, the funeral solemnities being in the usual manner completed at the tomb, on the ninth day, she had the slaves, the furniture, and all the beasts of burden, brought forth to be sold by auction, for the benefit of the heiress.
tgt_text.3066: Then did capricious fortune, by the chance results of a sale, disperse in various ways the property of one house.
tgt_text.3067: A poor gardener made purchase of me for fifty pieces of money, which he said was a great price;
tgt_text.3068: but he paid it in order that he might procure subsistence for himself by our common labour.
tgt_text.3069: The occasion appears to me to require that I shoul I explain the nature of these services of mine.
tgt_text.3070: Every morning, my master was in the habit of leading me to the next city, with a heavy load of vegetables;
tgt_text.3071: and after he had sold them to the general dealers there, he returned to his garden, sitting on my back.
tgt_text.3072: Then, while he was digging and watering, and was busied with other laborious employments, I was left to take my ease, and refresh myself with silence and rest.
tgt_text.3074: the revolving year had now, after the autumn delights of the vintage, descended to the wintry frosts of Capricorn;
tgt_text.3075: * and then I was perished with continual cold, through the constant rains and the nightly dews, being exposed to the open air in a stable without a roof.
tgt_text.3076: For my master, in consequence of his extreme poverty, could not purchase even for himself, much less for me, any straw, or bed-clothes, his only protec­ tion from the cold being the thatch of his little cottage.
tgt_text.3077: Besides this, in the morning I had to endure great fatigue, in walking with unshod feet on clay that was quite frozen, and pieces of very sharp ice;
tgt_text.3078: and I never even got a bellyful of food.
tgt_text.3079: For both my master and myself had meals alike in quality and quantity, and very meagre they were;
tgt_text.3080: since they consisted of old and unsavoury lettuces, which had run to seed, looked just like so many brooms, and were full of a clammy, bitter juice, that smelt disgustingly.
tgt_text.3081: One night, a householder who lived in the next village, having lost his way through the darkness of a moonless night, and got drenched to the skin with rain, turned with his wea­ ried horse into our garden;
tgt_text.3082: and being as courteously received as circumstances would allow of, and being invited to tako there a night's repose, which, if not surrounded by many re­ finements, was at all events very welcome, he desired to make a present to his hospitable entertainer, and promised that he would give him from his farm some corn and oil, and two casks of wine.
tgt_text.3083: My master therefore proceeded, without delay, to the farm of the householder, which was distant from his garden sixty stadia,*seated on my bare back, and carrying with him a little sack, and some empty wineskins.
tgt_text.3084: The journey accomplished, we arrived at the farm, and there the kind host immediately asked my master to partake of a sumptuous entertainment.
tgt_text.3085: But while they were drinking jovially, a most astonishing prodigy took place.
tgt_text.3086: One ofthe hens in the poultry-yard, running through the middle of the yard, kept up a continual cackling, as if she wanted to lay.
tgt_text.3087: On this her master, looking at her, said, "Notable servant that you are, and remarkably prolific, for this long time you have treated us with your daily productions.
tgt_text.3088: And now, too, I see, you are thinking about helping us to a dainty morsel.
tgt_text.3089: Boy!" said he, speaking to one of his servants, “get the basket that the hens lay in, and place it in the corner as usual."
tgt_text.3090: When the boy had done as he was desired, the hen, refusing to go to her nest as usual, produced before the very feet of her master a premature offspring, and one of a singularly ominous nature.
tgt_text.3091: For she did not bring forth an egg, as we usually see hens do, but a chicken, perfectly formed, with feathers and claws, eyes and voice;
tgt_text.3092: which immediately began to follow its mother about.
tgt_text.3093: Another prodigy also occurred, of a far more astonishing nature than the former, and at which all men might with great reason be terrified.
tgt_text.3094: For, under the very table which held the remnants of the entertainment, the earth opened with a yawning chasm from its inmost depths, and a copious foun­ tain of blood gushed forth;
tgt_text.3095: while numerous drops, as they splashed about, sprinkled the table with gore.
tgt_text.3096: At that very instant also, while every one was struck with astonishment and dismay at these divine presages, one of the servants came running from the wine cellar, and announced that all the wine, that had long ago been racked off, was boiling up in all the vessels, with a heat as if a large fire had been put under it.
tgt_text.3097: In the meantime also, some weasels were observed, outside of the house, dragging into it a dead serpent.
tgt_text.3098: Then, too, out of the mouth of the sheep-dog jumped a small green frog;
tgt_text.3099: and a ram that stood near him rushing on the same dog, strangled him at a single grip.
tgt_text.3100: These numerous portents, and others of a like nature, filled the minds of the master of the house and all his family with intense amazement and terror;
tgt_text.3101: what was to be done first or what last;
tgt_text.3102: what they ought especially to do, and what they ought not to do to appease the anger of the Gods;
tgt_text.3103: with how many and what sort of victims they should make atonement, they were quite at a loss to decide.
tgt_text.3104: While all were stupefied with expectation of some dreadful catastrophe, a servant came running in, and announced to the master of the house a great and fearful visitation.
tgt_text.3105: THIS good man was the proud father of three sons, now grown up, well educated, and remarkable for their good conduct.
tgt_text.3106: Between these young men and a poor man, the owner of a small cottage, there had been an intimacy of long standing.
tgt_text.3107: Now, close adjoining to the humble cottage lay the extensive and fertile domain of a wealthy and powerful young man, who made but bad use of the influence derived from his high birth.
tgt_text.3108: As he was powerful from the number of his dependents, and did what he pleased in the city, he behaved in a very un­ ceremonious manner to his poor neighbour, killing his sheep, driving away his oxen, and trampling down his corn before it was ripe.
tgt_text.3109: Already he had deprived him of all hopes of a harvest, and now he wanted to expel him from the posses­ sion even of his land.
tgt_text.3110: To this end, raising a frivolous ques­ tion about the boundaries of the fields, he laid claim to the whole of the land as his own.
tgt_text.3111: Upon this, the countryman, who was otherwise a mild, harmless man, seeing himself plundered, through the avarice of his rich neighbour, collected together a considerable number of his friends, for the purpose of ascertaining what were the actual boundaries of his land, in order that, at all events, he might keep enough of his paternal land to dig himself a grave.
tgt_text.3112: Among others, the three brothers were present, to give such small assistance as best they might, in their friend's extreme need.
tgt_text.3113: Still, the mad oppressor was not in the least daunted, or even moved, by the presence of many citizens, and was so far from being disposed to abstain from acts of rapine, that he would not even confine himself to civil language.
tgt_text.3114: For, when they mildly expostulated with him, and endeavoured to pacify his boisterous disposition by soothing words, he swore in the most solemn manner by his own life and that of his dearest relatives, that he cared but little for the inter­ ference of so many arbitrators;
tgt_text.3115: and that, in fact, he would forthwith order his servants to take that neighbour of his by the ears, and drag him far away from his cottage, and banish him altogether.
tgt_text.3116: His words aroused the greatest indignation in the minds of all who heard him;
tgt_text.3117: and one of the three brothers answered, without hesitation, and told him plainly, that it was in vain, that trusting to his riches, he made such arrogant threats, since the poor even can obtain redress against the insolence of the wealthy, through the liberal protection of the laws.
tgt_text.3118: What oil is to flame, what sulphur is to a conflagration, what the whip is in the Fury's hand, such was the fuel afforded by these words to the furious disposition of this man.
tgt_text.3119: Roused to a perfect frenzy, and bidding them all, and their laws too, go and be hanged, he ordered the shepherds' dogs to be let loose, as well as those upon the farm, savage and blood-thirsty creatures, accustomed to prey upon the dead carcases that were thrown into the fields, and to bite and mangle the passing traveller.
tgt_text.3120: Accordingly, incited by the well-known hallooing of the shepherds, the dogs rushed upon the men, barking hor­ ribly, and tore the flesh off their bones.
tgt_text.3121: Nor even when the men fled did they spare them;
tgt_text.3122: but pursued them with so much the more ferocity.
tgt_text.3123: In this scene of havoc and slaughter of the confused mul­ titude, the youngest of the three brothers stumbled against a stone, and was thrown to the ground, where he was devoured by those ferocious dogs.
tgt_text.3124: The moment his brothers recog­ nized his dying shrieks, they ran to help him, and wrapping their cloaks around their left hands, used every effort to pro­ tect their brother, and to drive off the dogs, by volleys of stones.
tgt_text.3125: But they were unable to quell their ferocity;
tgt_text.3126: and the unfortunate youth was torn in pieces, and died, entreating with his breath, that they would avenge the death of their youngest brother on that most villanous purse-proud man.
tgt_text.3127: Then the two remaining surviving brothers, not, by Hercules, eomuch despairing of, as spontaneously disregarding their own safety, made an attack upon the rich man, and with furious impetuosity hurled a shower of stones against him.
tgt_text.3128: Then the blood-thirsty wretch, who, before this, had been trained by practice in many similar deeds of outrage, hurled a lance, and pierced one of the two brothers through the middle of the breast.
tgt_text.3129: And yet, though mortally wounded, the young man did not fall to the ground.
tgt_text.3130: For the lance, which had pierced him, and the greater part of which had come out at his back, was by the force of the blow fixed in the earth, and kept his body suspended by the firmness of the handle, as it stood quivering in the ground.
tgt_text.3131: In addition to this, one of the assassin's servants, a tall robust fellow, violently hurled a stone from a distance, and tried to hit the third brother on the right arm;
tgt_text.3132: but the stone, passing just by the tips of his fingers, and so expending its force in vain, fell to the ground without inflicting any injury, contrary to the expectation of all who were present.
tgt_text.3133: Now as the youth was endowed with singular presence of mind, this fortunate circumstance afforded him some hope of revenge.
tgt_text.3134: For, pretending that his hand was disabled, he thus addressed his most savage antagonist:
tgt_text.3135: " Exult in the destruction of our whole family, glut your in­ satiable vengeance with the blood of three brothers, and com­ plete your glorious triumph over your prostrate fellow-citi­ zens ;
tgt_text.3136: only remember, that after you have deprived this poor man of his lands, extend and extend as you may, you will still always have some neighbour or other.
tgt_text.3137: But this right hand of mine, which should undoubtedly have struck off your head, hangs powerless, smitten by the iniquitous decree of fate."
tgt_text.3138: The furious cutthroat, exasperated by these words, seizing a sword, rushed eagerly on the wretched youth, with the inten­ tion of slaying him with his own hand.
tgt_text.3139: However, he had provoked one who was not inferior to himself.
tgt_text.3140: For the youth, quite contrary to his anticipation, seized hold of his right hand with a most powerful grasp;
tgt_text.3141: and then brandishing his sword, with repeated blows dismissed the impure soul of the rich man from his body ;
tgt_text.3142: and lastly, to free himself from the hands of the attendants who were running to give assistance, he cut his own throat with the sword that was still reeking with the blood of his enemy.
tgt_text.3144: These were the events which the astounding prodigies had foreshown;
tgt_text.3145: and these were the events which were related to the most unfortunate master.
tgt_text.3146: The old man, overwhelmed by so many misfortunes, could not so much as utter a single word, or even shed a tear, but seizing the knife with which he had just before been helping his guests to cheese and other viands, he pierced his own throat with numerous gashes, thus following the example of his most unhappy son;
tgt_text.3147: so that falling with his face on the table, he washed away, with a river of flowing blood, the stains of that portentous gore which had before fallen upon it.
tgt_text.3148: The gardener, commiserating the fate of this house, which had thus come to destruction in the shortest space of time, and deploring his own mischance, made a return for his meal with his tears, and ever and anon clasping together his empty hands, immediately mounted on my back, and re­ turned the way we came.
tgt_text.3149: His return, however, was by no means free from accident.
tgt_text.3150: For a certain tall fellow, who was a soldier belonging to one of the legions,* as his dress and appearance seemed to indicate, met us on the road, and asked the gardener, in a haughty and insolent tone, whither he was leading that unladen ass ?
tgt_text.3151: My master, who was still full of grief, and was ignorant, besides, of the Latin language, passed on without making any reply.
tgt_text.3152: Upon this, the soldier could not control the insolence that was so natural to him;
tgt_text.3153: but considering his silence as a mark of contempt, thrust him from my back, at the same time striking him with a vine-stick,†which he carried in his hand.
tgt_text.3154: The gardener humbly declared that he did not understand what the soldier said, being ignorant of the language in which he spoke.
tgt_text.3155: The soldier, therefore, demanded in Greek, " Whither are you leading that ass?"
tgt_text.3156: The gardener replied, that he was going to the next town. "
tgt_text.3157: But I am in want of it," said the soldier;
tgt_text.3158: " it must help, with other beasts, to carry from the neigh­ bouring village the baggage of our commanding officer."
tgt_text.3159: With that, laying hold of the rope by which I was led along, he began to pull me away.
tgt_text.3160: The gardener, however, wiping away the blood that trickled down his face from the blow he had just received, again entreated the soldier to act more civilly and humanely, and supplicated him to do so, by all his hopes of future good fortune.
tgt_text.3161: "This ass," said he, " is very lazy, and then besides, he has that abominable complaint, the falling sickness;
tgt_text.3162: it is as much as he can do to carry a few bundles of vegetables from my garden close by;
tgt_text.3164: so he is not a likely beast for the carriage of larger burdens.
tgt_text.3165: "When, however, he found that the soldier could not be softened by entreaties, but was still more and more savagely bent on plundering him, and that now he had shifted his hold of the vine-stick, and was preparing to fracture his skull with the large knob at the end, he had recourse to his last chance.
tgt_text.3166: deigning that he would embrace the soldier, in order to excite his compassion, he bent down, and pulling both legs from under him, dashed him violently to the ground;
tgt_text.3167: then instantly throwing himself upon his sprawling antagonist, he bit him, and thumped him, and jobbed him all over, face, arms, and ribs, with his fists, his elbows, and with a stone which he picked up in the road.
tgt_text.3168: As for the sol­ dier, he could neither resist nor at all defend himself, from the very moment that he was laid prostrate on the ground;
tgt_text.3169: but could only threaten'from time to time that the moment he got up he would cut him to pieces with his sword.
tgt_text.3170: The gar­ dener, taking warning by this hint, snatched the sword from his side, and throwing it far away, again pummelled him harder than ever, so that the soldier, stretched on his back and disabled with wounds and bruises, had to counterfeit death, as the only means of saving his life.
tgt_text.3171: The gardener, then taking the sword away with him, mounted my back, and made off at my utmost speed straight towards the town ;
tgt_text.3172: and, not caring to visit his own garden, at all events for the present, he directed his steps towards the house of an intimate friend of his.
tgt_text.3173: After relating all the circumstances, he begged and entreated his friend to stand by him in his present dangerous position, and to conceal him and his ass there for a short time, so that by keeping out of the way two or three days, he might escape the penalty of the capital offence he had committed.
tgt_text.3174: This man, not being forgetful of their former friendship, he readily re­ ceived him, and having dragged me with my legs tied together up stairs into an attic, the gardener crept into a chest that was in the warehouse below, and covering himself with the lid, there lay concealed.
tgt_text.3175: Meanwhile the soldier, as I afterwards learned, like one recovering from a violent fit of intoxication, made his way to the town, staggering and tottering, sore with the pain of so many wounds, and with difficulty supporting himself on his stick.
tgt_text.3176: Ashamed to mention to any of the citizens the parti­ culars of his own violence and his ignominious defeat, he silently digested the affront he had received, until meeting at last with some of his fellow-soldiers, he told them of his mis­ fortune.
tgt_text.3177: They were of opinion, that he should conceal him­ self for some time in the barracks;
tgt_text.3178: (for, besides the disgrace to himself, he feared also the military oath sworn by the Genius,* on account of the loss of his sword), while they, noting down the description he gave of us, would make the most zealous endeavours for our discovery, and the gratification of their own vengeance.
tgt_text.3179: Nor was a perfidious neighbour want­ ing to tell them very speedily where we were concealed.
tgt_text.3180: Thereupon, the soldier's comrades applied to the magis­ trates, and falsely assorted that they had lost on the road a silver cup of considerable value, that belonged to their com­ manding officer, and that a certain gardener had found it, and would not give it up, but was now lying concealed in the house of a friend.
tgt_text.3181: The magistrates, on being made acquainted with the loss, and the name of the commanding officer, came to the door of our dwelling, and with a loud voice, gave notice to our host that it would be better for him to deliver us up, whowere beyond a doubt concealed in his premises, than to render himself liable to capital punishment.
tgt_text.3182: But our friend, not being in the least daunted, and resolute to save the guest he had taken under his protection, declared that he knew no­ thing about us, and that he had not seen that gardener for several days.
tgt_text.3183: On the other hand, the soldiers, swearing by the Genius of the emperor, maintained that he was concealed there, and nowhere else.
tgt_text.3184: At length the magistrates were determined, by making a strict search, to confute him in this his obstinate denial.
tgt_text.3185: Ac­ cordingly, sending the lictors and other public officers into the Bouse, they ordered them carefully to search every hole and corner.
tgt_text.3186: But, after all their search, the officers reported that no human being, nor yet any ass, was to be found within the threshold.
tgt_text.3187: The dispute now grew very warm on both sides;
tgt_text.3188: the soldiers swore by Cæsar that they knew for certain we were there, while the master of the house swore as stoutly by all the gods in denial of the assertion.
tgt_text.3189: On hearing this conten­ tion and clamour, I, who was in general an ass of an inqui­ sitive and restless disposition, stretched my neck out of a little window, and tried to see what all the noise was about;
tgt_text.3190: but one of the soldiers, by chance turning his eyes in the direction of my shadow, instantly called out to all of them to observe it;
tgt_text.3191: whereupon they instantly raised a loud shout, and rushing up the steps, some of them seized hold of me, and led me prisoner from my place of concealment.
tgt_text.3192: And now, without more de­ lay, they narrowly examined every corner, and opening the chest, they found the wretched gardener, dragged him out, and carried him before the magistrates, and finally to the public gaol, in order that he might suffer capital punishment.
tgt_text.3193: Nor -could they ever have done joking and laughing at the notion of my looking out of the window.
tgt_text.3194: From this circumstance, also, the well-known proverb originated, about the peeping ass and his shadow.
tgt_text.3195: *WHAT became of my master, the gardener, on the following day, I know not.
tgt_text.3196: But the soldier, who had been so hand­ somely thrashed for his overbearing conduct, untied me from my manger and took me away, there being no one to hinder him.
tgt_text.3197: Then going to his barracks, as it appeared to me, he led me into the public road, laden with his baggage, and equipped quite in military style.
tgt_text.3198: For he put on my back a glittering helmet, of remarkable brightness, a shield still more splendid, and a long gleaming lance.
tgt_text.3199: The latter he took care to place conspicuously on the top of the pole, which he had arranged in the form of a trophy, not so much in compliance with the regu­ lations, as for the purpose of terrifying unfortunate travellers.
tgt_text.3200: Having passed over a level country by an easy road, we came to a little town, but we did not put up at an inn, but at the house of a certain decurion.
tgt_text.3201: After having delivered me to the care of a servant, the soldier repaired without delay to the presence of his officer, who had the command of a thousand men.
tgt_text.3202: I remember that a few days after our arrival, a most wicked and dreadful crime was perpetrated in that town.
tgt_text.3203: I will re­ cord it in my book, that you also may read it.
tgt_text.3204: THE master of the house had a son, a young man of great literary attainments, and consequently remarkable for his piety and modesty;
tgt_text.3205: so that any one would have wished to have just such a son.
tgt_text.3206: The mother of this young man having been dead many years, his father contracted a second marriage, and his second wife had borne him another son, who had now just passed his twelfth year.
tgt_text.3207: But the stepmother, who held supreme sway in her husband's house, rather in consequence of her good looks than her good morals, regarded her stepson with lustful eyes, whether it was that she was naturally vici­ ous, or was impelled by Fate to such extreme criminality.
tgt_text.3208: Know, therefore, excellent reader, that you are about to peruse a tragic, and not a comic tale, and that you will have to ascend from the sock* to the buskin.
tgt_text.3209: Now as long as the little Cupid was in its infancy, this woman easily repressed her rising blushes, and concealed them in silence.
tgt_text.3210: But when love, raging without control, wrapped her whole soul in flame, she then succumbed to the cruel God;
tgt_text.3211: and, feigning illness, concealed the disease of the mind under the pretence of bodily ailment.
tgt_text.3212: Now every one knows that all the morbid changes in the bodily condition and appearance are quite alike in those who are sick and those who are in love;
tgt_text.3213: such, for instance, as an unsightly paleness, languor of the eyes, restless sleep, and sighs the more deep from the slowness of the torment.
tgt_text.3214: You might have supposed that she was only afflicted by fitful attacks of fever, had it not been that she wept.
tgt_text.3216: for the unskilful impressions of her doctors!
tgt_text.3217: what meant the hurried pulse, the sudden flush, the oppressed respiration, the frequent tossings and turnings from side to side.
tgt_text.3219: how easy is it even for one who is no doctor, but is acquainted with the symptoms of love and passion, to comprehend the true nature of the case, when he sees a person burning without bodily heat ?
tgt_text.3220: Unable any longer to control her raging passion, she at length broke her long silence, and sent for her son to be called to her, a name she wished he had never borne or might bear no more, that she might not, by using it, be reminded of her shame.
tgt_text.3221: The young man obeyed without delay the command of his love-sick parent, and with a forehead wrinkled with sorrow, like that of an old man, he went into the chamber of her who was the wife of his father and the mother of his brother, pay­ ing that obedience to her which, to a certain degree, was her due.
tgt_text.3222: As for her, fast aground, as it were, upon the shoals of doubt, and long unable to break a silence that tortured her, she again rejects every word which she had at first conceived to be most adapted to the present interview, and even still in a state of indecision, through shame, she cannot tell how to begin.
tgt_text.3223: The young man, however, suspecting nothing wrong, with a down­ cast countenance, spontaneously asked her what was the cause of her present malady.
tgt_text.3224: Upon this, availing herself of the per­ nicious opportunity afforded her, she took courage to falter out these few words, while she wept profusely, and hid her face with her garment:
tgt_text.3225: "You yourself are the sole cause and origin of my malady, and you are the remedy too, and the only chance of life now left me.
tgt_text.3226: For those eyes of yours, penetrating through my own into the inmost core of my heart, have kindled there a most vehement fire.
tgt_text.3227: Take pity, therefore, on me, who am perish­ ing for your sake;
tgt_text.3228: and let no scruples on your father's ac­ count have the least weight with you, for, by complying with my wishes, you will preserve for him a wife, who is otherwise doomed to die.
tgt_text.3229: It is with reason that I love you, since in your face I recognize his features.
tgt_text.3232: you have full opportunity for this act, so ne­ cessary to my existence-a thing that no one knows.
tgt_text.3233: "The young man being in utter confusion at this unexpected misfortune, although he recoiled from the mere thought of such an abominable deed, yet did not think it right to exasperate her by too abrupt a refusal of a denial, but rather that he ought to appease her by a delusive promise.
tgt_text.3234: He promised, therefore, without reserve, and earnestly persuaded her to keep up her spirits, restore her strength by nutriment, and pay attention to her health, till his father should go on some journey or other, and leave them free to enjoy their pleasures.
tgt_text.3235: He then with­ drew from the baneful presence of his stepmother, and con­ ceiving likewise that this calamity with which his house was threatened called for the deepest consideration, he immediately related the affair to an aged mail of well-tried prudence, who had been his tutor.
tgt_text.3236: After long deliberation, nothing seemed to be so advisable as to escape this storm, let loose by adverse fortune, by instant flight.
tgt_text.3237: The woman, however, impatient at even the smallest delay, invented some pretext or other, and found means cunningly to persuade her husband to take a journey, with all speed, to some small farms of his, which were situate at a very con­ siderable distance.
tgt_text.3238: This being done, in a state of frantic eager­ ness for the fulfilment of her hopes, she solicited her stepson to perform his promise.
tgt_text.3239: The young man, however, now pre­ tending this thing, now that, as an excuse, avoids her execrable presence, till at last, clearly perceiving, from the varying na­ ture of his messages, that he refused to fulfil his promise, her nefarious love became suddenly changed into hatred far more intense.
tgt_text.3240: Immediately summoning a most villanous slave of hers, who had formed a portion of the dowry she brought her husband, and who was ready for the perpetration of any crime, she communicated to him her perfidious designs, and there was no course that seemed to them preferable to de­ priving the unfortunate youth of life.
tgt_text.3241: Accordingly, this vil­ lain was sent immediately to buy a poison of the most deadly quality, and, having carefully mixed it in wine, she prepared it for the destruction of her guiltless son-in-law.
tgt_text.3242: As it so happened, while the wicked pair were deliberating about a suitable opportunity for giving him the poison, the younger boy, this most abandoned woman's own son, returning home after his morning studies, and feeling thirsty from his breakfast, found the cup of wine which contained the poison,.
tgt_text.3243: and swallowed at a draught the contents;
tgt_text.3244: but no sooner had he drunk the deadly potion which had been prepared for his bro­ ther, than he fell lifeless on the ground.
tgt_text.3245: His tutor, horrified at his sudden death, alarmed the mother and the whole family with his cries.
tgt_text.3246: And now, when the cause was ascertained to have been the noxious draught, opinions varied as to who were the authors of the crime.
tgt_text.3247: But this wicked woman, a singular specimen of a stepmother's malice, not at all moved by the shocking death of her son, nor by the consciousness of having murdered him, nor by the misfortune of her house, nor by the grief her husband would feel for the loss of his son, seized upon the destruction of her own offspring as a ready means of vengeance.
tgt_text.3248: She immediately sent a messenger to inform her husband, who was on his journey, of the calamity which had befallen his house;
tgt_text.3249: and when he returned home with all pos­ sible haste, she, with enormous effrontery, pretended that her son had been destroyed by poison, administered to him by her stepson.
tgt_text.3250: And in this she did not altogether speak falsely, because the boy really had met with the death which had been intended for the young man.
tgt_text.3251: She, however, pretended that the younger brother had been put an end to through the wicked­ ness of her stepson, because she would not comply with the licentious proposals the latter had made to her.
tgt_text.3252: Nor was she contented with lies of such enormity, but even added, that he had likewise threatened her with a sword, in consequence of her detection of his wickedness.
tgt_text.3253: Grievously was the unhappy man afflicted at the death of both his sons;
tgt_text.3254: for he saw his younger son buried before his face, and he knew that his other son would certainly be con­ demned to death for incest and fratricide;
tgt_text.3255: and then, besides, he was impelled to extreme hatred of this son by the feigned lamentations of a wife whom he held too dear.
tgt_text.3256: No sooner, therefore, had the funeral rites of the unfortunate boy been arranged, than the unhappy old man hastened straight from the pile to the forum, with the tears still wet upon his cheeks, and tearing his white hairs, begrimed with ashes ;
tgt_text.3257: and there, giving loose to his passionate feelings, he used every endeavour to- procure the destruction of his remaining son, by tears and by.
tgt_text.3258: entreaties, even embracing the very knees of the decu­ rions;
tgt_text.3259: and never imagining the treachery of his most infam­ ous wife, he exclaimed that his son was an incestuous wretch, who had attempted to violate his father's bed;
tgt_text.3260: that he was a fratricide, and had threatened to kill his stepmother.
tgt_text.3261: In fine, by his lamentations, he aroused not only the senate but the people, to such a degree of pity and indignation, that, impatient of the tedious formality of a judicial process, and waiving in- contep.
tgt_text.3262: table proofs in support of the accusation, and the studied subterfuges of pleaders, they shouted out with one consent, that a public crime ought to be punished by the public, and that the author of it ought to be stoned to death.
tgt_text.3263: In the meantime, the magistrates, apprehensive, on their own account, lest the growing excitement should lead to results destructive of all order and of the civic weal, began, partly by expostulating with the decurions, and partly by soothing the feelings of the public, to induce them that the trial might proceed in due order, and in conformity with the customs of their ancestors, the allegations on both sides being duly weighed, and the sen­ tence pronounced in a legal manner.
tgt_text.3264: They added, that no one ought to be condemned without a hearing, after the manner of fierce barbarians or lawless tyrants, since, by so doing, they would leave, in those times of profound peace, a dreadful pre­ cedent for posterity.
tgt_text.3266: and immediately the crier proclaimed aloud that the senators were to assemble in the senate-house.
tgt_text.3267: These having immediately taken their accus­ tomed places, according to their rank and dignity, the crier again made proclamation aloud, and the accuser first came forward;
tgt_text.3268: then the prisoner was called and brought into court, and, lastly, the crier, in conformity with the law of Athens and the process of the Areopagus, announced to the advocates on both sides that they were to plead without pre­ amble, and to avoid all appeals for the purpose of exciting com­ miseration.
tgt_text.3269: That this was the manner of proceeding I learned from overhearing the remarks of many people, as they were talking with one another.
tgt_text.3270: But as I was not present at the trial, but tied up to a manger, I shall only commit here to writing what I ascertained to be exactly the truth.
tgt_text.3271: As soon as the harangues of the orators were concluded, the senators determined that the truth of the charges should be established by certain proofs, and that a question of such great consequence should not be left to suspicion and conjecture.
tgt_text.3272: They, likewise, thought it requisite that the servant, who was said to be the only person who knew the facts of the case, should be brought forward.
tgt_text.3273: Nor was that candidate for the gallows in the least dismayed, either by the doubtful result of so serious an investigation, or by the view of the thronged senate house, or even by his own guilty conscience, but began to state and affirm as true a number of things which he him­ self had invented.
tgt_text.3274: He said, that the young man, being indig­ nant at the repulse received from his step-mother, had sum­ moned him;
tgt_text.3275: that, in order to avenge the affront, he had or­ dered him to destroy her son;
tgt_text.3276: that he had promised him a great reward to ensure his secrecy ;
tgt_text.3277: that on his refusal to do what he wished, he had threatened to put him to death ;
tgt_text.3278: that he had delivered to him the poison mixed with his own hand, to be given to his brother;
tgt_text.3279: and that the young man, suspecting he had forborne to administer the potion, and had reserved it, to produce as evidence of the crime, at last gave it to the boy with his own hand.
tgt_text.3280: "When this villanous knave had, with an affected agitation, uttered these egregious lies, which bore a most plausible re­ semblance to truth, the trial was brought to a conclusion, and not one was there among the senators so favourably disposed towards the young man, as not to pronounce him clearly guilty, and condemn him to be sewed up in the leathern sack.
tgt_text.3281: The verdicts, in which they all agreed, were about to be com­ mitted to writing, according to custom, and to be placed in the brazen urn;
tgt_text.3282: after which, the die being cast, no change could lawfully be made, but the life of the criminal was placed in the hands of the executioner.
tgt_text.3283: Just then, an aged physician, a member of the senate, and a person of approved integrity, and of remarkable influence, covering with his hand the mouth of the urn, that no one might rashly put his billet into it, thus addressed the court:
tgt_text.3284: “I rejoice that, long as I have lived, I have ever enjoyed your approbation;
tgt_text.3285: and I will not suffer a manifest act of homi­ cide to be perpetrated, by condemning a man to death on a false accusation;
tgt_text.3286: nor you to violate your oath, as judges, for the lying testimony of a slave.
tgt_text.3287: I myself will not cheat my own conscience, and trample on the reverence which is due to the gods, by pronouncing an unjust sentence.
tgt_text.3288: Learn, there­ fore, from me, the real circumstances of the case.
tgt_text.3289: This vil­ lanous fellow came to me some time ago, and offered me a hundred golden solidi for a prompt and deadly poison, telling me he wanted it for a person who, being grievously afflicted with an incurable disease, wished to rid himself from the tor­ ment of life.
tgt_text.3290: Noticing the confusion and incoherence of the rascal's story, and feeling sure that he was about to perpetrate some crime, I certainly gave him the potion, but as a precaution, in case the affair should be looked into at some future time, I did not immediately take the money that was agreed upon, but said to him, ' Lest by chance any of these golden coins which you offer me should be found to be light or spurious, put them in this bag, and seal it with your own seal, till they are to-morrow examined in the presence of a money-changer.'
tgt_text.3291: lIe complied, and sealed up the money;
tgt_text.3292: as soon, therefore, as he was brought into court to give evidence, I ordered one of my servants to go with all haste and fetch the bag from my shop, and here I now produce it before you.
tgt_text.3293: Let him look at it, and examine the impression of his own seal.
tgt_text.3294: Now how can the brother be accused of having procured the poison which this fellow bought ?
tgt_text.3295: "On the instant, a violent fit of trembling seized the villain;
tgt_text.3296: his natural hue gave place to a deadly paleness;
tgt_text.3297: and a cold perspiration suffused all his limbs.
tgt_text.3298: He began to shift about his feet with irregular movements;
tgt_text.3299: to scratch now this, now that side of his head;
tgt_text.3300: and, with his mouth half open, stam­ mering and stuttering, to utter I know not what silly nonsense, insomuch that not a single person could reasonably suppose him to be innocent of the crime.
tgt_text.3301: Recovering, however, his craftiness once again, he unceasingly denied the charge, and accused the physician of lying.
tgt_text.3302: On this, the physician, inde­ pendently of his being bound by oath to give a just judgment, when he saw that his honour was openly impeached, made redoubled efforts to confute this villain;
tgt_text.3303: till at last the public officers, by order of the magistrates, seizing the slave's hand, found the iron ring, and compared it with the impression on the bag.
tgt_text.3304: As the result corroborated the suspicion previously entertained, the rack and the wooden horse were put in opera­ tion, according to the Greek custom.
tgt_text.3305: Being upheld, however, by a wonderful amount of boldness, he was proof against all blows, and even fire itself.
tgt_text.3306: At last, the physician exclaimed, " I will not suffer, by Hercules !
tgt_text.3307: I will not suffer, either that this innocent young man shall receive a punishment at your hands contrary to jus­ tice, or that this fellow shall stultify our judgment and escape the punishment due to his crimes.
tgt_text.3308: I will give you an evident proof on this matter under consideration.
tgt_text.3309: When this most abandoned man was anxious to obtain the deadly poison, I was of opinion that it ill accorded with my art to furnish any one with the means of producing death, being sensible that medi­ cine was sought not for the destruction, but for the preservation of mankind;
tgt_text.3310: yet I feared that if I should refuse to give it him, I should thereby prompt him to another method of perpetrating the crime, and that he would accomplish the criminal purpose upon which he had resolved, either by buying a deadly potion from some other person, or, at all events, by the sword, or some such weapon ;
tgt_text.3311: fearing this, I gave him indeed a drug, but it was a preparation of the soporiferous plant called mandrake, remarkable for the torpor which it is known to occasion, and which produces a sleep exactly resembling death.
tgt_text.3312: Nor is it to be wondered at, that this most desperate knave, being cer­ tain of undergoing, if convicted, the utmost penalty that can be inflicted on him, conformably to the customs of our ances­ tors, should be ready to endure these tortures, as being lighter evils.
tgt_text.3313: But if the boy has really taken the potion which was mixed by my hands, he is still alive, in a torpid state, and asleep :
tgt_text.3314: and immediately his drowsy slumbers are shaken off, he will return to the light of day.
tgt_text.3315: But if he is really dead, you may look for some other way of accounting for his de­ cease.
tgt_text.3316: "The old man having addressed them to this effect, they as­ sented to what he said;
tgt_text.3317: and immediately proceeded in great haste to the pile on which the body of the boy was laid.
tgt_text.3318: Not a member was there of the senate, nor a person of the first rank, who did not run thither, impelled by curiosity.
tgt_text.3319: And behold, the father himself, having with his own hands removed the lid of the coffin, found his son rising that moment from the dead, the deathlike sleep shaken off;
tgt_text.3320: and most ardently embracing him, and unable in words to express his present joy, he led him forth into the presence of the people, and the boy was brought into court, just as he was, swathed and bound in the grave-clothes.
tgt_text.3321: And now the naked truth was obvious to every one, the wickedness of the nefarious slave, and of the still more aban­ doned woman, being clearly exposed.
tgt_text.3322: Accordingly, the step- mother was condemned to perpetual banishment, the slave was crucified;
tgt_text.3323: and by the consent of all, the golden solidi were presented to the worthy physician, as a reward for the trance he had produced with such happy results.
tgt_text.3324: Thus did the sin­ gular and romantic fortune of the old decurion come to a termination worthy of Divine providence;
tgt_text.3325: since, in a passing moment, indeed an instant of time, he suddenly became the father of two young men.
tgt_text.3326: after he had been in danger of losing both.
tgt_text.3328: As for myself, you shall hear what changes of fortune I experienced at that time.
tgt_text.3329: The soldier who had made me his own without paying for me, being about to carry letters to the great prince at Rome, in obedience to the commands of his tribune, sold me for eleven denars to two brothers, servants of a very wealthy personage in the neighbourhood.
tgt_text.3330: One of them was a confectioner, who made bread and sweetmeats;
tgt_text.3331: the other was a cook, and dressed rich stews seasoned with the relishing juices of pounded herbs and aromatics.
tgt_text.3332: These two, dwelling together and living in common, bought me for the purpose of carrying the numerous vessels which were required for their master's use, when he was tra­ velling through different countries.
tgt_text.3333: I was admitted, there­ fore, as a third companion with these two brothers;
tgt_text.3334: and never, at any time, during my transformation, did I experience a fortune so marked with good luck.
tgt_text.3335: For, in the evening, after the supper, which was always on a magnificent scale, my masters were in the habit of bringing home to their little room numerous fragments that were left;
tgt_text.3336: the one brought ample remains of roast pig, chickens, fish, and delicate dishes of that kind;
tgt_text.3337: while the other brought bread, pastry, sugar­ plums, hook cakes, lizard cakes, and many kinds of honied sweetmeats.
tgt_text.3338: Accordingly, after they had fastened the door of their chamber, and had gone to the baths for the pur­ pose of refreshing themselves, I used to cram myself with the dainties that fell in my way through the favour of the Gods.
tgt_text.3339: For I was not so much a fool, nor so truly an ass, as to neglect this most delicious fare, and feed upon coarse hay.
tgt_text.3340: My thie­ vish manoeuvres for a long time succeeded most beautifully, because, as yet, I pilfered cautiously and sparingly, only a few articles out of a great number, and they had no suspicion of such tricks being played by an ass.
tgt_text.3341: But when, becoming still more fearless of detection, I devoured all the nicest bits, and, rejecting all that was stale, began to lick up the more choice morsels, the brothers were not a little surprized and per­ plexed.
tgt_text.3342: And though even then they did not believe such a thing of me, still they made diligent enquiry as to who was the author of their daily losses.
tgt_text.3343: At length, indeed, they even went so far as to accuse each other of this most base act of theft;
tgt_text.3344: and they began to keep sharper watch, and to count all they put by.
tgt_text.3345: At length, throwing off all hesitation and reserve, one of them thus addressed the other:
tgt_text.3346: "Why, really now, this is neither fair nor like a man, for you every day to be diminish­ ing what has been put by, and to be purloining the choicest parts, and then to go and sell them, so as silly to increase your own stock, and then cry halves of the remainder.
tgt_text.3347: If, in fact, you are tired of our partnership, we may still live as brothers in all other respects, and yet give up this partnership concern of ours.
tgt_text.3348: For I see that when dissatisfaction at the loss has in­ creased to a very considerable extent, it will create very great discord between us.
tgt_text.3349: "To this the other rejoined, “I do, by Hercules!
tgt_text.3350: admire this effrontery of yours, after you have secretly been pilfering the articles, to forestall my complaints, which, in silence and sorrow, I have kept to myself, being determined to put up with it as long as ever I could, rather than accuse my biothei of shabby theft.
tgt_text.3351: But it is well, that having spoken upon the matter on both sides, we are put upon seeking a remedy for our loss, lest our misunderstanding, gathering strength by si­ lence, should produce between us a strife like that of Eteocles and his brother.
tgt_text.3352: "Bandying these and similar reproaches against one another, they both of them solemnly declared that they had been guilty of no fraud whatever, nor of the slightest purloining;
tgt_text.3353: but agreed, that they ought by every possible contrivance try to discover the thief who was the author of their common loss.
tgt_text.3354: It was not possible, they said, that the ass, which was the only being there, could take a fancy to such kind of food:
tgt_text.3355: and still, every day the choicest portions were nowhere to be found ;
tgt_text.3356: and certainly no flies found their way into their room, that were as large as were the harpies of old, who robbed Phineas of his dainties.
tgt_text.3357: In the meantime, I, being bountifully crammed with dainty morsels, and well stuffed with human food, found my body plumped up, my hide softened with rich juices, and my coat grown sleek and shining.
tgt_text.3358: But that same comeliness was the cause of a great shock to my feelings.
tgt_text.3359: For being roused to suspicion by the uncommon breadth of my back, and perceiv­ ing that my hay remained every day quite untouched, they now directed all their attention to me.
tgt_text.3360: Accordingly, having shut the door at the accustomed hour as usual, as though they were going to the bath, they peeped at me through a little crevice, as I was intent upon eating the fragments which were exposed in various directions.
tgt_text.3361: And now, forgetting all con­ sideration for their loss, they burst into a violent fit of laughter at the monstrous epicurism of an ass ;
tgt_text.3362: and then calling toge­ ther a number of their fellow-servants, they pointed out to them the incredible appetite of an animal like me.
tgt_text.3363: Then laughter so loud and so continued seized them all, that the master, who happened to be passing by, asked what fun was going on to make his servants laugh so excessively.
tgt_text.3364: Being told what it was, he came himself and peeped through the same cranny.
tgt_text.3365: Then he too laughed until his stomach ached, and opening the door of the room, he came nearer to me, and observed me very attentively.
tgt_text.3366: But as for me, seeing that for­ tune was inclined to smile more propitiously upon me, I went on eating quite at my ease, the merriment of those present in­ spiring me with additional confidence;
tgt_text.3367: till at last the master of the house, enchanted by the novelty of the sight, ordered me to be led to the supper-room;
tgt_text.3368: or rather he led me to it with his own hands;
tgt_text.3369: and the table being laid, he directed every kind of substantial food to be placed before me, and dishes that had not been tasted.
tgt_text.3370: Now, though I was well stuffed already, yet desiring to render myself more agreeable, and more pleasing to 'him, I ate of the food placed before me as if I had been quite hungry.
tgt_text.3371: But they, prompted by extreme curiosity, thinking of every thing which an ass would be most likely to loathe, offered it to me, for the purpose of testing my politeness;
tgt_text.3372: such as meat seasoned with assafœtida, fowls sprinkled over with pepper, and fish soused in foreign pickle.
tgt_text.3373: In the meantime, the banquet room resounded with roars of laughter.
tgt_text.3374: At last, a bit of a buffoon who was present, said, " Give a little wine to our comrade." " Well said, rogue," cried the master ;
tgt_text.3375: “I dare say our friend would have no objection to a cup of honied wine." " Here, lad," said he, “ wash well that golden cup, fill it with honied wine, and offer it to my guest;
tgt_text.3376: and at the same time, tell him that I have drunk his good health."
tgt_text.3377: All the guests now awaited the result in a state of intense curiosity;
tgt_text.3378: the huge cup was handed to me, and wither more ado, I emptied it at a single draught quite deliberately, and with a very jovial air, screwing up the extremities of my lips, in resemblance of a tongue.
tgt_text.3379: Then a shout of applause arose, and all, with one accord, drank my health.
tgt_text.3380: In the end, the master, being excessively pleased, after calling the servants who had bought me, ordered that four times the price they had paid for me should be given to them;
tgt_text.3381: thereupon he delivered me into the charge of a certain person, a freedman of his, to whom he was much attached, and who was very well off, and desired him to take all possible care of me.
tgt_text.3382: This person treated me in a very humane and kind manner;
tgt_text.3383: and that he might still more deserve the esteem of his patron, most studiously consulted his amusement by teaching me clever tricks.
tgt_text.3384: In the first place, he taught me to recline at table, leaning on my elbow;
tgt_text.3385: next, to wrestle and to dance even, raising my fore feet;
tgt_text.3386: and-a thing that won especial admiration-to use signs instead of words, so as to indicate what I disapproved of by throwing back, and what I approved of by bowing my head.
tgt_text.3387: He also taught me, when I was thirsty, to look towards the cup-bearer, and by winking first one eyelid then another, to show that I wanted something to drink.
tgt_text.3388: In all these matters I showed myself very ready and obedient;
tgt_text.3389: as I could have done them all, though no one had shown me how.
tgt_text.3390: But I was afraid, lest, if I should happen to perform them, in imitation of human beings, without the aid of a master, most people would think that it portended sinister events, and that I, as a monster and prodigy, might have to part with my head, and be given as fat provender to the vultures.
tgt_text.3391: And now my renown was spread abroad in all directions, so that I rendered my master quite famous and illustrious, in con­ sequence of my wonderful accomplishments.
tgt_text.3392: “This," said the people, " is the man who has an ass for his guest and com­ panion ;
tgt_text.3393: an ass that wrestles, an ass that dances, and under­ stands the language of men, and expresses what he means by signs."
tgt_text.3394: It is proper, however, that I should now, at all events, inform you, though I ought to have done so in the be­ ginning, who this Thyasus was, and whence he came;
tgt_text.3395: for such was the name of my master.
tgt_text.3396: The country which gave him birth was Corinth, a city which ranks as the chief of all the province of Achaia.
tgt_text.3397: And, as he had gradually attained all the honours which his pedigree and dignity demanded, he had now been nominated to the office of quinquennial magis­ trate.
tgt_text.3398: Accordingly, in order that he might act conformably to the splendour of that office, he had promised to exhibit a show of gladiators for the space of three days;
tgt_text.3399: thus extending his liberality to the greatest possible degree.
tgt_text.3400: In fact, it was his desire of receiving the public applause that had now brought him to Thessaly, in order to procure from thence the most noble wild beasts and some celebrated gladiators.
tgt_text.3401: And now, having made all his arrangements and completed all his purchases quite to his satisfaction, he was preparing to return home.
tgt_text.3402: Disdaining, however, his own splendid chariots, which, some covered and some open, were drawn along in the .
tgt_text.3404: regardless also of his Thessalian horses, and his other beasts of Gallic breed, whose generous pedigree bore testimony to their rarity and value;
tgt_text.3405: despising and neglect­ ing all these, he rode most lovingly on me, who was decked out with golden trappings, a coloured saddle, purple cloths, a silver bit, an embroidered girth, and some little bells that tinkled as I went along, and sometimes he addressed me in the kindest of words.
tgt_text.3406: Among-many other expressions too which he made use of, he declared how extremely delighted he was at pos­ sessing in me, at one and the same time, a companion and a bearer.
