tgt_text.3407: And now, having finished our journey, partly by land and partly by sea, we arrived at Corinth, where vast numbers of the citizens came out to meet us, not so much as it seemed to me for the purpose of doing honour to Thyasus, as from a desire of seeing me.
tgt_text.3408: For so great a rumour had pervaded that city about me, that I was a source of no small emolument to my keeper.
tgt_text.3409: For perceiving that many were eagerly desirous to see my pastimes, he had the doors shut, and admitted them one by one, charging each a good price for admission.
tgt_text.3410: By this means he managed every day to pick up no small sums.
tgt_text.3411: Among the number of spectators, there was a lady of rank and fortune, who having purchased a sight of me, was quite enchanted with my manifold tricks, and at last conceived a wonderful desire of being more intimate with me.
tgt_text.3412: In short, her passion grew to such a height, that, like an asinine Pasi- phäe, she prevailed on my keeper, for a considerable sum of money, to let her have my company for a single night:
tgt_text.3413: and the good-for-nothing fellow consented, regardless of all con.
tgt_text.3414: siderations save only his own gain.
tgt_text.3415: And now, the laborious and wakeful night being finished, the woman, to avoid being seen, withdrew from my embraces before day-light, at the same time making a contract with my keeper for some future night, at the same price.
tgt_text.3416: He was willing enough to gratify her, partly for the large sum he re­ ceived from her, and partly for the opportunity afforded him of displaying such a novel spectacle to his lord;
tgt_text.3417: to whom, without delay, he unfolded the whole scene of our lust.
tgt_text.3418: There­ upon Thyasus, having liberally rewarded his freed man, des­ tined me to be shown in public.
tgt_text.3419: And, because that egregious wife of mine could not be publicly connected with me, being a person of quality, nor any other volunteer could be found for the same purpose, a certain vile woman, who had been sen­ tenced by the prefect to be devoured by wild beasts, was pro­ cured, for a great sum of money, to have connexion with me in the theatre, in the sight of all the spectators.
tgt_text.3420: Of this wo­ man I have heard the following history:
tgt_text.3421: -SiE had a husband, whose father, when setting out on a journey, had given directions to his wife, the young man's mother, whom he left in a state of pregnancy, that if she brought forth an infant of the weaker sex, she should imme­ diately have it put to death.
tgt_text.3422: Now she, having brought forth a girl during her husband's absence, and being moved by the natural affection of a mother, disobeyed the commands of her husband, and delivered it to her neighbours to be brought up.
tgt_text.3423: On her husband's return, she informed him that she had been delivered of a daughter, who had been destroyed.
tgt_text.3424: When now the bloom of age called for the maiden's nuptial day, as she could not give her daughter a portion suitable to her parentage, without the knowledge of her husband, the only way she could do was to disclose the secret to her son.
tgt_text.3425: Besides, she was very much afraid lest he, by some accident, might in the ardour of youth inadvertently make some attempt on the chas­ tity of his sister, who was also ignorant that he was her bro­ ther.
tgt_text.3426: The young man, who was remarkable for his' affectionate disposition, religiously obeyed the commands of his mother, behaved like a good brother, and kept the family secret so well, that to all appearance he entertained for his sister only an ordinary degree of good will.
tgt_text.3427: But he undertook to perform a brother's duties by receiving her into his own house, as if she had been some orphan girl of the neighbourhood, who had been deprived of the guardian care of her parents;
tgt_text.3428: and he proposed to marry her, ere long, to a most dear companion of his, with whom he was united by the closest ties of friend­ ship, and to bestow on her most liberally a dowry at his own expense.
tgt_text.3429: But these excellent and innocent arrangements could not escape the deadly malevolence of Fortune, who caused a dire jealousy to spring up in the young man's house, and drove the wife to those crimes for which she was now condemned to be thrown to the wild beasts.
tgt_text.3430: She began by suspecting the girl to be a rival, who supplanted her in her husband's affections ;
tgt_text.3431: then she hated her, and finally she resolved to put her to death in the most inhuman manner.
tgt_text.3432: Accordingly, she had recourse to the following 'wicked stratagem :
tgt_text.3433: having stolen her husband's ring, she went to a farm of theirs in the country, and from there sent a servant, who, though faithful to her, was an utter villain, and told him to inform the girl that the young man had come to the farm and desired to see her, adding, that she was to come alone, with all possible speed.
tgt_text.3434: And, lest any doubt might happen to arise in her mind about the propriety of coming, she delivered to him the ring which she had stolen from her hus­ band, to show as a token that his message was authentic.
tgt_text.3435: On this, in compliance with the injunctions of her brother, for she was the only one who knew that he was her brother, and having also taken notice of his seal, which was shown to her, she promptly did as she was desired.
tgt_text.3436: As soon, however, as, through this most base stratagem, she had fallen into the snares which were prepared for her, the wicked wife, goaded to mad- ness by her jealous fury, stripped the girl naked, and had her dogged until she was nearly dead.
tgt_text.3437: It was in vain that the poor girl confessed the truth, which was wrung from her by the lash, and declared that she was wrongfully accused;
tgt_text.3438: in vain she cried out again and again that the young man was her brother.
tgt_text.3439: Her sister-in-law treated her story as a false­ hood, and thrusting a burning brand between her thighs, made her suffer a hideous death.
tgt_text.3440: Immediately upon this, her brother and her husband being informed of her cruel death, hastened to her, and in sore afflic­ tion committed her to the tomb.
tgt_text.3441: Nor was the young man able patiently to endure the miserable fate of his sister, by the hands of her, too, by whom, least of all, it ought to have been occasioned;
tgt_text.3442: but, being racked with grief and choler, he fell into a burning fever, so that he seemed in urgent need of me­ dical aid.
tgt_text.3443: On this his wife, who had long since forfeited her claim to that title, went to a certain physician, notorious for his perfidy, who, being famous for his victories in many a mortal struggle, could enumerate the mighty trophies which his right hand had gained.
tgt_text.3444: To him she immediately offered fifty thousand sesterces, if he would sell her poison so efficacious as to destroy in an instant, that so she might purchase the death of her husband.
tgt_text.3445: This done, she and the physician pretended that the most excellent potion which they had brought, and which the learned call sacred, was necessary for mitigating pains of the viscera, and carrying off the bile;
tgt_text.3446: but, in its stead, was sub­ stituted another potion, sacred to the interests of Proserpine.*
tgt_text.3447: And now, in the presence of the sick man's household, and some of his relations and friends, the physician, with his own hand, after having well stirred the contents, offered the cup.
tgt_text.3448: But that audacious woman, in order that she might at the same moment remove the accomplice in her crime, and save the money which she had promised, held back the cup in the presence of them all, and said, "Most worthy of doctors, you must not give this draught to my dearest husband till you have swallowed a good portion of it yourself.
tgt_text.3449: For how am I to know but that there may be some deadly poison in it ?
tgt_text.3450: And this ought by no means to offend you, who are a man so pru­ dent and so learned, if I, as an affectionate wife, am anxious for the safety of my husband, and so perform a necessary act of duty."
tgt_text.3451: The physician, quite confounded by the desperate assurance of the bloodthirsty woman, and having no time to think of any subterfuge, could not help drinking largely of the potion, lest he should excite suspicion of his guilt if he showed any hesitation or fear.
tgt_text.3452: Then the young man, confidently fol­ lowing his example, took the cup from his hand, and drank what was left.
tgt_text.3453: The matter being for the present finished, the physician was preparing to return home as quickly as possible, in order that he might counteract the deadly effects of the poison he had taken, by a timely antidote.
tgt_text.3454: But the barbarous woman, bent on completing her infernal work, would not suffer him to de­ part from her a hair's breadth till, as she said, the potion should have been digested and its effect determined by actual proof.
tgt_text.3455: However, after much importunate entreaty, she at length reluctantly allowed him to go.
tgt_text.3456: In the meantime, the virulence of the fatal poison had spread through all his inside, and made havoc in his vitals.
tgt_text.3457: Stupified, and in excruciating pain, it was with the utmost difficulty he reached home, where he had barely time to relate what had happened, and give in­ junctions to his wife, at all events, to demand the promised re­ ward for thus ensuring the death of two persons.
tgt_text.3459: by a violent death, did this very celebrated doctor breathe his last.
tgt_text.3460: Nor did the young man live much longer, but perished by the same kind of death, amid the feigned tears of his false wife.
tgt_text.3461: After he had been committed to the tomb, and a few days had intervened, during which funeral obsequies were per­ formed for the dead, the widow of the physician came and demanded the money which was due for the double homicide.
tgt_text.3462: But the other widow, always consistent with herself, put on a very unreal appearance of good faith, and replied with great suavity, assuring the applicant that she would promptly pay ner the stipulated sum, only she wished she would give her a little of the same mixture, for the purpose of completing the business she had begun.
tgt_text.3463: Completely duped by her insidious perfidy, the doctor's widow readily consented to do as she was requested;
tgt_text.3464: and that she might ingratiate herself the more with this wealthy wo­ man, she hastened home, and immediately brought her the whole box of poison.
tgt_text.3465: Having, therefore, obtained that power­ ful instrument of crime, the wretch now prepared to indulge her murderous propensities without stint.
tgt_text.3466: She had an infant daughter, by the husband whom she had lately murdered;
tgt_text.3467: and she felt extremely galled that the laws would give to this little child the inheritance of her father, as being his next of kin.
tgt_text.3468: Coveting the whole patrimony of the daughter, she waited only for an opportunity of depriving her of life.
tgt_text.3469: Making sure, therefore, that wicked mothers come in for the reversion of the inheritances of their deceased children, she showed herself to be just such a parent as she had been a wife.
tgt_text.3470: Accordingly, preparing a breakfast, she seized her op­ portunity, and with the same poison destroyed both the widow of the physician and her own daughter.
tgt_text.3471: As for the child, the baneful venom instantly stopped her breathing, and consumed her tender life.
tgt_text.3472: But as for the doctor's widow, when she felt the virus of the detestable drug creeping through her lungs, she at once suspected the truth;
tgt_text.3473: the increasing difficulty of her breathing converted her suspicion into a certainty, and she hastened at once to the house of the governor of the province, clamorous for justice, and declaring she had enormous crimes to reveal.
tgt_text.3474: A great concourse of people gathered round her, and the governor immediately gave her a hearing.
tgt_text.3475: After she had unfolded to him from first to last all the atrocities of that horrible woman, she was seized with a fit;
tgt_text.3476: her mouth, that was open in the act of speaking, closed convulsively;
tgt_text.3477: she ground her teeth violently together, and fell dead at the go­ vernor's feet.
tgt_text.3478: That able and energetic functionary would not allow the manifold crimes of this execrable poisoner to lose their terrors by delay, but immediately ordered her chamber­ maids to be brought before him, and extracted the truth from them by means of torture.
tgt_text.3479: On their deposition he sentenced the culprit to a punishment which was no doubt less than she deserved, but as no other torment could be devised so well adapted to the enormity of her guilt, he ordered that she should be thrown to wild beasts.
tgt_text.3481: With such a woman as this it was determined that I should be publicly connected, as if I had been lawfully married to her.
tgt_text.3482: It was with extreme anguish, therefore, that I looked forward to the day of the spectacle;
tgt_text.3483: being frequently tempted rather to destroy myself with my own hand, than be defiled by con­ tact with such an abandoned woman, or be disgraced by the infamy of such a public spectacle.
tgt_text.3484: But, as I was destitute of human hands and of fingers, I had no means of drawing a sword with my round and stumpy hoof.
tgt_text.3485: However, I consoled myself, as well as I could, in my extreme anguish, with a slen­ der hope;
tgt_text.3486: for the spring now beginning to appear, would deck all the country with flowering buds, and clothe the meadows with a purple glow;
tgt_text.3487: the roses would burst forth from their thorny cells, exhaling aromatic odours, and these would restore me to my former shape as Lucius.
tgt_text.3488: And now behold, the day destined for the show came;
tgt_text.3489: and amid shouts of applause, a long train escorting me, I was led to the amphitheatre.
tgt_text.3490: During the first part of the performance, which was devoted to the joyous choral dances of the players, I was placed outside the gate, and was glad to crop some very fresh grass which grew just at the entrance;
tgt_text.3491: while I every now and then delighted my curious eyes with a most agreeable view of the spectacle through the open gate.
tgt_text.3492: Beautiful boys and maidens, in the bloom of youth, splen­ didly dressed, moved with great elegance of gesture through the graceful evolutions of the Greek Pyrrhic dance.
tgt_text.3493: Now they revolved in a circle;
tgt_text.3494: now they deployed into an oblique line, with hands joined ;
tgt_text.3495: at times they formed a wedge-like figure enclosing an open square;
tgt_text.3496: then they parted into two troops, and went through a variety of intricate movements, till they ceased at the sound of the trumpet.
tgt_text.3497: Then the screen was lowered, the hangings were drawn aside, and a dramatic scene was exhibited.
tgt_text.3498: There was a wooden structure formed in imitation of that celebrated mountain, Ida, of which the poet Homer has sung.
tgt_text.3499: It was a fabric of considerable height, covered over with turf and with growing trees up to the very top, whence, by the con­ trivance of the artist, a fountain was made to flow and pour down a stream of water.
tgt_text.3500: A few goats cropped the grass, and a young man, handsomely arrayed in flowing Barbaric vestments, and having his head covered with a golden tiara, in resemblance of Paris, the Phrygian shepherd, appeared to be employed in pas­ toral pursuits.
tgt_text.3501: A beautiful boy then came forward, his only garment being the mantle generally worn by striplings, which covered his left shoulder.
tgt_text.3502: His beautiful yellow hair flowed loosely, and from the midst of it issued a pair of little golden wings;
tgt_text.3503: these and the caduceus he carried showed him to be Mercury.
tgt_text.3504: He danced forward, holding in his hand a golden apple, which he presented to the performer who personated Paris, made known to him by signs what Jove commanded, and gracefully retired.
tgt_text.3505: A girl then made her appearance, of noble features, representing the goddess Juno.:
tgt_text.3506: for her head was surrounded with a white diadem, and she bore a sceptre in her hand.
tgt_text.3507: Another then entered, who was easy to be recog­ nized as Minerva, having on her head a shining helmet, en­ circled with a wreath of olive.
tgt_text.3508: She raised her shield aloft, and brandished her spear, like that goddess when engaged in battle.
tgt_text.3509: After these came another female, of surpassing beauty;
tgt_text.3510: the loveliness of her divine complexion declared her to be Venus, and Venus such as she was while yet a virgin.
tgt_text.3511: Her perfect form was naked, all but some charms imperfectly concealed by a gauze scarf, which the wind played with amorously, some­ times uncovering the beauties beneath it, sometimes pressing it against the limbs, and displaying their delicious contour.
tgt_text.3512: The goddess appeared in two different colours;
tgt_text.3513: her body was dazzlingly white, because she had descended from the heavens, while her silken garment was azure, because she had emerged from the sea.
tgt_text.3514: The virgins who represented the goddesses were accompanied by their respective attendants :
tgt_text.3515: Juno by two young players, representing Castor and Pollux, whose heads were covered with helmets of semi-oval form, graced with a cluster of stars.
tgt_text.3516: She advanced with a calm and unaffected air to the warbling of the flute, and promised the shepherd, with modest gestures, that she would bestow on him the empire of all Asia, if he adjudged to her the prize of beauty.
tgt_text.3517: She who personated Minerva was attended by two armed youths, Terror and Fear, who danced before her with drawn swords.
tgt_text.3518: Behind her a piper played a martial air, mingling shrill and deep-braying tones, and excited the agility of the dancers as with the blast of the trumpet.
tgt_text.3519: With restless head and threatening glances, Pallas bounded forward, and with animated gesture signified to Paris that if he pronounced her victorious in the contest of beauty, she woUld render him illustrious for his valour, and his achievements in war.
tgt_text.3520: Greeted with vast applause from the spectators, Venus ad­ vanced with a sweet smile, and stood still in a graceful attitude in the middle of the stage, surrounded by a throng of merry little boys, such plump, round-limbed, fair-skinned little fel­ lows, you would have sworn they were real Cupids, who had just flown from heaven or from the sea;
tgt_text.3521: for they had little wings, and arrows, and all other accoutrements conformable;
tgt_text.3522: and they carried gleaming torches before their mistress, as if to light her way to a nuptial banquet.
tgt_text.3523: She had also in her train a lovely choir of virgins, the charming Graces and the Hours, who strewed the path of their goddess with loose flowers and bouquets, and propitiated the queen of pleasure with the pleasant offerings of the spring.
tgt_text.3524: Presently the flutes began to breathe soft Lydian airs, that thrilled the audience with delight;
tgt_text.3525: but greater still was their delight, when Venus began to move in concert with the music, and with slow lingering steps, and gentle sinuous flexure of the spine and head, and graceful movements of the arms, to respond to the soft modulations of the flutes;
tgt_text.3526: while now her eyes swam with voluptuous languor, now flashed with the ardour of pas­ sion, and sometimes she seemed, as it were, to dance with her eyes alone.
tgt_text.3527: As soon as she had approached close to the judge, she was understood to promise, by the movements of her arms, that if she was preferred to the other goddesses, she would bestow on Paris a wife surpassing all women in beauty, in a word, one like herself.
tgt_text.3528: Gladly, then, did the young Phrygian deliver to her the golden apple he held in his hand, as a token of her victory.
tgt_text.3529: What wonder is it, then, you vilest of people, forensic cattle rather, vultures clad in gowns, if all judges now sell their de­ cisions for a price ?
tgt_text.3530: Even in the early ages of the world, favour was able to corrupt judgment in a question agitated between Gods and men, and a young man, a rustic and a shep­ herd, elected judge by the counsels of mighty Jupiter, bartered the first judicial decision for the lucre of lust, ensuring thereby the destruction of all his race.
tgt_text.3531: Ay, by Hercules, and another such judgment was given in later times, by the illustrious leaders of the Greeks, when Palamedes, renowned for wisdom and learning, was condemned on false accusations as a traitor;
tgt_text.3532: as also when the mendicant Ulysses was preferred to the mighty Ajax, who excelled in military prowess.
tgt_text.3533: And what sort of judgment was that given by those renowned lawgivers, the Athenians, .those clever people, and masters of all the sciences?
tgt_text.3534: Was not that divinely wise old man, whom the Delphic god pronounced superior in wisdom to all men, circumvented by the treachery and envy of a most infamous faction, as a de­ clared corrupter of youth, though he restrained their excesses as with a bridle ?
tgt_text.3535: Was he not cut off by the deadly juice of a pestilential herb, leaving to his fellow-citizens the stain-of indelible ignominy ?
tgt_text.3536: For even at this day the most excellent philosophers make choice of his most holy sect before all others, and swear by his name, in their highest aspirations for con­ summate happiness.
tgt_text.3537: Lest, however, any one blame this outburst of indignation, and say to himself, Look ye now, are we to suffer an ass to philosophize to us ?
tgt_text.3538: I shall again return to the point in the narrative from which I digressed.
tgt_text.3539: After that judgment of Paris was finished, Juno and Minerva retired from the stage in sorrow and anger, and showed by their gestures the indig­ nation they felt at being rejected;
tgt_text.3540: but Venus, full of joy and merriment, testified her gladness by dancing with all her choir.
tgt_text.3541: Then wine, mixed with saffron, burst forth on high from the summit of the mountain, through a pipe that lay concealed, and flowing in scattered streams, besprinkled as it fell, with an odoriferous shower, the goats that fed around, and changed their native whiteness for a more beautiful yellow tint.
tgt_text.3542: And now, the whole theatre exhaling a sweet odour, a chasm of the earth absorbed the wooden mountain.
tgt_text.3543: One of the soldiers now ran down the street, to fulfil the demands of the people, and bring from the public prison the woman before-mentioned, who, as I have stated, was condemned to the wild beasts, on account of her manifold crimes, and des­ tined to be my illustrious bride.
tgt_text.3544: What was intended also to be our genial bed was already prepared.
tgt_text.3545: It was brilliantly adorned with the Indian tortoise-shell, swelling with feathery heaps, and decorated with a silken coverlet.
tgt_text.3546: As for me, be­ sides the shame of being thus publicly exhibited, and besides the contact of that wicked and polluted woman, I was also in the highest degree tormented with the fear of death ;
tgt_text.3547: for it struck me that if, while we were performing our prescribed part in the exhibition, any wild beast should be let in on pur­ pose to destroy the woman, it would not be so remarkably well trained or sagacious, or so temperate and abstemious, as to tear the woman to pieces who was at my side, and spare me, as being uncondemned, and guilty of no crime.
tgt_text.3548: Being therefore alarmed, not on grounds of delicacy alone, but on account of my life, while my master was intent on pre­ paring for the representation, and all his servants were partly engaged in getting ready for the spectacle of hunting, and partly in gazing at the grandeur of the show :
tgt_text.3549: and as no one thought that so tame an ass required to be so very attentively watched, and I was free to follow my own devices, accordingly little by little I stole away softly and quietly.
tgt_text.3550: When I reached the nearest gate, I hurried along at a most rapid pace.
tgt_text.3551: And after I had travelled a hot gallop of six miles, I arrived at Cenchreæ;
tgt_text.3552: a city which has the reputation of being the most noble colony of the Corinthians, and is washed by the Ægean and Saronic sea.
tgt_text.3553: Here, also, there is a port, which is a most safe harbour for ships, and frequented by a vast concourse of people.
tgt_text.3554: Avoiding, therefore, the crowds, and choosing a sequestered spot on the sea-shore, close to the spray of the waves, I stretched my weary body on the soft bosom of the sand.
tgt_text.3555: The chariot of the sun had sped onward to the end of its course;
tgt_text.3556: and I re­ signed myself to repose, and was soon wrapped in sweet sleep.
tgt_text.3557: AWAKING in sudden alarm about the first watch of the night, I beheld the full orb of the moon shining with re­ markable brightness, and just then emerging from the waves of the sea.
tgt_text.3558: Availing myself, therefore, of the silence and soli­ tude of night, as I was also well aware that the great primal goddess possessed a transcendent majesty, and that human affairs are entirely governed by her providence;
tgt_text.3559: and that not only cattle and wild beasts, but likewise things inanimate, are invigorated by the divine influence of her light;
tgt_text.3560: that the bodies likewise which are on the earth, in the heavens, and in the sea, at one time increase with her increments, and at another lessen duly with her wanings;
tgt_text.3561: being well assured of this, I determined to implore the august image of the goddess then present, Fate, as I supposed, being now satiated with my many and great calamities, and holding out to me at last some pro­ spect of relief.
tgt_text.3562: Shaking off all drowsiness, therefore, I rose with alacrity, and directly, with the intention of purifying myself, began bathing in the sea.
tgt_text.3563: Having dipped my head seven times in the waves, because, according to the divine Pythagoras, that number is especially adapted to religious purposes, I joyously and with alacrity thus supplicated with a tearful countenance the transcendently powerful Goddess:
tgt_text.3565: Queen of heaven, whether thou art the genial Ceres, the prime parent of fruits, who, joyous at the discovery of thy daughter, didst banish the savage nutriment of the ancient acorn, and pointing out a better food, dost now till the Eleusi- nian soil;
tgt_text.3566: or whether thou art celestial Venus, who, in the first origin of things, didst associate the different sexes, through the creation of mutual love, and having propagated an eternal offspring in the human race, art now worshipped in the sea- girt shrine of Paphos;
tgt_text.3567: or whether thou art the sister of Phoebus, who, by relieving the pangs of women in travail by soothing remedies, hast brought into the world multitudes so innumerable, and art now venerated, in the far-famed shrines of Ephesus;
tgt_text.3568: or whether thou art Proserpine, terrific, with midnight bowlings, with triple features checking the attack of the ghosts, closing the recesses of the earth, and who wan­ dering over many a grove, art propitiated by various modes of worship ;
tgt_text.3569: with that feminine brightness of thine, illuminating the walls of every city, and with thy vaporous beams nurtur­ ing the joyous seeds of plants, and for the revolutions of the sun ministering thy fitful gleams:
tgt_text.3570: by whatever name, by whatever ceremonies, and under whatever form* it is lawful to invoke thee;
tgt_text.3571: do thou graciously succour me in this my extreme distress, support my fallen fortune, and grant me rest and peace, after the endurance of so many sad calamities.
tgt_text.3572: Let there be an end of my sufferings, let there be an end of my perils.
tgt_text.3573: Remove from me the dire form of a quadruped, restore me to the sight of my kindred, restore me to Lucius, my former self.
tgt_text.3574: But if any offended deity pursues me with inexorable cruelty, may it at least be allowed me to die, if it is not al­ lowed me to live.
tgt_text.3575: "Having after this manner poured forth my prayers and added bitter lamentations, sleep again overpowered my stricken feelings on the same bed.
tgt_text.3576: Scarcely had I closed my eyes, when behold!
tgt_text.3577: a divine form emerged from the middle of the sea, and disclosed features that even the gods themselves might venerate.
tgt_text.3578: After this, by degrees, the vision, resplendent throughout the whole body, seemed gradually to take its stand before me, rising above the surface of the sea.
tgt_text.3579: I will even make an attempt to describe to you its wondrous appearance, if, indeed, the poverty of human language will afford me the power of appropriately setting it forth;
tgt_text.3580: or, if the Divinity herself will supply me with a sufficient stock of eloquent diction.
tgt_text.3581: In the first place, then, her hair, long and hanging in tapered ringlets, fell luxuriantly on her divine neck;
tgt_text.3582: a crown of varied form encircled the summit of her head, with a diversity of flowers, and in the middle of it, just over her forehead, there was a flat circlet, which resembled a mirror, or rather emitted a white refulgent light, thus indicating that she was the moon.
tgt_text.3583: Vipers rising from furrows of the earth, supported this on the right hand and on the left, while ears of corn pro­ jected on either side.
tgt_text.3584: Her garment was of many colours, woven of fine flax;
tgt_text.3585: in one part it was resplendent with a clear white colour, in another it was yellow like the blooming crocus, and in another flaming with a rosy redness.
tgt_text.3586: And then, what rivetted my gaze far more than all, was her mantle of the deepest black, that shone with a glossy lustre.
tgt_text.3587: It was wrapped around her, and passing from below her right side over the left shoulder, was fastened in a knot that resem­ bled the boss of a shield, while a part of the robe fell down in many folds, and gracefully floated with its little knots of fringe that edged its extremities.
tgt_text.3588: Glittering stars were dispersed along the embroidered extremities of the robe, and over its whole surface;
tgt_text.3589: and in the middle of them a moon of two weeks old breathed forth its flaming fires.
tgt_text.3590: Besides this, a garland, wholly consisting of flowers and fruits of every kind, adhered naturally to the border of this beautiful mantle, in whatever direction it was wafted by the breeze.
tgt_text.3591: The objects which she carried in her hands were of a diffe­ rent description.
tgt_text.3592: In her right hand she bore a brazen sistrum,* through the narrow rim of which, winding just like a girdle for the body, passed a few little rods, producing a sharp shrill sound, while her arm imparted motion to the triple chords.
tgt_text.3593: An oblong vessel, made of gold, in the shape of a boat, hung down from her left hand, on the handle of which, in that part in which it met the eye, was an asp raising its head erect, and with its throat puffed out on either side.
tgt_text.3594: Shoes, too, woven from the palm, the emblem of victory, covered her ambrosial feet.
tgt_text.3595: Such was the appearance of the mighty goddess, as, breath­ ing forth the fragrant perfumes of Arabia the happy, she deigned with her divine voice thus to address me:
tgt_text.3597: moved by thy prayers, I appear to thee;
tgt_text.3598: I, who am Nature, the parent of all things, the mistress of all the ele­ ments, the primordial offspring of time, the supreme among Divinities, the queen of departed spirits, the first of the celes­ tials, and the uniform manifestation of the Gods and Goddesses;
tgt_text.3599: who govern by my nod the luminous heights of heaven, the salubrious breezes of the ocean, and the anguished silent realms of the shades below:
tgt_text.3600: whose one sole divinity the whole orb of the earth venerates under a manifold form, with different rites, and under a variety of appellations.
tgt_text.3601: Hence the Phrygians, that primaeval race, call me Pessinuntica, the Mother of the Gods;
tgt_text.3602: the Aborigines of Attica, Cecropian Minerva;
tgt_text.3603: the Cyprians, in their sea-girt isle, Paphian Venus;
tgt_text.3604: the arrow- bearing Cretans, Diana Dictynna;
tgt_text.3607: and the Eleusinians, the ancient Goddess Ceres.
tgt_text.3608: Some call me Juno, others Bellona, others Hecate, and others Rhamnusia.
tgt_text.3609: But those who are illumined by the earliest rays of that divinity, the Sun, when he rises, the Æthopians, the Arii, and the Egyptians, so skilled in ancient learning, worshipping me with ceremonies quite appropriate, call me by my true name, Queen Isis.
tgt_text.3610: Behold then, commiserating your calamities, I am come to thy assistance;
tgt_text.3611: favouring and pro­ pitious I am come.
tgt_text.3615: Soon, through my providence, shall the day of deliverance shine upon you.
tgt_text.3616: Listen, there­ fore, attentively to these my instructions."
tgt_text.3617: Eternal religion has consecrated to me the day which will be born from this night;
tgt_text.3618: to-morrow my priests offer to me the first fruits of the opened navigation, and dedicate to me a new ship, for that the wintry tempests are now appeased, and the stormy waves of the ocean lulled, and the sea itself has become navigable.
tgt_text.3619: That sacred ceremonial you must await, with a mind neither full of anxiety, nor intent upon subjects that are profane.
tgt_text.3620: For the priest, at my command, will carry in the procession a crown of roses, attached to the sistrum in his right hand.
tgt_text.3621: Without delay, then, pushing the crowd aside, join my procession, and put your trust in my gracious disposition ;
tgt_text.3622: then, having approached close, as though to kiss the hand of the priest, gently pluck the roses, and at once divest yourself of the hide of that abominable beast, which I have long looked upon with detestation."
tgt_text.3623: Nor hold in dread any thing pertaining to my concerns as difficult.
tgt_text.3624: For even at this very same instant* of time in which I appear to you here present, I am giving orders also to my priest how to bring about the things that are to take place hereafter.
tgt_text.3625: By my command, the dense crowds of people shall give way before you.
tgt_text.3626: Neither, amid the joyous rites and festive scenes, will any one view with abhorrence the unsightliness of the figure which you bear, or malignantly accuse you, by putting a sinister interpretation on the sudden change of your form.
tgt_text.3627: Only remember, and always keep it fast in the very depths of your heart, that the remaining period of your life must be dedi­ cated to me, even to the moment of your latest breath.
tgt_text.3628: Nor is it unjust that you should devote your whole life to that god­ dess, by whose assistance you will have been restored to human form.
tgt_text.3629: But under my protection you will live happy, you will live glorious:
tgt_text.3630: and when, having passed through the allotted period of your life, you shall descend to the realms beneath, there, also, in the subterranean hemisphere, you, dwelling in the Elysian fields, shall frequently adore me whom you now behold thus propitious to you, and shall there see me shining amidst the darkness of Acheron, and reigning in the Stygian realms.
tgt_text.3631: And further, if you shall be found to deserve the protection of my divinity by sedulous obedience, religious de­ votion, and inviolable chastity, you shall be sensible that it is possible for me, and me alone, to extend your life beyond the limits that have been appointed to it by your destiny.
tgt_text.3632: "The venerable oracle having thus concluded, the invin­ cible divinity dissolved into herself.
tgt_text.3633: Instantly shaking off sleep, I arose, in a state of fear and joy, and bathed in per­ spiration.
tgt_text.3634: Astonished in the highest degree at so evident a manifestation of the powerful goddess, having sprinkled myself with the spray of the sea, and intent on her high commands, I tried to recall to mind the successive particulars of her injunc­ tions.
tgt_text.3635: Soon after this, the golden sun arose, and put to flight the clouds of dark night:
tgt_text.3636: and now, behold, a crowd of people filled all the streets with a religious procession, conducted in a style of triumph.
tgt_text.3637: All things likewise, independently of my own delight, seemed to me to be affected with the greatest hilarity, insomuch that I thought even the cattle of all kinds, every house, and the day itself, wore an aspect of gladness and serenity;
tgt_text.3638: for a sunny and placid day had suddenly succeeded to the frost of the previous one;
tgt_text.3639: so that, allured by the warmth of the spring, the tuneful little birds sang sweetly, and with their merry warbling soothed Her who was the mother of the stars, the parent of the seasons, and the mistress of the whole universe.
tgt_text.3640: And then the trees, too, both those prolific and those which only yielded a shade, unbound from their wintry sleep by the warm southern breezes, and embellished with young foliage, sent forth a sweet rustling sound from their branches.
tgt_text.3641: The waves of the sea, no longer heaving turbidly to the roaring blast of the tempest, gently washed the shore;
tgt_text.3642: the dark clouds were dispersed, and the heavens shone with the serene splendour of their native light.
tgt_text.3643: And now, behold, the prelude to the grand procession came gradually into action.
tgt_text.3644: The persons who composed it were all finely caparisoned in various ways, each according to his own taste and inclination.
tgt_text.3645: This man, being girded with a belt, repre­ sented a soldier;
tgt_text.3646: another was equipped as a hunter, with a short scarf, a hunting-knife, and javelin.
tgt_text.3647: Another, wearing gilded sandals, a silken garment, and precious female ornaments, and with false hair on his head, personated a woman by his appear­ ance and his gait.
tgt_text.3648: Another, with his boots, his shield, his helmet, and his sword, appeared as though he had come straight from the school of the gladiators.
tgt_text.3649: There was one who played the part of a magistrate, with the fasces and the purple robe;
tgt_text.3650: another that of a philosopher, with his cloak, his staff, his wooden-clogged shoes, and his goatish beard;
tgt_text.3651: two persons, with dissimilar reeds, represented, the one a fowler with bird­ lime, and the other a fisherman with his hook.
tgt_text.3652: I also saw a tame she-bear, wearing the dress of a woman, and carried in a chair;
tgt_text.3653: an ape, too, with a plaited straw hat on its head, and clothed with a Phrygian garment of saffron colour, carrying in its hand a golden cup, and representing the shepherd Ganymede;
tgt_text.3654: likewise an ass, on which wings were glued, and which walked near a feeble old man ;
tgt_text.3655: so that you would certainly have said that the one was Bellerophon, and the other Pegasus;
tgt_text.3656: but still you would have enjoyed your laugh at both.
tgt_text.3657: Amid this merry masquerade of the swarming people, the procession proper of the guardian Goddess now advanced.
tgt_text.3658: Females, splendidly arrayed in white garments, expressing their joy by various gestures, and adorned with vernal chaplets, scattered flowers on the ground from their bosoms, along the path of the sacred procession.
tgt_text.3659: Others, again, with mirrors placed upon their backs, showed all who followed to the God­ dess, with their faces towards her as if they were coming to meet her.
tgt_text.3660: Others, carrying ivory combs, imitated the combing and bedecking of her regal hair, with the motion of their arms, and the twisting of their fingers.
tgt_text.3661: There were others, too, who sprinkled the streets with drops of genial balsam, and other kinds of perfume.
tgt_text.3662: In addition to all this, there was a great multitude of men and women, who propitiated the Goddess, offspring of the celestial stars, by bearing lamps, torches, wax- tapers, and other kinds of artificial light.
tgt_text.3663: Next came musicians, playing sweetly on pipes and flutes.
tgt_text.3664: A graceful choir of chosen youths, in snow-white garments, followed them, repeating a beautiful song, which an excellent poet had composed under favour of the Muses, the words of which explained the first origin of the votive procession.
tgt_text.3665: Pipers also, consecrated to the great Serapis, played an air appropriate to the worship of the god, on pipes with transverse mouth-pieces, and tubes held ob­ liquely towards their right ears.
tgt_text.3666: There were, also, a number of persons, whose office it was to give notice that room should be left for the sacred procession to pass.
tgt_text.3667: Then came a multi­ tude of those who had been initiated into the sacred rites of the goddess, consisting of men and women of all classes and ages, resplendent with the pure whiteness of their linen gar­ ments.
tgt_text.3668: The women had their anointed hair enveloped in a transparent covering;
tgt_text.3669: but the men had shaven and shining pates ;
tgt_text.3670: earthly stars were these of extreme sanctity, who kept up a shrill and incessant tinkling upon brazen, silver, and even gold sistra.
tgt_text.3671: But the chief ministers of the sacred rites, clothed in garments of white linen, drawn close over the breast, and hanging down to their feet, carried the insignia of the mighty Gods, exposed full to view.
tgt_text.3672: The first held aloft a brilliant lamp, not by any means resembling those lamps of ours which illumine banquets at night;
tgt_text.3673: but it was of gold, of a boat-like form, and emitted a flame of considerable magnitude, from an aperture in the middle.
tgt_text.3674: The second was arrayed in a similar manner, but carried in both his hands models of altars, * to which the auxiliary providence of the supreme goddess gave the appropriate name of auxilia."
tgt_text.3675: The third bore a palm tree, the leaves of which were beautifully wrought in gold, as also the caduceus of Mercury.
tgt_text.3676: The fourth displayed the sym­ bol of Equity, a left hand, fashioned with the palm expanded ;
tgt_text.3677: which seems to be more adapted to administering Equity than the right, from its natural inertness, and its being endowed with no craft and no subtlety.
tgt_text.3678: The same person also carried a golden vessel, which was rounded in the shape of the female breast, and from which he poured forth milk on the ground.
tgt_text.3679: The fifth bore a golden corn-fan, made with thickset branches of gold ;
tgt_text.3681: In the next place, appeared the gods that deigned to walk with the feet of men.
tgt_text.3682: Here, dreadful to view, was the mes­ senger of the gods above, and of those of the realms beneath, standing erect, with a face partly black, and partly of a golden hue, bearing in his left hand a caduceus, and shaking in his right a green branch of palm ;
tgt_text.3683: close upon whose footsteps fol­ lowed a cow, in an erect position ;
tgt_text.3684: this cow being the prolific resemblance of the all-parent goddess, and seated on the shoul­ ders of one of the blessed devotees of this divinity, who acted gesticulatingly as he walked.
tgt_text.3685: Another carried a chest, con­ taining the secret utensils of this stupendous mystery.
tgt_text.3686: Another bore in his beatified bosom a venerable effigy of his supreme Divinity, bearing no resemblance to any bird or beast, wild or tame, or even to man;
tgt_text.3687: but worthy of all veneration for the exquisite art with which it was wrought, as also for its very originality, and an ineffable symbol of a sublime religion, the mysteries of which were ever to be kept in deep silence.
tgt_text.3688: It was of burnished gold, after the following manner:
tgt_text.3689: there was a small urn, hollowed out in a most artistic manner, with a bottom quite round, and which outside was covered with the wonderful hieroglyphics of the Egyptians.
tgt_text.3690: The spout of this urn was very long, not much elevated;
tgt_text.3691: a handle was attached to the other side, and projected from the urn with a wide sweep.
tgt_text.3692: On this lay an asp, uplifting its scaly, wrinkled, and swollen throat, and embraced it with its winding folds.
tgt_text.3693: At last the moment was at hand, when I was to experience the blessing promised me by the most potent goddess;
tgt_text.3694: and the priest, attired just as she had described, approached with the .
tgt_text.3696: In his right hand he carried the sistrum of the goddess, and a crown of roses ;
tgt_text.3697: and by Hercules, a crown it was for me;
tgt_text.3698: since by the providence of the mighty goddess, after having endured so many hardships, and escaped so many dangers, I should now achieve a victory over my cruel enemy, Fortune.
tgt_text.3699: Still, however, though agitated by a sudden burst of joy, I did not rush forward at once, lest the tranquil order of the sacred procession should be disturbed by the impetuosity of a quadruped;
tgt_text.3700: but passed through the crowd with a quiet and altogether human step, and a sidelong movement of my body, and as the people gave way, through the interference, no doubt, of the goddess, I gradually crept nearer and nearer.
tgt_text.3701: But the priest, as I could plainly perceive, recollecting the nocturnal oracle, and struck with wonder at the coincidence with the duty which he had been commanded to perform, instantly stood still, and extending his right hand of his own accord, presented the chaplet to my very mouth.
tgt_text.3702: Trembling, and with a great beating of my heart, I seized the bright rosy chaplet, and greedily, most greedily devoured it.
tgt_text.3703: Nor did the celestial promise deceive me;
tgt_text.3704: for immediately my unsightly and brutal figure left me.
tgt_text.3705: First of all, my rough hair fell off, and next my thick skin became thin;
tgt_text.3707: my hoofs spread out into feet and toes;
tgt_text.3708: my hands were no longer feet, but ready for the duties of their elevated position, My long neck was shortened;
tgt_text.3709: my face and my head became round;
tgt_text.3710: my enormous ears were restored to their former small dimensions;
tgt_text.3711: my stony teeth returned to the diminutive size of those of men;
tgt_text.3712: and the tail, which before especially annoyed me, was no where to be seen.
tgt_text.3713: The people were as­ tonished, and the religious adored the power of the supreme Divinity, so manifested in the facility of my restoration, which resembled the visions of a dream.
tgt_text.3714: Extending their hands to­ wards the heavens, they attested, with a loud and unanimous voice, the favour of the goddess thus signally displayed.
tgt_text.3715: As for me, I stood riveted to the spot in excessive asto­ nishment, my mind being unable to contain a delight so sudden and so great, quite at a loss what first and in especial to say, how to make a commencement with a new voice, how most auspiciously to prepare my address, my tongue being now born • again, and in what words sufficiently to express my thanks to a Goddess so great.
tgt_text.3716: The priest, however, who through the divine admonition knew all my misfortunes from the beginning, though he himself also was in a state of utter astonishment at this remarkable miracle, at once signified his wish by nodding his head, and ordered that a linen garment should be given me, for the purpose of covering my nakedness.
tgt_text.3717: For, the very instant that the ass had laid aside his abominable covering, I carefully shaded myself with a natural screen, as much as it was possible for a naked person to do, by closely compressing my thighs, and applying my hands.
tgt_text.3718: Upon this one of the throng of devotees promptly throwing me his upper tunic, covered me therewith;
tgt_text.3719: which being done, the priest with a benign countenance, and, by Hercules, astonished at my perfectly human appearance, thus addressed me:
tgt_text.3720: —" At last, Lucius, you have arrived at the haven of peace and the altar of mercy, after the many and various hardships you have undergone, and all the buffetings of stormy Fortune.
tgt_text.3721: Neither the nobility of your descent, nor your dignified posi­ tion, nor even the learning in which you excel, have benefited you in the slightest degree;
tgt_text.3722: but falling into the slavery of pleasure, in the wantonness of buxom youth, you have reaped the inauspicious reward of your ill-fated curiosity.
tgt_text.3723: Never­ theless, blind Fortune, while harassing you with the worst of dangers, has conducted you, in her short-sighted malice, to this state of religious beatitude.
tgt_text.3724: Let her go now, and rage with all her fury, and let her seek some other object for her cruelty ;
tgt_text.3725: * for direful calamity has no power over those whose lives the majesty of our Goddess has claimed for her own service.
tgt_text.3726: What advantage has unscrupulous For­ tune derived from the robbers, from the wild beasts, from the servitude, from the long toils on rugged roads, and from the fear of death to which you were daily exposed?
tgt_text.3727: You are now received under the guardianship of Fortune, but of a For­ tune who can see, and who even illuminates the other Deities with the splendour of her light.
tgt_text.3728: Assume henceforth a more joyous countenance, such as befits that white garment which you wear.
tgt_text.3729: Follow the train of the Goddess your deliverer with triumphant steps.
tgt_text.3730: Let the irreligious see, let them see and ac­ knowledge their error.
tgt_text.3731: Behold now, Lucius, rejoicing in the providence of great Isis, and freed from his former miseries, triumphs over his destiny.
tgt_text.3732: Nevertheless, that you may be more secure and better protected, enrol your name in this holy militia, which you will hereafter rejoice to belong to;
tgt_text.3733: dedicate yourself to the service of our religion, and voluntarily bend your neck to the yoke of this ministry;
tgt_text.3734: for when you have once begun to serve the Goddess, you will then in a still higher degree enjoy the fruit of your, liberty.
tgt_text.3735: "The worthy priest having uttered these words, while his breath heaved with inspiration, concluded his address, and I mingling with the throng of devotees, accompanied the pro­ cession;
tgt_text.3736: an object of curiosity to the whole city.
tgt_text.3737: All pointed at me with their fingers and heads, and said, "
tgt_text.3738: This day has the august power of all mighty God restored that person to the human form.
tgt_text.3740: and thrice blessed he, to have merited, by the innocence and probity of his past life, such special patronage of heaven;
tgt_text.3741: in that, being after a manner born again, he is immediately affianced to the service of the sacred ministry.
tgt_text.3742: "While these remarks were being made, and amid the tumult of their noisy congratulations, moving slowly on, we now ap­ proached the sea-shore, and came to that very place where, on the preceding day, I, while yet an ass, had laid me down.
tgt_text.3743: The images of the Gods being there arranged in proper order, the chief priest dedicated and consecrated to the Goddess a very skilfully built ship, pictured all over with the curious hiero­ glyphics of the Egyptians, after having most carefully purified it with a lighted torch, an egg, and sulphur, while at the same time his chaste lips poured forth solemn prayers.
tgt_text.3744: The shining white sail of this auspicious bark bore an inscription in large characters, which was a repetition of a vow that had been made on shore for the prosperity of the convoy at this season of the re­ commencement of navigation.
tgt_text.3745: Now the mast was raised, which was a rounded pine tree, tall and well polished, and conspicuous for the beauteous appearance of its head.
tgt_text.3746: The prow also was turned in imitation of a goose's neck,* and covered with gold leaf, the bark shone resplendently, while the whole of the highly polished keel consisted of shining citron wood.
tgt_text.3747: All the people, religious and profane, t vied with each other in heaping together corn-fans laden with aromatics and other sacrificial offerings, and poured upon the waves a libation of milk mixed with other ingredients;
tgt_text.3748: until the ship, freighted with abundant gifts and auspicious prayers, and let slip from the ropes that held the anchor, put to sea with a serene breeze, which seemed to have sprung up for her sake alone.
tgt_text.3749: And after she had pro­ ceeded so far on her course that she could no longer be distin­ guished by us, the bearers of the sacred things again took what each had brought, and began joyfully to return to the temple, in an orderly manner, and in the same form of procession in which they had come.
tgt_text.3750: Now as soon as we arrived at the temple, the chief priest and those who carried the sacred images, and those who had already been initiated into the venerable mysteries, being admitted into the sanctuary of the Goddess, deposited in the accustomed form the breathing effigies.±+
tgt_text.3751: Then, one of these, whom all of them called the scribe, standing before the doors, whilst the company of the Pastophori,* which is the name of the brotherhood of this sacred college, convoked together as to a council, uttered from a high pulpit auspicious wishes, from a book in which was written:
tgt_text.3752: —" To the great Prince, to the Senate, to theEquestrian order, in naval matters and in ships, and all those who are subject to our dominion ;
tgt_text.3753: " and then he pronounced in the Greek language, and according to the Greek custom, the Λαοις ἄϕεσις, [the people may depart.] to which the people responded with a clamour which testified their general satisfaction.
tgt_text.3754: Then every one went home, full of joy, carrying branches of olive, sweet herbs, and garlands of flowers, and after kissing the feet of a silver image of the Goddess, which stood on the steps of the temple.
tgt_text.3755: But my feelings would not allow me to move so much as a nail's breadth from that place;
tgt_text.3756: but wi th my eyes intently fastened on the image of the Goddess, I recalled to memory my past misfortunes.
tgt_text.3757: Fleeting Fame, however, had not in the meantime let her wings remain idle, but had immediately circulated in all direc­ tions in my native country the adorable bounty of the provident Goddess, and my own memorable adventures.
tgt_text.3758: Accordingly, my domestics and servants, and those who were nearest to me by blood, laying aside the sorrow with which they had been afflicted at the false intelligence of my death, and elated with this sudden joy, hastened forthwith to see me, who had been divinely saved and brought back, as it were, from the shades below, and they presented me with gifts of various kinds.
tgt_text.3759: I, too, was delighted to see them, and returned them many thanks for their handsome presents, and the more especially, as my domestics had providently taken care to bring me what would be abundantly sufficient in the way of clothes and money.
tgt_text.3760: Having, therefore, spoken to each of them in such manner as I was in duty bound to do, and related to them my former sorrows and my present joyous prospects, I again re­ turned to what was to me the greatest subject of delight, the contemplation of the Goddess, and procured for myself a tem­ porary habitation within the enclosure of the temple, constantly taking part in the private services of the Goddess, and being inseparable from the brotherhood of the priests, and a constant adorer of the great Divinity.
tgt_text.3761: Nor did I pass a single night or ever close my eyes without some vision from this Divinity, in which she commanded me to be now initiated in her sacred mysteries, to which I had long since been destined.
tgt_text.3762: As for me, though prompted by eager inclination, I was still restrained by religious fear.
tgt_text.3763: For after diligent enquiry, I had found that the requirements of a religious life were full of difficulties;
tgt_text.3764: that the chastity required was a very difficult thing to observe, and that it needed extreme circumspection to preserve such a habit of life from casual defilements.
tgt_text.3765: Frequently pondering over these things, I somehow or other delayed being initiated, although hastening to that conclusion.
tgt_text.3766: One night I had a dream, in which I thought that the chief priest made his appearance, and presented to me his lap full of various things, and on my asking what they were, he answered me, that the things had been sent to me from Thessaly;
tgt_text.3767: for that a servant of mine, whose name was Candidus, had arrived from that province.
tgt_text.3768: When I awoke, I revolved in my mind over and over again what the vision portended, especially as I was certain that I never had any servant who was called by that name.
tgt_text.3769: Still, however, I believed that some profitable result was undoubtedly signified by the priest offering me the things.
tgt_text.3770: Thus, in a state of anxious and bewildered eagerness, I awaited the opening of the temple in the morning.
tgt_text.3771: The white curtains having been drawn aside, we prayed to the venerable presence of the Goddess;
tgt_text.3772: and the priest going round the altars, performed the sacred ceremonial with solemn supplications, and poured forth libations from a chalice of water drawn from a fountain in the precincts of the sanctuary.
tgt_text.3773: The sacred rites therefore, being now duly performed, the devotees, saluting the breaking dawn, in a loud voice announced tho first hour of the day.
tgt_text.3775: some servants arrived from my country whom I had left there at the time when Fotis, by her unfortu­ nate mistake, had fitted me for a halter;
tgt_text.3776: so recognizing them as my own servants, and finding that they had brought back that horse of mine, after it had been sold from place to place, and which I identified by a mark on its back;
tgt_text.3777: I was then especially struck with admiration at the fitness of my dream, because not only had it come true with respect to the gain it had promised, but it had also predicted to me the recovery of my horse, which was of a white colour, under the designation of my servant Candidus.
tgt_text.3778: I continued to apply myself wholly to attendance on the worship of the Goddess, perceiving that the hopes which I had conceived of future good were now confirmed by present benefits.
tgt_text.3779: And besides, my desire of receiving initiation in the sacred duties, increased daily more and more.
tgt_text.3780: Accordingly, I frequently went to the chief priest, and most earnestly en­ treated him to initiate me into the mysteries of the holy night;
tgt_text.3781: but he, who was a man of a grave disposition, and remarkable for his strict observance of that abstemious religion, checked my urgent importunity in a mild and gentle manner, and in the way in which parents are in the habit of moderating the inconsiderate requests of their children, while at the same time he soothed me with hopes for the better.
tgt_text.3782: For he said, that the day on which each aspirant might be initiated was indicated by tokens from the Goddess, and that by her providence the priest was selected who was to perform the sacred rites;
tgt_text.3783: and that in like manner by her mandate the expense necessary for the ceremonial was ordained.
tgt_text.3784: All these circumstances, he was of opinion, ought to be awaited with obsequious patience, since we ought, on every consideration, to avoid precipitation and contumacy, and neither be dilatory when called, nor pre­ cipitate when not called.
tgt_text.3785: Nor, indeed, was there a single one of their number who was so lost to a sense of propriety, or rather so bent on his own destruction, as to dare rashly and sacrilegiously to undertake the ministry of the Goddess, and so bring upon himself a deadly mischance, unless she especially ordered him so to do ;
tgt_text.3786: for the gates of the realms beneath, and the guardianship of life, are placed in the hands of the God­ dess, and the initiation into her mysteries is celebrated as bearing a close resemblance to a voluntary death, with a pre­ carious chance of recovery.
tgt_text.3787: Wherefore the divine will of the Goddess has been accustomed to choose for this purpose men who, having arrived at a great age, are now standing at the very utmost limit of life, to whom, however, the mighty secrets of her religion may be safely entrusted,* and whom, through her providence, being after a manner born again, she restores to the career of a new existence.
tgt_text.3788: Therefore it was requisite that I should await the celestial mandate, although by the clear and manifest favour of the great Deity I had already been marked and destined for her blessed ministry;
tgt_text.3789: and I ought thenceforth to abstain from profane and forbidden food, in com­ mon with the other devotees, in order that I might with the most scrupulous strictness proceed on my course to the secret mysteries of the most pure religion.
tgt_text.3790: Thus did the priest express himself, nor was my compliance interrupted by feelings of impatience;
tgt_text.3791: but I attentively per­ formed the daily duties of the sacred ministry, intent upon maintaining a calm demeanour and laudable silence.
tgt_text.3792: Nor did the salutary benevolence of the powerful goddess disappoint me, or torment me with a long delay;
tgt_text.3793: but she clearly admo­ nished me by no obscure mandates in the darksome night, that the day was now arrived that had always been the object of my desire, .and in which she would put me in possession of my extreme wishes.
tgt_text.3794: She also stated what sum of money would be requisite for the expenses of the ceremonial, and at the same time appointed for me, as the dispenser of the rites, the same Mithras, her own high priest, who, she said, was united to me by a certain conjunction of the stars.
tgt_text.3795: Refreshed in mind by these and other benevolent precepts of the supreme Goddess, and shaking off slumber, though it was not yet clear day, I hastened at once to the dwelling of the priest, and saluted him just as he was coming .out of his bed- chamber.
tgt_text.3796: I had now determined to request more earnestly than ever initiation into the sacred rites, as being a thing that was due to me.
tgt_text.3797: He, however, the instant that he saw me, was the first to speak:
tgt_text.3798: "0 my Lucius, how happy and blessed are you, whom the august divinity has thus greatly honoured by her propitious will!
tgt_text.3799: And why," said he, "do you now stand idle, or make any delay?
tgt_text.3800: The day you so earnestly prayed for has now arrived, in which you will be initiated into the most holy mysteries by these hands of mine, in obedience to the divine mandates of the many-titled Goddess.
tgt_text.3801: "And the old man, taking me by the right hand, led me im­ mediately to the doors of the vast temple;
tgt_text.3802: and having performed the office of opening them in the accustomed solemn way, and celebrated the morning sacrifice, he drew forth from the secret recesses of the shrine certain books, written in unknown cha- racters, partly representing in compendious form the words ex­ pressive of their meaning by figures of animals of every kind, and partly fortified against the inquisitive perusal of the pro­ fane, by characters wreathed like knots, and twisting round in shape of a wheel, and with extremities twining one with an­ other, like the tendrils of a vine.
tgt_text.3803: From these books he in­ formed me what was necessary to be provided by me for the purpose of initiation.
tgt_text.3804: Immediately, therefore, I diligently set about purchasing and procuring requisites, and even on a more liberal scale than I was ordered to do, partly at my own expense, and partly through my friends.
tgt_text.3805: And when, now the time, as the priest said, required it, he led me to the nearest bath, accompanied by a crowd of devotees ;
tgt_text.3806: and after I had taken the customary bath, he himself washed and sprinkled me with the purest water, having first implored the pardon of the Gods.
tgt_text.3807: Then, again, he brought me back to the temple, and there placed me at the very feet of the Goddess, two-thirds of the day having now elapsed ;
tgt_text.3808: and giving certain secret instructions, which are too holy to be uttered, he distinctly ordered, before all who were present, that I should abstain from luxurious food for the ten succeeding days, and that I should eat the flesh of no animal, and should abstain from wine.
tgt_text.3809: These ten days having been duly passed by me in reverential abstinence, the day had now arrived for pledging myself to the sacred ministry, and the sun descending, was ushering in the evening.
tgt_text.3810: Then, behold, there was a concourse of the people flocking from every side, every one honouring me with various gifts, according to the ancient custom of these sacred rites.
tgt_text.3811: After this, the priest, all the profane being removed to a dis­ tance, taking hold of me by the hand, brought me into the inner recesses of the sanctuary itself, clothed in a new linen gar­ ment.
tgt_text.3812: Perhaps, curious reader, you may be eager to know what was then said and done ?
tgt_text.3813: I would tell you, were it lawful for me to tell you;
tgt_text.3814: you should know it, if it were lawful for you to hear.
tgt_text.3815: But both the ears that heard these things, and the tongue that told them, would reap the evil results of their rashness.
tgt_text.3816: Still, however, kept in suspense as you probably are with religious longing, I will not torment you with long- protracted anxiety.
tgt_text.3817: Hear, therefore, but believe what is the truth.
tgt_text.3818: I approached the confines of death, and having trod on the threshold of Proserpine, I returned therefrom, being borne through all the elements.
tgt_text.3819: At midnight I saw the sun shining with its brilliant light;
tgt_text.3820: and I approached the presence of the Gods beneath, and the Gods of heaven, and stood near, and worshipped them.
tgt_text.3821: Behold, I have related to you things of which, though heard of by you, you must ne­ cessarily remain ignorant.
tgt_text.3822: I will therefore only relate that which may be enunciated to the understanding of the un­ initiated without a crime.
tgt_text.3823: The morning came, and, the solemnities being performed, I came forth consecrated by being dressed in twelve stoles, an habiliment no doubt of most religious character, but of which I am not forbidden by any obligation to speak, because it was seen by many who were present on the occasion.
tgt_text.3824: For, by order of the priest, I ascended a wooden pulpit, which was in the very middle of the sacred dwelling, and placed before the image of the Goddess, 'full in view, in a garment which was of linen, but elegantly coloured.
tgt_text.3825: A precious scarf also descended from my shoulders behind my back down to my ankles, and to whatever part of me you directed your view, you would have seen something to arrest your attention in the animals which were painted round my vestment in various colours.
tgt_text.3826: Here were Indian serpents, there Hyperborean griffins, which the other hemisphere generates in the form of a bird wearing wings.
tgt_text.3827: The persons devoted to the service of the divinity call this the Olympic stole.
tgt_text.3828: Then, in my right hand I carried a burning torch;
tgt_text.3829: while a graceful chaplet encircled my head, the shining leaves of the palm tree projecting from it like rays of light.
tgt_text.3830: Thus arrayed like the sun, and placed so as to resemble a statue, on a sudden, the curtains being drawn aside, I was ex­ posed to the gaze of the multitude.
tgt_text.3831: After this, I celebrated the most joyful day of my initiation, as my natal day, and there was a joyous banquet and mirthful conversation.
tgt_text.3832: The third day also was celebrated with the like rites and cere­ monies, and was accompanied by a religious breakfast, and the due termination of the ceremonial.
tgt_text.3833: After this, having stayed for some days in that place, I enjoyed the inexplicable pleasure of viewing the holy image, being indebted to it for a benefit which can never be sufficiently rewarded.
tgt_text.3834: At length, how­ ever, through the admonition of the Goddess, having suppli­ antly given her thanks, not such as she deserved, but still, to the best of my ability, I prepared myself, though very slowly, to return home.
tgt_text.3835: With difficulty did I rend asunder the ties of my most ardent affection.
tgt_text.3836: At last I prostrated myself in the presence of the Goddess, and having for a long time watered her feet with my tears, interrupting my words by frequent sobs, and, as it were, half swallowing my voice, I thus addressed her:
tgt_text.3837: —“ Thou, 0 holy and perpetual preserver of the human race, always munificent in cherishing mortals, dost bestow the sweet affec­ tion of a mother on the misfortunes of the wretched.
tgt_text.3838: Nor is there any day or night, nor so much as the minutest particle of time, which passes unattended by thy bounties.
tgt_text.3839: Thou dost protect men both by sea and land, and, dispersing the storms of life, dost extend thy health-giving right hand, by which thou dost unravel the inextricably entangled threads of the Fates, and dost assuage the tempests of fortune, and restrain the malignant influences of the stars.
tgt_text.3840: The gods of heaven adore thee, those in the shades below do homage unto thee;
tgt_text.3841: thou dost roll the sphere of the universe round the steady poles, thou dost illuminate the sun, thou dost govern the universe, thou dost tread the realms of Tartarus.
tgt_text.3842: The stars move re­ sponsive to thy command, the Gods rejoice in thy divinity, the seasons return by thy appointment, and the elements are thy servants.
tgt_text.3843: At thy nod the breezes blow, the clouds are nur­ tured, the seeds germinate, and the blossoms increase.
tgt_text.3844: The birds as they hover through the air, the wild beasts as they roam on the mountains, the serpents that hide in the earth, and the monsters that swim in the sea, are terrified at the ma­ jesty of thy presence.
tgt_text.3845: But I, so weak in capacity for cele­ brating thy praises, and possessing such slender means for offering sacrifices, have far from eloquence sufficient to express all that I conceive of thy majesty;
tgt_text.3846: not a thousand mouths, and tongues as many, not an eternal flow of unwearied speech, would be equal to the task.
tgt_text.3847: I will, therefore, use my utmost endeavours to do what, poor as I am, still one truly religious may do—I will figure to myself thy divine countenance, and will ever preserve this most holy divinity locked up in the deepest recesses of my breast.
tgt_text.3848: "After this manner, having offered up my prayer to the supreme Goddess, I embraced the priest Mithras, who was now my parent, and hanging on his neck, and giving him many kisses, I begged him to forgive me, that I could not remunerate him in a manner adequate to such mighty benefits.
tgt_text.3849: At length, after having been long engaged in giving him thanks, I de­ parted, and prepared to journey directly to my paternal abode, in order to revisit it after an absence so prolonged.
tgt_text.3850: A few days after, having hastily tied up my packages, through the admonition of the powerful Goddess, embarking on board a ship, I set sail for Rome.
tgt_text.3851: Being sure of a favourable wind during my voyage, I very speedily entered into port, and tra­ velling by chariot* with the greatest rapidity, arrived at the holy city, † on the day before the Ides of December in the evening.
tgt_text.3852: Thenceforward no study was there of such primary importance with me, as that of daily supplicating the supreme divinity of Queen Isis;
tgt_text.3853: who is there propitiated with the greatest veneration under the name of Campensis,‡ which ap­ pellation she derives from the situation of her temple.
tgt_text.3854: In fine, I became a constant worshipper, a foreigner indeed as to her temple, but indigenous as to her religion.
tgt_text.3855: §Behold the mighty sun, having passed through the sign- bearing circle of the zodiac, had completed the year, when the vigilant care of the beneficent Goddess again interrupted my sleep, and again reminded me of initiation and sacred rites.
tgt_text.3856: On this I wondered what object she had in view, and what future event she announced.
tgt_text.3857: For how could I do otherwise ?
tgt_text.3858: as I considered myself to have been most fully initiated already.
tgt_text.3859: While, therefore, I revolved my religious doubts in my own mind, and availed myself of the counsels of the priest, I as­ certained a thing that was novel and quite wonderful to me;
tgt_text.3860: that I was only inititated into the mysteries of the goddess, but that I had not yet been admitted to the knowledge of the rites of the great God, and supreme parent of the Gods, the invincible Osiris.
tgt_text.3861: For though the essence of their divine nature and religion is connected, or rather, is tran­ scendently united, nevertheless, there is a very considerable difference in the initiations into their mysteries.
tgt_text.3862: Hence, it was for me to know that I was called upon by the great God to become one of his servants.
tgt_text.3863: Nor did the matter long remain am­ biguous.
tgt_text.3864: For on the following night, I saw in a dream one of the devotees, who, clothed in linen garments, and bearing in his hands thyrsi and ivy, and certain other things which I am not permitted to mention, placed them before my household Gods, and then seating himself in my chair, announced to me that I must prepare a plentiful religious banquet.
tgt_text.3865: He also walked gently with a hesitating step, the ancle of his left foot being slightly bent, in order no doubt that he might afford me some sign, by which I might recognize him.
tgt_text.3866: All the mists of am­ biguity were therefore removed, after such a manifest declara.
tgt_text.3867: tion of the will of the gods.
tgt_text.3868: Accordingly, the instant I had performed the morning salu­ tations to the goddess, I made a most careful examination of each, to see whether there was any one of the priests resem­ bling him whom I had seen in the dream.
tgt_text.3870: For I immediately beheld one of the Pastophori, exactly cor­ responding with the nocturnal vision, not only' with regard to the mark of his foot.
tgt_text.3871: but also in his stature and general ap­ pearance ;
tgt_text.3872: whose name I afterwards learnt to be Asinius Mar­ cellus, an appellation not without some degree of reference* to my transformation.
tgt_text.3873: Without delay, therefore, I addressed this priest, who was himself very far from ignorant of what I intended to say, because he had already been admonished by a similar mandate, that he should initiate me into the mysteries of Osiris.
tgt_text.3874: For on the preceding night, while he was placing chaplets on the statue of the great God, he imagined that he had also heard from that mouth of his by which he pronounces the destinies of all things, that he should send to him a native of Madaura, to whom, though he was very poor, he must im­ mediately impart the sacred mysteries.
tgt_text.3875: That, through his pro­ vidence, glory would accrue to that person from his religious exercises, and great profit for himself.
tgt_text.3876: After this manner, being affianced to the sacred mysteries, I was retarded, contrary to my inclination, by reason of the slenderness of my means.
tgt_text.3877: For the expense to which I had been put in my journey had frittered away the small substance of my property;
tgt_text.3878: and the sums I was obliged to expend in the city, exceeded those which had been disbursed in the provinces.
tgt_text.3879: Rigid poverty, consequently, greatly interfering with my wishes, I was much afflicted, being placed, as the old proverb says, between the altar and the stone. *
tgt_text.3880: Nor yet was I less urged from time to time by the present mandates of the God.
tgt_text.3881: At last, after being repeatedly reminded, and finally com­ manded, not without considerable perturbation, taking off my back my garment, small as it was, I scraped together a suf­ ficient sum.
tgt_text.3882: And this very thing I had been expressly com­ manded to do.
tgt_text.3883: For the God said to me, " Would you hesitate in the least to part with your garments, if you were attempting to procure any thing which might administer to your pleasures ?
tgt_text.3884: and are you now, when you are going to enter upon so great a ceremonial, doubtful whether you shall commit yourself to a poverty of which you will never have to repent?
tgt_text.3885: "All things, therefore, being abundantly prepared, again being satisfied for ten days with other than animal food, and besides this, being also admitted to the nocturnal orgies of Serapis, a god of the first rank, I now applied myself to the service of the god, full of that confidence which my knowledge of a kin­ dred ritual produced.
tgt_text.3886: This event afforded me the greatest consolation for my sojourn in a foreign country, and at the same time supplied me more plentifully with the means of sub­ sistence.
tgt_text.3887: For, under favour of the deity of Good Event, I sup­ ported myself on a little gain which I made in the forum by pleading causes in the Latin tongue.
tgt_text.3888: A short time after, I was again addressed by the unexpected and perfectly miraculous mandates of the gods, and was com­ pelled to undergo a third initiation.*
tgt_text.3889: This caused me no slight anxiety, and much was I perplexed to know what could be the meaning of this new and unusual expression of the will of the gods;
tgt_text.3890: and what could still remain to be added by way of supplement to an initiation that had been already twice re­ peated.
tgt_text.3891: Surely, thought I, both the priests have advised me either wrongly or less fully than they ought to have done.
tgt_text.3892: And, by Hercules, I now began even to entertain a bad opinion of their fidelity.
tgt_text.3893: While, however, I was thus fluctuating amid a stormy tide of thought, and agitated to the verge of insanity, the benevolent figure of the divinity instructed me by a noc­ turnal vision.
