tgt_text.4465: And not a jot the less, in the case of the matters which I have mentioned, may similar suspicions be broached, in accord­ ance with their respective names.
tgt_text.4466: You affirm that things gathered from the sea, and that bear the names of the male and female organs, are efficacious in venereal matters, be­ cause of the similitude of the names;
tgt_text.4467: how, then, can it possibly be other than the fact, that the calculus or smooth pebble that is picked up from the same sea-shore bears some reference to the bladder, the shell known to us as " testa"f to a testamentary devise, the cancer to a cancerous ulcer, the " alga," or sea-weed, to ague?
tgt_text.4468: ‡Assuredly, Claudius Maximus, you are a most forbearing man, and one endowed with the greatest humanity, for having, by Hercules!
tgt_text.4469: so long tolerated these arguments of theirs.
tgt_text.4470: For my own part, when these things were stated by them as being matters serious and unanswerable, I laughed at their folly, and was surprised at your powers of endurance.
tgt_text.4471: But as Æmilianus is so very anxious about my affairs, he must be made ac­ quainted why it is that I have examined so many fishes of late, and why I did not wish to remain unacquainted with any of them.
tgt_text.4472: Although he is well-stricken in years, and in the decline of life, still, if he chooses, let him receive some in­ struction, however late, and in a manner posthumous.
tgt_text.4473: Let him read the records of the ancient philosophers, that at last he may understand, that I was not the first to make these researches;
tgt_text.4474: but that, long before me, my predecessors Axis.
tgt_text.4475: totle, Theophrastus, Eudemus, Lycon, and others after the time of Plato, enquired into these matters;
tgt_text.4476: and let him know that they have left many books which treat of the generation of animals, their diet, their formation, and all their classifications.
tgt_text.4477: It is fortunate, Maximus, that this cause is tried before you, who, learned as you are, have no doubt read the numerous volumes of Aristotle On the Generation of Animals," "On the Anatomy of Animals," " On the History of Animals be­ sides innumerable problems of the same writer, as well as works written by others of the same sect, in which various matters of the same nature are treated of.
tgt_text.4478: If it was honorable and praiseworthy in them to write on these particulars which had been investigated with such scru­ pulous care, why should it be disgraceful for me to try to do the same ?
tgt_text.4479: And the more especially, when I am making it my object to write on the same subjects, both in the Greek and Latin languages, with an improved arrangement, and in more concise terms, and to ascertain what has been omitted on each point, or else to supply what is defective?
tgt_text.4480: Permit, if you have the leisure, some of my magical compositions to be read, in order that Æmilianus may learn that I have made more care­ ful researches and enquiries than he imagines.
tgt_text.4481: Produce* one of my Greek books, which perhaps my friends have brought here with them, and which treats on researches into nature, and that one, in especial, in which are set forth a great number of facts relative to the class of fishes.
tgt_text.4482: In the meantime, while he is looking for it, I will just men­ tion an instance appropriate to the present occasion.
tgt_text.4483: Sophocles, the poet who was the rival of Euripides, and his survivor (for he lived to a very advanced age), was accused by his own son of madness, as having, through extreme old age, fallen into a state of dotage.
tgt_text.4484: On this, it is said he produced his (Edipus Coloneus, the most excellent of his Tragedies, and which he happened just then to be writing, and having read it to the judges, he added not a word in his defence, except that he requested them, without hesitation, to pronounce him mad if the lines written by him in his old age should show him to be so.
tgt_text.4485: On that occasion, I find that all the judges arose to pay all due respect to a great poet, and wondrously extolled him, both for the skill displayed in his plot, and the tragic elegance of his composition;
tgt_text.4486: and it all but turned out that, on the contrary, they pronounced the accuser mad.
tgt_text.4488: I am much obliged to you.
tgt_text.4489: Come now, let us make trial, whether my literary productions too will stand my friends in a court of justice ?
tgt_text.4490: Read a few lines at the beginning, and then something on the subject of fishes.
tgt_text.4491: And do you, while he is reading it, take care and keep the water from dropping.*
tgt_text.4492: [The officers read some pas­ sages from the speaker's physical works, which are now lost.]
tgt_text.4493: You have heard here, Maximus, much that no doubt you have read in the writings of the ancient philosophers ;
tgt_text.4494: bear in mind, too, that these volumes were written by me on the subject of fishes alone;
tgt_text.4495: in them you will find it stated, which of them are produced from copulation, which are generated from mud,.
tgt_text.4496: how often, and at what time of the year, the females and the males of each kind are bent on coupling;
tgt_text.4497: in what pacts, and from what causes, nature has produced a difference between such of them as are viviparous, and such as are oviparous;
tgt_text.4498: for by those names I denote those which the Greeks call ζωοτόϰα and ὠοτόϰα.
tgt_text.4499: And, not to be at the trouble of going through all the genera of animals, I will next request a few passages to be read from my Latin compositions, which likewise treat of the same kind of knowledge, both with reference to their classifications, their food, their members, their ages, and numerous other particu­ lars, which, necessary as they are to be known, have but little to do with a court of justice;
tgt_text.4500: in these, you will find, how­ ever, facts that are known to but very few, as well as some names that are even unknown by the Romans, and are not used, as far as I know, up to the present day;
tgt_text.4501: they are names, however, which by means of my labour and study have been so derived from the Greek, as still to bear upon them the stamp of the current Latin coinage.
tgt_text.4502: If such is not the fact, then, Æmilianus, let your advocates inform us where they have read these names set forth as being Latin words.
tgt_text.4503: I will only touch upon aquatic animals, and no other class, except in those cases where there are differences of genera in common with them and others.
tgt_text.4504: Listen now to what I am going to say.
tgt_text.4505: You will presently cry out, that I am repeating a string of magical terms aftei the Egyptian or Babylonian custom-these are the classes-
tgt_text.4506: νέποδα, μονήρη, συναγελαστιϰὰ.-I could still go on, but it is not worth while to consume the day on these subjects, in order that I may have time to proceed to other points.
tgt_text.4507: In the meantime, as to the few that I have mentioned, run over the names I have given them in Latin.
tgt_text.4508: [The Latin names for the same genera offishes are lost.]
tgt_text.4509: Which, then, do you think, in case of a philosopher, not one, rude and untaught, in accordance with the impudence of the cynics, but one who bears in mind that he belongs to the school of Plato, which do you think is the more disgraceful to him, to know these matters, or to be ignorant of them ?
tgt_text.4510: to neglect or to attend to them ?
tgt_text.4511: To come to a perception how fully, even in these objects, the workings of providence are displayed, or merely to take your father's and mother's word as regards belief in the immortal gods ?Q. Ennius, in his work called " Hedyphagetica,"* which he has written in verse, enumerates the almost numberless genera of fish which he had, no doubt curiously, examined.
tgt_text.4512: I remember a few of his lines, which I will repeat. "
tgt_text.4513: The best of eel-pouts are at Clypea found ;
tgt_text.4515: From Abydos come Oysters in plenty.
tgt_text.4521: if they're large, make sure and buy.
tgt_text.4522: Know that Tarentum sends of boar-like fish ‡
tgt_text.4524: Buy sword-fish at Surrentum, buy Blue fish at Cumæ.
tgt_text.4526: The scarus, equal to the brain of Jove!
tgt_text.4527: In Nestor's land 'tis found, both fine and good ;
tgt_text.4528: The black-tail, sea-thrush, whiting, an I the swift Sea-shadow,* the Corcyrean polypus ;
tgt_text.4529: Atarna's skull-fish fat, the purpura, Murex, muriculus ;
tgt_text.4531: Others, besides, he has celebrated in many of his lines, and has shown in what countries each of them is to be found, and whether it has the finest flavour when boiled or pickled;
tgt_text.4532: and yet, for all this, he is not censured by the learned.
tgt_text.4533: Let me not be censured then, when I set forth in the Latin tongue, under elegant and appropriate names, matters which, having been hitherto treated of in Greek, are known to but very few indeed.
tgt_text.4534: As I have spoken at sufficient length on this subject, next hear me on another.
tgt_text.4535: Now what can they say against it, pray, if, being neither unacquainted with the medical art, nor un­ skilled in it, I seek for certain antidotes in fishes ?
tgt_text.4536: for as very many such are mingled and implanted in all other ob­ jects by the bounty of nature, so too there are some, no doubt, to be found in fishes.
tgt_text.4537: Do you suppose that to under­ stand the nature of antidotes, and to search for them, is the province rather of a magician, than of a physician, or a phi­ losopher even ?
tgt_text.4538: One who is going to use them not for his own profit, but for the purpose of benefiting others ?
tgt_text.4539: Why, the ancient physicians were even acquainted with certain charms by way of remedy for wounds, as Homer, that most trust.
tgt_text.4540: worthy author of all antiquity, informs us, when he represents the blood that flowed from the wound of Ulysses, as being staunched by means of a charm.t
tgt_text.4541: Nothing that is done for the purpose of ensuring health can be criminal in itself."
tgt_text.4542: But then," says he, " for what purpose but a bad one did you cut up the fish which your servant Themiso brought you?"
tgt_text.4543: As though, indeed, I did not say, a short time since, that I have written on the parts of all animals, their position, their num­ ber, and their purposes;
tgt_text.4544: and that I make it my study to ex­ amine and to enlarge the' works written by Aristotle " On Dissections."
tgt_text.4545: And, indeed, I am surprised that you should only know that one little fish has been examined by me, when I have in the same manner, on previous occasions, examined vast numbers of them, whenever they have been brought to me;
tgt_text.4546: especially, seeing that I do nothing in secret, but everything openly, and any one, a stranger even, may come and be present, as a spectator.
tgt_text.4547: Herein I act according to the customs and usages of my masters, who say, that a man of ingenuous birth and high spirit, ought, if he can, to carry his mind pourtrayed in the very front of his forehead.
tgt_text.4548: Now this little fish, which you call a sea-hare, I showed to a great number of persons who were present, and I can not yet make up my mind what it shall be called, until I shall have made a more careful examination of it;
tgt_text.4549: for among the ancient philosophers, I find no account of the properties of this fish, although it is the rarest of all kinds, and, by Her­ cules !
tgt_text.4550: one that well deserves to be described.
tgt_text.4551: For this is the only fish, so far as I know, that, being without bones in other parts, has certain bones, twelve in number in the belly, con­ nected and united one with another, much like the pastern bones of a pig in appearance.
tgt_text.4552: If Aristotle had been aware of this fact, he certainly never would have omitted to commit it to writing, since he has mentioned, as a remarkable fact, that there is a little heart found in the middle of the belly of the codfish, and of that fish alone."
tgt_text.4553: You cut up the fish," says he.
tgt_text.4554: Who can endure that being a crime in a philosopher, which would not have been so in a butcher or a cook? "
tgt_text.4556: Is it because it was raw, that you censure me for so doing ?
tgt_text.4557: If I had ex­ amined the belly, after boiling the fish, and had dug out the entrails, just as this stripling, Sicinius Pudens, has learned to do at your house,* with fish bought with his own pocket- money;
tgt_text.4558: would you not have deemed that a fitting ground for accusing me ?
tgt_text.4559: But know that it is a greater crime for a philosopher to eat fishes than to examine them.
tgt_text.4560: Shall sooth- navers, then, be allowed to inspect the entrails, and shall a philosopher be forbidden to observe them, when he knows that he is the diviner, who gathers omens from all animals;
tgt_text.4561: that he is the priest of all the Gods ?
tgt_text.4562: Do you censure in me, the very thing that Maximus and I agree in admiring in Aristotle?
tgt_text.4563: whose books unless you banish from the libraries, and tear them from the hands of the studious, you can bring no accusation against me.
tgt_text.4564: But on this point I have almost said more than I ought.
tgt_text.4565: Now, only see to what an extent these people confute them­ selves.
tgt_text.4566: They say, that a woman was captivated by me through magic arts and charms derived from the sea;
tgt_text.4567: this, too, at a time at which they will not deny that I was far inland among the mountains of Gætulia, where may be found fishes left by Deucalion's flood.
tgt_text.4568: I really congratulate myself that they were not aware that I have also read the tract of Theo­ phrastus, "On animals that bite and are venomous," as well as the book on antidotes written by Nicander.
tgt_text.4569: For in such case, they would have accused me of poisoning too, though I have only pursued these studies in imitation of Aristotle, whose works I have carefully read, my own Plato, in some measure, encouraging me thereto, when he says, that he who investigates these matters, "knows things that are godlike and immortal, if he hits upon the truth.
tgt_text.4570: "Now that their fish story has been sufficiently exposed, listen to another invention of theirs, quite its equal in folly, but far more absurd and dishonest.
tgt_text.4571: They knew, themselves, that their fish argument would turn out utterly futile and worthless, and ridiculous for its singularity.
tgt_text.4572: For who ever heard of fishes being wont to be scaled and boned for magical malpractices ?
tgt_text.4573: On the contrary, they ought rather to have con­ cocted something with reference to matters more universally known, and that have already obtained credit.
tgt_text.4574: For this reason it is, that they have trumped up a tale quite in accordance with prescribed notions and common report, how that,-all overlookers being removed-in a secret spot, with lamp and little altar, I bewitched a certain boy by my incan­ tations-and how that, a few witnesses being privy thereto, after he had been enchanted, he fell to the ground, and after­ wards awoke in a fit of utter bewilderment.
tgt_text.4575: No further, however, than this, did they dare to proceed in their fiction;
tgt_text.4576: but still, that the story might be rendered complete, it was found necessary to add, that the same boy had, in a spirit of pro­ phecy, foretold many events, for such, we generally hear, is the result of employing incantations.
tgt_text.4577: And not only by the universally received notions of the vulgar, but even by the authority of learned men, is this miraculous power of boys con­ firmed.
tgt_text.4578: I remember, that in the works of Varro the philosopher, a man who was most intimately acquainted with all learning and knowledge, I read the following relation among others of a similar nature :
tgt_text.4580: When the people of Tralles were consult­ ing the magical art, as to what would be the result of the Mithridatic war;
tgt_text.4581: a boy,* while looking upon the reflection of a statue of Mercury in the water, uttered a prophecy of a hun­ dred and sixty lines, setting forth what was about to come to pass:
tgt_text.4582: Furthermore, that Fabius, having lost five hundred denars, came to Nigidius,t to consult him;
tgt_text.4583: on which, certain boys, who had been inspired by him by means of charms, pointed out in what place the purse had been buried, together with some part of the money;
tgt_text.4584: how the rest had been distri­ buted, and how that even M.
tgt_text.4585: Cato the philosopher was in possession of one of the pieces;
tgt_text.4586: upon which, M. Cato con­ fessed that he had received that very coin at the hands of an attendant of his for the contribution to Apollo.‡,These, and other statements, about boys being employed for magical purposes, I certainly have read in many authors;
tgt_text.4587: but I am doubtful whether to say that such things are possible, or to deny it.
tgt_text.4588: Still, I do think with Plato, that there are certain divine powers which are intermediate both in nature and locality, between the Gods and mankind, and that these powers preside over all divinations and miracles of magicians.
tgt_text.4589: And I am further of opinion, that the human mind, and espe­ cially the uncontaminated mind of a boy, may be lulled to sleep, and so estranged from the body, as to become oblivious of the present, being either summoned away from it by the agency of charms, or else enticed by the allurements of sweet odours ;
tgt_text.4590: and that so, all remembrance of what is done in the body having been banished for a time, it may be restored and brought back to its original nature, which no doubt is divine and immortal, and thus, being in a kind of trance, as it were, may presage future events.
tgt_text.4591: *But be this as it may, if any credit is to be given to these matters, whatever boy is to prophesy, ought, so far as I can understand, to be of graceful features and of unblemished body, of quick wit, and fluent in speech;
tgt_text.4592: that so, either the Divine power may take up its abode in him, as in a beseeming habitation, (if, indeed, it can, under any circumstances, be becomingly enclosed in the body of a boy ;
tgt_text.4593: ) or else, his mind, on being released from the body, may quickly return to its power of divination ;
tgt_text.4594: and that such power being readily within its reach, and not blemished or impeded by obliviousness, may be the more easily resumed.
tgt_text.4595: For, as Pythagoras used to say, "It is not out of every log of wood that a Mercury can be carved.
tgt_text.4596: "If, then, such is the fact, mention the name of this boy, of sound mind, good health, quick wits, and singular beauty, whom I have thought proper to initiate in these arts, through my incantations.
tgt_text.4597: As for this Thallus, whom you have named, he stands more in need of a physician than of a magician.
tgt_text.4599: is so affected with epilepsy, that fre­ quently, as many as three or four times in a day, he falls to the ground without any incantations whatever, and injures all his limbs with the blows so received:
tgt_text.4600: he has a face, too, full of ulcers;
tgt_text.4601: his head, both before and behind, is covered all over with bruises;
tgt_text.4602: his sight is dim, his nostrils are ex. panded, and he is quite shaky in the .legs.
tgt_text.4603: He would be the greatest magician of all, in whose presence Thallus could stand up for any length of time together ;
tgt_text.4604: so frequently does he stagger and fall down under the influence of his disease, just as though he were fast asleep.
tgt_text.4605: And yet you have thought proper to assert, that he has been made to fall down through my incantations, because he happened to fall on one occasion when I was present.
tgt_text.4606: Many of his fellow-servants are here, whom you gave notice to produce.
tgt_text.4607: They can tell you, all of them, why they shun the society of Thallus;
tgt_text.4608: why it is that no one ventures to eat with him from the same dish, to drink with him from the same cup.
tgt_text.4609: But why speak of the servants ?
tgt_text.4610: Deny it yourselves, if you dare, that Thallus, long, long before I came to Oëa, was in the habit of falling down when suffering from attacks of this disease, and had been repeatedly in the hands of the physicians.
tgt_text.4611: Can his fellow-servants, who are in your own service, deny that ?
tgt_text.4612: I will confess myself guilty on all the charges, if he has not, this long time past, been banished to a farm at a great distance in the country, lest he might infect the whole house­ hold.
tgt_text.4613: That this is the fact, not even they themselves can deny.
tgt_text.4614: This, too, has been the reason, why he could not be produced by us to-day.
tgt_text.4615: For, just in accordance with the pre­ cipitate and hurried manner in which this accusation was preferred, it was only the day before yesterday, that Æmilianus gave us notice to produce our fifteen servants before you.
tgt_text.4616: The fourteen who were in the city are present.
tgt_text.4617: Thallus, as I mentioned, is the only one that has been sent away into the country, almost a hundred miles out of our sight.
tgt_text.4618: Thallus is the only one absent;
tgt_text.4619: but still we have sent a person, post haste, for the purpose of bringing him hither.
tgt_text.4620: Enquire, Maximum, of these fourteen servants, whom we produce, where the boy Thallus is, and in what state of health;
tgt_text.4621: enquire of the servants of my accusers.
tgt_text.4622: They will not deny the fact, that this most unsightly lad has a body rotten and diseased, that he is liable to falling fits, is uncouth, and a mere clod.
tgt_text.4623: A handsome youth, indeed, you have chosen, for any person to employ in the sacred rites, to touch his head, [in initiating nim], to clothe him with a pure garment, and to expect him to give responses!
tgt_text.4625: I only wish he had been here, I would have handed him over to you, Æmilianus, to take hold of him, and question him yourself.
tgt_text.4626: Why, in the very middle of your examination of him, here, in this same spot, and before the very tribunal, he would have fixed his staring eyes upon you, slobbered and spit in your face, clenched his hands, dropped his head, and, at last, fallen right upon your breast.
tgt_text.4627: The fourteen servants, whom you demanded, I have brought;
tgt_text.4628: why don't you make use of them for examination ?
tgt_text.4629: One lad, and that one a poor epileptic creature, you ask for, when you know, as well as I do, that he has long since left this place.
tgt_text.4630: How can there be a more manifest calumny than this ?
tgt_text.4631: At your demand, fourteen servants-are here-of them you take no notice-one young boy is absent, about him you at­ tack me.
tgt_text.4632: After all, what is it you want ?
tgt_text.4633: Suppose Thallus to be pre­ sent, do you wish to prove that in my presence he fell to the ground ?
tgt_text.4634: I am quite ready to admit it.
tgt_text.4635: Do you say that this was effected through incantations ?
tgt_text.4636: About that, the lad knows nothing at all:
tgt_text.4637: I will prove that such was not the fact.
tgt_text.4638: Now that the lad was suffering from epilepsy, not even you yourself will dare to deny.
tgt_text.4639: Why, then, ought his falling down to be attributed to incantations rather than to disease ?
tgt_text.4640: Could it not possibly happen that he should be seized with an attack in my presence, just as he has often been seized on other occa­ sions, while many other persons were present ?
tgt_text.4641: If I had con­ sidered it a matter of great importance to make an epileptic person fall down, what necessity was there for me to use in­ cantations, when the stone called "agate," after being subjected to the action of fire, as I read in the writers on Physics, readily and easily tests the presence of this malady ?
tgt_text.4642: It is by means of the smell of this, too, that trial is usually made in the slave-markets of the soundness or unsoundness of the slaves.
tgt_text.4643: Then besides, the wheel, when whirled round by the potter, readily affects with vertigo a person suffering from this ma­ lady, so much does the sight of the rotatory motion affect his debilitated spirits;
tgt_text.4644: so that a potter is much better able than a magician to cause the epileptic to fall prostrate.
tgt_text.4645: You have asked, and for no purpose, that I should produce the servants;
tgt_text.4646: I ask, and not for no purpose, that you will mention by name the witnesses who were present at these ne.
tgt_text.4647: farious rites, when I thus brought to the ground the already tottering Thallus.
tgt_text.4648: Only one young lad, after all, do you name, this Sicinius Pudens here, in whose name you accuse me;
tgt_text.4649: he declares that he was present;
tgt_text.4650: but even if his boyhood did not in the slightest degree detract from his credibility with the court, still his position as accuser would impair the value of his testimony.
tgt_text.4651: It would have been much easier, .,Emilianus, and would have carried much greater weight, if you had said you yourself were present, and that in consequence of these rites you were first attacked with insanity, rather than entrust all this business, as though it were a mere joke, to boys..
tgt_text.4652: A boy fell down,-a boy saw him fall down,-and may not some boy have acted the enchanter too ?
tgt_text.4653: Tannonius Pudens here, craftily enough, when he perceived that this lying fiction also fell cold and harmless, and that it was all but hissed outright, as­ serted that he would produce some other boys who had also been enchanted by me, that thus at least, by raising your ex­ pectations, he might lull the suspicions of some among you;
tgt_text.4654: and then he passed on to another head of his argument.
tgt_text.4655: Now, although I might very well have taken no notice of this, still, as I have challenged him to proof on all other points, so I volunteer to do on this.
tgt_text.4656: For I long for these boys to be produced, who, I hear, have been encouraged to give false evidence against me, through hopes held out to them that they shall thereby gain their liberty.
tgt_text.4657: However, no more do I say than this:
tgt_text.4659: I demand, Tan­ nonius Pudens, and insist that you will fulfil the promise you have made.
tgt_text.4660: Produce these boys, in whom you have put such confidence;
tgt_text.4661: inform us what are their names ;
tgt_text.4662: a portion of the time that has been allotted for my own speech I give you leave to employ for the purpose.
tgt_text.4666: why cast your eyes on the ground ?
tgt_text.4667: If he does not know what it is he has said, or if he has forgotten the names, then do you, Æmili­ anus, step this way;
tgt_text.4668: say what were the instructions you gave to your counsel;
tgt_text.4670: what makes you turn so pale ?
tgt_text.4672: Is this the way to bring an accusation of such magnitude ?
tgt_text.4673: to make a laughing-stock of Claudius Maximus, a man of such exalted station, and to per­ secute me with your calumnious charges?
tgt_text.4674: But if, perchance, your advocate did make a slip, and if you have no.
tgt_text.4675: such boys to produce, at all events employ, fot some purpose or other, the fourteen servants whom I have brought here;
tgt_text.4676: or else why was it that you required such a large household to be brought into court ?
tgt_text.4677: Accusing me of magic, you have given me notice to produce fifteen servants.
tgt_text.4678: If you had accused me of acts of violence, how many servants, pray, would you have demanded ?
tgt_text.4679: Is it, then, that the fifteen servants know all about it, and yet it is a secret ?
tgt_text.4680: or is it no secret at all, and yet an affair of magic ?
tgt_text.4681: One of these two things you must necessarily confess;
tgt_text.4682: either that what I did was not unlawful, since I did not fear to allow so many per­ sons to be privy to it, or else that if it was unlawful, so many witnesses ought not to have been privy to it.
tgt_text.4683: This magic, from all I can learn, is a thing denounced by the laws, and from the remotest times forbidden by the Twelve Tables, in consequence of the incredible blasting of standing corn by means of incantations.
tgt_text.4684: Consequently, it is a thing no less secret in its practices than foul and abominable;
tgt_text.4685: it is gene­ rally carried on by night, hidden in deep gloom, removed from all observation, and effected by whispered spells:
tgt_text.4686: a process at which few, not to say slaves, but even free men, are allowed to be present.
tgt_text.4687: Do you want to make out that fifteen servants were present as spectators ?
tgt_text.4688: Was it a wedding, then, or some other cere­ monial, or an afternoon carousal ?
tgt_text.4689: Fifteen servants are here taking part in these magic rites, just like so many Quinde­ cemvirs,* elected for the performance of sacred duties.
tgt_text.4690: But to what end should I have employed so large a number, if the privity of but one is far more than is requisite ?
tgt_text.4692: why, that makes a whole borough.t
tgt_text.4695: the same number, if placed in chains, would fill a whole gaol;
tgt_text.4696: t or was it that such a multitude as this was necessary to hold the victims for sacrifice ?
tgt_text.4697: But all the while you have mentioned no victims except hens.
tgt_text.4698: Or were they required to count the grains of frankincense t or to knock down Thallus ?
tgt_text.4699: You stated, besides, that a free-born woman had been brought to my house, afflicted with the same malady as Thallus;
tgt_text.4700: that I promised to cure her, and that she, too, fell to the ground enchanted by me.
tgt_text.4701: So far as I can see, you have come here to charge me with being a wrestler, and not a magician, seeing that you assert in this fashion that all who have come near me have been levelled with the ground.
tgt_text.4702: How­ ever, upon being questioned by you, Maximus, Themiso, the doctor, by whom the woman was brought for me to examine, denied that anything whatever happened to her, except that I put the question, whether there was a ringing in her ears, and if so, in which of them in the greatest degree?
tgt_text.4703: upon which she made answer, that her right ear was very much dis­ turbed by it, and immediately after took her departure.
tgt_text.4704: And here, Maximus, although at the present moment I am careful to refrain from praising you, that I may not appear to flatter you with a view to this trial, still I cannot forbear from praising your acuteness in cross-examination.
tgt_text.4705: For just now, when these matters were discussed, and they asserted that the woman was enchanted, whilst the doctor, who was present, denied it, you very sagaciously enquired, what I was to gain by thus bewitching her;
tgt_text.4706: on which they answered, that the woman should fall to the ground. "
tgt_text.4707: Well, what then?" you asked, " did she die ?"
tgt_text.4708: They said no. " How then," say you, " what advantage would it have been to Apuleius if she fell?"
tgt_text.4709: For to this effect did you fairly and perseveringly put the question to them as many as three several times, be­ cause you well knew that the motives for all actions ought most carefully to be enquired into, and that often, when facts are admitted, the causes of them become subjects for enquiry;
tgt_text.4710: and you were aware that for this very reason the advocates of persons engaged in suits at law have the name given to them of " causidici," because it is their province to explain the causes for which each thing has been done.
tgt_text.4711: But, on the other hand, to deny that a thing has been done is an easy matter, and needs the services of no advocate whatever;
tgt_text.4712: while to show that it has been done rightfully or wrongfully is a most arduous and difficult task.
tgt_text.4713: It is useless, then, to enquire whether a thing has been done, which has had no evil cause to prompt its being done.
tgt_text.4714: Hence it is, that he who is accused before a conscientious judge of having done a thing, is free from all fears of enquiry, if he has had no reason for doing what was wrong.
tgt_text.4715: Now, since they have neither proved that the woman was enchanted, nor yet that she was thrown to the ground, and as I do not deny that, at the request of a medical man, she was examined by me, I will tell you, Maximus, why I did make the enquiry about the ringing in the ears ;
tgt_text.4716: and I shall do so, not so much for the sake of exculpating myself in this affair, which you have already pronounced to have nothing in it of faultiness or criminality, as because I would not wish to be silent on any matter that is suited to your ears and your learn­ ing.
tgt_text.4717: I will state it, then, as succinctly as possible, seeing that you are to be put in mind only, not instructed by me.
tgt_text.4718: The philosopher Plato, in that most celebrated dialogue of his, entitled " Timæus," after having, with a sort of celestial eloquence, explained the structure of the entire universe, most ingeniously discussed the threefold powers of our mind, and aptly shown why our several parts were formed by the Divine Providence, proceeds to range the causes of all maladies under three heads.
tgt_text.4719: The first cause he attributes to the elements of our bodies, in cases where the qualities of those elements, being the moist and the cold, and the two qualities that are their opposites, do not agree the one with the other;
tgt_text.4720: and this takes place when any one of them has exceeded its limits, or has shifted from its proper locality.
tgt_text.4721: The next cause of maladies exists in the corruption of those parts which are formed by a coalition of simple elements, united so as to form a single sub­ stance ;
tgt_text.4722: these are, for instance, blood, flesh, bones, and marrow;
tgt_text.4723: and then those parts, which are formed from a mixture of these several substances.
tgt_text.4724: In the third place, there are in the body collections of various coloured bile, and of restless and flatulent wind, and gross humours, all which are most frequent causes of diseases.
tgt_text.4725: In the number of these last is especially to be found the primary cause of the falling-sickness, about which I purposed to speak.
tgt_text.4726: For the flesh, through a noxious degree of heat, sometimes deliquesces into a moist state, that is, dense and cloggy, and a certain flatulency rises therefrom, in consequence of the heat of the compressed air, and a corrupt matter of whitish and frothy appearance flows from it.
tgt_text.4727: Now, this cor rupt matter, if it can find a vent to ooze forth from the body, is ejected with more unseemliness than danger.
tgt_text.4728: For it marks the exterior of the skin with leprosy, and variegates it with all kinds of spots;
tgt_text.4729: the person, however, to whom this happens is never afterwards attacked by epilepsy;
tgt_text.4730: and thus it is that a most afflicting malady of the mind is compensated by a slight disfigurement of the body.
tgt_text.4731: But, on the other hand, if these pernicious secretions are held in check, and become united with the black bile, these, raging at large, penetrate through all the vessels;
tgt_text.4732: and when they have done this, making their way towards the crown of the head, they mingle their destructive humours with the brain;
tgt_text.4733: and instantly affect that regal portion of the under­ standing which, all-important as it is in the reasoning facul­ ties, has fixed its seat in the head of man as its citadel and its palace.
tgt_text.4734: For its divers passages and its paths that lead to wis­ dom, these humours clog up and overwhelm;
tgt_text.4735: this, however, they do with less work during the hours of sleep, as at such times the patient, being filled with food and drink, only suffers from a slight attack of impeded respiration, which is a symptom of epilepsy.
tgt_text.4736: But if the humours increase to such a degree as even to attack the head while the patient is awake, then, a cloud suddenly comes across the spirit, he becomes torpid, the breath ceases, and the body falls to the ground, like that of a dead person.
tgt_text.4737: This our forefathers styled, not only the "major" and the " comitial," but also the " divine" disease;
tgt_text.4738: just as the Greeks, with good reason, have styled it ίερα νοσὸς, inasmuch as it attacks especially the reasoning parts of the mind, which are by far its most holy portion.
tgt_text.4739: You see, then, Maximus, what is the theory of Plato, which I have explained as perspicuously as I could, considering the time allowed me;
tgt_text.4740: and as I believe with him, that the Divine disease [or epilepsy] proceeds from these bad humours mounting to the head, it is clear I had good reason to make the enquiry, did this woman's head ache, was her neck torpid and stiff, and was there a throbbing in her temples, and a tingling in her ears ?
tgt_text.4741: And, what is still more, inasmuch as she admitted that she had a repeated ring­ ing in the right ear, that was a clear sign that the malady had taken a deep root.
tgt_text.4742: For as the right side of the body is the strongest, the less hope of recovery is there left, when even that gives way to disease.
tgt_text.4743: Aristotle has also left it written in his Problems, that, in the case especially of those who are epileptic, and are attacked by the disease on the right side, the cure will be most difficult.
tgt_text.4744: It would take a long time if I were to repeat the opinions stated by Theophrastus also with reference to the same malady;
tgt_text.4745: but there is in existence an excellent book of his, written on the subject of epilepsy.
tgt_text.4746: Persons afflicted with this disease, are told in another book which he has written IOn animals that envy," that the sloughs- of newts (which those animals, like the rest of the serpent tribe, cast aside at stated periods, like a sort of old age,) are very useful as a remedy ;
tgt_text.4747: but if you do not quickly take them' away, these animals will instantly turn round and devour them, whether it is that they act through a malignant pre­ sage [of their possible usefulness], or through a natural appetite.
tgt_text.4748: These matters I have mentioned, and have been careful to name both the points discussed and the books written by these celebrated philosophers, while, at the same time, I have not thought of giving any of the physicians or poets, in order that these people may cease to wonder, if philosophers, by the aid of those studies which are peculiar to themselves, gain some knowledge of the causes and remedies of diseases.
tgt_text.4749: Ad. mitted, then, that an afflicted woman was brought to me to examine for the purpose of effecting a cure, and that, by the;
tgt_text.4750: confession of the medical man who brought her, I acted rightly, then I think, they must either come to the conclusion that it is the part of a magician, and of a man guilty of malpractices, to heal diseases, or else, if they do not dare to make such an assertion, they must confess that, in the case of the boy and the woman afflicted with epilepsy, they have uttered frivolous and abortive calumnies.
tgt_text.4751: Nay, if you wish to hear the truth, Æmilianus, you yourself are much afflicted with the falling-sickness, having fallen flat so often in attempts to calumniate me.
tgt_text.4752: For it is not a more grievous thing to fail in body than in spirit, to be found giving way rather in the feet than in the mind, and to be defiled with spittle in a private chamber, than to be execrated in this most illustrious assembly.
tgt_text.4753: However, you fancy, perhaps, that you are sane in mind, because you are not confined at home, but follow your mad fit just where it may chance to lead you.
tgt_text.4754: Still, if you compare your own madness with that of Thallus, you will find that there is no such great difference between them, except that Thallus attacks himself, while you go so far as to attack others.
tgt_text.4756: Thallus distorts his eyes, you the truth;
tgt_text.4757: Thallus screws his hands, you your advocates;
tgt_text.4758: Thallus falls flat on the pavement, you before the tribunal.
tgt_text.4759: In fine, whatever he does, he does through infirmity;
tgt_text.4760: he offends in ignorance, while you, wretched man, knowingly and advi­ sedly, are guilty.
tgt_text.4761: So extreme is the violence of the disease that holds its sway over you, that you accuse me of what is false as though it were the truth;
tgt_text.4762: a thing that was never done, you charge me with doing;
tgt_text.4763: one whom you know, beyond a doubt, to be innocent, you still accuse as though he were guilty.
tgt_text.4764: I have omitted, besides, to say that there are some things of which you con­ fess yourself ignorant, and yet persist in charging me with, just as though you were fully acquainted with them.
tgt_text.4765: For you assert that I kept something wrapped up in a napkin in the same room with the Lares of Pontianus.
tgt_text.4766: What these things were, thus wrapped up, and what was their nature, you con­ fess you know not, and you admit there is no one who has seen them;
tgt_text.4767: and yet, at the same time, you assert that they were appliances of magic..
tgt_text.4768: Let no one flatter you, AEmilianus.
tgt_text.4769: This is no proof of your skill in framing an accusation, nor of your effrontery even;
tgt_text.4770: so don't you suppose that it is.
tgt_text.4772: It is the unhappy frenzy of an embittered spirit, the wretched insanity of a soured old age.
tgt_text.4773: For, almost in these very words did you plead before a judge so distinguished for his gravity and his shrewdness:
tgt_text.4774: " Apuleius kept certain articles wrapped up in a linen cloth in the same room with the Lares of Pon­ tianus.
tgt_text.4775: As I do not know what these articles were, I assert that they were for magical purposes ;
tgt_text.4776: believe me, therefore, in what I assert, because I am asserting what I know no­ thing about."
tgt_text.4777: An excellent argument, and one that so con­ vincingly proves my guilt!
tgt_text.4778: " Such and such it was, because I know not what it was."
tgt_text.4779: You are the only person that has ever yet been found, Æmilianus, to know even those very things that you do not know.
tgt_text.4780: To such a degree as this have you been exalted above all in folly!
tgt_text.4781: While, on the one hand, the ablest and most sagacious of philosophers have asserted that we must not so much as place confidence in those things even which we see ;
tgt_text.4782: you, on the other hand, go so far as to assert the existence of things that you have never so much as seen or heard of.
tgt_text.4783: If Pontianus were alive, and you were to ask him what was within that cover, he would tell you he did not know.
tgt_text.4784: The freed man, too, who has kept the keys of that place up to this very day, and is one of your supporters, declares that he never looked into it, although, as being the keeper of the books which were put away there, he opened and shut the place nearly every day.
tgt_text.4785: Many a time has he gone into the room with me, and much more frequently alone, and has seen a linen cloth lying upon the table, without any seal, without any fastening upon it.
tgt_text.4787: Magical imple­ ments were concealed in it--that was the reason why I kept them in such a careless manner.
tgt_text.4788: Still more, I needlessly exposed them for him to pry into and examine, and even, if he had thought fit, to take them away;
tgt_text.4789: I entrusted them to the care of another person, I left them at the mercy of another.
tgt_text.4790: What, then, is it that you now want to be believed ?
tgt_text.4791: That a thing about which Pontianus, who lived on terms of inse­ parable intimacy with me, knew nothing at all, you are fully acquainted with, you, whom, before I met you in this court of justice, I never in my life set eyes upon ?
tgt_text.4792: Or is it that, when a freedman was there at all times and seasons, and had every opportunity of examining, you, who never went there, saw a thing which that same freedman never saw?
tgt_text.4793: In short, do you wish it to be believed that a thing which you never saw, is just what you affirm it to have been ?
tgt_text.4794: But, you blockhead, if you, this very day, had gained possession of that same nap- in, whatever you might have produced therefrom, I could have denied that it was ever employed for magical purposes.
tgt_text.4795: However, I give you full permission ;
tgt_text.4796: invent whatever you please, plan, devise anything that may possibly appear appli­ cable to magical practices, I could still dispute the question with you ;
tgt_text.4797: I could either say that it had been surreptitiously placed there, or that it was employed as a remedy, or that it had been entrusted to me for the performance of sacred rites, or had been recommended to me in a dream.
tgt_text.4798: There are a thousand other means by which I could, after the most ordi­ nary methods in use, truthfully rebut your assertions.
tgt_text.4799: Now, this is what you require, that the very thing which, if made known and discovered, would not prejudice me before an up­ right judge, may, while it remains undiscovered and un­ known, lead to my condemnation, upon an idle suspicion.
tgt_text.4800: I don't know whether you will again say, as usual with you,—"What was it, then, that you kept covered up with a linen cloth, and so carefully put away in the same room with the Lares ?"
tgt_text.4802: You make your accusations in such a way that you gain all your information from the person accused, while you yourself bring forward nothing that is known for certain.
tgt_text.4803: "For what purpose did you try to procure the fishes?"
tgt_text.4804: "Why did you examine the sick woman?" "
tgt_text.4805: What was it you kept in the napkin ?"
tgt_text.4806: Which of the two have you come here to do, to accuse or to interrogate me ?
tgt_text.4807: If to accuse me, prove yourself the assertions you make;
tgt_text.4808: if to in­ terrogate me, do not prejudge the fact, since the very reason that makes it necessary for you to interrogate me, is that you are ignorant of the fact.
tgt_text.4809: But really, according to this mode of proceeding, all men will have accusations brought against them, if there is to be no necessity for one who makes a charge against another to prove his case, but, on the contrary, he may enjoy every possible facility for making enquiries.
tgt_text.4810: For in such case, charges of magical practices may be made against any body, and every thing he may chance to have done, will be brought forward against him. "
tgt_text.4811: You placed your vow in writing upon the thigh of some statue, therefore you are a magician;
tgt_text.4812: if not, why did you so place it?" "
tgt_text.4813: You silently put up prayers to the Gods in a temple, therefore you are a magician, or else why did you so express your wishes ?"
tgt_text.4814: On the other hand, " You omitted to pray in the temple, therefore you are a magician, else why did you not address your supplications to the Gods?"
tgt_text.4815: Just the same may happen, whether you present some donation, offer up a sacrifice, or take home some of the sacred herbs.
tgt_text.4816: The day would not suffice for me, if I were to attempt to enumerate all the matters on which a calumnious accuser will thus call for an explanation.
tgt_text.4817: In especial, what is put away in one's house, what is placed under seal, what is shut up, and kept there;
tgt_text.4818: all these things, by the same line of reasoning, will be said to be of a magical nature, or else will have to be transferred from the store-room to the forum, and into a court of justice.
tgt_text.4819: For my own part, Maximus, I could discuss at very considerable length the value to be set upon such points as these, what their character is, how large a field for calumnious charges is opened by this course adopted by Æmilianus, and what an enormous amount of trouble* and vexation has been caused to innocent persons by this one single napkin.
tgt_text.4820: I will do, however, as I originally purposed, even where there is no necessity that I should do so;
tgt_text.4821: I will give him the benefit of an admission, and, as I have been interro­ gated by Æmilianus, I will give him an answer.
tgt_text.4822: You ask, Æmilianus, what it was I had in the napkin.
tgt_text.4823: Now, although I might utterly deny that any napkin belong- in- to me was ever placed in the library of Pontianus, I will grant, by all means, that such was the case, as it still remains in my power to say, that nothing whatever was wrapped up in that napkin.
tgt_text.4824: And if I do say so, by the testi­ mony of no one, by no proof can I be refuted.
tgt_text.4825: For there is not a person who ever touched it, and only a single freed man, according to your own story, who saw it.
tgt_text.4826: Still I tell you, so far as I am concerned, I am quite ready to admit that it was stuffed full of something ;
tgt_text.4827: think so, if you like, just as in days of yore the companions of Ulysses fancied that they had found a treasure when they fingered the leather bag that was blown out with the winds.
tgt_text.4829: Would you like me to tell you what the things were, thus wrapped up in the napkin which I entrusted to the charge of the Lares of Pontianus ?
tgt_text.4831: I have been initiated into most of the sacred rites of Greece.
tgt_text.4832: Certain of their tokens and insignia, which have been given to me by the priests, I carefully keep as reminiscences.
tgt_text.4833: Of nothing unusual, nothing unheard-of am I speaking.
tgt_text.4834: You, too, brother members of the college of that single God, father Bacchus, who are here present, you, I say, know full well what it is you keep so carefully trea­ sured up at home, and what it is that, after excluding the uninitiated, you venerate in silence.
tgt_text.4835: Well, then, I, as I was saying, in my eagerness for truth and in performance of my duty towards the Gods, have become acquainted with mani­ fold rites, usages, and ceremonials.
tgt_text.4836: I do not invent this to suit the present occasion;
tgt_text.4837: for nearly three years since, when, at the very earliest period after my arrival at Oea, I was de­ livering a public lecture on the majestic attributes of AEscu­ lapius, I mentioned the very same thing with reference to my­ self, and reckoned up the number of sacred mysteries with which I was acquainted.
tgt_text.4838: That lecture of mine is very well known;
tgt_text.4840: it is in the hands of all;
tgt_text.4841: being recommended to the religious of Oëa, not so much by my own eloquence, as by its mention of Æsculapius.*
tgt_text.4842: Repeat some of you, if there are any who happen to remember it, the be­ ginning of that discourse.
tgt_text.4844: Do you hear, Maximus, how many are able to quote it?
tgt_text.4846: the book is handed to me.
tgt_text.4847: I will request that those same passages be read;
tgt_text.4848: for judging by the very kind expres­ sion of your countenance, I am fully assured that you will not object to hear them read.
tgt_text.4849: [The passages so read are want­ ing.]
tgt_text.4850: Can it, then, seem wonderful to any man who has any thought or regard whatever for religion, that a person who has been initiated into so many sacred mysteries of the Gods, keeps in his house certain tokens connected with those sacred rites, and that he wraps them up in woven linen, a substance that forms.
tgt_text.4851: the purest of all coverings for things of a holy nature?
tgt_text.4852: For wool, being an excrement of a most inert body, and taken from an animal's back, has ever been held to be an im­ pure covering, in conformity with the dicta of Orpheus and Pythagoras;
tgt_text.4853: while, on the other hand, flax, the purest pro­ duction of the earth, and one that springs up from the ground among the choicest of its fruits, is employed by the most holy of the priests of the Egyptians, not only for their dress, but also for the purpose of covering things of a sacred nature.
tgt_text.4854: Still, I am quite aware that there are some, and Æmilianus here especially, who make a joke of sacred matters, and laugh them to scorn.
tgt_text.4855: For, from what I can learn from some of the people of Oëa, who are acquainted with him, up to this pre.
tgt_text.4856: sent advanced period of life, he has offered his supplications to no deity, crossed the threshold of no temple.
tgt_text.4857: If he chances to pass by any holy place, he holds it an abomination to move his hand to his lips for the purpose of shewing venera­ tion.
tgt_text.4858: Not even to the Gods of husbandry, who feed him and clothe him, does this man offer any first-fruits of his crops, or his vines, or his flocks:
tgt_text.4859: no shrine is there built on his estate, no consecrated spot or grove is there to be found.
tgt_text.4860: But why do I talk about groves and shrines ?
tgt_text.4861: Those who have been there, declare that they never so much as saw a single anointed stone within the boundaries of his estate, or one branch crowned with garlands.
tgt_text.4862: Hence it is, that two nicknames have been given him, Charon, as I have mentioned already, in consequence of the unseemliness of his features and his dis­ position ;
tgt_text.4863: and another, which he likes better, and which is given him on account of his contempt for the Gods, namely, that of Mezentius.*
tgt_text.4864: For this reason, I can very easily un­ derstand that these initiations into so many sacred rites will appear to him to be mere nonsense;
tgt_text.4865: and perhaps, in his con­ tempt for things divine, he will persuade himself not to be­ lieve me, when I say that I most religiously preserve these tokens and reminiscences of so many sacred ceremonials.
tgt_text.4866: But what Mezentius may choose to think of me, not one snap of a finger do I care.
tgt_text.4867: To the rest, however, who are around me, in my loudest voice I give notice, that if any one happens to be present who has been initiated into the samt rites as myself, if he will give me the sign, he shall then be at liberty to hear what it is I keep with such care.
tgt_text.4868: For, so far as I am concerned, by no peril will I ever be compelled to dis­ close to the uninitiated the things that I have had entrusted to me on condition of silence.
tgt_text.4869: I have now then, Maximus, to my thinking, fully satisfied the mind of any man, even the most unreasonable;
tgt_text.4870: and, so far as the napkin is concerned, have wiped away every stain of suspicion;
tgt_text.4871: and I believe I may now pass on in perfect security from the suspicions of Æmili­ anus to the testimony of Crassus, which, next to the preceding matters, they adduced as of the greatest importance.
tgt_text.4872: You heard read in the information, the testimony of a cer- tain glutton and desperate debauchee, Junius Crassus by name, who stated that I had been in the habit of performing sacred rites at night in his house, together with my friend Appius Quintianus, who had paid a sum for the hire of that house.
tgt_text.4873: This Crassus affirms, too, that although at that very time he.
tgt_text.4874: was at Alexandria, he still knows this for a fact, from the smoke left by the torches and from the feathers of birds which were found there.
tgt_text.4875: I suppose he means to say, that while he was celebrating his orgies at Alexandria, (for this, you must know, is that same Crassus who delights to creep at midday into his dens of brothels,) he caught, amid the steams of the kitchen, the feathers that had been wafted thither all the way from his abode, and that he recognized the smoke of his own house, as it curled afar from his paternal roof.
tgt_text.4876: If he really did manage to see it with his eyes, he certainly is blessed with a power of sight that far transcends the wishes and as­ pirations of Ulysses himself.
tgt_text.4877: Ulysses, for many a year, looked out in the distance from the sea-shore, and longed in vain to espy the smoke as it ascended from his native land.*
tgt_text.4878: Crassus, in the few months during which he was absent, without the slightest trouble, espied that smoke while seated in a wine- shop.
tgt_text.4879: And if, too, he managed to snuff up with his nostrils the fumes that arose from his house, why, then, he outdoes even dogs and vultures in the keenness of his scent.
tgt_text.4880: For by what dog, by what vulture, under the Alexandrian sky, can any­ thing possibly be smelt all the way from the confines of Oea ?
tgt_text.4881: No doubt this Crassus is an inordinate glutton, and far from unskilled in all kinds of fumes;
tgt_text.4882: but really, considering his fondness for drinking, the only thing for which he has become distinguished, it would be much more easy for the fumes of wine, than the smell of smoke to reach him at Alexandria.
tgt_text.4883: Even he himself was sensible that this would not be easily be­ lieved.
tgt_text.4884: For the report is, that before the second hour of the day, with an empty stomach, and before he had taken a drop of wine, he made sale of this same testimony of his;
tgt_text.4885: upon which, he wrote down that he had made this discovery in the follow­ ing manner.
tgt_text.4886: Upon his return from Alexandria, he straightway repaired to his own house, which Quintianus had just quitted:
tgt_text.4887: in the vestibule of it he found a great many feathers of birds, and perceived that the walls were black with soot.
tgt_text.4888: On enquiring of his servant, whom he had left at Oëa, what was the reason of this, the servant informed him of the nocturnal rites cole.
tgt_text.4891: What a very likely story, that, if I had wanted to do anything of that kind, I should not have done it at my own house in preference.
tgt_text.4892: That Quintianus here, who is now standing by me, (whose name, in consideration of the strictest ties of friendship which exist between him and me, of his extraordi­ nary learning and his most consummate eloquence, I here men­ tion for the purpose of honouring and extolling him,) that this same Quintianus, I say, if he was going to have any fowls for his dinner, or if, as they say, he required them to be killed for magical purposes, could find no servant to pluck the feathers and throw them away!
tgt_text.4893: Moreover, that the smoke was in such volumes, that it quite blackened the walls!
tgt_text.4894: and that Quin­ tianus was willing to put up with this dirty appearance in his room, all the time that he was residing there !
tgt_text.4895: You make no answer to this, Æmilianus;
tgt_text.4896: it is not likely you would;
tgt_text.4897: but perhaps Crassus, on his return, did not direct his steps to the chamber, but, consistently with his usual prac­ tice, made straight for the kitchen-stove.
tgt_text.4898: But on what ground did the servant of Crassus form this suspicion of his, that the walls got blackened in the night time precisely ?
tgt_text.4899: or why, that it was smoke with which they were discoloured ?
tgt_text.4900: It is, I sup­ pose, because smoke that escapes by night, is blacker than the smoke of the daytime, and so differs from it in its effect!
tgt_text.4901: And then, why should a servant, so full of his suspicions, and so notable a person, allow Quintianus to leave, without having the house cleaned out?
tgt_text.4902: Why did those feathers, just like so many lumps of lead, lie there all that time, even till Crassus had returned ?
tgt_text.4903: Ought not Crassus to scold his servant for this ?
tgt_text.4904: No, he has preferred to trump up this falsehood about the soot and the feathers, because, even in giving his evidence, he can­ not tear himself from the kitchen.
tgt_text.4905: And then, why did you read his evidence from the record ?
tgt_text.4907: Has he got tired of his house, and returned to Alexandria ?
tgt_text.4908: Is he busily engaged in cleaning down those walls of his ?
tgt_text.4909: Or, what is much more likely, is that gormandizer at this moment laid up with a fit of in-- digestion?
tgt_text.4910: For I, my own self, AEmilianus, saw him no longer ago than yesterday, here at Sabrata,* publicly enough, hiccupping away to you, in the middle of the market-place.
tgt_text.4911: Make enquiry then, Maximus, of your clerks of court, although, no doubt, he is better known to cookshop-keepers than to clerks of court;
tgt_text.4912: still, ask them, I say, whether they have seen here Junius Crassus, a native of Oea ;
tgt_text.4914: There­ fore, let AEmilianus bring before us this most worthy youth, in whose testimony he places such confidence.
tgt_text.4915: You see what time of the day it is.
tgt_text.4916: I am ready to affirm, that long before this hour, Crassus has been snoring away dead drunk, or else, that he is at this moment taking his second bath, and sweat­ ing off his wine, that he may be ready for a second drinking bout after dinner.
tgt_text.4917: This fellow, though he is quite close at hand, speaks through the record :
tgt_text.4918: not but that he is so utterly void of shame, that if even he were in your presence, he would lie, without changing colour in the slightest;
tgt_text.4919: but very prp- bably, from his drunken habits, he has not been able to exer­ cise even such a slight degree of control over himself, as to keep sober and await this hour.
tgt_text.4920: Or else it is, that Æmilianus has done this designedly, in order that he might not have to place him before such scrutinizing eyes as yours;
tgt_text.4921: his object being that you might not, from his appearance, form a bad opinion of the brute, with his lank jaws, and his sinister aspect;
tgt_text.4922: when you saw his head despoiled of beard and hair, though he is still a young man, his eyes distilling rheum, his eyelids swollen, his lips bedewed with slaver, his voice quite cracked, his hands shaking, as he grinst and belches by turns.
tgt_text.4923: All his patrimony he has long ago devoured, and nothing of his family possessions is there now left, except one solitary house, for the purpose of affording him an opportunity of making sale of his false evidence;
tgt_text.4924: and which he has never let at a more remunerating rate, than in affording this bit of testimony.
tgt_text.4925: For this drunken fabrication of his, he has bartered to JEmilianus for three thousand pieces of money, a fact of which there is not a person in Oea who is ignorant.
tgt_text.4926: Before the bar­ gain was concluded, we all knew of it, and by giving timely information, I might have put a stop to it, if I had not been well aware that so silly a lie would do far more harm to JEmi­ lianus, who was making purchase of it to no purpose, than to myself, who could well afford to hold it in contempt.
tgt_text.4927: I was willing that Æmilianus should have to suffer a loss, and that Crassus should be exposed for the disgraceful character of his evidence.
tgt_text.4928: Why, it is no longer ago than the day before yesterday, that, without the slightest attempt at concealment, the transaction was concluded, at the house of one Rufinus, of whom I shall just now have to make mention, the said Rufinus and Calpur­ nianus acting as the go-betweens and promoters of the trans­ action.
tgt_text.4929: And this part Rufinus was the more ready to act, because he felt very sure that Crassus would bring by no means the smallest part of his bribe to his own wife, at whose intrigues he purposely connives.
tgt_text.4930: I perceived you too, Maxi­ mus, the very moment that the information was produced, showing, by your looks, that you regarded the whole matter with contempt;
tgt_text.4931: for, with your usual wisdom, you suspected their plot, and saw that it was a conspiracy got up against me.
tgt_text.4932: And yet, after all, possessed though they are of unbridled auda­ city and insolent effrontery, not even they have dared to read through the evidence of Crassus, for they saw that it stunk in your nostrils, nor have they ventured to place any reliance upon it.
tgt_text.4933: INow this is why I have mentioned these things, not that with you for my judge, I was frightened by their feathers and their smoke stains, but that Crassus might not escape unpu­ nished for his offence in selling smoke* to a country clown like Æmilianus.
tgt_text.4934: Then there was a charge made by them, when they read the letters of Pudentilla.
tgt_text.4935: It was about a certain little image, which they say I ordered to be secretly made, of the most costly wood, for purposes of magic.
tgt_text.4936: They assert, too, that, although it was the figure of a skeleton, something quite shocking and horrible, I was in the habit of paying the greatest veneration to it, and calling it by the Greek name of βασιλευς, or " king."
tgt_text.4937: If I am not mistaken, I am following their steps in regular order, and unravelling the whole tex­ ture of their calumnies piecemeal.
tgt_text.4938: How can the fabrication of the image have possibly been secret, as you allege, when you know so well who was the maker of it, that you have given him notice to appear ?
tgt_text.4939: Look, here is Cornelius Saturninus, the carver, a man praised among his fellow-citizens for his skill and esteemed for his character;
tgt_text.4940: the same person, Maximus, who, a short time since, when you carefully enquired into all the circumstances of the transaction, recounted them with the strictest fidelity and veracity.
tgt_text.4941: He stated that, after I had seen at his house a number of geometrical figures made of box- wood, in a very clever and workmanlike manner, I was induced by his skill to request him to make for me some mechanical implements, and at the same time gave him a commission to carve for me the figure of any god he might think fit, and out of any material, so long as it was wood, that I might address my prayers to it, after my usual practice.
tgt_text.4943: He also stated that, in the meantime, while I was in the country, my son-in-law, Sicinius Pontianus, who made it his study how to gratify me, having obtained from a most respectable lady, Capitolina by name, some boxes made of ebony, brought them to him, and requested him to make the implements of that material in preference, as being rarer and more durable;
tgt_text.4944: remarking that I should be especially gratified by such a present.
tgt_text.4945: In conformity with my son-in-law's request, he made the articles, as far as the wood of the boxes sufficed, and was able to complete besides a small figure of Mercury, by putting the layers of ivory piece by piece one upon another, in order to give it the requisite thickness.
tgt_text.4946: As I say, all these particulars you heard from him:
tgt_text.4947: added to which, on examining the son of Capitolina, a most worthy young man, who is now present, you were told to the same effect;
tgt_text.4948: how that Pontianus asked for the boxes, and how that Pontianus took them to the artist, Saturninus.
tgt_text.4949: The fact, too, is not denied, that Pontianus received the image when completed from Saturninus, and afterwards made a present of it to me.
tgt_text.4950: All these matters being clearly and distinctly proved, what remains after aH this, in which any ground for suspicion of magical practices can lurk ?
tgt_text.4951: Or rather, what is there in the whole matter that does not convict you of a manifest lie ?
tgt_text.4952: You declared that the image was made secretly, while the fact is, that Pontianus, an illustrious knight, had it made ;
tgt_text.4953: and that Saturninus, a man of respectability and of high character among his fellow-citizens, seated in his own workshop, carved it openly and without concealment;
tgt_text.4954: while a lady of the highest reputation aided the work by the present she made ;
tgt_text.4955: num­ bers, too, both of my own servants and of my friends, who were in the habit of visiting me, knew that it was about to be made, and that it was made.
tgt_text.4956: Were you not ashamed to invent such a lie, and to assert that I had gone all the city over in search of the wood, and that I had taken the greatest trouble in so doing, whereas you knew full well that at that very time I was absent, and had given orders, as was fully proved, that it was to be made of any kind of material ?
tgt_text.4957: Your third lie was, that the figure was made to resemble a frightful corpse, all lean, or rather fleshless, quite horrible and spectre-like.
tgt_text.4958: Now, if you were aware of the existence of such an evident proof of magic, why did you not give me notice to produce it ?
tgt_text.4959: Was it that you might be at liberty to lie as you pleased about a thing that was not be­ fore the court ?
tgt_text.4960: Thanks, however, to a certain habit of mine, you cannot make this falsehood pass.
tgt_text.4961: For it is my custom, wherever I go, to carry with me the image of some god or other stowed away among my books, and to address my prayers to it on festive days, together with offerings of frankincense and wine, and sometimes victims.
tgt_text.4962: Accordingly, when I heard just now that most impudent fabrication of yours about a ske­ leton, I requested a person to go, post haste, and fetch from my lodgings the little image of Mercury which Saturninus had made for me at Oëa.
tgt_text.4965: There it is before you—the thing that this scoundrel has called a ske­ leton.
tgt_text.4966: Do you not hear the expressions of displeasure so loudly uttered by all present ?
tgt_text.4967: Do you not hear their con­ demnation of your falsehood ?
tgt_text.4968: Are you not at last utterly ashamed of so many calumnious charges ?
tgt_text.4970: Is this the figure of a spectre ?
tgt_text.4971: Is this a thing that you will persist in calling a demon ?
tgt_text.4972: Is this an image adapted to ma gical practices, or is it one of the usual and ordinary kind ?
tgt_text.4973: Take it, pray, Maximus, and look at it:
tgt_text.4974: to hands so pure and so holy as yours a sacred thing is well entrusted.
tgt_text.4975: There, now, just look at it;
tgt_text.4976: how beauteous its figure, and how replete with stalwart vigour;
tgt_text.4977: how smiling are the features of the god;
tgt_text.4978: how becomingly does the first growth of down overspread the cheeks, and how gracefully do the crisped locks peep forth upon the head from beneath the shelving brim of the cap!
tgt_text.4979: How charmingly do the wings shoot forth above his temples !
tgt_text.4980: How smartly, too, is the garment laid down in plaits about the shoulders !
tgt_text.4981: Any one who dares to call this a skeleton, it is clear that he never sees an image of the Gods;
tgt_text.4982: or if he does, he passes them all in heedless contempt.
tgt_text.4983: Any one who takes this to be the figure of a spectre, is a spectre-stricken being himself.
tgt_text.4984: In return, Æmilianus, for this lie of yours, may this Di­ vinity, who visits the Deities above and the shades below, bring upon you the enmity of the Gods who dwell in either realm, and may he thrust upon your vision phantoms of the dead, all the shades of hell, all the Lemurs, all the Manes, all the hobgoblins, all the apparitions of the night, all the spectres of the sepulchres, all the terrors of the tombs-from making a more intimate acquaintance with which, you are not very far distant, both in age and in deserts.
tgt_text.4985: But as for us, the dis­ ciples of Plato, of nothing do we .know, except that which is festive and joyous, consistent with propriety, divine and heavenly.
tgt_text.4986: Nay, more, in its aspirations for what is exalted, this sect has even explored things loftier than the very heavens, and has taken up its abode on the convex side* of the firma­ ment.
tgt_text.4987: Maximus knows that I speak the truth, for he has attentively read in the Phædrus of " the place" which Plato mentions as "being above the heavens, and upon the back thereof."
tgt_text.4988: Maximus, too, understands full well (to answer you in relation to the namet) who it is that was called first of all, not by me but by Plato, by the title of " Basileus," the first cause, and reason, and primitive origin of universal nature, the supreme father of the mind, the eternal preserver of ani­ mated beings, the ever-watchful artificer of his universe.
tgt_text.4989: And, indeed, he is an artificer who knows not labour, a preserver devoid of anxiety, a father without generation, one compre- hended by no space, by no time, by no name, and therefore to be conceived by few, to be expressed by none.
tgt_text.4990: See, then, I volunteer to add to your suspicions of my magical pursuits.
tgt_text.4991: I do not answer you, Æmilianus, as to who it is I worship under the name of " Basileus."
tgt_text.4992: Nay, more, even if the proconsul himself were to ask me who my God is, I should be silent.
tgt_text.4993: With reference to the name, for the present I have said enough;
tgt_text.4994: as for the rest, I am not unaware that some who stand around me are anxious to hear why I wished the image to be made not of silver or gold, but of wood especially;
tgt_text.4995: and this I be­ lieve they desire to know, not so much for the purpose of en­ suring my acquittal as of gaining information, so that they may have their minds set at ease even upon this little matter, when they have seen every ground for suspicion abundantly confuted.
tgt_text.4996: Listen, then, you who wish to know;
tgt_text.4997: listen with the closest attention, as though you heard the very words of the sage Plato, which are found in his last book, "On the Laws."
tgt_text.4998: "It is right that a moderate man should present offerings in mo­ deration to the Gods.
tgt_text.4999: But as the earth, like the domestic hearth, is sacred to all the Gods, let no one dedicate that a second time to the Gods."
tgt_text.5000: He gives this prohibition in order that no private person may presume to erect a temple on his own property.
tgt_text.5001: For he thinks that public temples are sum- cient for the citizens for the purpose of immolating victims.
tgt_text.5002: He then subjoins, " For gold and silver, both in other cities and in our own, employed in temples, is an odious thing.
tgt_text.5003: Ivory, too, as proceeding from a body deprived of life, is not a becoming offering.
tgt_text.5004: Again, iron and copper are instruments of warfare.
tgt_text.5005: But of wood, let each person consecrate as much as he pleases, so long as it is of a single kind, and the same as to stone, in the temples that are common to all.
tgt_text.5006: "The expressions of assent on all sides, and yours especially who sit here in judgment, show that I have most fortunately employed Plato not only as the guide of my life, but as my ad­ vocate in this trial, whose directions you see me so ready to obey.
tgt_text.5007: It is now time* to turn to the letters of Pudentilla, or, in- deed, to go a little further back, and retrace all these events, in order that it may be palpable to all, that if I, who, they persist in saying, effected an entrance into the house of Puden­ tilla from motives of cupidity, had thought of any thing like gain, I ought rather to have always shunned that house, and an alliance that in other respects has turned out for me so far from fortunate.
tgt_text.5008: It is one, indeed, that would have proved disastrous to me, had it not been that my wife in herself, by her many virtues, makes ample amends for disadvantages so numerous ;
tgt_text.5009: for really nothing can you find but disappointed envy as the prompter of this accusation, and the source of many previous perils to which I have been exposed.
tgt_text.5010: But why, even if he really had found me to be a magician, should AEmilianus have been moved to indignation, when not only has he never been injured by any act, but not by the slightest word even of mine, so as to give him a pretext for taking umbrage and entertaining a desire for revenge ?
tgt_text.5011: Nor yet is it for the sake of renown that he accuses me;
tgt_text.5012: the ruling motive when M. Antonius accused Cneius Carbo;
tgt_text.5017: For all these persons, men of the greatest learning and in the prime of life, made these their first efforts in the forensic art for the sake of gaining re­ nown ;
tgt_text.5018: and their object was, that by engaging in some cele­ brated cause they might become known to their fellow-citizens.
tgt_text.5019: But this custom, which, among those of farmer times, was allowable in rising young men, for the purpose of showing off the vigour of their intellect, has long since gone out of usage;
tgt_text.5020: and even if at the present day it were in use, it ought to have been resorted to by him the last of all.
tgt_text.5021: For neither would the boasts of eloquence have become a person so rude and so unlearned, the desire of glory one so clownish and so uncouth, nor the practice of pleading causes an aged man with one foot in the grave;
tgt_text.5022: unless it is, perchance, that AEmilianus, in ac­ cordance with nis severity of manners, has wished to set an example, and from the very hostility that he entertains to vice itself, has, in conformity with the unblemished character of his morals, taken upon himself to make this charge.
tgt_text.5023: But this I could hardly have believed even of Æmilianus, not this African one, but him who was called Africanus* Numantinus, and who had held, too, the office of censor;
tgt_text.5024: much less can I entertain the notion that in this stick here there is any hatred of crimes, or even so much as a comprehension of what they are.
tgt_text.5026: To any one it is as clear as day that it is nothing else but envy that has instigated him and his prompter, Herennius Rufinus (of whom I shall have to speak presently), and the rest of my enemies, to frame these calumnious charges of magical practices.
tgt_text.5027: There are five points, then, which it is incumbent upon me to discuss ;
tgt_text.5028: for so many, if I remember aright, have they objected against me in relation to Pudentilla.
tgt_text.5029: Now, the first point is, their assertion that after her first husband's decease she would never have married again, had she not been forced by my incantations;
tgt_text.5030: the second concerns her letters, which they consider to be an admission of magical practices;
tgt_text.5031: then, in the third and fourth places, they have made the objection that in the sixtieth year of her age she was married to gratify lustful propensities, and that the marriage contract was signed not in town, but at her country house.
tgt_text.5032: The last and the most odious charge is that which bears reference to her fortune.
tgt_text.5033: Into that they have with all their might discharged their whole venom;
tgt_text.5034: upon that point they were most especially anxious, and this is what they have alleged;
