tgt_text.5035: they say that immediately after we were married, at her country house, remote from all witnesses, I ex­ torted from my fond wife this large fortune of hers.
tgt_text.5036: All these assertions I will prove to be so false, so worthless, so unfounded, and will so easily and beyond all question refute them, that truly, Maximus, and you councillors, I do very much fear you will think that the accuser has been engaged and suborned by me, to give me an opportunity publicly to extinguish the rancor­ ous hatred with which I have been pursued.
tgt_text.5037: Believe me when I say it, and the event will prove my words true, that I shall have to take all possible pains that you may not suppose rather that I have in my craftiness devised, than that they have in their folly undertaken so frivolous a prosecution.
tgt_text.5038: Now, while I briefly recount the circumstances of the case in their order, and force AEmilianus himself to own on what false grounds he has been induced to hate me, and that he has wan- dered far indeed from the truth, I beg that you will as carefully as you have already done, or even more so, if possible, consider cne very origin and foundation of this trial.
tgt_text.5039: Æmilia Pudentilla, who is now my wife, had, by one Sici­ nius Amicus, to whom she was previously married, two sons, Pontianus and Pudens.
tgt_text.5040: These children were left orphans, and under care of their paternal grandfather (for it so hap­ pened that Amicus died, leaving his father surviving him), on which she manifested the most exemplary affection, and brought them up with the greatest care for a period of four­ teen years.
tgt_text.5041: Still, however, it was by no inclination of hers that, in the flower of her age, she remained so long in a state of widowhood ;
tgt_text.5042: but the grandfather of the children used all his endeavours to unite her, much against her wish, to Sicinius Clarus, another son of his, and for that reason he kept all other suitors at a distance, while at the same time he threatened that if she should marry a stranger, he would by his will leave no portion of their paternal property to her sons.
tgt_text.5043: Being a woman endowed with prudence and of ex­ emplary affection, and seeing this match so perseveringly proposed to her, she complied, and executed a marriage con­ tract with Sicinius Clarus, that she might not, through any con­ duct of hers, be the cause of detriment to her children.
tgt_text.5044: How­ ever, by resorting to various pretexts, she put off the nuptials until such time as the grandfather of the children had de­ parted this life, leaving her sons his heirs, and upon the under­ standing that Pontianus, who was the elder, should be the guar- than of his brother.
tgt_text.5045: On being thus set free from this state of perplexity, she was sought in marriage by men of the highest rank, and she accord­ ingly made up her mind no longer to remain in a state of widowhood;
tgt_text.5046: for, although she might have been able to endure the tediousness of celibacy, she was quite unable to bear up against bodily ailment.
tgt_text.5047: A woman of inviolable chastity, who had lived so many years in a state of widowhood, without a blemish, without an aspersion on her character, with her system torpid from her prolonged disuse of the married state, afflicted with a protracted inactivity of the vital parts, the interior of her womb disordered—she was often brought by her sufferings to extreme peril of her life.
tgt_text.5048: Both doctors and midwives agreed that the disease had taken its rise through disuse of the married state, that the malady would gain strength every day, and her weakness become still greater;
tgt_text.5049: and they strongly suggested that while some hopes of life were still re­ maining, recourse ought to be had to marriage.
tgt_text.5050: Other persons, too, approved of this advice, Æmilianus here, in especial, the very man who, a short time since, asserted with most audacious falsehood, that Pudentilla never enter­ tained a thought about marriage, until she was coerced by me through magical practices ;
tgt_text.5051: and that I was the only one found to violate the flower of her widowhood, a kind of virginity, as it were, by means of my charms and drugs.
tgt_text.5052: I have many a time heard it said, with very good reason too, that " A liar ought to have a good memory."
tgt_text.5053: Now, did it not occur to your recollection, Æmilianus, that before I even came to Oëa, you had gone so far as to write a letter to her son, Pontianus, who was then grown up, and residing at Rome, in which you recommended that she should marry?
tgt_text.5054: Give me the letter, will you, or rather hand it to him;
tgt_text.5056: by his own voice and by his own words let him convict himself.
tgt_text.5057: [He reads the beginning of the letter.]
tgt_text.5058: Is not that your own writing ?
tgt_text.5062: Read it, I beg, and aloud, too, so that all may understand what a vast difference there is between this man's tongue and his hand, and how much less he disagrees with me than with himself.
tgt_text.5063: [The clerk of court reads the rest of the letter.]
tgt_text.5064: Were you not the writer, Æmilianus, of these words which have been read?
tgt_text.5065: "I know that she wishes and ought to marry;
tgt_text.5066: but whom she may choose, I do not know."
tgt_text.5067: Quite right, no doubt you did not know.
tgt_text.5068: For Pudentilla, being well aware of your spiteful malignity, only thought proper to inform you of the fact, but said nothing at all about a suitor.
tgt_text.5069: You, however, deluded by vain hopes that she would marry your brother Clams, even went so far as to advise her son Pontianus to consent to her marriage.
tgt_text.5070: Consequently, if she had made choice of Clarus, a clownish* and decrepit old man, you would have been ready to assert that, quite spontaneously, and without any magical practices whatever, she had long been anxious to marry;
tgt_text.5071: but as she has made choice of such a youth as you talk of, you affirm that it was by compulsion she did so, and that, otherwise she always entertained an aversion to marriage.
tgt_text.5072: You little thought, dishonest man, that your letter on this matter had been preserved;
tgt_text.5073: you little thought that you were going to be convicted on your own testimony.
tgt_text.5074: Pu­ dentilla, however, knowing full well how fickle and change­ able you were, and how untruthful and shameless to boot, thought it better to keep this letter than to part with it, as an evidence of your own wishes on the subject.
tgt_text.5075: Besides, she herself wrote to her son, Pontianus, while he was at Rome, on the same subject, and entered very fully too upon the causes that prompted her to take this resolution.
tgt_text.5076: She mentioned to him all the matters connected with her health, that besides there was no reason why she should per­ sist any longer in remaining unmarried;
tgt_text.5077: she reminded him, how that, disregarding her own welfare, she had, by her pro­ longed state of widowhood;
tgt_text.5078: obtained for them their grand­ father's property, and had with the most scrupulous carefulness increased the same;
tgt_text.5079: that, thanks to the Gods, he himself was now of marriageable estate, and his brother ready to assume the manly gown:
tgt_text.5080: * that they ought now at last to allow her to find some alleviation for her state of solitude and sickliness:
tgt_text.5081: that they need be under no apprehension as to the constancy of her affection, and her remembering them in her last will:
tgt_text.5082: that such as she had shown herself towards them while a widow, she would still prove when a wife.
tgt_text.5083: I will request the copy of this letter to be read, which she sent to her son.
tgt_text.5084: [The copy of the letter of Pudentilla to her son Pontianus is read.
tgt_text.5085: ]I think that from this letter it may be quite manifest to any one that it was not by any incantations of mine that Pudentilla was prevailed upon to abandon her prolonged state of widowhood, but that having been for a long time not averse to marriage, she perchance preferred me to the rest.
tgt_text.5086: And I really do not see why this choice made by a woman of such respectability, ought to be imputed to me as a crime, rather than an honor.
tgt_text.5087: But I do wonder that Æmilianus and Rufinus take amiss this decision of the lady, when those persons who aspired to the hand of Pudentilla bear with resignation the fact that I was preferred to them.
tgt_text.5088: Besides, in so doing, she rather consulted her son's wishes, than her own feelings on the subject.
tgt_text.5089: That such was the fact, not even AEmilianus can deny.
tgt_text.5090: For Pontianus, on receiving his mother's letter, instantly flew hither with all haste from Rome, being greatly afraid, if she should take some greedy fellow for a husband, she would be carrying off everything, as too frequently is the case, to her husband's house.
tgt_text.5091: This anxiety influenced his feelings in no slight degree :
tgt_text.5092: for all the hopes of himself and of his brother were centred in possessing the property of their mother.
tgt_text.5093: Their grandfather had left a small property, their mother's possessions amounted in value to four millions of sesterces.
tgt_text.5094: Out of this sum she did, no doubt, owe some money to her sons, which she had borrowed from them without giving any vouchers, but simply on her own credit.
tgt_text.5095: These apprehensions of his he kept secret;
tgt_text.5096: for he did not dare openly to offer op­ position, lest he should seem to distrust her.
tgt_text.5097: While mat­ ters were in this state, the mother being wooed, and the son racked with apprehensions, whether it was by chance, or by a kind of fatality, I happened to arrive there, being on my road to Alexandria. " By Hercules, I only wish it had never so happened," I might add, if respect for my wife did not pro- vent me.
tgt_text.5099: Fatigued by the journey, I made a stay of several days at the house of the Appii, old friends of mine, whose names I mention to testify for them my honor and my esteem.
tgt_text.5100: While I was staying there, Pon­ tianus called upon me;
tgt_text.5101: for, some few years before, he had been introduced to me at Athens, by some common friends of ours, and had been subsequently united to me by ties of the strictest intimacy.
tgt_text.5102: He was in everything sedulous to testify his respect for me, to promote my welfare, and dexterously to prompt my affections.
tgt_text.5103: For he thought that in me he had now found a very suitable husband for his mother, and one to whom he might, without any risk, entrust the welfare of the family.
tgt_text.5104: He began to sound my inclination by hints, and as he per­ ceived that I was intent upon pursuing my travels, and averse to wedlock, he begged that I would at least make a short stay.
tgt_text.5105: He said that it was his wish to accompany me, that it was un­ advisable then to proceed on account of the burning heat of [the sands of] the Syrtis, and the wild beasts that infested it, and that as my bad state of health had deprived me of the present winter, it would be as well to wait for the next.
tgt_text.5106: By force of entreaties, he withdrew me from the house of my friends, the Appii, to transfer me to his mother's abode, as likely to prove a more healthy place of residence for me;
tgt_text.5107: be­ sides, I should be able from her house to enjoy a very exten­ sive view of the sea, a thing that for me has especial charms.
tgt_text.5108: He urged these considerations with great earnestness, and in­ troduced to me his mother and his brother, this same youth.
tgt_text.5109: They received some assistance from me in their common studies, and the intimacy increased apace.
tgt_text.5110: In the meantime I re­ covered my health, and at the request of my friends I gave a public lecture.
tgt_text.5111: All who were present in the thronged basilica,* the place appointed for its delivery, cried out with one accord, requesting that I would remain there, and become a citizen of Oea.
tgt_text.5112: When the audience had departed, Pontianus addressed me, and began by saying that he interpreted this accordance in the public voice as an omen from heaven.
tgt_text.5113: Then he disclosed to me that it was his own wish, if I had no objection, to unite me to his mother, whom a great many persons were eager to obtain;
tgt_text.5114: seeing that, as he said, I was the only person in whom he placed entire trust and confidence.
tgt_text.5115: Would I take upon me that incumbrance ?
tgt_text.5116: for it was no pretty maiden he offered me, but a woman, the mother of children, and of homely features.
tgt_text.5117: If, on thinking over these things, I should reserve myself for some other match, with the view of gaining beauty or riches, he would neither take me for a friend nor a true philosopher.
tgt_text.5118: My speech would be far too long, were I to relate what I stated to him in answer;
tgt_text.5119: at what length, and how frequently the subject was discussed by us;
tgt_text.5120: with what repeated and earnest entreaties he plied me;
tgt_text.5121: and how he never ceased till he had finally gained his point.
tgt_text.5122: Not but that having now lived in the same house with her a whole year, I had become tho­ roughly acquainted with Pudentilla's character, and had dis­ covered her virtuous endowments;
tgt_text.5123: still, as I was anxious to travel, I declined for some time to marry, as being likely to prove an impediment to my design.
tgt_text.5124: Before very long, how­ ever, I was no more disinclined to take such a woman for my wife, than if I had sought her of my own accord.
tgt_text.5125: Pontianus, too, had prevailed upon his mother to choose me in preference to all others, and showed incredible anxiety to bring it about as soon as possible.
tgt_text.5126: It was with difficulty we obtained of him even a short respite, until such time as he himself should have married, and his brother have assumed the manly gown;
tgt_text.5127: after which we agreed to be united in mar­ riage.
tgt_text.5129: it were possible, without the greatest injury to my cause, to pass over the matters which I am obliged next to mention, that I might not appear now to accuse Pontianus of fickleness, whom I forgave freely and with­ out reserve, when he asked forgiveness for his error.
tgt_text.5130: For I am ready to confess a thing that has been brought forward as a charge against me, that, after he was married, he was guilty of a breach of that fidelity which he had pledged to me, and that, suddenly changing his mind, he endeavoured with equal pertinacity to prevent that which he had before endea­ voured with the greatest zeal to promote--that, in fact, he was ready to submit to anything, to do anything, in order that our marriage might not take place.
tgt_text.5131: And still, all this unbecoming change of mind on his part, and this ill-will against his mo­ ther, ought not to be imputed as a fault to him, but rather to his father-in-law, who stands there, Herennius Rufinus, a man who has left not one individual upon the face of the earth more vile, more dishonest, or more iniquitous than himself.
tgt_text.5132: ,In a very few words, as I am necessitated so to do, I will describe the man, but still in language as moderate as I pos­ sibly can;
tgt_text.5133: lest, if I should be altogether silent about him, he should have lost his pains, in using his utmost endeavours to create for me all this trouble.
tgt_text.5134: For it is he who is the instigator of this stripling;
tgt_text.5135: it is he who is the prompter of this prosecution;
tgt_text.5136: it is he who is the hirer of these advocates;
tgt_text.5137: it is he who is the suborner of these witnesses;
tgt_text.5138: it is he who is the furnace wherein this calumny has been annealed;
tgt_text.5139: it is he who acts as the torch and the goad of Æmilianus here;
tgt_text.5140: while in the presence of all, he boasts most immoderately that it is through his machinations that I have been accused.
tgt_text.5141: And, no doubt, he has in these matters very good grounds for congra­ tulating himself.
tgt_text.5142: For he is the base contractor of all litigation, the inventor of all falsehoods, the framer of all pretences, the hot­ bed of all mischiefs;
tgt_text.5143: he, too, is a very haunt, a den, a brothel for lusts and debaucheries;
tgt_text.5144: from his very earliest age he has been universally notorious for his disgraceful vices.
tgt_text.5145: Formerly, in his boyhood, before he was disfigured by that baldness of his, he was subservient to his corruptors in the perpetration of every infamous crime;
tgt_text.5146: after that, in his youth, as a dancer on the stage, he was so pliant in body as to seem to be utterly with­ out bones and nerves ;
tgt_text.5147: but, from what I hear, he was remark­ able for a coarse and uncouth effeminacy.
tgt_text.5148: Indeed, he is said to have had nothing whatever of the actor, except the immo­ desty.
tgt_text.5149: At his present age, too, the years at which he has now arrived-may the Gods confound him!—high commen­ dations these to be uttered in his hearing-his whole house is a brothel, his entire household a mass of corruption, himself devoid of all shame, his wife a prostitute, his sons just like himself.
tgt_text.5150: His door, a sport, day and night, for the young men of the place, is battered by their heels, his windows serenaded by their ditties, his dining-room kept in an uproar by revellers, and his bed-chamber a common thoroughfare for adulterers ;
tgt_text.5151: nor, in fact, has any one the least fear to enter it, with the ex­ ception of, him who has brought no admission-fee to the hus­ band.
tgt_text.5152: In this way is the dishonor of his bed a source of in­ come to him.
tgt_text.5153: Formerly he used to earn money by his own person;
tgt_text.5154: now he earns it by letting out the person of his wife.
tgt_text.5155: With this same man, many a one—I am telling no falsehood -with this same man, I say, many a one has bargained for a night with his wife.
tgt_text.5156: Hence, then, that collusion which is so notorious between the husband and the wife.
tgt_text.5157: When people have brought a handsome compliment for the woman, no one takes any notice of them, and they take their departure at their own time and pleasure.
tgt_text.5158: But as for those who have come not so well supplied, on a signal given, they are seized as adul­ terers ;
tgt_text.5159: and, as though they had come for the purpose of learn­ ing a lesson, they do not get away before they have done a little writing.
tgt_text.5160: *But really what was the wretched man to do when he had lost a very handsome fortune-one, however, which he had quite unexpectedly picked up through his father's fraudulent proceedings ?
tgt_text.5161: This father of his, being eaten up by usurious debts due to a great number of creditors, preferred to save his money rather than his honor.
tgt_text.5162: For when he was dunned on all sides on his bonds, and clutched hold of by all who met him, just as though he had been a madman—"Have patience," he exclaimed;
tgt_text.5163: and then he declared it was not in his power to pay his debts;
tgt_text.5164: laid aside his gold rings and all the insignia of his rank, and made a composition with his creditors.
tgt_text.5165: But, by a most artful fraud, he managed to trans­ fer the greater part of his property into the name of his wife ;
tgt_text.5166: and so, himself in want, and stripped naked, though covered with his ignominy, he left to Rufinus here—I am telling no falsehood in so saying-three millions of sesterces for him to devour.
tgt_text.5167: For fully that sum came to him as his mother's pro­ perty, free and unencumbered, besides all that his wife has earned for him by her marriage-portions* from day to day.
tgt_text.5168: All these sums, however, this gluttonous wretch has so care­ fully stowed away in his paunch, and squandered upon his orgies of all kinds, that you would really suppose he was afraid lest it might be said that he retained possession of anything that was the result of his father's frauds.
tgt_text.5169: This man, so just and so pure in his morals, used his utmost endeavours that what was so badly gotten should be as badly lost;
tgt_text.5170: and, from being the possessor of this enormous fortune, he has nothing left, except a wretched ambition and an insatiate appetite.
tgt_text.5171: As for his wife, being now an old woman and nearly worn out, she has at last given up her disgraceful courses.
tgt_text.5172: And then, as for his daughter, after having, to no purpose, at the insti­ gation of her mother, gone the round of all the rich young men, and after having been lent even to some of her suitors for them to make trial of her, if she had not fallen in with the good-natured, easy tempered Pontianus, she would perhaps have been still sitting at home a widow before she was a wife.
tgt_text.5173: Although we most strongly dissuaded him from doing so, Pontianus con­ ferred on her the false and misplaced name of wife, not being unaware that, shortly before he married her, she had been de­ serted by a young man of the highest respectability, who had become tired of her, and to whom she had been previously engaged.
tgt_text.5174: Accordingly, his new-married wife came home to him full of assurance, and unabashed, with her chastity rifled, her vir­ ginity lost, her nuptial veil all sullied;
tgt_text.5175: after her so recent re­ pudiation, a virgin once more, but bringing with her rather the name than the unblemished character of a maid.
tgt_text.5176: In a litter supported by eight persons was she borne along.
tgt_text.5177: You saw,- no doubt, you who were present, how shamelessly she stared about her at the young men, how immodestly she ex­ posed herself.
tgt_text.5178: Who was there that did not recognize the mo­ ther's training, when, in the daughter, he beheld the face be- plastered with cosmetics, the rouged cheeks, and the ogling eyes ?
tgt_text.5179: The very day before, her entire fortune was swept away by a creditor, to the utmost farthing, and certainly a larger one than a house impoverished and full of children would bespeak.
tgt_text.5180: *However, this fellow, whose circumstances are as limited as his hopes are inordinate, his avarice being commensurate with his neediness, had in his vain anticipations gulped up the whole four million sesterces belonging to Pudentilla;
tgt_text.5181: and therefore, as he thought that I ought to be got out of the way, in order that he might more easily practise upon the pliable disposition of Pontianus and the solitary state of Pudentilla, he began to rate his son-in-law for having engaged his mother to me;
tgt_text.5182: prompted him, while yet he had the opportunity, as speedily as possible, to extricate her foot from such great peril;
tgt_text.5183: told him that he himself ought to possess his mother's property, rather than purposely hand it over to a stranger;
tgt_text.5184: and in case he should decline to do so, this crafty knave alarmed the ena­ moured youth by threatening that he would take home his daughter.
tgt_text.5186: At his own will he led the simple-minded youth, entangled in the allure­ ments of his new-made bride, quite away from his original design.
tgt_text.5187: Carrying with him the words of Rufinus, he goes straight to his mother.
tgt_text.5188: However, after trying in vain to shake her constancy, after taking upon himself to censure her for levity and fickleness, he had to carry back no pleasing re­ port to his father-in-law:
tgt_text.5189: that, contrary to her extremely mild and imperturbable disposition, his mother had been roused to anger by his expostulations, which served in no slight degree to support her in her obstinate determination:
tgt_text.5190: that, finally, she declared she was by no means unaware that it was through the advice of Rufinus he expostulated with her, for which reason she should be all the more in- dined to obtain the protection of a husband against his despe­ rate avarice.
tgt_text.5191: On hearing these words, this pander to his wife so swelled with anger, so blazed with rage, that in the presence of her own son he said things against this lady, a woman of most chaste and modest character, which would have been far more befitting his own chamber, and shouted out that she was a love-sick creature, and I was a magician and sorcerer;
tgt_text.5192: and this in the hearing of many persons, whom, if you desire it, I will name ;
tgt_text.5193: and declared that with his own hand he would put an end to me.
tgt_text.5195: can I moderate my anger, so great is the indignation which rises in my mind.
tgt_text.5196: What, you, you most effeminate wretch!
tgt_text.5197: do you threaten death to be dealt with your hand to any man ?
tgt_text.5199: Is it the hand of Philomela ?
tgt_text.5202: whom, when you personate in the dance, such is the effeminacy of your disposition, such is your dread of steel, that you are afraid to dance with the mimic sword.
tgt_text.5203: *But, not to digress any further, when Pudentilla saw that her son was corrupted contrary to her expectations, she went into the country, and there wrote to him that famous letter of hers, in which, as they said, she admitted that she had been bereft of her senses and induced to love me through my magical practices.
tgt_text.5204: And yet this very letter, by your order, Maximus, I copied at length the day before yesterday, in pre­ sence of the public registrar, and before witnesses, Æmilianus taking a copy at the same time;
tgt_text.5205: and in every point it is found to tell in my favour, and against their accusations.
tgt_text.5206: For even if she had distinctly called me a magician, it might seem that in excusing herself to her son, she preferred to do so rather on the ground of my irresistibleness than of her own inclination.
tgt_text.5207: Is Phædra the only woman that ever wrote an untrue letter on the subject of love ?
tgt_text.5208: Is not this a common artifice with all females, to try and make it appear that they act by compul­ sion, when they have once set their minds upon any thing of this nature ?
tgt_text.5209: And even if she did in her own mind think that I was a magician, am I any the more a magician, because Pudentilla , has written to that effect?
tgt_text.5210: You, by your numerous argu­ ments, your multitude of witnesses, your lengthy oration, fail to prove that I am a magician;
tgt_text.5211: was she by a single ex­ pression of hers to prove it ?
tgt_text.5212: And yet of how much greater weight ought a charge to be considered which is undertaken to be proved in a court of justice, than an assertion merely made in a letter ?
tgt_text.5213: But why do you not convict me by my own actions, and not by the words of another person ?
tgt_text.5214: Henceforth, on the same principle, many will be accused of all sorts of offences, if things are to be held as true which anybody, influenced by love or by hatred of another, has written in a letter.
tgt_text.5215: Pudentilla has written that you are a magician, therefore you are a magician.
tgt_text.5216: Suppose she had written that I was a consul, would it follow that I really am a consul ?
tgt_text.5217: And what if a painter, what if a physician ?
tgt_text.5218: what, in fine, if she had said I was innocent?
tgt_text.5219: would you have believed her in any one of these assertions, merely because she said So.?
tgt_text.5220: In none of them, no doubt.
tgt_text.5221: Well, but it is most unjust to give credit for evil to one to whom you would decline to give the same credit for good;
tgt_text.5222: to allow his letters to have power to injure, and yet not to have power to save. "
tgt_text.5223: But her feelings were racked with anxiety," you say;
tgt_text.5225: For the moment, I will grant it.
tgt_text.5226: Is it the fact, then, that all who are beloved are magicians, if the person who loves happens to write to that effect ?
tgt_text.5227: You must admit, now, that at this period Pudentilla did not love me, inasmuch as she wrote that to others which was destined to be to my prejudice before the public.
tgt_text.5228: In fine, which do you wish to assert, that she was sane, or that she was insane, when she wrote the letter ?
tgt_text.5230: then she has suffered nothing from my magical practices.
tgt_text.5232: then she did not know what it was she wrote, and therefore we must put no faith in her assertion.
tgt_text.5233: And then, besides, if she had been insane, she would not have known that she was insane.
tgt_text.5234: For in the same way that the person acts absurdly who says that he is silent, because in the very act of saying that he is silent, he is not silent, and by his very affirmation he contradicts what he affirms:
tgt_text.5235: so, even more self-contradictory is the expression, "I am insane," be­ cause it is not true, unless he who says it knows what it is to be insane.
tgt_text.5236: But he who knows what insanity is, is sane;
tgt_text.5237: whereas insanity can no more be sensible of its own existence, than blindness can see itself.
tgt_text.5238: Consequently, Pudentilla, if she fancied that she was not in her senses, was quite in her senses.
tgt_text.5239: I could, if I chose, enlarge upon the subject, but I will now have done with logic.
tgt_text.5240: I will have the letter itself read, which cries aloud to a far different effect, and which seems as though it had been prepared and framed for the very purpose of this trial.
tgt_text.5241: Take it and read on until I interrupt you.
tgt_text.5242: [Part of the letter of Pudentilla is read.]
tgt_text.5243: Cease reading for a moment, for we have now arrived at the turning point in this matter.
tgt_text.5244: Thus far, Maximus, from all that I can perceive, this lady has no where mentioned the name of magic, but has re­ counted the very same train of circumstances that I did a short time since, as to her long widowhood, the cause of her bad state of health, her wish to marry, my own good qualities, of which she had heard an account from Pontianus, and his re­ commendation that she should marry me in preference to any one else.
tgt_text.5245: Thus far has now been read;
tgt_text.5246: there remains the other portion of the letter, which, though written in like manner in my favour, has been made to turn its horns against me, and which, while it was sent for the very purpose of removing from me all suspicion of magical practices, has, to the transcendent glory of Rufus, changed sides, and gone so far as to gain for me a quite opposite character in the eyes of certain persons in Oëa, as though I really were a magician.
tgt_text.5247: Much in the inter­ change of conversation, Maximus, you have heard, still more in reading you have learned, and no little knowledge by expe­ rience you have gained;
tgt_text.5248: but still, you must declare that treachery so insidious, and contrived with such astounding wickedness, you never heard of.
tgt_text.5249: What Palamedes, what Sisyphus, what Eurybates, in fine, what Phrynondas* could have thought of such a thing ?
tgt_text.5250: All those whom I have named, and any besides who have been famed for their cunning, if put in comparison with this single device of Rufinus, would seem to be utter fools and blockheads.
tgt_text.5252: 0 subtlety, worthy of the prison and the dungeon cell!
tgt_text.5253: who would have believed that it could come to pass that what was a defence, could possibly, while the characters still remained the same, be transformed into an accusation ?
tgt_text.5257: But how this thing, which so transcends belief, was brought about, I will now explain to you.
tgt_text.5258: It was the rebuke of a mother to her son, because, at the dictation of Rufinus, he was now declaring, that I, a man whom he had so highly extolled to her, was a magician.
tgt_text.5259: The words themselves were to this effect:
tgt_text.5261: "Apuleius is a magician, and I have been enchanted by him!
tgt_text.5263: Come then to me, until such time as I shall have recovered my senses."
tgt_text.5264: Now these words, which I have read in Greek, picked out by themselves, and separated from their proper con­ text, Rufinus showed to everybody, as a confession made by the lady, at the same time leading Pontianus with him as he hawked them about the forum.
tgt_text.5265: He allowed the letter which she wrote to be read, just as far as I have quoted;
tgt_text.5266: what was written before and after he used to conceal, saying, it was of too disgraceful a nature to be shewn, and that it was enough to know that the lady had made confession of magical practices.
tgt_text.5268: It appeared a very probable story to all.
tgt_text.5269: The very words that had been written for the purpose of exculpating me, stirred up intense hatred against me, among those who did not un­ derstand the matter.
tgt_text.5270: This abominable fellow, raving in the midst of the forum, like a very bacchanal, collected crowds together;
tgt_text.5271: ever and anon opening the letter, he would appeal to the citizens, and exclaiming, "Apuleius is a magician, what she feels and suffers she herself declares;
tgt_text.5273: There was no one to take my part, and thus to answer him, "Have the goodness to give me the whole of the letter.
tgt_text.5274: Allow me to see every part of it, and to read it from beginning to end.
tgt_text.5275: There are many things, which when pro­ duced in an unconnected form, may seem amenable to accusa­ tion.
tgt_text.5276: Any person's language may afford ground for a charge, if words which are connected with preceding ones are to be curtailed of their beginning;
tgt_text.5277: if certain parts in the current order of what has been written are to be suppressed at plea­ sure ;
tgt_text.5278: if what has been asserted ironically, is to be read rather in the tone of a person who admits, than of one who indig­ nantly expostulates.
tgt_text.5280: How justly these and other such remarks might have been made on those occasions, the tenor itself of the letter will show.
tgt_text.5281: Now tell us, Æmilianus, whether you did not, in the presence of witnesses, copy these words at the same time as myself.
tgt_text.5283: For when I was desirous, for the reasons I mentioned, to marry, you yourself persuaded me to choose him in preference to all others, because you admired the man, and greatly wished, through my means, to make him a connection of ours.
tgt_text.5284: But now, when wicked and evil-minded men prompt you, all on a sudden, Apuleius is a magician, and I have been enchanted by him.
tgt_text.5286: Come then to me, until such time as I shall have recovered my senses."
tgt_text.5287: I ask you, Maximus, if letters, some of which are called vocals [vowels], could indeed find a voice, if words were winged, as poets say, would they not, the instant Rufinus, with such bad faith, made these extracts from this letter, and read a few words only, while he purposely withheld the greater and better part,—would not the rest of the letters have shouted aloud, that they were being wickedly suppressed?
tgt_text.5288: Would not the words so suppressed, have taken flight from the hands of Rufinus ?
tgt_text.5289: Would they not have filled the whole forum with their outcries ?
tgt_text.5290: Would they not have declared that they, too, were sent by Pudentilla, that they, too, had a message to speak ?
tgt_text.5291: Would they not have said this, in order that people might not listen to a dishonest and wicked man attempting to establish a falsehood by means of the letter of another person, but listen in preference to their own decla­ ration, that Apuleius was not accused by Pudentilla of the prac­ tice of magic, but when accused by Rufinus, was acquitted by her of the fact.
tgt_text.5292: All these things, although not then expressed, are now made clearer than daylight, at a time when they are of still greater service to me.
tgt_text.5293: Your artifices, Rufinus, are ex­ posed ;
tgt_text.5295: your falsehoods are set forth to view.
tgt_text.5296: The truth, before suppressed by you, now raises it­ self erect, and emerges as it were from the deep pit of ca­ lumny.
tgt_text.5297: You challenged me to abide by the letter of Puden­ tilla ;
tgt_text.5298: by that letter do I conquer;
tgt_text.5299: and if you choose to hear the latter portion of it also, I will not prevent it.
tgt_text.5300: Read the words with which this spell-bound, insane, demented, and love-stricken woman closes her epistle :
tgt_text.5301: "I have not been enchanted at all;
tgt_text.5302: that I am in love, is the work of Fate.
tgt_text.5303: "What more than this do you require ?
tgt_text.5304: Pudentilla contra- diets you, and, by proclamation as it were, defends her sanity from your calumnious charges.
tgt_text.5305: For the cause or necessity of her marrying, she ascribes to fate, from whose operations magic is far removed indeed, nay, utterly estranged.
tgt_text.5306: For what virtue is there left in spells and enchantments, if the fate of each individual thing, like a torrent of most impetuous violence, can neither be restrained,, nor yet accelerated in its course ?
tgt_text.5307: Why, in this sentence of hers, Pudentilla has not only denied that I am a magician, but even that such a thing as magic exists.
tgt_text.5308: It is fortunate that Pontianus, according to his usual cus­ tom, kept his mother's correspondence safe;
tgt_text.5309: it is fortunate that the speedy hearing of this cause has precluded you from finding leisure to make any alteration in this letter.
tgt_text.5310: This ad­ vantage is owing to you, Maximus, and to your foresight;
tgt_text.5311: be­ cause, seeing from the very first into the calumnious nature of these charges, you hurried on the hearing of them, in order that they might not gain strength by lapse of time;
tgt_text.5312: and so, by granting them no respite, you have nipped their growth.
tgt_text.5313: Suppose, now, that in a letter written in confidence, the mo­ ther had, as often is the case, made some confession to her son with reference to love, would it have been right, Rufinus, not to say duteous or manly even, for the contents of such a letter to be divulged and published, and that above all, on the infor­ mation of her son?
tgt_text.5314: But I am a simpleton to expect that you should be observant of the fair name of another, seeing that you have lost your own.
tgt_text.5315: But why do I complain of what is past, when the present is no less distressing ?
tgt_text.5316: That this boy should be so utterly corrupted by you, as to read aloud the letters of his own mother, which he takes to be of an amatory character!
tgt_text.5317: and that he should, before the tribunal of a proconsul, before Claudius Maximus, a man of the strictest virtue, in presence of these statues of the emperor Pius,* ac­ cuse his own mother of shameless incontinence!
tgt_text.5318: Who is there so meek as not to be incensed at this?
tgt_text.5320: make it your business to pry into your parent's thoughts in such matters;
tgt_text.5327: spy out what is done in the retirement of the chamber, not to say by your own mother when in love, but by any lady whatsoever!
tgt_text.5328: Is it possible you can imagine that she was inspired by any other than the affectionate feelings of a parent ?
tgt_text.5331: Oh, barren­ ness, how far preferable to progeny !
tgt_text.5332: Oh, ten months* pro­ ductive of what unhappiness!
tgt_text.5333: Oh, fourteen years of widow­ hood thus ill repaid!
tgt_text.5334: The viper, I have heard say, eats through the womb of its mother, and crawls forth to light, and so owes its birth to parricide.
tgt_text.5335: But upon thee, while living, are in­ flicted wounds still deeper, those, too, by a son who has already arrived at years of maturity.
tgt_text.5336: Thy state of solitude is lacerated, thy fair name is mangled, thy breast is stabbed, thy inmost vitals are torn away !
tgt_text.5337: Is this the way that, like a good son, you make return to your mother for having given you life—for acquiring an in­ heritance for you—for providing for your support during four­ teen long years ?
tgt_text.5338: Or has your uncle trained you in a course like this, in order that you might feel convinced that your sons would turn out like yourself, and so might not venture to marry?
tgt_text.5339: There is a line of a poet † which is not uncom­ monly quoted:
tgt_text.5340: "I hate precocious wisdom in young boys."
tgt_text.5341: But, still more, who would not hate and detest precocious wickedness in a boy ?
tgt_text.5342: when he beholds him, like a sort of monster, full grown up in crime before he is mature in years, venomous before he is come to his strength, green in boyhood, in villany hoary, and even more baneful because he is sure of impunity, and while he is abundantly able to inflict injuries, he is not liableJ to pains and penalties.
tgt_text.5344: Nay, crimes rather, and those against a parent;
tgt_text.5346: Why, the Athenians, in con­ sideration of the common rights of humanity, when the inter­ cepted letters of Philip of Macedon, their enemy, were read in public, forbade one to be published which had been written by Philip to his wife, Olympias.
tgt_text.5347: They chose rather to spare an enemy than to divulge the secrets which had been entrusted by a husband to his wife, being of opinion that universal right ought to be regarded rather than private vengeance.
tgt_text.5348: Such did enemies shew themselves towards an enemy;
tgt_text.5349: what sort of a son have you shewn yourself towards your mother ?
tgt_text.5350: Do you see how extremely similar are the cases I compare ?
tgt_text.5351: And yet you, a son, read letters written by your own mother, on amorous subjects, as you allege, in the presence of this numerous assemblage, before whom, if you had been requested to read some wanton poet, you assuredly would not have ven­ tured to do so, but would have been prevented by some sense of shame;
tgt_text.5352: indeed, if you had ever touched upon letters in general, you would never have touched letters* written by your own mother.
tgt_text.5353: But what an epistle of your own was it that you ventured to give to be read !
tgt_text.5354: the letter which, most disrespectfully, most insultingly, and most basely, you wrote about your mother, and secretly sent to Pontianus, at the very time that you were still nurtured in her bosom!
tgt_text.5355: in order, I suppose, that you might not have sinned once only, and that such reputable conduct as yours might not be buried in obli­ vion.
tgt_text.5357: you do not perceive that your uncle allowed this to be done, in order that he might exculpate him­ self in the sight of men, when it should become known from your own letter, that even before you betook yourself to him, even when you were still fawning upon your mother, even then you were acting a fox-like and unnatural part.
tgt_text.5358: Besides, I cannot bring myself to believe that Æmilianus is so simple as to suppose that the letter of a:
tgt_text.5359: boy, and that boy my ac­ cuser, could do me any injury.
tgt_text.5360: Then, there was that counterfeit letter, which was neither written by my hand, nor even forged with any likelihood, by which they wished to make it appear that this lady had been plied by me with blandishments.
tgt_text.5361: Why should I need to re­ sort to blandishments, if I relied on my magical powers ?
tgt_text.5362: Besides, by what means, too, was a letter to come into their hands, which was, no doubt, sent to Pudentilla by the hands of some trusty messenger, as usual in matters of this nature ?
tgt_text.5363: And why should I write in expressions so ungrammatical, in lan­ guage so barbarous, when they assert that I am far from unac­ quainted with the Greek language ?
tgt_text.5364: Why, too, should I solicit her with compliments so absurd, so pot-house like,* when they say that I am able to express myself elegantly in the wanton numbers of amatory verse ?
tgt_text.5365: The truth, no doubt, is this;
tgt_text.5366: to every one it is self-evident :
tgt_text.5367: -he who was not able to read the letter of Pudentilla, because it was expressed in purer Greek, could read this more easily, and find himself more at home in descanting upon it, because the composition was his own.
tgt_text.5368: But now, I shall consider that I have said sufficient on the subject of these letters, when I shall have added this single fact, that Pudentilla, after having written by way of irony and joke, " Come until such time as I shall have come to my senses," after the date of that very letter invited to her house her sons and her daughter-in-law, and lived there with them for a period of nearly two months.
tgt_text.5369: Let this dutiful son de­ clare what, during that period, he saw his mother either do or say that was unbecoming, in consequence of this insanity of hers.
tgt_text.5370: Let him deny that she did,.
tgt_text.5371: in the most intelligent manner, audit and sign the accounts of the bailiffs, and the shep­ herds, and the grooms ;
tgt_text.5372: let him deny that his brother Ponti­ anus was seriously warned by her to be on his guard against the insidious designs of Rufinus;
tgt_text.5373: let him deny that he was justly censured for having everywhere carried about the letter which she had written to him, and yet not having read it faithfully;
tgt_text.5374: let him deny that, after all this, his mother was married to me at her country-house, the place previously agreed on between us.
tgt_text.5375: For we had thought it better for us to be united at her country-house in the suburbs, in order that the people of the city might not again flock to us for largesses;
tgt_text.5376: as it was not very long since Pudentilla had expended fifty thousand pieces of money, her own property, upon the public, on the day on which Pontianus was married, and this boy was invested with the manly gown.
tgt_text.5377: Another reason, was our wish to escape nume­ rous invitations and annoyances which newly-married people generally have to submit to.
tgt_text.5379: Here, JEmilianus, you have the entire cause why the marriage contract between me and Puden­ tilla was signed, not in town, but at the country-house, that she might not have again to expend fifty thousand pieces of money, and that we might not be obliged to feast in your com­ pany, or at your house.
tgt_text.5380: Was not the cause, then, a reasonable one ?
tgt_text.5382: prised that you, who generally live in the country, have such a remarkable aversion to a country-house.
tgt_text.5383: The Julian law, at all events, in its ordinances for the regulation of marriages, no­ where contains any prohibition to this effect—"
tgt_text.5384: Marry not a wife at a country-house."
tgt_text.5385: Nay, to say the truth, a wife is married under much better auspices, so far as relates to pro­ geny, at a country-house, than in a town-upon a fruitful soil, than in a sterile spot--upon the glebe of the field, than upon the stones of the Forum.
tgt_text.5386: She who is destined to be a mother, ought to enter upon the marriage state in the very bosom of her mother, among the ripening ears of corn, and upon the fertile sod;
tgt_text.5387: or else she should recline beneath the wedded elm, on the lap of her mother earth, amid the offspring of the grass, the progeny of the vines, and the offshoots of the trees.
tgt_text.5388: Closely in accordance with this is that line,* so frequently quoted in the comic writers- " Children in fields are lawfully begot.
tgt_text.5389: "To the Romans of ancient times, the Quintii, † the Serrani, and many others like them, not only wives, but consulships even, and dictatorships, were presented in the country.
tgt_text.5390: I will check, myself, however, in a field of such ample range, that I may not gratify you [a rustic] by lavishing praises upon a country-house.
tgt_text.5391: And now, as to the age of Pudentilla, about which, after these other matters, you uttered falsehoods with such great assurance, as even to assert that she was sixty years of age when she mar­ ried, I will say a few words;
tgt_text.5392: for, on a matter so self evident, it is not necessary to descant at any great length.
tgt_text.5393: Her father, at her birth, made the usual declaration, that she was his daughter.
tgt_text.5394: Her register is preserved, one part in the public registry, the counterpart at home, and the latter is now presented before your face.
tgt_text.5396: Let him see the fastenings, J examine the impression of the seal, read the names of the consuls, and count the years.
tgt_text.5397: Of the sixty years that he gave to this lady, let him prove as much as five and fifty.
tgt_text.5398: By a whole lustrum* has he deviated from the truth.
tgt_text.5400: I will deal with him still more libe­ rally.
tgt_text.5401: For he has made a present of a great number of years to Pudentilla;
tgt_text.5402: I shall, therefore, have to give them back to him by way of return.
tgt_text.5403: Like Ulysses, Mezentius † has gone astray ten whole years;
tgt_text.5404: let him prove, at least, that this lady is fifty years of age.
tgt_text.5406: To deal with him as I would with a four-fold informer, J I will double the five years twice over, and at once strike off twenty.
tgt_text.5407: Order the consuls to be reckoned, Maximus:
tgt_text.5408: if I am not mis­ taken, you will find that Pudentilla is not now much beyond her fortieth year.
tgt_text.5409: Oh, audacious and outrageous lie, that ought to be visited with an exile of twenty years!
tgt_text.5410: Do you dare, Æmilianus, to amplify your lies, by thus adding to them one half as much again ?
tgt_text.5411: If it had been thirty years§ that you stated instead of ten, you might possibly have appeared to have made a mistake in the position of your fingers in count­ ing, and, where you ought to have contracted the fingers in a circle,|| to have opened them too wide. ¶
tgt_text.5412: But when the num­ ber forty, which is denoted more easily than any of the others, by opening out the palm of the hand, when this number forty you increase by half as much again, you can have made no such mistake in the position of your fingers;
tgt_text.5413: unless, perhaps, you took the years of Pudentilla to be thirty, and accidentally added together the two consuls for each year.
tgt_text.5414: All these matters I pass by:
tgt_text.5415: I now come to the very root of this accusation, to the very cause of the alleged magic.
tgt_text.5417: Emilianus and Rufinus make answer for what profit, even if I had been the greatest of magicians, I should by charms and ' by drugs have enticed Pudentilla to marry me.
tgt_text.5418: And yet I am Well aware, that many a person has been accused of a crime where certain motives for the commission of it could be proved to exist, and still, has most successfully defended himself by shewing that his whole course of life has been utterly averse to misdeeds of such a nature;
tgt_text.5419: and that it ought not to prove to his detriment if there seemed to exist some inducements for the perpetration of the crime.
tgt_text.5420: For not every thing which possibly may have happened, ought to be considered'as really having happened.
tgt_text.5421: There are various fluctuations in human affairs ;
tgt_text.5422: but the disposition of each person affords a sure evi­ dence, for, as it is always affected with the same tendency to­ wards virtue or towards vice, it affords an unerring proof of the readiness to embrace criminality or to reject it.
tgt_text.5423: Although I might, with the greatest justice, make use of these arguments, still, I spare you them;
tgt_text.5424: nor do I deem it enough to have abundantly proved my innocence on all the points on which you accuse me, and to have never allowed the slightest suspicion even of the practice of magic to attach to me.
tgt_text.5425: Only consider what a degree of confidence in my own innocence I display, and what supreme contempt of you [my accusers], when I say that if even the slightest ground shall appear why I should have coveted this match with Pudentilla for the sake of any advantage to myself, if you shall prove the most trifling gain to me thereby, then may I be held to be a Phrynondas, a Damigeron,* a Moses, a Jannes, an Apollonius, or even Dardanus himself, or any one else, who, since the days of Zoroaster and Ostanes, has been celebrated among magicians.
tgt_text.5426: Do see, Maximus, I beg of you, what an uproar they raise, merely because I have enumerated a few of the magicians by name.
tgt_text.5427: What am I to do with men so ignorant, so barbar­ ous ?
tgt_text.5428: Am I to tell them over again, that these and very many other names I have read in public libraries, in the works of authors of the highest reputation ?
tgt_text.5429: Or am I to discuss the point, that it is one thing to be acquainted with their names, but quite another to have been initiated into the art itself, and that the appliances of learning, and the recollections of erudi­ tion, are not to be held to be a confession of criminality ?
tgt_text.5430: Or shall I do better, and rely, Claudius Maximus, on your learn­ ing, and extensive information, and not think it worth my while to make answer on these matters to foolish and illiterate men ?
tgt_text.5432: What they may think of it, I care not a nutshell.
tgt_text.5433: I will proceed to prove what I stated:
tgt_text.5434: that I had no reason whatever for using incantations to induce Pudentilla to form an alliance with me.
tgt_text.5435: They took it upon themselves to disparage the looks and the age of this lady, and then they imputed it to me as a crime, that I desired to gain such a wife, in order to satisfy my avarice, and that for that reason, at the very earliest moment after our union, I wrested from her a large and ample fortune.
tgt_text.5436: It is not my intention to fatigue you, Maximus, by a lengthened speech in reply to this.
tgt_text.5437: There is no need of words, when the documents themselves speak so much more eloquently;
tgt_text.5438: docu­ ments by which you will find that I have acted throughout, both as regarded present arrangements, and provisions for the future, in a manner quite at variance with what they sur­ mised of me, in conformity with their own rapacious dispo­ sitions.
tgt_text.5439: In the first place, then, the amount put in settle- . ment by this lady of such vast wealth, you will find to have been but small, and that amount not a sum paid down, but only secured in remainder.
tgt_text.5440: Besides this, you will find that the union took place upon these terms;
tgt_text.5441: in case ahe should depart this life without issue by me, the entire sum so settled was to go to her sons, Pontianus and Pudens;
tgt_text.5442: but, if she should die, leaving one such son or one daughter surviving her, then, in such case, one half of the sum was to go to the last born son, and the residue to the older ones.
tgt_text.5443: This, I say, I will prove, from the instrument itself.
tgt_text.5444: It may possibly happen, that not even then, .,Emilianus will believe that only three hundred thousand pieces of money were so settled, and that by arrangement they were to go in reversion to the sons of Pu­ dentilla.
tgt_text.5445: Take this document in your own hands, [Æmilianus], and give it to your prompter, Rufinus, for him to read.
tgt_text.5446: Let him be ashamed of his swelling aspirations, and his ambitious mendicity;
tgt_text.5447: for he himself, though in utter want, and stripped naked, gave, as a marriage portion to his daughter, four hun­ dred thousand pieces of money taken from a creditor;
tgt_text.5448: Pu­ dentilla, on the other hand, a wealthy woman, has contented herself with a settlement of three hundred thousand pieces, and has a husband, too, who, after having many a time re­ jected settlements of ample sums, rests contented with the empty name of such a trifling sum as this, for he reckons all other things, except his wife, as nothing at all, and centres all his possessions and all his wealth in the concord of the marriage state, and in mutual attachment.
tgt_text.5449: And yet, who, of all men that had the slightest knowledge even of the world, would have presumed to censure her, if a woman, who was a widow and of average good looks, but be­ yond mid age, being desirous to marry, had by offering an ample settlement and handsome terms, held out a temptation to a young man who was by no means to be despised either for his looks, his intellect, or his fortune ?
tgt_text.5450: A beauteous virgin, even though she may chance to be utterly destitute, is still provided with an ample marriage portion ;
tgt_text.5451: for she brings to her new husband the winning nature of her disposition, the charms of her beauty, the first fruits of her maidenhood.
tgt_text.5452: The very recommendation itself of virginity is rightly and de­ servedly most highly esteemed by all husbands.
tgt_text.5453: For whatever else you gain by way of portion, you may, whenever you please, return the whole of it, so as to remain under no obli­ gation whatever.
tgt_text.5454: Money you may repay in full, slaves you may restore, a house you may quit, an estate you may leave.
tgt_text.5455: Virginity alone, when once it has been bestowed, can never be returned;
tgt_text.5456: of the things that form a marriage portion, that alone must of necessity remain with the husband.
tgt_text.5457: A widow, on the other hand, on a divorce taking place, de­ parts just as she came on marriage ;
tgt_text.5458: nothing does she bring that she may not reclaim;
tgt_text.5459: but she comes to you deflowered by another;
tgt_text.5460: to say the least, very far from being an apt scholar in carrying out your wishes;
tgt_text.5461: holding her new abode in no less sus­ picion than that in which, by reason of her separation from her former husband, she herself deserves to be held;
tgt_text.5462: whether it is that she has lost that husband by death, in which case, as being a woman of unlucky omen, and unfortunate in wedlock, she ought to be avoided ;
tgt_text.5463: or whether it is, that she has been sepa­ rated from him by divorce, in which latter case a woman must have one or the other of these two faults;
tgt_text.5464: she must have been either so unbearable as to have been repudiated, or else so fro­ ward as to have divorced herself.
tgt_text.5465: For these and other reasons it is, that widows generally invite suitors by more ample set­ tlements ;
tgt_text.5466: a thing that Pudentilla, even, might have done in the case of another husband, if she had not met with a philo­ sopher who held all settlements in contempt.
tgt_text.5467: Well, now, if I had desired to gain this lady in order to satisfy my avarice, what plan would there have been more feasible by which to gain possession of her house, than to sow discord between the mother and her sons ?
tgt_text.5468: to erase from her feelings all affection for her children, in order that I might the more freely and the more certainly, on being left without rivals, gain full possession of the desolate woman ?
tgt_text.5469: Was not this the part of a robber such as you pretend that I am ?
tgt_text.5470: and yet I, the author, promoter, and supporter of peace, and con­ cord, and affection, not only did not sow new dissensions, but even utterly eradicated those which previously existed.
tgt_text.5471: I prompted my wife, the whole of whose property they assert I had already made away with, I prompted her, I say, and at last succeeded in persuading her, on her sons demanding repayment of their money, as I have already mentioned, to repay them without delay, and that in lands valued at a low figure, and at whatever price they themselves pleased.
tgt_text.5472: Besides this, out of her own private-property, I persuaded her to give them some of the most fertile of her farms, a fine house, too, fitted up in a most costly manner, with a great quantity of wheat, barley, wine, oil, and other products of the soil;
tgt_text.5473: slaves, too, no less than four hundred in number, and cattle not a few, and of no small value;
tgt_text.5474: and all this, that she might set them at ease as to that portion of her property which she thus gave them, and encourage them to be of good hopes as to the remainder.
tgt_text.5475: All this I obtained with great difficulty, and by urgent entreaties, from the angry and reluctant Pudentilla—for as such was the fact, she will not obj ect to my saying so.
tgt_text.5476: I reconciled the mother to her sons;
tgt_text.5477: I enriched my step-sons, (who in this first expe­ rienced the benefit of having a step-father,) with a large sum of money.
tgt_text.5478: Throughout the whole city this fact was well known.
tgt_text.5479: All vented execrations against Rufinus, and lavished commend­ ations upon me.
tgt_text.5480: Pontianus came to us, together with this bro­ ther of his, so unlike him in disposition, before his mother would consent to make this gift;
tgt_text.5481: and, throwing himself at our feet, asked us to forget and forgive all that had passed, weeping and kissing our hands, and saying how much he repented that he had listened to Rufinus and those like him.
tgt_text.5482: After that, he suppliantly entreated me to excuse him to Lollianus Avitus,* that most illustrious man, to whom, shortly before, he had been recommended by me at the outset of his professional career;
tgt_text.5483: t for he had become aware that a few days previously I had written and informed A vitus of every thing that had taken place.
tgt_text.5484: This, too, he prevailed upon me to do.
tgt_text.5485: Accordingly, furnished with a letter by me, he set out for Carthage, where, Maximus, the period of his proconsulship being now nearly expired, Lollianus A vitus was awaiting your arrival.
tgt_text.5486: After reading my letter, in conformity with his usual extreme kindness of disposition, he commended Pontianus for having so readily made amends for his error, and wrote back to me, by him, good Gods!
tgt_text.5488: what a style, what wit, what grace and sweetness of expression!
tgt_text.5489: He wrote, in fact, just as a good man, and one skilled in the arts of elo­ quence, ought to write.
tgt_text.5490: I am sure, Maximus, that you will hear his letter with pleasure;
tgt_text.5491: and if I do read it, it shall be with my own lips.
tgt_text.5492: Hand me the letter of A vitus, that so, what has ever been an ornament to me, may now prove my safety too.
tgt_text.5493: You, in the meantime, may suffer the water [of the Clepsydra] to run on;
tgt_text.5494: for were I to read over the letter of that most excellent man three or four times, I would not think it lost time.
tgt_text.5495: [He reads the letter of Lollianus Avitus, which is now lost.
tgt_text.5496: ]I am not unaware that I ought, after that letter of A vitus, to come to a close.
tgt_text.5497: For whom can I produce to speak more abundantly in my commendation ?
tgt_text.5498: what witness to my charac ter more worthy of all confidence ?
tgt_text.5500: Many eloquent men who bore the Roman name have I known and studied during my life, but never did I admire any one so much as him.
tgt_text.5501: There is not an individual at this day, in my opinion, of any name, of any promise in the arts of elo­ quence, but would greatly prefer to be Avitus, if, all envy laid aside, he would think proper to institute a comparison be­ tween Avitus and himself.
tgt_text.5502: For in this one man are united all the various gifts of eloquence, even those that are almost opposite in their nature.
tgt_text.5503: Whatever the speech Avitus may compose, so perfect and finished will it be in all its parts, that in it Cato would not fail to find his own gravity, Lælius his smoothness, Gracchus his vehemence, Caesar his vigorous subtlety, Hortensius his perspicuity, Calms his wit, Sallust his terseness, nor Cicero his richness of expression ;
tgt_text.5504: once, for all, I say, not to review each particular, if you were to hear Avitus, you would wish nothing added, nothing withdrawn, nothing changed.
tgt_text.5505: I see, Maximus, with what pleasure you hear those characteristics described, which you recognize as distinguishing your friend Avitus.
tgt_text.5506: It is your kindness that has induced me to say even this little of him.
tgt_text.5507: But I will not so far indulge your sympathy as to allow myself, nearly exhausted as I now am, and my defence drawing to its close, to begin at this late hour to descant on his exemplary virtues;
tgt_text.5508: but I will, in pre­ ference, reserve these topics for my recruited strength and a leisure opportunity.
tgt_text.5509: For now, to my disgust, my discourse must be turned from the praises of a man of such eminent worth, to these pestilent wretches.
tgt_text.5510: And would you dare then, Æmilianus, to set your­ self in comparison with Avitus ?
tgt_text.5511: Him whom he pronounces to be a good man;
tgt_text.5512: him whose manner of life Avitus so abundantly commends in his letter, will you pursue with your charges of magic and criminality ?
tgt_text.5513: Is it for you to be more annoyed at my thrusting myself into the house of Pudentilla and plunder- , ing her of her property, than was Pontianus, who, even in my absence, made full amends to me before Avitus, for the en­ mity of a few days into which he had been led by your insti­ gation ;
tgt_text.5514: and who expressed his gratitude to me in presence of a man of such eminence ?
tgt_text.5515: Suppose, now, I had stated what took place before Avitus, but had not read his letter, what would you, or what would any one, have found to censure in this matter ?
tgt_text.5516: Pontianus himself declared that it was by my bounty he had received what had been presented to him by his mother;
tgt_text.5517: from his in­ most heart Pontianus congratulated himself that it had fallen to his lot to have me for a step-father, and would that he had returned in safety from Carthage!
tgt_text.5518: or, since it was thus decreed by Fate, would that you, Rufinus, had not obstructed the carrying out of his latest intentions!
tgt_text.5519: What grateful thanks would he have expressed to me, either personally or in his last will!
tgt_text.5520: Still the letters which he sent to me from Carthage, as well as while on the road home-those written while in robust health, the others when reduced by sickness, but both' replete with commendations of me, both filled with expressions of affection—these, Maximus, I beg you will allow, for a mo­ ment, to be read, in order that his brother, my accuser, may know how different in every respect is the career which he is running from that of his brother, a man of most blessed me­ mory.
tgt_text.5522: Did you hear the epithets which your brother, Pontianus, bestowed on me;
tgt_text.5523: how, both repeatedly on other occasions, as also at his latest moments, he called me his parent, his master, his instructor?
tgt_text.5524: I could also produce letters of yours to the like effect, if I thought it worth while to waste a mo­ ment upon them.
tgt_text.5525: I would prefer, rather, that your brother's last will, unfinished as it is, should be produced, in which he makes most affectionate and most honorable mention of me.
tgt_text.5526: That will, however, Rufinus would not allow to be seen, nor even to be completed, through his vexation at losing the pro­ perty ;
tgt_text.5527: a property which he had valued at the large price of the nights of a few months during which he was the father-in-law of Pontianus.
tgt_text.5528: Besides this, he had consulted some Chaldæan astrologers or others, in what way he might dispose of his daughter with profit to himself.
tgt_text.5529: They, as I hear, and I only wish that they had not in this given a true answer, replied that her first husband would die in the course of a few months.
tgt_text.5530: But the rest of their answer, as to his property, they framed, as is generally the case, just in conformity with the wishes of the person who consulted them.
tgt_text.5531: However, the Gods so willed it, that just like some blind beast, he opened wide his jaws, but got nothing at all.
tgt_text.5532: For Pontianus, on detecting her guilt, ,not only did not make the daughter of Rufinus his heir, but did not so much as leave her a decent legacy;
tgt_text.5533: but ordered that, as a mark of disgrace, linen cloth,* of about two hundred denars in value, should be presented to her, in order that it might be understood that he had disinherited her, prompted by a feeling of indignation, and had not omitted her through forgetfulness.
tgt_text.5534: For in this will, as well as in a former one which was read, he made his mother and his brother his heirs;
tgt_text.5535: the latter of whom, though'still a mere boy, as you see, Rufinus is plying with this same daughter of his, as his engine of attack, throw­ ing her in his way, and thrusting upon this wretched youth a woman greatly his senior in age, and but recently the wife of his own brother.
tgt_text.5536: As for him, being captivated and enthralled by the allurements of the harlot of a daughter and the wiles of the pimp of a father, the moment that his brother breathed his last, he left his mother, and betook himself to his uncle, in order that, being at a distance from us, his designs might be the better put into execution.
tgt_text.5537: For Rufinus is a favourite with Æmili­ anus, who wishes him success in his plans.
tgt_text.5539: it is well that you have reminded me ;
tgt_text.5540: † his own expectations, too, this worthy uncle, cherishes and promotes, by adopting this course, as he well knows that he is more likely ‡ to be the legal heir of the boy if he dies intestate, than his appointed heir under a will.
tgt_text.5542: I should have been sorry if that notion had originated with me.
tgt_text.5543: It is not in accordance with my moderation openly to give vent to what are the secret suspi­ cions of all:
tgt_text.5544: it was wrong on your part to suggest it.
tgt_text.5545: At all events, AEmilianus, if you would have the truth, many persons are surprised at this affection of yours for this boy, which has so suddenly sprung up since the death of his brother Pontianus;
tgt_text.5546: whereas, before that, you were so much a stranger to him, that, many a time when you met him, you did not know by face the son of your own brother.
tgt_text.5547: Now, however, you show yourself so considerate of him, so spoil him by indulgence, are so careful not to thwart him in anything, as, by this course, to produce a confirmation of such suspicions.
tgt_text.5548: You received him from us a stripling;
tgt_text.5549: you instantly invested him with the privileges of puberty.
tgt_text.5550: As long as he was under our management, he was in the habit of attending masters ;
tgt_text.5551: now, taking a wide flight from them, he makes for the brothel;
tgt_text.5552: his friends of steady demeanour he shuns, while, at his tender age, this young boy passes his life with young men of the most abandoned character, amid courtesans and cups.
tgt_text.5553: It is he who is the ruler in your house, it is he who is the head of your family, it is he who is the master of your banquets.
tgt_text.5554: At the gladiatorial exhibitions, too, he is a constant attendant, and, like a lad of gentility, he is instructed by his fencing-master in the names of the gladiators, their combats, and their wounds.
tgt_text.5555: He never speaks but in the Punic tongue, or any little smattering of Greek he may still retain, after learning it from his mother.
tgt_text.5556: But in Latin he has neither the will nor the inclination to speak.
tgt_text.5557: You heard, Maximus, a short time ago, my step-son, the brother of Pontianus, a young man who was distinguished for his eloquence-shame and disgrace to him!— stammering out with the greatest difficulty a few syllables, at the time when you enquired of him whether his mother had presented to them the property which I asserted she had at my prompting so presented.
tgt_text.5558: I therefore call you to witness, Claudius Maximus, and you who are sitting here in judgment, and you also who aid me with your presence on this my trial, that these corruptions, and scandals in his life, ought to be attributed to his uncle here, and to this candidate for the honor of being his father-in-law;
tgt_text.5559: and I protest that I shall, from this time forward, congratulate myself that such a step- son as this has shaken off from his neck the yoke of my guardianship, and shall no more think of entreating his mother in his behalf.
tgt_text.5560: For,—I had all but forgotten to mention it-very recently, and since the death of her son Pontianus, Pudentilla, being then in bad health, was making her will, on which I had a struggle with her of considerable duration in order to prevent her from disinheriting him, in return for insults so glaring, for injuries so numerous.
tgt_text.5561: With earnest entreaties I begged her to strike out [of the will] a most severe character of him, the whole of which, I solemnly declare, she had already written.
tgt_text.5562: In fine, I threatened to separate from her, if I did not prevail in my request.
tgt_text.5563: I entreated her to grant me this favour, to conquer her wicked son by kindness, and so release me from all chance of incurring hatred.
tgt_text.5564: Nor did I cease until she had complied with my request.
tgt_text.5565: I am vexed that I have thus removed this ground of anxiety from Æmilianus, that I have pointed out to him a path so entirely unexpected.
tgt_text.5566: Do look, I beg of you, Maximus, how, on hearing this, he has suddenly become quite bewildered, how he has riveted his eyes upon the ground.
tgt_text.5567: For he had fancied, and not without reason, that the fact was far otherwise.
tgt_text.5568: He knew that this lady was offended at the insults offered by her son, and was strongly influenced by my attentions to her.
tgt_text.5569: As regarded me, too, he had good grounds for apprehension.
tgt_text.5570: For any person, even though he had been as much a despiser of wealth as I am, might still not have declined to take his re­ venge on a step-son who had shown himself so undutiful.
tgt_text.5571: It was this anxiety, above all, that urged them to bring this accusa­ tion against me.
tgt_text.5572: Arguing from a knowledge of their own avarice, they have wrongly conjectured that the whole of her property has been left to me.
tgt_text.5573: As regards the past time, I will release you from that fear;
tgt_text.5574: for neither the opportunity of gain­ ing property, nor yet revenge, were able to shake my mind in the position which it had taken.
tgt_text.5575: I, the step-father, struggled with his offended mother in behalf of a wicked step-son, just as though I had been a father striving with a step-mother in favour of his best of sons;
tgt_text.5576: nor was I content unless I checked, far more than I ought to have done, the abundant generosity of an affectionate wife, which was ready to be shown in my own favour.
tgt_text.5577: Hand me the will which has been made by the mother since her son has been at enmity with her, and of which I, whom these people call a robber, prefaced each word with my entreaties.
tgt_text.5578: Order, Maximus, that document to be opened;
tgt_text.5579: you will find her son named as her heir, while to myself, as a mark of regard, there is left some trifling legacy or other;
tgt_text.5580: in order that, if anything should happen to her, I, the husband, might not find my name altogether omitted in the will of my own wife.
tgt_text.5581: Take that will, written by your mother, a will which is truly forgetful of the ties of duty.
tgt_text.5583: In it she has disinherited a most attentive husband, while she has named as her heir a most vindictive son, or rather, I may say, not her son, but the hopes of Æmilianus, and the match de­ signed by Rufinus, as well as that besotted crew, your para­ sites.
tgt_text.5584: Take it, I say, best of sons, and lay aside for a moment the amatory epistles of your mother, and read her will in prefer­ ence.
tgt_text.5585: If she has written anything when labouring under a kind of insanity, as it were, here you will find it, ay, and from the very beginning-" Let SiciniusPudens, my son, be my heir."
tgt_text.5586: He who reads that, I admit, will take her to be insane. "
tgt_text.5587: Is this son [he will say] appointed your heir, who, on the occa­ sion of the very funeral of his brother, having called together a band of most abandoned youths, attempted to exclude you from the house which you yourself had presented to him ?
tgt_text.5588: A youth who was vexed and annoyed that you had been left by his brother joint-heir with himself?
tgt_text.5589: Who, amid your sorrow and mourning, instantly abandoned you, and fled from your bosom to Rufinus and Æmilianus ?
tgt_text.5590: Who afterwards, before your very face, gave utterance to numerous insults, and, with the assistance of his uncle, was guilty of perpetrating others ?
tgt_text.5591: Who bandied your name about before tribunals ?
tgt_text.5592: Who at­ tempted publicly to cast a stain upon your fair name, by pro­ ducing your own letters against you ?
tgt_text.5593: Who brought a capital charge against the husband of whom you had made choice, a husband whom, as he himself objected against you, you loved to distraction?"
tgt_text.5594: Open, worthy youth, open the will, I beg;
tgt_text.5595: by so doing you will the more easily prove your mother's in­ sanity.
tgt_text.5597: Why refuse ?-that, too, after you have had all anxiety removed as to the inheritance of your mother's property.
tgt_text.5598: I will, however, Maximus, place this document here, in this spot, before your feet, and I protest that, from henceforth, I shall take much less interest in what it is Pudentilla inserts in her will.
tgt_text.5599: Let him, from this time forward, entreat his mother, as he pleases;
tgt_text.5601: has left no grounds for supplicating any more in his behalf.
tgt_text.5602: Henceforth let him, as he is his own master, and addresses most virulent letters to his mother, take upon himself to assuage her wrath.
tgt_text.5603: He who could undertake a prosecution, will be able to plead his own cause.
tgt_text.5604: It is quite enough for me, if I have not only most abun­ dantly disproved the crimes laid to my charge, but have even utterly uprooted the grounds for bringing me to trial—I mean the envy on account of the property supposed to have been sought by me.
tgt_text.5605: That I may omit no one of all these things, I will prove, before I come to a conclusion, that this, too, has been falsely laid to my charge.
tgt_text.5606: You have asserted that with a large sum of money belonging to this lady, I have made purchase in my own name of a very fine estate.
tgt_text.5607: I say, in answer, that it was a small property, worth but sixty thousand pieces of money;
tgt_text.5608: and that I was not the purchaser, but Pudentilla, who bought the estate in her own name;
tgt_text.5609: that the name of Pudentilla is in the purchase-deed, and that it is in the name of Pudentilla that the taxes are paid for this farm.
