tgt_text.5610: The public qusestor is here present, to whom they have been paid, Corvinus Celer, a man of the highest character.
tgt_text.5611: There is also here the guardian* and adviser of the lady, a man of the greatest respectability and of the most unblemished name, one who deserves to be mentioned by me with all honor and re­ spect, Cassius Longinus, I mean.
tgt_text.5612: Ask him, Maximus, as in making this purchase he acted as her adviser, at what a trifling price it was that a lady so wealthy purchased this farm of hers.
tgt_text.5613: [ Cassius Longinus and Corvinus Celer being questioned, gave their evidence.]
tgt_text.5614: Is it not as I said ?
tgt_text.5615: Does my name anywhere ap­ pear in this purchase ?
tgt_text.5616: Is the price paid for this little property any ground for complaint ?
tgt_text.5617: Or, at all events, has it been trans­ ferred to me ?
tgt_text.5618: What is there still remaining, Æmilianus, that I have not, in your judgment, refuted?
tgt_text.5619: What reward of my magical practices have you discovered ?
tgt_text.5620: Why should I work upon the feelings of Pudentilla by incantations?
tgt_text.5621: To gain what ad­ vantages from her?
tgt_text.5622: Was it that she might make a trifling settlement upon me in preference to a large one ?
tgt_text.5624: Or was it that she might enter into a new engagement, and settle her fortune in reversion upon her sons, rather than leave it to me?
tgt_text.5625: What else is there that can possibly be added to such a magic as this ?
tgt_text.5626: Is it the fact that, at my entreaty, she presented the greater por­ tion of her property to her sons, when, before she was married to me, she had given them nothing at all-this, too, while she bestowed nothing whatever upon myself?
tgt_text.5627: Oh atrocious crime, shall I say, or rather, oh kindness ill repaid ?
tgt_text.5628: Or is it rather the fact that, in the will which she made when angered against her son, she left that very son with whom she was offended her heir, rather than myself, to whom she was so much at­ tached ?
tgt_text.5629: This I certainly did, after employing many spells,* with the greatest difficulty obtain.
tgt_text.5630: Suppose, now, that this cause is being tried, not before Clau­ dius Maximus, a man of equity and scrupulous justice, but substitute some other judge, a dishonest and cruel man, one who is an encourager of accusations, and anxious to condemn;
tgt_text.5631: give him some point upon which to fasten, supply him with ever so slight a ground, wearing the semblance of probability, on which he may be enabled to pronounce in your favour.
tgt_text.5632: At least, invent, devise something to say by way of answer, when he invites you so to do.
tgt_text.5633: And, as it is a matter of necessity that some cause or other should precede every effect, state, you who say that Apuleius influenced the mind of Pudentilla by magic spells, what it was he wanted of her, and why he did so.
tgt_text.5634: Was it her beauty he was anxious to gain ?
tgt_text.5636: At all events, was it her riches that he coveted ?
tgt_text.5637: The marriage-contract, the deed of gift, the will, say "no" to that, in all of which he is shown not only not to have grasped at with greediness, but even to have harshly repulsed, the libe­ rality of his wife.
tgt_text.5638: What other ground then is there ?
tgt_text.5641: Where is that fierce commencement of your charge, drawn up in the name of my step-son ? "
tgt_text.5642: Him, my lord Maximus, I have determined to accuse before you."—
tgt_text.5643: Why did you not add, then, " to accuse my instructor, to ac­ cuse my step-father, to accuse my mediator?"
tgt_text.5644: But what comes next ?-" of numerous offences, and those most evi­ dent."
tgt_text.5645: Of these so "numerous," produce but a single one;
tgt_text.5646: of these offences " most evident," produce but one which is even so much as dubious, one which can even sustain a mo­ ment's question.
tgt_text.5647: To each of your innumerable charges I answer in a couple of words.* " You clean your teeth"—Pardon my cleanliness.
tgt_text.5648: 11 You look in a mirror"—A philosopher ought. " You com­ pose verses"—'Tis not unlawful to do so. " You examine fishes"—Aristotle teaches me. " You make Gods of wood"- Plato advises it.
tgt_text.5649: "You marry a wife"—The laws enjoin it. " She is older than you"—No uncommon thing. "
tgt_text.5650: You have sought to advantage yourself "-Take up the deed of settle­ ment, recollect the gifts you have received, read over her will.
tgt_text.5651: If I have abundantly rebutted all these charges;
tgt_text.5652: if I have refuted all these calumnies ;
tgt_text.5653: if, amid not only all the accusa­ tions, but even all the aspersions uttered against me by these persons, I have kept philosophy aloof from censure;
tgt_text.5654: if I have in no way blemished the honour of philosophy, which is dearer to me than my own well-being, nay, rather, if I have kept it most carefully shielded on every side;
tgt_text.5655: if, in each of these respects, what I say is found to be the truth, then I may more securely afford to respect your good opinion than to dread your power;
tgt_text.5656: seeing, I deem it less grievous and less to be dreaded by me, to be condemned by a proconsul, than to incur the censure of a man so good and so virtuous as yourself.
tgt_text.5657: END OF THE DEFENCE OF APULEIUS.
tgt_text.5658: PLATO has made a triple division of all nature, and especially of that part of it which comprises animated beings;
tgt_text.5659: and he is of opinion, that there are Gods of the highest, the middle, and the lowest station.
tgt_text.5660: Understand, however, that this di­ vision is based not only upon local separation, but also upon comparative dignity of nature, which is itself distinguished not in one or two, but in many modes.
tgt_text.5661: It was the clearer way, however, to begin with the distinction of locality;
tgt_text.5662: * for this has assigned the heavens to the immortal Gods, conformably to what their majesty demands.
tgt_text.5663: And of these celestial Gods, some we form a notion of by sight, while others we endeavour to comprehend by the intellect.
tgt_text.5665: refulgent ministers of light, Who through the heavens conduct the gliding year.t
tgt_text.5666: We do not, however, perceive by the eyes, those principal Gods only, the Sun the maker of the day, the Moon the rival of the Sun, and the glory of night;
tgt_text.5667: whether she is horned or divided,t whether gibbous or full;
tgt_text.5668: exhibiting a varying bright­ ness in her light;
tgt_text.5669: being more largely illuminated the farther she departs from the Sun;
tgt_text.5670: and, by an equal increase both of her path and her light, defining the month by means of her increments, and afterwards by means of her decrements in like degree:
tgt_text.5671: whether it is, as the Chaldeans think, that she pos­ sesses a proper or§ permanent light of her own, and is on one side gifted with light, but destitute of brightness on the other, and so changes her appearance by manifold revolutions of her various coloured face;
tgt_text.5672: or whether it is that being wholly void of brightness of her own, and standing in need of foreign light, with an opaque body, or with a body polished like a mirror, she receives either obliquely or direct the rays of the Sun, and, to use the words of Lucretius, Book IV.— " Throwsfrom her orb a spurious light."
tgt_text.5673: Whichever of these opinions is true, (for that I shall afterwards consider,) there is not any Greek, or any barbarian, who will not easily conclude that the Sun and Moon are Gods;
tgt_text.5674: and not these only, as I have observed, but also the five stars, which are commonly styled " erratic," or "planets," by the unlearned, though, in their undeviating, certain, and established course, they perform, by their divine changes, movements most orderly and eternal;
tgt_text.5675: movements which are indeed various in appear­ ance, but which are made with a celerity that is always equable, and represent with wonderful alternation, at one time pro­ gressions, and at another retrogressions, according to the posi­ tion, elliptic] ty, and inclination of their orbits, with which he is well acquainted who understands the risings and settings of the stars.
tgt_text.5676: You who are of the same opinion with Plato, must also rank in the same number of visible Gods those other stars, The rainy Hyades, Arcturus, both the Bears:
tgt_text.5677: * and likewise the other radiant Gods, by whom we perceive, in a serene sky, the celestial choir bedecked and crowned, when the nights are painted with a severe grace and a stern beauty;
tgt_text.5678: beholding, as Ennius says, in this most "perfect shield of the universe," engravings wrought with surprising brilliancy.
tgt_text.5679: There is another species of Gods, which nature has denied to our sight;
tgt_text.5680: and still we may contemplate them with admira­ tion through intellect, acutely surveying them with the eye of the mind.
tgt_text.5681: In the number of these are those twelve Gods † who are included by Ennius, with a metrical arrangement of their names, in two verses:
tgt_text.5682: Juno, Vesta, Minerva, Ceres, Diana, Venus, Mars, Mercurius, Jovi, ‡ Neptunus, Vulcanus, Apollo;
tgt_text.5683: and others of the like kind, whose names, indeed, have been long known to our ears, but whose powers are conjectured by our minds, our attention being called to them through the various benefits which they impart to us in the affairs of life in those things over which they severally preside.
tgt_text.5684: The crowd, however, of the ignorant, who are rejected by Philosophy as uninitiated, whose notions of holiness are misplaced, who are deprived of genuine reason, who are destitute of religion;
tgt_text.5685: and incapable of grasping the truth, dishonour the Gods, either by a worship most over acted, or a most insolent disdain of them;
tgt_text.5686: one part being always in alarm through superstition, while the other is always swelling with contempt.
tgt_text.5687: Very many there are who venerate all these Gods, established in the lofty heights of the firmament, and far removed from human contagion :
tgt_text.5688: but not in such manner as they ought:
tgt_text.5689: all fear them, but through ignorance;
tgt_text.5690: a few deny their existence, but in a spirit of im­ piety.
tgt_text.5691: Plato thought these Gods to be incorporeal* and ani­ mated natures without an end.
tgt_text.5692: or beginning, but eternal both with reference to time past and time to come;
tgt_text.5693: spontaneously separated from the contact of the body by the nature peculiar to themselves;
tgt_text.5694: through perfection of intellect possessing su­ preme beatitude;
tgt_text.5695: good, not through participation in any ex­ traneous good, but of themselves;
tgt_text.5696: and able to procure for themselves every thing requisite, with a facilitywhich is prompt, simple, unrestrained, and absolute.
tgt_text.5697: But of the parent of these, who is the lord and author of all things, and who is free from all obligations to act or to suffer, not being bound by any necessity to the performance of any duties, why should I now begin to speak ?
tgt_text.5698: For Plato, who was endowed with a heavenly eloquence, discoursing in lan­ guage worthy of the immortal Gods, frequently proclaims that on account of the incredible and ineffable transcendency of his majesty, he cannot possibly be even in the slightest degree com­ prehended, under any definition, through the poverty of human language;
tgt_text.5699: and that the intellectual apprehension of this God can hardly flash upon wise men, when they have separated them- selves from body, as much as possible, through the vigour of the intellect;
tgt_text.5700: and that sometimes this knowledge does blaze forth with a most instantaneous flash, like a dazzling light amid the most profound darkness.*
tgt_text.5701: I will therefore omit the discussion of this theme, for which all words adequate to the amplitude of the subject are not only wanting to me, but could not even be found by my master Plato.
tgt_text.5702: Hence I shall at once sound a retreat, as to things which very far surpass my humble powers, and at length bring down my discourse from heaven to earth, in which we men are the principal animated things, though most of us, through the neglect of training, are so depraved, and are so imbued with all errors and the most atrocious crimes, and have become so utterly ferocious, through having nearly quite abandoned the mildness of our nature, that it may seem there is not an animal on the earth more vile than man.
tgt_text.5703: But at present our object is not to discuss feelings, but to treat of the natural distribution of things.
tgt_text.5704: Men, therefore, dwell on the earth, possessing the gift of speech, having immortal souls, but mortal members, with fri­ volous and anxious minds, with bodies brutish and infirm, of dissimilar manners, but similar errors, of presumptuous auda­ city, long-lived hope, labouring in vain, with variable for­ tunes, severally mortal, but taken altogether in their whole species, eternal, quitting the scene in regular succession, and leaving offspring to supply their place, fleeting in their time, tardy at gaining wisdom, speedy in meeting with death, and dis­ satisfied in life.
tgt_text.5705: You have, then, in the meantime, two kinds of animated beings, Gods entirely differing from men, in the sublimity of their abode, in the eternity of their existence, in the perfection of their nature, and having no proximate com­ munication with them;
tgt_text.5706: † since those that are supreme are separated from the lowest habitations by such a vast interval of distance;
tgt_text.5707: and life is there eternal and never-failing, but here decaying and interrupted, and the natures are there subli­ mated to beatitude, while those below are depressed to wretch­ edness.
tgt_text.5709: Has r ature connected itself by no bond, but allowed itself to be separated into the divine and human parts, and to be thus split and crippled, as it were ?
tgt_text.5710: For, as the same Plato remarks, "No God mingles with men."
tgt_text.5711: But this is the principal mark of their sublime nature, that they are not contaminated by any contact with us.*
tgt_text.5712: One part of them only is to be seen by us with our blunted vision;
tgt_text.5713: as the stars, about whose magnitude and colour men are still in doubt, while the rest are only known to our understandings, and that by no prompt perception.
tgt_text.5714: This, however, ought by no means to be wondered at with reference to the immortal Gods, since even among men, who are raised to opulence by the favour ot Fortune, and are elevated to the tottering throne and the un­ steady tribunal of a kingdom, access is rare, all beholders being kept at a distance, and they enjoy their dignity in re­ tirement;
tgt_text.5715: familiarity breeds contempt, t but privacy gains admiration."
tgt_text.5716: What, then, shall I do," some person may object, "after this very celestial, but almost inhuman decision of yours?
tgt_text.5717: if, so it is, that men are entirely removed from the immortal Gods, and are so exiled in these Tartarean realms of earth that all communica­ tion whatever with the heavenly Gods is denied them, and not one of the celestials occasionally visits them, as a shepherd visits his flocks of sheep, a groom his horses, or a herdsman his lowing cattle, in order that he may curb the more vicious, heal the diseased, and assist those which are in want ?
tgt_text.5718: No God, you say, interferes in human affairs.
tgt_text.5719: To whom, then, shall I ad­ dress my prayers ?
tgt_text.5720: To whom shall I make my vows ?
tgt_text.5722: Whom shall I invoke through­ out my whole life, as the helper of the unfortunate, the fa- vourer of the good, and the adversary of the wicked ?
tgt_text.5723: And whom, in fine, (a thing for which necessity most frequently occurs,) shall I adduce as a witness to my oath ?
tgt_text.5724: Am I to say, like Virgil's Ascanius,* " Now by this head I swear, by which before My father used to swear ?"
tgt_text.5725: Why, no doubt, Iulus, your father might use this oath among Trojans, who were allied to him by birth, and also perhaps among Greeks, who were known to him in battle;
tgt_text.5726: but among the Rutuli, who were but recently known by you, if no one believed in this head, what God would you have to be surety for you ?
tgt_text.5727: Would you have your right hand and your dart, like the ferocious Mezentius ?
tgt_text.5728: For these only, by which he defended himself, did he adjure:
tgt_text.5729: " For me ray right hand and the missile dart, Which now well-poised I hurl, are each a God."t
tgt_text.5730: Away, I beseech you, with such sanguinary Gods;
tgt_text.5731: a right hand weary with slaughter, and a dart rusted with gore.
tgt_text.5732: Neither of these is a fit object for you to adjure, nor that you should swear by them, for this is an honor that is peculiar to the highest of the Gods.
tgt_text.5733: For a solemn oath, as Ennius says, is also called Jovisjurandum.
tgt_text.5735: Am I to swear by Jupiter, in the shape of a stone, after the most ancient custom of the Romans ?
tgt_text.5736: Why, if the opinion of Plato is true, that God never mingles with men, a stone will hear me more easily than Jupiter.
tgt_text.5738: for Plato shall answer for his opinion in my words. "
tgt_text.5739: I do not affirm, " says he, " that the Gods are so far separated and alienated from us, that not even our prayers can reach them;
tgt_text.5740: for I have not removed them from attention to the affairs of mankind, but only from contact with them.
tgt_text.5741: "Besides, there are certain divine powers of a middle nature, situate in this interval of the air, between the highest ether and the earth below, through whom our aspirations and our deserts are conveyed to the Gods.
tgt_text.5742: These the Greeks call by name 11 dæmons," and, being placed as messengers between the inhabitants of earth and those of heaven, they carry from tho one to the other, prayers and bounties, supplications and as­ sistance, being a kind of interpreters and message carriers for both.
tgt_text.5743: Through these same demons, as Plato says in his Sym­ posium, all revelations, the various miracles of magicians, and all kinds of presages, are carried on.
tgt_text.5744: For specially appointed individuals of this number, administer everything according to the province assigned to each;
tgt_text.5745: either by framing dreams, or caus­ ing ominous fissures in entrails, or governing the flights of some birds, or instructing others in song, or inspiring prophets, or by launching thunders, or causing the lightning to flash in the clouds, or other things to take place means of which we obtain a know­ ledge of future events.
tgt_text.5746: And we have reason to believe that all these particulars are by the will, the power, and the authority of the celestial Gods, but through the obedience, aid, and ser­ vices of demons;
tgt_text.5747: for it was through the employment, the ser­ vices, and the care of these, that dreams forewarned Hannibal of the loss of one of his eyes;
tgt_text.5748: that inspection of the entrails foretold to Flaminius a perilous carnage;
tgt_text.5749: and that auguries assured to Attius Navius the miracle of the whetstone.
tgt_text.5750: Just in the same manner, tokens of future empire are imparted be­ forehand to certain persons;
tgt_text.5751: as, for instance, an eagle hovered over the cap on the head of Tarquinius Priscus, and a-flame shone from the head of Servius Tullius.
tgt_text.5752: And lastly, to these are owing all the presages of diviners, the expiatory sacrifices of the Etrurians, the sacrificial enclosure of places struck by light­ ning, and the verses of the Sibyls;
tgt_text.5753: all which, as I have said, are effected by certain influences that carry on the communica­ tion between men and Gods.
tgt_text.5754: Nor, indeed, would it be conformable to the majesty of the celestial Gods, that any one of them should either frame a dream for Hannibal, or withdraw the victim from Flaminius, or direct the flight of the bird for Attius Navius, or form in verse the predictions of the Sibyl, or be willing to snatch the hat from the head of Tarquin, and restore it, or place a splendid flame upon the head of Servius, but so as not to burn him.
tgt_text.5755: It is not becoming that the Gods of heaven should condescend to things of this nature.
tgt_text.5756: This is the pro­ vince of the intermediate Gods, who dwell in the regions of the air, which are adjacent to the earth, and on the confines of the heavens, just as in each part of the world there are animals peculiarly adapted to it, those which fly living in the air, and those which walk, on the earth.
tgt_text.5757: For since there are four ele­ ments universally known, nature being as it were divided into four grand portions, and there are animals peculiar to earth, water, and flame;
tgt_text.5758: (for Aristotle informs us that certain animals pecu­ liar thereto, and furnished with wings, fly about in burning furnaces, and pass the whole period of their existence in fire,* come to life therein, and with it die), and besides this, since, as we have already observed, so many stars are beheld floating above in æther, that is to say, in the very brightest heat of fire,†—since this is the case, why should nature suffer this fourth element, the air, which is so widely extended, to be the only one void of every thing, and destitute of its own inhabitants ?
tgt_text.5759: Why should not animated beings be generated in this air in the same manner as animals that exist in flame are generated in fire, animals that float, in water, and those of an earthly nature, on earth ?
tgt_text.5760: For you have every reason to pronounce his opinion false who assigns the birds to the air;
tgt_text.5761: for not one of them raises itself above the summit of Mount Olympus, which, though it is said to be the highest of all mountains, yet if you measure its height in a straight line, the distance to its summit is not equal, according to the opinions of geometricians, to ten stadia;
tgt_text.5762: whereas the immense mass of air extends as far as the nearest portion of the cycle of the moon, beyond which æther takes its rise in an upward direction.
tgt_text.5763: What, then, are we to say of such a vast body of air, which ranges in extent from the nearest part of the revo­ lutions of the moon as far as the highest summit of Mount Olympus ?
tgt_text.5764: Will that, pray, be destitute of its own appropriate animated beings, and will this part of nature be without life, and impotent?
tgt_text.5765: Moreover, if you attentively consider the matter, birds themselves may, with greater propriety, be said to be terrestrial than aerial animals;
tgt_text.5766: for their whole living is always on the earth;
tgt_text.5767: there they procure food, and there they rest;
tgt_text.5768: and they only make a passage through that part of the air in flying which lies nearest to the earth.
tgt_text.5769: But, when they are wearied by the rowing motion of their wings, the earth is to them as a harbour.
tgt_text.5770: If, therefore, reason evidently requires that its appropriate animals must also be admitted to exist in the air, it remains for us to consider what they arc, and what is their nature.
tgt_text.5771: They are then by no means animals of an earthly nature, for such have a downward tendency, through their gravity.
tgt_text.5772: But neither are they of a fiery nature, lest they should be carried aloft by their heat.
tgt_text.5773: A certain middle nature, there­ fore, must be conceived by us, in conformity to the middle position of their locality, that so the nature of the inhabitants may be conformable to the nature of the region.
tgt_text.5774: Well, then, let us form in our mind and generate in our ideas bodies so constituted as neither to be so sluggish as terrestrial, nor so light as ethereal, but in a certain measure distinct from both, or else composed of a mixture of both, either removed from, or modified by, a participation of both.
tgt_text.5775: They will, however, be more easily conceived, if admitted to be a mixture of both, than if they assumed to be mingled with neither.
tgt_text.5776: The bodies of these demons, therefore, must have some little weight, in order that they may not be carried aloft;
tgt_text.5777: and they must also have some lightness, in order that they may not be precipitated to the realms below.
tgt_text.5778: However, that I may not appear to you to be devising things that are incredible, after the manner of the poets, I will just give you an example of this equipoised middle nature.
tgt_text.5779: We see the clouds unite in a way not much different from this tenuity of body;
tgt_text.5780: but if these were equally light as those bodies which are entirely devoid of weight, they would never cap the heights of a lofty mountain with, as it were, certain wreathed chains, depressed beneath its ridges, as we frequently perceive they do.
tgt_text.5781: On the other hand, if they were naturally so dense and so ponderous that no union with a more active levity could elevate them, they would certainly strike against the earth, of their own tendency, just like a mass of lead and stone.
tgt_text.5782: As it is, however, being pendulous and moveable, they are guided in this direction and in that by the winds amid the sea of air, in the same manner as ships, shift- in- sometimes in proximity and remoteness;
tgt_text.5783: for, if they are teeming with the moisture of water, they are depressed downward, as though for the purpose of bringing forth.
tgt_text.5784: And on this account it is that clouds that are more moist descend lower, in dusky masses, and with a slower motion, while those that are serene ascend higher, and are impelled like fleeces of wool, in white masses, and with a more rapid flight.
tgt_text.5785: Have you not heard how Lucretius most eloquently expresses himself concerning thunder in his Sixth Book ? "
tgt_text.5786: The azure heavens with dreadful thunders shake.
tgt_text.5787: Because th' ethereal clouds, ascending high, Dash on each other, driven by adverse winds."
tgt_text.5788: But if the clouds fly aloft, all of which originate from the earth, and again flow downward to it, pray what should you conclude as to the bodies of demons, which are so much more attenuated in their composition ?
tgt_text.5789: For they are not heaped up from feculent vapours and dense mists, as is the nature of clouds, but they are formed of the most pure liquid and serene element of air, and on this account they are not visible on every occasion to the human eye, but only when by divine command they allow themselves to be seen.
tgt_text.5790: For in them no earthly density occupies the place of light, so as to encounter our perception, and necessarily to arrest our visual ray by that solidity;
tgt_text.5791: but the lineaments of the bodies which they have are rare, shining, and attenuated, to such a degree, that they allow all the rays of our vision to pass through them in consequence of their rarity, refract them by their bright­ ness, and baffle them by their subtlety.
tgt_text.5792: Hence that de­ scription of Minerva, in Homer, presenting herself in the midst of the assembly of the Greeks, for the purpose of check­ ing the wrath of Achilles.
tgt_text.5793: If you will wait a moment I will give you the Geeek line in Latin, and here it is on the spur of the moment.
tgt_text.5794: Minerva, then, as I said, by the command of Juno came, in order to moderate the wrath of Achilles, " Seen by him only, by the rest unseen." * Hence, also, Virgil's Juturna, when in the midst of many thou­ sands of men, for the purpose of aiding her brother, " With soldiers mingled, though by none perceived," t fully accomplishing that which the captain in Plautus boasted of having effected by his shield, " Which dazzled by its light the vision of his foes."
tgt_text.5795: And not to discuss prolixly the rest of the instances, the poets, from this multitude of demons, are accustomed, in a way by no means remote from the truth, to feign the Gods to be haters and lovers of certain men, and to give prosperity and promotion to some, and to oppose and afflict others.
tgt_text.5796: Hence, they are in­ fluenced by pity, moved by indignation, racked with vexation, elated with joy, and are subject to all the affections of the human mind;
tgt_text.5797: and are agitated by all the fluctuations of human thought, with similar commotions of the spirit and agitations of the feelings.*
tgt_text.5798: All which storms and tempests are far alien from the tranquil state of the celestial Gods.
tgt_text.5799: For all the celestials always enjoy the same state -of mind, with an eternal equanimity, which in them is never driven from its own fixed state either in the direction of pleasure or of pain;
tgt_text.5800: nor is it moved by any thing from its own everlasting rule, towards any sudden line of conduct;
tgt_text.5801: neither by any external force, because there is nothing more powerful than deity;
tgt_text.5802: nor of their own impulse, because nothing is more perfect than deity.
tgt_text.5803: And furthermore, how can he appear to have been per­ fect, who moves from a former condition of being to another condition which is better ?
tgt_text.5804: And this the more especially, as no one spontaneously embraces any thing new, unless he is tired of what he had before;
tgt_text.5805: for a new mode of proceeding cannot be adopted, without disapproving the preceding modes.
tgt_text.5806: Hence, it follows, that a God ought not to be employed in any temporal functions either of beneficence or love;
tgt_text.5807: and, therefore, is neither to be influenced by indignation nor by pity, nor to be disquieted by any anxiety, nor elated by any hilarity;
tgt_text.5808: but he is free from all the passions of the mind, so as never either to grieve or to rejoice, nor on sudden impulse to will or unwill.
tgt_text.5809: †But all these, and other qualities of the like kind, properly accord with the middle nature of demons.*
tgt_text.5810: For they are in­ termediate between us and the Gods, both in the place of their habitation, and in their nature ;
tgt_text.5811: having immortality in common with the Gods of heaven, and passions in common with sub­ ordinate beings.
tgt_text.5812: For they are capable, just as we are, of being affected by all that soothes as well as all that moves the mind;
tgt_text.5813: so as to be stimulated by anger, influenced by pity, allured by gifts, appeased by prayers, exasperated by affronts, soothed by ho­ nours, and swayed by all other circumstances, just in the same way that we are.
tgt_text.5814: For, to embrace the nature of them in a de­ finition, demons are as to genus animated beings, as to mind rational, as to feelings passive, as to body aerial, as to duration eternal.
tgt_text.5815: Of these five characteristics which I have mentioned, the three first are the same as those which we possess, the fourth is peculiar to themselves, and the last they possess in common with the immortal Gods, from whom they differ in being subject to passion.
tgt_text.5816: Hence, according to my idea, I have not absurdly called demons passive, because they are subject to the same perturbations as we are:
tgt_text.5817: and on this account it is that we may place some confidence in the different observances of religions, and the various propitiatory offerings made in sacred rites.
tgt_text.5818: There are likewise some among this number of Gods who rejoice in victims, or ceremonies, or observances, nocturnal or diurnal, public or performed in secret, replete with the greatest joy or marked with extreme sadness.
tgt_text.5819: Thus, the Egyptian deities are almost all of them delighted with lamentations, the Grecian in general with dances, and those of the Barbarians with the sound produced by cymbals, tambourines, and pipes.
tgt_text.5820: So. in like manner, other points relating to sacred rites present consider­ able diversities, according to different regions;
tgt_text.5821: as, for instance, the crowds that swell the sacred processions, the mysteries, the duties performed by the priests, and the observances per- formed by the devotees:
tgt_text.5822: and then, again, the images of the Gods, and their insignia, the rites performed in, and the situa­ tions of, their temples, and the variety of blood and colour in their victims.
tgt_text.5823: All these particulars are regulated and set forth in the accustomed form peculiar to the usage of each place, so much so that we have frequently ascertained by means of dreams, oracles and prophecies especially, that the Divinities have been indignant, if anything in their sacred rites has been neglected through slothfulness or contumacy;
tgt_text.5824: of which cir­ cumstances I have an abundance of examples.
tgt_text.5825: They are, how­ ever, so universally mentioned, and so generally known, that no one could attempt to recount them, without omitting a great number more than he mentioned.
tgt_text.5826: On this account, I shall desist for the present from expending words upon these parti.
tgt_text.5827: culars, which if they have not obtained assured credit with all men, still, at least, are universally within the knowledge of all.
tgt_text.5828: It will be more advisable, therefore, to discuss this point in the Latin tongue, that there are kinds of demons enumerated by the philosophers, in order that you may more clearly and more fully come to an understanding on the presage of Socrates, and his familiar demon.
tgt_text.5829: Now, according to a certain signification, the human soul, even when it is still situate in the body, is called a demon. " 0 say, Euryalus, do Gods inspire
tgt_text.5830: In minds this ardour, or does fierce desire Rule as a God in its possessor's breast ?"*
tgt_text.5831: If, then, this is the case, a longing of the soul that is of gooa tendency is a good demon.
tgt_text.5832: Hence it is that some think, as we have already observed, that the blessed are called ἐυδαίμονες, eudæmones, the demon of whom is good, that is, whose mind is perfect in virtue.
tgt_text.5833: You may call this demon in our language, according to my mode of interpretation, by the name of " Genius," whether quite correctly I am not altogether sure, but at all events, at any risk you may so call it;
tgt_text.5834: because this God, who is the mind of every one,† though immortal, is never- theless, after a certain manner, generated with man;
tgt_text.5835: so that those prayers in which we implore the Genius, and which we employ when we embrace the knees [genua] of those whom we supplicate, seem to me to testify this connexion and union, since they comprehend in two words the body and the mind, through the communion and conjunction of which we exist.
tgt_text.5836: There is also another species of demons, according to a se­ cond signification, and this is the human soul, after it has per­ formed its duties in the present life, and quitted the body:
tgt_text.5837: I find that this is called in the ancient Latin language by the name of Lemur.
tgt_text.5838: Now, of these Lemures, the one who, under­ taking the guardianship of his posterity, dwells in a house with propitious and tranquil influence, is called the "familiar" Lar.
tgt_text.5839: But those who, having no fixed habitation of their own, are punished with vague wandering, as with a kind of exile, on account of the evil deeds of their life, are usually called "Larvæ," thus becoming a vain terror to the good, but a source of punishment to the bad.
tgt_text.5840: But when it is uncertain what is the allotted condition of any one of these, and whether it is Lar or Larva, it is called a God Manes ;
tgt_text.5841: the name of God being added for the sake of honor.
tgt_text.5842: For those only are called Gods, who being of the number of the Lemures, and having regulated the course of their life justly and prudently, have afterwards been celebrated by men as divinities, and are uni­ versally worshipped with temples, and religious rites;
tgt_text.5843: such, for instance, as Amphiaraus in Boeotia, Mopsus in Africa, Osiris in Egypt, and others in other nations, but Esculapius every­ where.
tgt_text.5844: All this distribution, however, has been made of those demons, who once existed in a human body.
tgt_text.5845: But there is another species of demons, more exalted and august, not fewer in number, but far superior in dignity, who, being for ever liberated from the bonds and conjunction of the body, preside over certain powers.
tgt_text.5846: In the number of these are Sleep and Love, who possess powers of a different nature;
tgt_text.5847: Love, of exciting to wakefulness, Sleep of lulling to rest.
tgt_text.5848: From this more elevated order of demons, Plato is of opinion that a peculiar demon is allotted to every man, to be a witness and a guardian* of his conduct in life, who, without being visible to any one, is always present, and is an overseer not only of his actions, but even of his thoughts.
tgt_text.5849: But when life is finished, and THE SOUL has to return to its judges, then the demon who has presided over it immediately seizes, and leads it as his charge to judgment, and is there present with it while it pleads its cause;
tgt_text.5850: and censures it if it is guilty of any un­ truthfulness ;
tgt_text.5851: corroborates what it says, if it asserts what is true;
tgt_text.5852: and conformably to its testimony, sentence is passed.
tgt_text.5853: All you, therefore, who hear this divine opinion of Plato, as ex­ plained by me, so adapt your minds to whatever you may have to do, or to whatever may be the subject of your meditation, as men who know that there is nothing concealed from those guardians either within the mind or external to it;
tgt_text.5854: but that the demon scrupulously takes part in all these matters, sees all things, understands all things, and dwells in the most profound recesses of the mind, in the place of conscience. †
tgt_text.5855: He of whom I speak is entirely our guardian, our individual keeper, our watcher at home, our own proper regulator, a searcher into our inmost fibres, our constant observer, our in­ separable witness, a reprover of our evil actions, an approver of our good ones;
tgt_text.5856: if he is becomingly attended to, sedulously examined and devoutly worshipped, in the way in which he was worshipped by Socrates in justice and in innocence;
tgt_text.5857: he is our forewarner in uncertainty, our monitor in matters of doubt, our defender in danger, and our assistant in need.
tgt_text.5858: He is able also by dreams, and by tokens, and perhaps even openly, when necessity demands it, to avert from you evil, to increase your blessings, to aid you when depressed, to support you when falling, to lighten your darkness, to regulate your prosperity, and modify your adversity.
tgt_text.5859: What wonder, then, if Socrates, who was a man perfect in the highest degree, and wise even by the testimony of Apollo, should know and venerate this his God;
tgt_text.5860: and that hence, this Lar, his keeper, and nearly, as I may say, his co-mate and his domestic associate, should repel from him everything which ought to be repelled, foresee what ought to be foreseen, and forewarn him of what he ought to be forewarned of, if at any time, the functions of wisdom falling short, he stood in need, not of counsel, but foreknowledge;
tgt_text.5861: in order that when he was vacillating through doubt, he might take a firm stand through being forewarned.
tgt_text.5862: For there are many things respecting which even wise men have recourse to diviners and oracles.
tgt_text.5863: Do you not very clearly perceive in Homer, as in a kind of large mirror, these two properties of divination and of wisdom separated widely from each other ?
tgt_text.5864: For when those two pillars of the whole expedition disagreed, Agamemnon potent in sway, and Achilles powerful in battle, and a man famed for his elo­ quence and renowned for his skill, was wanting, who might allay the pride of the son of Atreus, and curb the anger of the son of Peleus, command the attention of both by the weight of his character, admonish them by examples, and soothe them by his words;
tgt_text.5865: who, then, on such an occasion undertook to speak ?
tgt_text.5866: Why, Ne8tor, the Pylian orator, who was so bland in his elo­ quence, wary through experience, and venerable for his age ;
tgt_text.5867: who was known by all to have a body weakened by years, but a mind vigorous in counsel, and words flowing with honeyed sweetness.
tgt_text.5868: In like manner, when in dubious and adverse circumstances, spies are to be chosen, to penetrate into the camp of the enemy at midnight, are not Ulysses and Diomedes selected for that purpose, as counsel and aid, mind and hand, spirit and sword ?
tgt_text.5869: But, on the other hand, when the Greeks are detained in Aulis, kept back by the winds, and through weariness are shrinking from the difficulties of the war;
tgt_text.5870: when the means of proceeding, the tranquillity of the sea, and the clemency of the winds, have to be ascertained by means of the indications of the entrails, the courses taken by birds, and the food de­ voured by serpents ;
tgt_text.5871: * then were those two supreme summits of the Grecian wisdom, the Ithacan and the Pylian, both of them silent;
tgt_text.5872: but Calchas, who was far more skilful in divining, as soon as he had surveyed the birds, and the altars, and the tree, immediately through his divination appeased the tempests, brought the fleet out to the sea, and foretold a war which should last ten years.
tgt_text.5873: Just so in the Trojan army also, when affairs required the aid of divination, that wise senate is silent, nor does either Hicetaon, Lampus, or Clytius, presume to give any opinion;
tgt_text.5874: but all of them listen in silence, either to the distasteful auguries of Helenus, or to the discredited predic­ tions of Cassandra.
tgt_text.5875: After the same manner, Socrates too, if at any time advice not within the province of wisdom was re­ quisite, was then governed by the prophetic power of his dmeon;
tgt_text.5876: and he was sedulously attentive to his admonitions, and on that account was acceptable in a far higher degree to his God.
tgt_text.5877: The reason also, has been in some measure already stated, why the demon of Socrates was generally in the habit of for­ bidding him to do certain things, but never exhorted him to the performance of any act.
tgt_text.5878: For Socrates, being of himself a man exceedingly perfect, and prompt to the performance of all requisite duties, never stood in need of any one to exhort him;
tgt_text.5879: though sometimes he required one to forbid him, if danger happened to lurk in any of his undertakings;
tgt_text.5880: in order that, being admonished, he might use due precaution, and desist for the present from his attempt, either to resume it more safely at a future period, or enter upon it in some other way.
tgt_text.5881: On occasions of this kind, he used to say, " That he heard a cer­ tain voice, which proceeded from the divinity."
tgt_text.5882: For so it is asserted by Plato;
tgt_text.5883: and let no one suppose that he was in the habit of deriving omens from the ordinary conversation of men.
tgt_text.5884: Once, for example, when he was with Phsedrus, beyond the precincts of the city, under the covering of a shady tree, and at a distance from all overlookers, he perceived a sign which announced to him that he must not pass over the small stream of the river llissus, until he had appeased Love, who was indignant at his censure of him, by a recantation.*
tgt_text.5885: And then, besides, if he had been an observer of omens, he would sometimes also have received positive encouragement from them, as we see frequently the case with many of those, who, through a too superstitious observance of omens, are not directed by their own minds, but by the words of others;
tgt_text.5886: and who creeping about the lanes, gather counsel from the remarks of strangers, and, if I may use the expression, do not think with the under­ standing, but with the ears.
tgt_text.5887: But be this as it may, it is certain that those who hear.
tgt_text.5888: the words of soothsayers, generally receive a voice with their ears, concerning the nature of which they have no doubt, and which they know to proceed from the human mouth.
tgt_text.5889: But Socrates did not simply say that he heard a voice, but a 11 certain voice," transmitted to him:
tgt_text.5890: by which addition, you must certainly understand, that neither an ordinary nor a human voice is signified;
tgt_text.5891: for had it been so, it would have been no use to say a " certain" voice, but rather 11 a voice," " or the.
tgt_text.5892: voice of some one," as the courtesan in Terence says, " I thought just now I heard the captain's voice."t
tgt_text.5893: But he who says that he heard a certain voice, is either igno­ rant whence that voice originated, or is in some doubt con­ cerning it, or shows that it had something unusual and mys­ terious about it, as Socrates did of that voice, which he said was transmitted to him opportunely and from a divine source.
tgt_text.5894: And, indeed, I think that he used to perceive indications of his demon, not only with his ears, but even with his eyes;
tgt_text.5895: for he very frequently declared that not a voice, but a divine sign, had been presented to him.
tgt_text.5896: This sign too might have been the form of his demon, which Socrates alone beheld, just as, in Homer, Achilles beheld Minerva.
tgt_text.5897: I suppose that most of you will with difficulty believe what I have just said, and will greatly wonder what was the form of the demon Socrates was in the habit of seeing.
tgt_text.5898: Aristotle, however, who is a pretty good authority, I think, informs us that it was usual with the Pythagoreans to express great surprise if any one denied that he had ever seen a demon.
tgt_text.5899: If, there­ fore, the power of beholding a divine form may be possessed by any one, why might it not, in an especial degree, fall to the lot of Socrates, whom the dignity of wisdom rendered equal to the very highest divinity?
tgt_text.5900: For nothing is more similar and more acceptable to Deity, than a man intellectually good in a perfect degree, for he as much excels other men as he himself is surpassed by the immortal Gods.
tgt_text.5901: Do we not, then, ourselves feel elevated by the example and mention of Socrates ?
tgt_text.5902: And ought we not to devote ourselves to the feli­ citous study of a like philosophy, and stand in awe of like Divinities ?
tgt_text.5903: A study from which we allow ourselves to be drawn away, for what reason I know not.
tgt_text.5904: And nothing is there which excites in me so much surprise, as that all men should desire to live most happily, and should know that they cannot so live in any other way than by cultivating the mind, and yet leave their minds uncultivated.
tgt_text.5905: Just so, if any one wishes to see clearly, it is requisite that he should pay atten­ tion to his eyes by which he sees ;
tgt_text.5906: if he desires to run swiftly, attention must be paid to the feet by which he runs;
tgt_text.5907: and so, too, if you wish to be a stout pugilist, your arms must be strengthened with which you engage in that exercise.
tgt_text.5908: So it is with all the other members;
tgt_text.5909: the care of each must be made your study.
tgt_text.5910: And, as all men may easily see that this is true, I cannot sufficiently account to myself, and wonder to the extent that the thing deserves, why they do not, with the aid of reason, cultivate their minds.
tgt_text.5911: For this art of living is equally necessary for all;
tgt_text.5912: whereas the same is not the case with the art of painting, nor with the art of singing, which any worthy man may despise, without any censure upon his understanding, without baseness, and without disgrace.
tgt_text.5913: I know not how to play on the flute like Ismenias, still I feel no shame that I am not a player on the flute :
tgt_text.5914: I know not how to paint in colours like Apelles, nor to carve like Lysip­ pus, still I am not, ashamed that I am not an artist;
tgt_text.5915: and the same as to other arts, not to recount them all individually;
tgt_text.5916: you are at liberty to be ignorant of them, and yet not to feel ashamed.
tgt_text.5917: But, on the other hand, be good enough to say, I know not how to live aright as Socrates, as Plato, and as Pythagoras lived, and I feel no shame that I know not how to live aright.
tgt_text.5918: This you will never dare to say.
tgt_text.5919: It is, however, especially to be wondered at, that people should still neglect to learn those things of which they by no means wish to appear ignorant, and shun at one and the same moment, both acquaintance with and ignorance of the same art.
tgt_text.5920: Hence, if you examine their daily outlay, you will find that they are prodigally profuse in their ordinary ex­ penditure, but bestow nothing on themselves;
tgt_text.5921: I mean on proper attention to their demon, which proper attention is nothing else than the secret obligations of philosophy.
tgt_text.5922: They build sumptuous villas, no doubt, richly decorate their houses, and collect a numerous household;
tgt_text.5923: but in all these, and amidst such vast affluence, there is nothing to be ashamed of but the master himself, and with good reason;
tgt_text.5924: for they have an accu­ mulation of things which they have collected with exquisite care, while they themselves wander about among them, rude, uncultivated, and ignorant.
tgt_text.5925: Accordingly, you will find the things on which they have lavished their patrimony, to be most pleasing to the view, and most exquisitely built;
tgt_text.5926: villas raised that rival cities, houses decorated like temples, most numerous retinues of servants, with carefully curled locks, costly furniture, every thing be­ tokening affluence, every thing bespeaking opulence, every thing bearing marks of refinement, except the master himself;
tgt_text.5927: who alone, just like Tantalus, needy, poor, and in want in the midst of his riches, though he does not snatch at retreating fruit, nor endeavour to quench his thirst with shifting water, still hungers and thirsts for want of true beatitude, that is to say, a genuine life,* and a happy and discreet existence.
tgt_text.5928: For he does not perceive that it is usual to look upon rich men in the same way that we do horses when we buy them;
tgt_text.5929: for in purchasing horses we do not look to the trappings, nor the decorations of the belt, nor do we contemplate the riches of the neck with all its ornaments, and examine whether chains of various patterns, and made of silver, gold, or gems, are hanging from it;
tgt_text.5930: whether elaborate baubles surround the head and neck;
tgt_text.5931: whether the bits are embossed, the saddle painted, and the girths gilt;
tgt_text.5932: but all this outside show being removed, we survey the bare horse itself, and direct our attention only to his body and his temper, in order to ascertain whether he is of handsome form, vigorous for the race, and strong for purposes of carriage.
tgt_text.5933: In the first place, we consider whether there is in his body "
tgt_text.5934: A head that's slender, and a belly small, A back obese, and animated breast, In brawny flesh luxuriant."*
tgt_text.5935: And besides, whether a twofold spine passes along his loins;
tgt_text.5936: for I would have him not only to carry me swiftly, but to afford me an easy seat.
tgt_text.5937: In a similar manner, therefore, in examining men, do not take into account these foreign particulars, but closely consider the man himself, and look upon him in a state of poverty, as was my Socrates.
tgt_text.5938: But I call those things foreign which our parents have produced, and which Fortune has bestowed, none of which do I mingle with the praises of my Socrates;
tgt_text.5939: no nobility of birth, no high pedigree, no long line of ancestors, no envied riches, for all these, I say, are foreign.
tgt_text.5940: It is glory sufficient derived from Protaonius, if he was such a man that he was not a disgrace to his grandson.
tgt_text.5941: In like manner, may you enumerate every thing of a foreign nature.
tgt_text.5945: I put no trust in Fortune;
tgt_text.5946: nor do I admire these things a bit the more.
tgt_text.5948: He will be weakened by sickness.
tgt_text.5949: Is he swift in the race ?
tgt_text.5950: He will fall into old age.
tgt_text.5952: Wait a little, and he will be so no longer.
tgt_text.5953: But is he well in­ structed, and extremely learned in the pursuits of philosophy, and wise, and skilled in the knowledge of good, as much as it is possible for man to be?
tgt_text.5954: Now, then, at last you praise the man himself. ,
tgt_text.5955: For this is neither an hereditary possession from his father, nor depending on chance, nor yet on the suf­ frages of the people, nor subject to bodily decay, nor mutable through age.
tgt_text.5956: All these my Socrates possessed, and therefore cared not for the possession of other things.
tgt_text.5957: Why, then, do not you apply yourself to the study of wisdom, or, at least, strive that you may hear nothing of an alien nature in your praises?
tgt_text.5958: but that he who wishes to compliment you, may praise you in the same manner as Accius praises Ulysses, in his Philoctetes, where he says, at the beginning of that tragedy "
tgt_text.5959: Fam'd hero, in a little island born, Of celebrated name and powerful mind, Once to the Grecian ships war's leading light, And to the Dardan race th' avenger dire, Son of Laertes."
tgt_text.5960: He mentions his father last of all.
tgt_text.5961: But you have heard al- the praises of that man;
tgt_text.5962: Laertes, Anticlea, and Acrisius, claim no share of it.
tgt_text.5963: The whole of the praises are, as you see, a possession belonging to Ulysses alone.
tgt_text.5964: Nor does Homer teach you anything else with regard to the same Ulysses, in always representing Wisdom as his companion, whom he poetically calls Minerva.
tgt_text.5965: Hence, attended by her, he encounters all terrific dangers, and rises superior to all adverse circumstances.
tgt_text.5966: For, assisted by her, he entered the cavern of the Cyclops, but escaped from it;
tgt_text.5967: saw the oxen of the Sun, but abstained from them, and descended to the realms beneath, but emerged from them.
tgt_text.5968: With the same Wisdom for his companion, he passed by Scylla, and was not seized by her;
tgt_text.5969: he was surrounded by Charybdis, and was not retained by her;
tgt_text.5970: he drank the cup of Circe, and was not transformed;
tgt_text.5971: he came to the Lotophagi, yet did not remain with them;
tgt_text.5972: he heard the Sirens, yet did not approach them.
tgt_text.5973: *END OF APULEIUS ON THE GOD OF SOCRATES.IT is a common custom with religious travellers, when they come upon some grove or sacred place, to beseech favour, offer -up prayers, and sit down a while;
tgt_text.5974: in like manner, now that I have entered this most hallowed city, though I am in great haste, I must entreat favour, make oration, and check my hurry.
tgt_text.5975: For the traveller can find no fitter motives for a religious pause in an altar decked with flowers, or a dell shaded with foliage, or an oak loaded with horns, or a beech festooned with skins, or even a consecrated and enclosed hil­ lock, or a trunk chiselled into the form of an image, or a turf redolent of libation, or a stone bedewed with ointment.
tgt_text.5976: These are small things indeed, and though adored by the few who scrutinise them, are passed unnoticed by those who are not aware of them.
tgt_text.5977: But not so my predecessor, Socrates, who, when he had looked for some time upon a handsome but silent youth, ex­ claimed :
tgt_text.5979: Say something, that I may see you."
tgt_text.5980: Socrates saw not a silent man;
tgt_text.5981: for he thought that men were to be considered not with the eyes, but with the rays of the intellect and the gaze of the soul.
tgt_text.5982: In this he differed in opinion with the soldier in Plautus, who says :
tgt_text.5983: " One eye-witness is worth more than ten ear-witnesses."
tgt_text.5984: Nay, he held the converse of this verse with regard to the examination of men:
tgt_text.5985: " One ear- witness is worth more than ten eye-witnesses."
tgt_text.5986: But if the judgments formed by the eyes were more valued than those of the mind, the palm of wisdom would be due to the eagle.
tgt_text.5987: For we men can neither discern things far away nor very near us, but are all in a measure blind ;
tgt_text.5988: and if you consider us only with regard to our eyes, and our earthly and dull vision, truly the great poet has well said that there is a mist, as it were, before our eyes, and that we cannot see clearly beyond a stone's throw.
tgt_text.5989: But the eagle when he has soared aloft as high as the clouds, sweeping with his wings all that space in which it rains and snows, a height beyond which there 's.
tgt_text.5990: no place for the thunder or lightning, on the very base of the ether and summit of the tempest, so to speak;
tgt_text.5992: eagle when he has soared thither, glides along bodily, with a gentle inclination left or right, turning his sail-spread wings in whatever direction he pleases, using his tail as a small helm.
tgt_text.5993: Looking down thence on all below him, with unwearied rowing of his wings, and with his flight stayed awhile, he remains at gaze suspended nearly in the same spot, and considers in what direction he shall swoop down on his prey like a thunderbolt;
tgt_text.5994: seeing at one glance, himself unseen in the heavens, cattle in the fields, wild beasts on the mountains, and men in the towns, he considers where he may pierce with his beak or hook with his talons a heed­ less lamb or timid hare, or any living thing that chance may offer him to tear and devour.
tgt_text.5995: Hyagnis, as we have heard say, was the father and teacher of Marsyas the flute-player, and surpassed all in his perform­ ance in an age as yet uncultivated in music;
tgt_text.5996: not that he played, indeed, with such soul-subduing tone as later musicians, or with such manifold modulations, or on a pipe of so many holes;
tgt_text.5997: for the art had been but recently invented, and was then in its infancy.
tgt_text.5998: Nothing can be perfect in the beginning, but in almost all cases some rudiment of the promised thing precedes its consummation.
tgt_text.5999: Before Hyagnis appeared then, most people could do no more than, like the shepherd or neat- herd in Virgil, " Grate on their scrannel pipes of wretched straw."*
tgt_text.6000: And if there was any one who appeared to have made some­ what more progress in the art, even he too, followed the common practice of playing only on one pipe, just as on one trumpet.
tgt_text.6001: Hyagnis was the first who separated the hands in playing;
tgt_text.6002: the first who gave breath to two pipes ;
tgt_text.6003: the first who mingled a shrill and a grave tone in musical concert, by means of left and right apertures.
tgt_text.6004: His son Marsyas, when he had acquired the paternal art of minstrelsy-a Phrygian and a barbarian he was, a rough brutish-looking fellow, hirsute, with a dirty beard, covered with bristles and hairs,-is said (oh monstrous!) to have contended with Apollo:
tgt_text.6005: a Thersites with a beautiful youth, a clown with a scholar, a brute with a god!
tgt_text.6006: The Muses with Minerva sat as.
tgt_text.6007: judges by way of a joke, to laugh at the barbarity of that monster, and no less to punish his stu­ pidity.
tgt_text.6008: But Marsyas, not perceiving that he was made a laughing stock, which is the greatest proof of folly, before he began to play, sputtered out some barbarous nonsense about himself and Apollo, praising himself because he had short crisp hair, a squalid beard, a shaggy breast, was in art a flute- player, and in fortune needy ;
tgt_text.6009: on the other hand, ridiculous to relate, he decried the opposite merits as so many faults in Apollo, saying:
tgt_text.6010: that Apollo had unshorn locks, a handsome face, and a smooth body;
tgt_text.6011: that he was of manifold proficiency in art, and opulent in fortune.
tgt_text.6012: In the first place, said he, his locks flow freely, those in front being drawn forward, those be­ hind tossed back ;
tgt_text.6014: his limbs are smooth and fair;
tgt_text.6015: his tongue is prophetic, and endowed with equal eloquence in prose and verse.
tgt_text.6017: his garment is fine in texture, soft to the touch, and glowing with purple.
tgt_text.6019: his lyre is ruddy with gold, white with ivory, and variegated with gems.
tgt_text.6021: he trills most skilfully and most sweetly. "
tgt_text.6022: All these prettinesses," he says, " are by no means becoming to virtue, but adapted to luxury, whereas the native quality of my own person exhibits the greatest comeliness."
tgt_text.6023: The Muses laughed when they heard things like these, which a wise man might well desire, charged as crimes against Apollo ;
tgt_text.6024: and when the flute-player had been beaten in the contest, they left him, like a two-footed bear, stripped of his skin, with his flesh naked and torn.
tgt_text.6025: Thus Marsyas played for punishment and suffered it.
tgt_text.6026: But Apollo was ashamed of so low a victory.
tgt_text.6027: Antigenidas was a certain flute-player, a honeyed modulator of every tone, and a skilled performer in every mode, whether it were the simple Æolian, the varied Asian, the plaintive Lydian, the religious Phrygian, or the warlike Dorian.
tgt_text.6028: Being thus a most distinguished flutist, he used to say, that nothing so vexed and fretted his mind, as, that the horn-players at fune­ rals were called flutists.
tgt_text.6029: But he would have patiently endured this community of names if he had seen mimes.
tgt_text.6030: Then he would have seen some commanding, others suffering blows, and all dressed nearly alike in purple.
tgt_text.6031: So also if he saw our games:
tgt_text.6032: for there too he would see a man preside, a man fight.
tgt_text.6033: He would see the toga employed both for the registering of a vow and for a funeral.
tgt_text.6034: Likewise he would see corpses covered, and philosophers clad with a pallium.
tgt_text.6035: For you have assembled in the theatre with good will, as knowing that the place does not detract from the weight of what is delivered there ;
tgt_text.6036: but that the chief thing to be con­ sidered is, what you find in the theatre.
tgt_text.6037: For if it is a mime, you may laugh;
tgt_text.6038: if it is a rope-dancer, you may be alarmed;
tgt_text.6039: if it is a comedy, you may applaud ;
tgt_text.6040: if it is a philosopher, you may learn.
tgt_text.6041: The Indians are a populous nation of vast extent of terri.
tgt_text.6042: tory, situated far from us to the East, near the reflux of the ocean and the rising of the sun, under the first beams of the stars, and at the extreme verge of the earth, beyond the learned Egyptians, and the superstitious Jews, and the mercantile Na- bathæans, and the flowing robed Arsacidæ, and the Ityræans, poor in crops, and the Arabians rich in perfumes.
tgt_text.6043: Now I do not so much admire the heaps of ivory of these Indians, their harvests of pepper, their bales of cinnamon, their tempered steel, their mines of silver, and their golden streams;
tgt_text.6044: nor that among them the Ganges, the greatest of all rivers, Rolls like a monarch on his course, and pours
tgt_text.6045: His eastern waters through a hundred streams, Mingling with ocean by a hundred mouths;
tgt_text.6047: situated at the dawn of day, are yet of the colour of night;
tgt_text.6048: nor that among them immense dragons fight with enormous elephants, with parity of danger, to their mutual destruction;
tgt_text.6049: for they hold them enwrapped in their slippery folds, so that when the elephants cannot dis­ engage their legs, or in any way extricate themselves from the scaly bonds of the tenacious dragons, they are forced to seek revenge from the fall of their own bulk, and to crush their 'captors by the mass of their bodies.
tgt_text.6050: There are among them also various kinds of inhabitants.
tgt_text.6051: I will rather speak of the marvellous things of men than of those of nature.
tgt_text.6052: There is among them a race who know nothing but how to tend cattle ;
tgt_text.6054: There are races clever in trafficking with merchandise, and others stout in fight, whether with arrows or hand-to-hand with swords.
tgt_text.6055: There is also among them a pre-eminent race called Gymnosophists.
tgt_text.6056: These I exceedingly admire, for they are men skilled not in propa­ gating the vine, nor in grafting trees, nor in tilling the ground.
tgt_text.6057: They know not how to cultivate the fields, or to wash gold, or to break horses, or to tame bulls, or to shear or feed sheep or goats.
tgt_text.6059: They know one thing in­ stead of all these.
tgt_text.6060: They cultivate wisdom, both the aged pro­ fessors and the young students.
tgt_text.6061: Nothing do I so much applaud in them as that they hate torpor of mind and sloth.
tgt_text.6062: Accordingly, when the table is laid, before the meal is served up, all the young men assemble round it from their several places and occupations, and the masters enquire what good thing each has done that day since sunrise.
tgt_text.6063: Thereupon one relates that hav­ ing been chosen arbitrator between two, he has allayed their quarrel, restored good will, cleared up suspicion, and changed them from enemies to friends.
tgt_text.6064: Another states that he has obeyed some command or another of his parents;
tgt_text.6065: and another, that he has found out something by his own reflection, or from another's teaching.
tgt_text.6066: In short, all tell their tale.
tgt_text.6067: He who has no cause to offer why he should dine, is turned out of doors, and sent about his business without a dinner.
tgt_text.6068: It was the will of Alexander, that moot excellent of all kings, who received the surname of the Great for his achieve­ ments, that he who had attained that singular glory, should never be named without praise.
tgt_text.6069: For he alone, since the begin­ ning of time, as far as human memory extends, having pos­ sessed himself invincibly of the dominion of.
tgt_text.6070: the world, was greater than his fortune, and both induced its vast successes by his valour, and equalled them by his merits, and surpassed them by his superior greatness.
tgt_text.6071: He alone was so illustrious beyond all rivalry, that no one can dare to hope for his excel­ lence or covet his fortune.
tgt_text.6072: You would be wearied with ad­ miring the lofty deeds of that great Alexander, whether those which he achieved in war, or those which he wisely accom­ plished in peace;
tgt_text.6073: ' all which, my Clemens, the most learned and sweetest of poets, has undertaken to illustrate in a very beautiful poem.
tgt_text.6074: Now this is a most signal fact respecting Alexander,.that in order to have his image descend the more authentically to posterity, he would not allow it to be vulgar­ ised by many artists, but commanded throughout all his em­ pire, that no one should presumptuously make the king's like­ ness in brass, or in painting, or with the graver;
tgt_text.6075: but that Polycletus alone should mould it in brass, Apelles alone deli­ neate it in colours, Pyrgoteles alone should elaborate it with the graver.
tgt_text.6076: Besides these three artists, far the most eminent in their several kinds, if any other was found to have put his hands to the king's most sacred image, he should be punished just as one who had committed sacrilege.
tgt_text.6077: The consequence of that fear imposed on all was, that Alexander was presented with singular excellence in all his likenesses;
tgt_text.6078: so that in all statues, pictures, and engraved gems, he appears with the same vigorous aspect of a most intrepid warrior, the same genius of a mighty hero, the same beauty and freshness of youth, the same noble expansion of forehead.
tgt_text.6079: Now I would that in like manner, it were a valid decree of philosophy that no one should presumptuously attempt its likeness;
tgt_text.6080: that a few good artists, and those soundly instructed, should consider the study of philosophy in every way, and that no rude, squalid, ignorant pretenders should imitate philosophers as far as re­ gards their garb, and should disgrace that royal science which was devised both for speaking well and living well, by talk­ ing ill and living no better.
tgt_text.6081: Both which things are indeed very easy;
tgt_text.6082: for what can be easier than rabidness of tongue and baseness of conduct, the former from contempt of others, the latter from self contempt ?
tgt_text.6083: For to conduct oneself basely is self-contempt;
tgt_text.6084: to vilify others barbarously, is insolence to­ wards one's hearers.
tgt_text.6085: Does he not insult you in the highest degree who supposes you to delight in slanders against any good man;
tgt_text.6086: who thinks you do not understand bad and vicious words, or that if you understand, you like them ?
tgt_text.6087: Where is the clown, the porter, or the pothouse sot, so silly that if he had a mind to put on the pallium, he could rail in better terms ?
tgt_text.6088: For he owes more to you than to his dignity, although that is not common to him with others.
tgt_text.6089: For out of countless men there are but few senators, and of senators few are of noble birth ;
tgt_text.6090: and of those consular men few are good, and of those good, moreover, few are learned.
tgt_text.6091: But to speak only of his dignity, its insignia are not to be lightly assumed either in the garments or the foot-dress.
tgt_text.6092: If perchance in this fair assembly sits any malicious person of the number of those my enemies-since in a great city that kind of men is also found who like rather to rail at their betters than to imitate them, and who affect enmity towards those whom they cannot hope to resemble;
tgt_text.6093: men whose own names being obscure, wish to become known through mine;
tgt_text.6094: if, then, any of those croakers has come hither to be a blot upon this brilliant assembly, I should like him to run his eyes for a while over this incredible concourse ;
tgt_text.6095: and having contemplated such a crowd as never before my time was seen gathered to­ gether to listen to a philosopher, let him compute in his own mind, how great a risk of sustaining his reputation is here en­ countered, by one who has not been used to be contemned;
tgt_text.6096: since it is an arduous and very difficult thing to satisfy even the moderate expectations of a few, especially for me, whom my acquired reputation, and your favourable predisposition towards me, suffer not to utter any thing negligently, and without deep reflection.
tgt_text.6097: For which of you would forgive me a single solecism r
tgt_text.6098: Which of you would absolve me for one syllable of barbarous pronunciation ?
tgt_text.6099: Which of you would permit me to jabber, like crazy people, any unauthorised and corrupt words that come uppermost?
tgt_text.6100: Yet these faults you easily and very justly pardon in others.
tgt_text.6101: But every phrase of mine you scrutinise keenly, weigh it carefully, test it by the file and the rule, and again compare it with the lathe and the buskin.*
tgt_text.6102: Lowliness is as much excused as dignity is difficult to sus- tain.
tgt_text.6103: I acknowledge then my difficulty, and do not desire you to think otherwise of it.
tgt_text.6104: Nor let a paltry and spurious similitude mislead you, since, as I have often said, certain cloaked lies* walk about.
tgt_text.6105: The crier ascends the tribunal with the proconsul, and he too is seen there dressed in the toga;
tgt_text.6106: and indeed he stands there a long while, or he walks about, or he bawls often with all his might;
tgt_text.6107: but the proconsol him­ self speaks in a moderate tone, rarely, and in a sitting pos­ ture, and he generally reads from a tablet.
tgt_text.6108: For the crier's garrulous voice is the function of his office;
tgt_text.6109: but the tablet is the proconsol's sentence, which when once read, cannot be lengthened or shortened by a single letter, but as soon as it is pronounced, it is inserted in the registry of the province.
tgt_text.6110: I, in my degree, suffer something like this in my studies.
tgt_text.6111: For whatever I have delivered to you is immediately taken up and recited, nor is it free to me to recall any part of it, or to change or correct it in any respect.
tgt_text.6112: Wherefore, I must be the more scrupulous in speaking, and that too not in one kind of matter only.
tgt_text.6113: For there are extant more works of mine in the Muses than of Hippias in art.
tgt_text.6114: What that means, give me your attention, and I will diligently and accurately set forth.
tgt_text.6115: This Hippias was one of the sophists, superior to all in the number of the arts he knew, inferior to none in eloquence.
tgt_text.6116: He was contemporary with Socrates, a native of Elis, of what family is not known.
tgt_text.6117: His glory was great, his fortune small;
tgt_text.6118: but his genius was great, his memory excellent, his studies various, his rivals many.
tgt_text.6119: This Hippias came once to Pisa to the Olympic games, where he was not less remarkable for the ornaments he wore than for the fact that he had wrought them himself.
tgt_text.6120: Of all those things he had with him he had purchased not one, but had made them with his own hands;
tgt_text.6121: the garments in which he was clad, the shoes on his feet, and everything he carried on his person.
tgt_text.6122: For clothing he had an inner tunic of very fine texture, of triple thread, and double purple dye.
tgt_text.6123: He had wrought it single-handed at home.
tgt_text.6124: He was girt with a belt adorned with a sort of Babylonian pic­ ture of admirable colours.
tgt_text.6125: Nor had any one helped him in that work.
tgt_text.6126: His outer covering was a white cloak, which also is known to have been his own handiwork.
tgt_text.6127: Also he had put together the soles of his own foot gear;
tgt_text.6128: and as for the gold ring on his left hand, bearing a most skilfully cut seal which he often exhibited, he himself had rounded the ring, and had closed the pallet, and engraved the gem.
tgt_text.6129: I have not yet told all he did.
tgt_text.6130: For I shall not be loth to relate what he was not ashamed to display, who asserted in a large assembly that he had also made himself an oil flask which he carried about him, of a lenticular form, of a rounded outline and small convexity;
tgt_text.6131: and with it a neat little scraper to be used in the bath, with a convenient handle and tubulated face, so that it might be held steadily in the hand, and that the sweat might flow out of it in a stream.
tgt_text.6132: Who will not extol a man skilled in so many arts;
tgt_text.6133: illustrious for such manifold know­ ledge ;
tgt_text.6134: a Dædalus in the use of so many tools ?
tgt_text.6135: Certainly, I admire Hippias, but I would rather rival the fecundity of his genius in matters of learning, than in multitudinous appliances for personal use.
tgt_text.6136: I confess, indeed, that I am not expert in handicraft arts;
tgt_text.6137: that I buy my garments at the clothier's—these shoes at the shoe-maker's;
tgt_text.6138: that I wear no ring, and hold gems and gold of no more account than lead and pebbles ;
tgt_text.6139: that I buy a scraper, a flask, and other bath utensils at the shops.
tgt_text.6140: I am far from denying that I do not know how to use the loom, or the awl, or the file, or the lathe, or any such implements;
tgt_text.6141: instead of these, I confess I prefer to compose with a writing reed, poems of all kinds adapted to the laurel branch,* the lyre, the sock, the buskin;
tgt_text.6144: as, also, orations praised by the eloquent, and dia­ logues praised by philosophers;
tgt_text.6145: and to compose these and such like works, both in Greek and Latin, with two-fold study, with equal diligence and in similar style.
tgt_text.6146: These things I would, indeed, Proconsul, excellent man, that I could lay before you not singly and piece-meal, but collectively in one heap, and enjoy your honourable testimony regarding all my literary labours.
tgt_text.6147: It is not, indeed, from penury of fame that I de­ sire this, for fame has long subsisted for me, bright and un­ broken among all your predecessors,' down to yourself;
tgt_text.6148: but because by no one am I more desirous of being esteemed than by him which I justly esteem above all others.
tgt_text.6149: For it is a law of nature that whom you praise, him you also love;
tgt_text.6150: and moreover, whom you love, by him you would wish to be praised.
tgt_text.6151: Now I profess myself one who prizes you dearly, being bound to you by no private, but by all manner of public favours.
tgt_text.6152: I have, indeed, obtained nothing from you, for nothing have I asked.
tgt_text.6153: But philosophy has taught me to love not only kind­ ness but injury, and rather to do homage to reason than to seek my own advantage, and to prefer public expediency to my own.
tgt_text.6154: Hence, whilst the majority love the beneficial effects of your goodness, I love its principle.
tgt_text.6155: And this I have begun to do whilst considering your conduct in the affairs of the inha­ bitants of this province, for which they ought to love you intensely:
tgt_text.6156: such of them as have felt it in their own persons, for sake of the benefit they have received;
tgt_text.6157: such as have not personally experienced it for sake of the example.
tgt_text.6158: For you have benefited many individually, and all by your example.
tgt_text.6159: For who does not delight to learn from you by what adjust­ ment may be acquired that pleasant gravity of yours, that mild austerity, that placid firmness, that gracious vigour of mind.
tgt_text.6160: Never, to my knowledge, did the province of Africa ever revere more, and fear less any proconsul;
tgt_text.6161: in no year of administration but yours, had shame more power than fear towards restraining offences.
tgt_text.6162: No one but you has used the like power so often to serve, so seldom to terrify.
tgt_text.6163: No one has brought with him a son more resembling himself in virtue.
tgt_text.6164: Hence, no proconsul has remained longer in Carthage.
tgt_text.6165: For at the time you made a tour of the province, while Honorinus remained with us, we did not feel your absence so much as rather to wish you back.
tgt_text.6166: There is in the son the equity of the father, in the youth the prudence of the old man, in the legate the personal weight of the consul.
